4. Over the past week, he has experienced worsening dyspnea, both at rest and during activity.
5. He also has a chronic cough that has recently worsened, producing clear sputum without changes in volume or purulence.
6. Five days ago, his primary care physician prescribed furosemide 40 mg daily, which has not alleviated his symptoms.
7. On examination, his blood pressure is 127/83 mm Hg, heart rate is 89 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air.
8. Lung auscultation reveals diminished air entry with bilateral crackles at the bases that clear with coughing, along with expiratory wheezing.
9. A cardiac exam identifies a 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, which intensifies with inhalation.
10. His internal jugular venous pressure (JVP) is 11 cm H₂O, rising to 16 cm with abdominal pressure and returning to baseline within 2–3 seconds.
11. His lower extremities show erythema and 1+ pitting edema to the mid-ankle, which the patient reports has been stable for a month.
12. Laboratory results include a serum creatinine level of 0.9 mg/dL (reference range: 0.8–1.3), hemoglobin concentration of 10.2 g/dL (13.5–17.5), and N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) level of 1337 pg/mL (10–131).
question_options:
Which of the following interventions is most likely to alleviate this patient’s dyspnea?

A. Add spironolactone 50 mg daily, and continue furosemide 40 mg daily  
B. Initiate therapeutic anticoagulation with enoxaparin  
C. Begin digoxin 0.125 mg daily  
D. Increase the dose of furosemide to 80 mg daily  
E. Begin prednisone 40 mg daily and inhaled ipratropium  
F. Start oral amoxicillin-clavulanate for 7 days  
G. Start combination inhaled fluticasone/salmeterol  
H. Start supplemental oxygen at 2L/min via nasal cannula  
I. Add lisinopril 10 mg daily  
J. Begin oral metoprolol 25 mg twice daily

step1_excerpts:
1. A 24-year-old woman with no significant medical history presents to the emergency department for progressive shortness of breath.
2. She endorses decreased exercise tolerance as well as intermittent palpitations.
3. She returned from a recent missionary trip to South America 12 months prior where she endorsed eating a local delicacy as well as a period of fevers and eyelid swelling during her stay.
4. Her temperature is 99.1°F (37.3°C), pulse is 95/min, blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air.
5. Physical exam is notable for a laterally displaced point of maximal impulse as well as a 2/6 diastolic murmur radiating to the axilla.
6. A blood smear is shown in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

A. Benznidazole  
B. Ganciclovir  
C. Praziquantel  
D. Amphotericin B

step1_excerpts:
1. A newborn boy is evaluated 30 minutes after birth.
2. He was born at 39 weeks gestation to a 27-year-old primigravid mother via cesarean section for cervical insufficiency.
3. The pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes and the amniotic fluid was clear.
4. Upon delivery, the patient had strong respiratory effort and a strong cry.
5. His Apgar scores at 1 and 5 minutes were 7 and 8, respectively.
6. The patient now is exhibiting increased work of breathing and is progressively more tachypneic.
7. His birth weight is 3,568 g (7 lb 14 oz).
8. His temperature is 99.0°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 60/44 mmHg, pulse is 146/min, and respirations are 72/min.
9. On physical exam, the patient is grunting with nasal flaring and subcostal retractions.
10. Breath sounds are decreased at the bases bilaterally.
11. The patient has central cyanosis.
12. His chest radiograph can be seen in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s presentation?

A. Meconium aspiration syndrome  
B. Persistent pulmonary hypertension  
C. Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome  
D. Transient tachypnea of the newborn

step1_excerpts:
1. A 25-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with joint and muscle pain.
2. She has a general aching/pain in her joints that lasts all day.
3. The pain is constant and is not relieved by rest or activity.
4. She also has pain in her hands at times and occasionally notices trouble swallowing when she is eating.
5. She has a medical history of anxiety and is not currently taking any medications.
6. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 115/72 mmHg, pulse is 74/min, and respirations are 11/min.
7. On physical exam, the patient is a healthy young woman with a sunburn.
8. Her hands are mildly edematous with the findings in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following antibodies is most likely to aid in making the diagnosis in this patient?

A. Anti-nuclear antibody  
B. Anti-IgG Fc region  
C. Anti-ribonuleoprotein  
D. Anti-dsDNA

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 60s presented to the hospital because she felt abdominal pain and increasing asthenia during the previous 4 months.
2. She reported a weight loss of 40 kg during the previous 12 months concomitant with depression.
3. The patient had a history of cardiac arrhythmia, hypertension, and sigmoidectomy for diverticulitis.
4. Medications included lasilix, amlodipine, amiodarone, and atenolol.
5. On examination, the patient appeared well.
6. Her vital signs were normal.
7. The abdomen was soft without distension.
8. A positive Murphy sign was observed.
9. Her white blood cell count was 11400/μL (to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001), her hemoglobin level was 11.5 g/dL (to convert to g/L, multiply by 10.0), and her platelet count was 233 ×103/μL (to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 1.0).
10. The C-reaction protein level was elevated to 41 mg/L (to convert to nmol/L, multiply by 9.524).
11. The results of renal and liver function, coagulation, blood level of electrolytes, total protein, albumin, antigen carcino embryonnaire, carbohydrate antigen 19-9, carbohydrate antigen 125, and β2 microglobulin tests were normal.
12. The patient had a normal esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy.
13. Ultrasonography revealed a 10 × 8-m mass in the right hypochondrium.
14. Abdominal computed tomography scan revealed a thickened gallbladder wall infiltrating the liver parenchyma.
15. There were 3 perihepatic lymph nodes.
16. Magnetic resonance imaging showed a greatly enlarged gallbladder with a thickened wall without invading adjacent structures, a continuous mucosal line, and a hypoattenuated intramural nodule (Figure 1).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Carcinoma of the gallbladder  
B: Acute cholecystitis  
C: Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis  
D: Lymphoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 70s presented with a 1-year history of a facial cutaneous eruption initially affecting malar cheeks and eyebrows.
2. Subsequently it spread to involve nose, chin, upper trunk, and extremities.
3. The lesions were mildly pruritic.
4. Her medical history included a cadaveric renal transplant 2 years earlier for end-stage renal failure.
5. Immunosuppressant medications included mycophenolate mofetil, 200 mg, twice daily and tacrolimus, 8 mg, twice daily.
6. Tacrolimus levels were therapeutic.
7. Physical examination revealed multiple 1-mm flesh-colored follicular papules and keratin spines against a diffuse erythematous background affecting the face (Figure, A and B) and upper trunk.
8. Her scalp and eyebrow hairs were unremarkable.
9. Serology results were unremarkable.
10. Results of skin biopsy from the right ear demonstrated dilatation and keratotic plugging of the hair infundibula with marked dystrophy and expansion of the inner root sheath.
11. The inner root sheath cells were enlarged with irregular trichohyaline granules and apoptotic cells with abrupt cornification without formation of a granular layer (Figure, C).
12. Immunohistochemical analysis for SV40 polyomavirus was positive (Figure, D).Photographs of (A) forehead and (B) nose depicting multiple follicular papules and keratin spines against a diffuse erythematous background.
13. C, Hematoxylin-eosin staining (original magnification ×40).
14. D, SV40 polyomavirus stain (original magnification ×40).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Trichodysplasia spinulosa  
B: Lichen spinulosus  
C: Demodecosis  
D: Disseminated keratosis pilaris

step1_excerpts:
1. A 76-year-old woman presented with a palpable left axillary mass.
2. When she was 36 years old, she underwent a hysterectomy due to abnormal uterine bleeding and was taking estradiol to control postmenopausal vasomotor symptoms for the past 20 years.
3. Bilateral diagnostic mammography revealed a high-density irregular mass in the left axilla with no nodules, architectural distortions, or microcalcifications in the breasts.
4. Ultrasonography of the left breast showed a 4.6-cm lobulated mixed cystic and solid left axillary mass.
5. Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging showed an enhancing 5.2-cm left axillary mass with no breast lesions (Figure 1A).
6. The biopsy examination indicated high-grade adenocarcinoma with papillary features (estrogen receptor– and progesterone receptor–positive, ERBB2 [formerly HER2]–negative, and a high Ki67 index).
7. Positron emission tomography/computed tomography revealed only high uptake in the left axilla region.
8. The patient was treated at an outside hospital with neoadjuvant dose-dense doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide, followed by weekly paclitaxel for 10 weeks.
9. She then transferred her care to our center for surgical management.
10. We requested the pathology slides for review at our laboratory and additional immunostaining was performed, which revealed high-grade adenocarcinoma with tumor cells positive for PAX8 (Figure 1B), p53, and WT1 and negative for GATA3.A, Magnetic resonance image of the breasts shows an enhancing 5.2-cm left axillary mass (arrowhead) but no breast lesions.
11. B, Immunohistochemical staining revealed tumor cells positive for PAX8 (original magnification ×100).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid  
B: High-grade serous carcinoma of gynecological origin  
C: High-grade carcinoma of the breast with occult primary  
D: High-grade papillary carcinoma of unknown primary

step1_excerpts:
1. A 32-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider with pelvic pain.
2. She reports that for the last several years, she has had chronic pain that is worse just before her menstrual period.
3. Over the past 2 months, she has also had worsening pain during intercourse.
4. She denies dysuria, vaginal discharge, or vaginal pruritus.
5. The patient has never been pregnant and previously used a copper intrauterine device (IUD) for contraception, but she had the IUD removed 1 year ago because it worsened her menorrhagia.
6. She has now been using combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for nearly 1 year.
7. The patient reports improvement in her menorrhagia on the OCPs but denies any improvement in her pain.
8. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable.
9. Her temperature is 98.0°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 124/73 mmHg, pulse is 68/min, and respirations are 12/min.
10. The patient has pain with lateral displacement of the cervix on pelvic exam.
11. A pelvic ultrasound shows no abnormalities, and a urine pregnancy test is negative.
question_options:
Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

A. Hysteroscopy  
B. Abdominal ultrasound  
C. Hysterosalpingogram  
D. Laparoscopy

step1_excerpts:
1. The parents of a 14-year-old girl contact their primary care provider 10 minutes after their daughter lost her right front tooth during a basketball game.
2. She was struck in the mouth by another player’s elbow, causing bleeding, but she did not fall, lose consciousness, or experience symptoms such as headache, dizziness, or nausea.
3. Her only complaint is mouth pain.
4. After rinsing her mouth, the parents found a small cut on her lip and noticed her right front tooth was missing.
5. They located the tooth, which appears intact.
6. The girl is otherwise healthy and does not take any regular medications.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate recommendation for the parents at this time?

A. Wrap the tooth in a clean tissue and seek dental care immediately  
B. Sterilize tooth and store in cold milk  
C. Place the tooth in hydrogen peroxide for disinfection before replantation  
D. Remove debris and manually replant tooth in socket  
E. Store tooth in tap water and drive to primary care provider  
F. Avoid touching the root of the tooth and store it in the patient’s cheek  
G. Immerse the tooth in saline and wait for dental consultation  
H. Store tooth under the patient's tongue and drive to nearest dentist  
I. Go to emergency department for maxillofacial CT scan  
J. Rinse the tooth with alcohol and consult a dentist for reimplantation

step1_excerpts:
1. A 57-year-old woman comes to the office for a preoperative evaluation 2 weeks before undergoing scheduled laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
2. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable and the patient takes no medications.
3. Family history is significant for stable angina in her father and rheumatoid arthritis in her mother.
4. The patient has a 102-year-old grandmother who resides in a nursing care facility and has Parkinson disease.
5. The patient does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcoholic beverages.
6. During the interview, her face is expressionless.
7. She has a flexed posture and is unable to open her mouth wide.
8. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 81 kg (179 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2 .
9. Vital signs are normal.
10. Physical examination discloses thickening and hardening of the skin over the dorsum of the hands and forearms, as well as mild kyphosis.
11. Strength testing shows no abnormalities; muscle tension is normal.
12. Passive and active range of motion of the upper extremities is full.
13. Gait is slow and deliberate.
14. The remainder of the physical examination discloses no abnormalities.
question_options:
Prior to surgery, further evaluation is indicated for which of the following conditions in this patient?

A. Parkinson disease

B. Progressive supranuclear palsy

C. Sarcopenia

D. Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma)

step1_excerpts:
1. A 41-year-old man presents to his primary care provider with a 2-month history of abdominal pain.
2. He says that the pain “comes and goes” throughout the day and usually lasts 20-30 minutes per episode.
3. The pain is above his umbilicus.
4. He denies any feeling of regurgitation or nighttime cough but endorses nausea.
5. He used to eat 3 large meals per day but has found that eating smaller meals more frequently improves his pain.
6. He tried ibuprofen with food and thinks it helped.
7. He has gained 4 pounds since his last appointment 3 months ago.
8. He denies any diarrhea or change in his stools.
9. He has no known medical history.
10. He drinks 5-6 beers on the weekend and has a 20 pack-year smoking history.
11. He denies any family history of cancer.
12. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 117/72 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 13/min.
13. On physical exam, he is tender to palpation above the umbilicus.
14. Bowel sounds are present.
15. A stool guaiac test is positive.
16. The patient undergoes an endoscopy with a biopsy to diagnose his condition.
question_options:
Which of the following is most likely to be found on histology?

A. Crypt abscesses in the large intestine  
B. Mucosal defect in the stomach  
C. Noncaseating granulomas in the small intestine  
D. Urease-producing organism in the small intestine

step1_excerpts:
1. A 5-year-old girl was referred to ophthalmology care for evaluation of nystagmus.
2. Her medical history included esophageal atresia, small bowel obstruction, mild cognitive impairment, low tone, and increased reflexes.
3. Prenatal history was complicated by insulin-controlled gestational diabetes and polyhydramnios.
4. Her ocular history was notable for eye movement abnormalities since birth.
5. She had no family history of ocular disease.
6. On examination, her visual acuity was 20/150 OU and did not improve with correction (right eye, −1.50 [2.00] × 180; left eye, −1.00 [1.50] × 180).
7. Pupillary responses were normal.
8. Alternating vertical and torsional nystagmus was noted (Figure 1).
9. Specifically, 1 eye was noted to rise and intort while the other would fall and extort, followed by reversal of the vertical and torsional components in the opposite eye (Video).
10. The optic nerve and foveal reflexes were normal in both eyes.
11. Flash visual evoked potential (VEP) demonstrated strong ipsilateral activity of the occipital lobe.
12. Results of a previously obtained brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan were reported as normal.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Review brain MRI and order electroretinogram  
B: Refer for strabismus surgery  
C: Order genetic workup  
D: Treat with clonazepam

step1_excerpts:
1. A 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of cramping in his hands and feet and numbness and tingling around his lips and in his fingers; these symptoms occurred intermittently for 6 months but have been progressively severe during the past 2 weeks.
2. He also has had a 13-kg (30-lb) weight loss and bulky, foul-smelling stools that do not flush easily.
3. He has a 10-year history of drinking 8 to 10 beers daily.
4. He has been hospitalized twice for severe abdominal pain 4 and 6 years ago.
5. His pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg.
6. He appears cachectic and chronically ill.
7. The abdomen is nontender.
8. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally.
9. Chvostek and Trousseau signs are present.
10. His serum calcium concentration is 6.5 mg/dL.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Hypomagnesemia

B. Hypoparathyroidism

C. Osteomalacia

D. Vitamin D deficiency

step1_excerpts:
1. A 59-year-old man who had been taking warfarin for 16 years for recurrent deep vein thrombosis and a left ventricular thrombosis presented to the anticoagulation management service for a follow-up visit.  
2. His warfarin had been managed via point-of-care (POC) testing for the past 4 years with a goal international normalized ratio (INR) of 2.0 to 3.0.  
3. On presentation, his POC INR was 3.7.  
4. He reported no extra warfarin doses, medication changes, dietary nonadherence, or bleeding.  
5. His warfarin dosage was 36 mg/wk (3 mg every Wednesday and Saturday and 6 mg all other days) for the past year.  
6. The Table shows the patient’s laboratory test results.  
7. Continue current warfarin dosing and perform a point-of-care (POC) international normalized ratio (INR) test in 1 week.  
8. Skip 2 doses of warfarin then resume current dosage and perform a POC INR test in 2 weeks.  
9. Skip 2 doses of warfarin, reduce weekly dosage by 10%, and perform a POC INR in 2 weeks.  
10. Perform a plasma INR test to confirm POC INR test results.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Continue current warfarin dosing and perform a point-of-care (POC) international normalized ratio (INR) test in 1 week.  
B: Skip 2 doses of warfarin then resume current dosage and perform a POC INR test in 2 weeks.  
C: Skip 2 doses of warfarin, reduce weekly dosage by 10%, and perform a POC INR in 2 weeks.  
D: Perform a plasma INR test to confirm POC INR test results.

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine physical examination.  
2. He is currently taking no medications.  
3. His pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 165/95 mm Hg.  
4. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities.
question_options:
The presence of which of the following mechanisms is most likely to increase this patient's blood pressure further?

A. Decreased cardiac output

B. Decreased pulse

C. Decreased stroke volume

D. Increased peripheral vascular resistance

step1_excerpts:
1. A 62-year-old man presented with subacute, painless vision loss in the right eye that developed over the course of 1 week.
2. He had a history of well-controlled type 2 diabetes and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma that was diagnosed 3 years earlier.
3. The lymphoma was initially treated with chemotherapy, followed by a relapse that required additional chemotherapy and ultimately autologous bone marrow transplant 3 months before presentation.
4. At the time of presentation, he was taking no immunosuppressive medications and was taking prophylactic acyclovir, 800 mg twice daily, and sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim (800 mg/160 mg) 3 times weekly.Snellen visual acuity measured 20/40 OD and 20/20 OS.
5. Intraocular pressure (IOP) measured 24 mm Hg OD and 12 mm Hg OS.
6. There was no afferent pupillary defect.
7. Right eye examination results revealed 1+ anterior chamber inflammation, iris neovascularization, keratic precipitates, vitritis, and a granular necrotizing retinitis (Figure, A).
8. Left eye examination results were unremarkable.
9. Fluorescein angiography of the right eye demonstrated panretinal occlusive vasculopathy with severe peripheral nonperfusion (Figure, B).
10. His white blood cell count was moderately low at 3.1 kilos/μL (to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001; reference range, 4.0-10.0 kilos/μL); a complete blood count and serum chemistry panel were otherwise normal.
11. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) testing results were negative.
12. An aqueous tap was performed and sent for culture and polymerase chain reaction.A, Wide-field fundus photograph demonstrating vitreous haze, vascular attenuation, macular cotton wool-spots, diffuse intraretinal hemorrhages, and superior granular necrotizing retinitis.
13. B, Late-phase fluorescein angiogram demonstrating disc leakage and marked peripheral nonperfusion.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Administer intravitreal clindamycin  
B: Administer intravitreal foscarnet and admit for intravenous acyclovir  
C: Administer intravitreal foscarnet and initiate valganciclovir  
D: Administer an intravitreal anti–vascular endothelial growth factor agent followed by panretinal photocoagulation

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 40s with a history of chronic blurry vision in both eyes (worse in the right eye) had latent extrapulmonary tuberculosis that had been treated with antitubercular therapy 1 year earlier.
2. Oral prednisone provided visual improvement.
3. However, the therapy was complicated by avascular hip necrosis that required total hip arthroplasty, and his visual symptoms recurred with corticosteroid tapering.
4. At presentation, his visual acuity was 20/150 OD and 20/15 OS.
5. The anterior segment was normal in both eyes.
6. Dilated ophthalmoscopic examination of the right eye revealed a diffuse subretinal yellow mass and an exudative retinal detachment temporal to the fovea (Figure 1).
7. Ophthalmoscopic examination of the left eye was normal.
8. B-scan of the right eye showed a dome-shaped choroidal lesion with an apical height of 3.4 mm and medium to high internal reflectivity.
9. Fluorescein angiography demonstrated heterogeneous leakage, and optical coherence tomography of the macula showed subretinal fluid with irregular retinal and choroidal thickening.
10. Results from extensive workup for infectious and autoimmune etiologies (including serum angiotensin-converting enzyme, lysozyme, lumbar puncture, magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and orbits, and computed tomography of the chest) were negative, except for positive purified protein derivative skin testing and positive interferon-γ release assay (QuantiFERON-TB Gold; Cellestis, Inc).
11. Large choroidal tuberculoma at presentation.
12. In a fundus view of the right eye, a moderate amount of subretinal fluid is seen adjacent to the lesion, involving the fovea center.
13. B-scan (not shown) measured an apical height of 3.4 mm.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Consult infectious diseases for alternative antitubercular therapy  
B: Initiate corticosteroid-sparing immunosuppressive therapy  
C: Inject intravitreous triamcinolone acetonide  
D: Perform pars plana vitrectomy with intravitreous methotrexate

step1_excerpts:
1. A 73-year-old African American woman presented with a widespread scaly pruritic rash lasting 2 months.
2. Her medical history included hypertension, diabetes, pulmonary sarcoidosis, and acid reflux, for which she takes amlodipine, carvedilol, repaglinide, hydroxychloroquine, and pantoprazole.
3. Her history also included chronic renal insufficiency and chronic hepatitis C, for which she takes no medications.
4. She reported no fevers, new skin exposures, oral ulcers, arthritis, alopecia, or photosensitivity and no worsening pulmonary symptoms of cough or shortness of breath.
5. The rash did not improve after 2 weeks of applying topical triamcinolone ointment (0.1%).
6. Physical examination revealed annular coalescing scaly patches with erythematous borders on her forehead, neck, back, and upper and lower extremities (Figure, panels A and B).
7. Laboratory workup revealed an antinuclear antibodies titer of 1:80 with a speckled pattern, elevated Sjögren syndrome–related antigen A (SS-A) level (>8 AI), and no elevation of Sjögren syndrome–related antigen B (SS-B), ribonucleoprotein, double-stranded DNA, Smith, or anti-histone antibodies.
8. Complete blood cell count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein level were within normal limits.
9. Creatinine level was elevated but stable at 1.8 mg/dL (159.1 μmol/L).
10. Skin biopsy revealed an inflammatory pattern of vacuolar interface dermatitis (Figure, panel C).
11. A, Widespread annular and polycyclic scaly patches on the trunk and extremities.
12. B, Magnified view of scaly patches, showing erythematous borders.
13. C, Skin biopsy revealing vacuolar interface changes accompanied by hyperkeratosis, necrotic keratinocytes, and a superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate in the dermis (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×200).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Obtain a chest radiograph to evaluate progression of sarcoidosis  
B: Discontinue pantoprazole  
C: Start oral prednisone  
D: Order testing for anti–Mi-2 and anti–Jo-1 antibodies

step1_excerpts:
1. After being severely beaten and sustaining a gunshot wound to the abdomen, a 42-year-old woman undergoes resection of a perforated small bowel.  
2. During the operation, plastic reconstruction of facial fractures, and open reduction and internal fixation of the left femur are also done.  
3. Thirty-six hours postoperatively, she is awake but not completely alert.  
4. She is receiving intravenous morphine via a patient-controlled pump.  
5. She says that she needs the morphine to treat her pain, but she is worried that she is becoming addicted.  
6. She has no history of substance use disorder.  
7. She drinks one to two glasses of wine weekly.
question_options:
Which of the following initial actions by the physician is most appropriate?  

A. Reassure the patient that her chance of becoming addicted to narcotics is minuscule  

B. Maintain the morphine, but periodically administer intravenous naloxone  

C. Switch the patient to oral acetaminophen as soon as she can take medication orally  

D. Switch the patient to intramuscular lorazepam

step1_excerpts:
1. An 84-year-old woman with a history of chronic kidney disease, prior stroke, and hypertension was admitted with a 2-week history of spontaneous subcutaneous ecchymoses and hematomas.
2. She did not have any history of bleeding disorders, preceding trauma, or other precipitating factors such as recent heparin exposure, surgical procedures, underlying liver disease, or receipt of anticoagulation agents.
3. There was no family history of hematologic disorders.
4. Her vital signs were normal.
5. Physical examination showed large ecchymoses on the left arm, right shoulder, left anterior chest wall, and flank.
6. Initial laboratory results showed isolated severe anemia.
7. Computed tomographic imaging showed a large soft-tissue hematoma in the left chest wall without evidence of internal hemorrhage.
8. Test results for other causes of anemia were unremarkable.
9. Laboratory values and mixing study results are shown in the Table.
question_options:
How Do You Interpret These Test Results?

A: The patient has a common clotting factor inhibitor.  
B: The patient has an extrinsic clotting factor inhibitor.  
C: The patient has an intrinsic clotting factor inhibitor.  
D: The patient does not have a clotting factor inhibitor.

step1_excerpts:
1. A 61-year-old man presents with a painless plaque on the right side of his scrotum; the plaque first appeared 1.5 years ago and has been slowly enlarging since.
2. The patient reports experiencing no fevers or chills since the plaque developed.
3. On examination the bright reddish, irregularly shaped plaque measures 4.0 × 1.5 cm and has erosions on the surface (Figure 1).
4. The physical examination is otherwise unremarkable.
5. Results of complete blood cell count and differential are normal.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Empirically treat with a topical steroid  
B: Initiate treatment with valacyclovir and send culture for further studies  
C: Order laboratory studies to rule out syphilis  
D: Obtain a biopsy of the lesion for pathological examination

step1_excerpts:
1. A 31-year-old man presents to the emergency department for fever, malaise, and cough.
2. For the last week, his cough has been progressively worsening, and he has been noticing blood in his sputum.
3. He denies any recent travel or sick contacts and infrequently smokes cigarettes.
4. Approximately 5 weeks ago, he presented with similar symptoms and was found to have a right upper lobe lung infiltrate, a CD4 count of 40/mm^3, and an HIV viral load of 115,000 copies/mL.
5. He was appropriately treated and discharged home.
6. Four weeks after initiation of treatment, his CD4 count was over 400/mm^3 and HIV viral load was negligible.
7. His temperature today is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, and respirations are 20/min.
8. A radiograph of the chest demonstrates new nodules in the left upper lobe and hilar adenopathy.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Continue current anti-retroviral treatment, antimicrobial, and anti-tuberculoid therapies  
B. Determine drug sensitivities against the patient’s pulmonary infection  
C. Discontinue antimicrobial treatment  
D. Obtain a D-dimer level

step1_excerpts:
1. A 77-year-old man is brought to the physician because of a 12-hour history of word-finding difficulty and weakness and sensory loss of the right arm and leg.
2. He has no history of similar symptoms.
3. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation.
4. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, and aspirin.
5. He is alert.
6. His pulse is 80/min and irregular, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 170/90 mm Hg.
7. He follows commands but has nonfluent aphasia.
8. There is moderate weakness and decreased sensation of the right upper and lower extremities.
9. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally.
10. Babinski sign is present on the right.
11. His serum glucose concentration is 162 mg/dL.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

A. Carotid duplex ultrasonography

B. CT scan of the head

C. EEG

D. Lumbar puncture

step1_excerpts:
1. A 59-year-old male presents to the clinic with his wife, reporting nausea and dizziness.
2. He is uncertain about the onset of his symptoms but states they have been ongoing "for a while." Initially, he experienced episodes of "unsteadiness," which have progressed to a sensation of "spinning." He cannot confirm if his symptoms are positional but mentions that failing to lie down leads to nausea.
3. He also reports worsening hearing loss, particularly on the right side.
4. His medical history includes hypertension, alcohol use disorder, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
5. Current medications are aspirin, amlodipine, and fluticasone-salmeterol.
6. He consumes one glass of red wine nightly with dinner and smokes cigars on weekends.
7. Vital signs are as follows: temperature 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure 135/91 mmHg, pulse 72/min, and respirations 12/min.
8. Physical examination reveals delayed horizontal nystagmus.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition?

A. Betahistine  
B. Diuretic therapy  
C. Epley maneuver  
D. Low-salt diet  
E. Corticosteroid therapy  
F. CN VIII ablation  
G. Gentamicin intratympanic injection  
H. Meclizine  
I. Vestibular rehabilitation therapy  
J. Endolymphatic sac decompression

step1_excerpts:
1. A 57-year-old male with atrial fibrillation on warfarin therapy is brought to the emergency department with altered mental status.
2. Two days prior, he had visited the ED for severe epistaxis that was managed with nasal packing.
3. Current vital signs show: temperature 97.6°F (36.4°C), blood pressure 64/33 mmHg, heart rate 160/min, respiratory rate 32/min, and oxygen saturation 100% on room air.
4. The patient is obtunded and unresponsive to questions.
5. Physical examination reveals a dark, purpuric rash on his trunk and extremities.
6. Upon removal of the nasal packing, no active bleeding is observed.
question_options:
After initiating IV fluids and obtaining blood cultures, which medication should be administered as the first priority?

A. IV corticosteroids  
B. Ceftriaxone  
C. Vancomycin  
D. Vitamin K  
E. Amphotericin B  
F. Penicillin  
G. Clindamycin  
H. Piperacillin-tazobactam  
I. Meropenem  
J. Fresh frozen plasma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 64-year-old female presents to the emergency department following a fall, resulting in a right distal radius fracture.
2. Initial testing reveals a serum sodium of 128 mEq/liter.
3. Her medical conditions include hypertension, hypothyroidism, osteoporosis, and depression, managed with lisinopril 20 mg daily, amlodipine 5 mg daily, levothyroxine 100 μg daily, sertraline 100 mg daily, and alendronate 70 mg weekly.
4. She is alert and oriented, with normal vital signs and physical examination findings except for her casted right forearm.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate subsequent step in managing this patient's hyponatremia?

A. Limit intake of free water to 1500 mL daily  
B. Begin oral salt tablets with loop diuretics  
C. Administer isotonic saline infusion  
D. Initiate fluid restriction with urea supplementation  
E. Perform a water deprivation test  
F. Administer hypertonic saline infusion  
G. Discontinue sertraline therapy  
H. Increase dietary sodium intake  
I. Limit intake of all fluids to 1000 mL daily  
J. Administer 1 liter of 0.9% normal saline intravenously

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 40s with a medical history of multiple sclerosis consulted for the sudden development of 2 adjacent nodules on the left arm.
2. An excision with 1-cm margins of the left arm demonstrated desmoplastic melanoma with a Breslow thickness of 1 mm, and a left axillary sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) had been performed 3 weeks before under general anesthesia.
3. The patient was also being treated with subcutaneous interferon beta 1a for the multiple sclerosis.
4. Physical examination revealed 2 indurated and mobile subcutaneous nodules on the anterior surface of the arm 5 cm distal to the surgical scar, the larger of them measuring 15 mm in diameter (Figure, A) and the smaller of them measuring 4 mm.
5. When the arm was abducted to 90°, the patient denied pain but described a subtle tightness sensation on the arm.
6. An excisional biopsy from the larger lesion was performed (Figure, B-D).
7. A, Clinical image showing indurated and mobile subcutaneous nodule on the anterior surface of the arm.
8. Arrowheads highlight a subtle linear plaque adjacent to the nodule.
9. B, Histopathologic image showing dilated and thrombosed lymphatic vessels in subcutaneous tissue with recanalization (hematoxylin-eosin).
10. C, Histopathologic image of partially thrombosed vessels.
11. D, Immunohistochemistry finding was positive for D2-40 (podoplanin).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Intravascular papillary endothelial hyperplasia  
B: Pseudo-aneurysmal metastasis of melanoma  
C: Axillary web syndrome  
D: Traumatic humeral pseudo-aneurysm

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pressure and diaphoresis.
2. His symptoms started at work when he was lifting boxes.
3. He states that he currently feels crushing pressure over his chest.
4. He is given aspirin and an ECG is performed in triage, as seen in Figure A.
5. His past medical history is notable for diabetes and obesity.
6. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years.
7. His temperature is 97.9°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 155/99 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
8. Physical exam reveals an uncomfortable, diaphoretic man.
9. His heart and breath sounds are unremarkable.
10. A repeat ECG in the emergency department is performed, also seen in Figure A.
11. The patient’s chest pain is worse when the ECG in the emergency department is taken, compared to the one taken in triage.
12. He is given nitroglycerin, with minimal improvement in his symptoms.
13. A troponin level is drawn.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Repeat ECG in 10 minutes  
B. Cardiac catheterization  
C. Heparin  
D. Chest radiograph

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her early 70s underwent laparoscopic right partial nephrectomy for oncocytoma.
2. During workup, she was found to have an asymptomatic cystic lesion in the right iliac fossa.
3. Fifteen months later, a contrast-enhanced computed tomographic (CT) scan of her abdomen showed a progressive 16-mm cystic lesion in close relation to the cecum (Figure 1).
4. The rest of the colon and small intestine, as well as the adenexa, solid organs, and peritoneum, appeared normal.
5. There was no other positive radiologic finding except for right partial nephrectomy.
6. The general physical and abdominal examinations were unremarkable.
7. The results of other investigations such as a hemogram, liver and kidney function tests, and serum tumor markers, including serum carcinoembryonic antigen levels (0.94 ng/mL [to convert to micrograms per liter, multiply by 1.0]), were within the prescribed normal range.
8. She had good exercise tolerance, and the results of cardiopulmonary investigations, as a part of preanesthesia workup, were normal.Contrast-enhanced computed tomographic scan of the abdomen showing a cystic lesion (arrowheads) in the right iliac fossa (axial view [A] and planar reconstruction image [B]).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Mucocele of the appendix  
B: Cecal diverticulum  
C: Meckel diverticulum  
D: Ileal duplication cyst

step1_excerpts:
1. A 41-year-old woman presented with a rapidly growing, painful nodule on her upper cutaneous lip (Figure, A) as well as several smaller papules on her face and neck, all of which had developed within the preceding 6 months.
2. She was otherwise asymptomatic.A, Centrally depressed, firm, pink 1.1-cm nodule on the upper cutaneous lip and skin-colored papule on the left medial cheek (above marker dots).
3. B, Cup-shaped tumor demonstrated keratinocyte atypia with a central core of keratinaceous debris.
4. C, Sebaceous tumor with a modestly increased ratio of basaloid cells to sebocytes.The patient’s medical history included diabetes mellitus type 2, hypercholesterolemia, hypertension, and depression.
5. Review of her family medical history revealed that her paternal grandfather died from melanoma and that her father died from colon cancer.
6. She stated that most of the men in her family had died from some form of cancer by the fourth decade of life.On physical examination, a tender, centrally depressed, firm, pink 1.1-cm nodule was present on her upper cutaneous lip (Figure, A).
7. Three other skin-colored to pink papules were present on her face and neck.
8. Shave biopsies of all 4 skin lesions were performed (Figure, B and C).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Cowden syndrome  
B: Muir-Torre syndrome  
C: Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome  
D: Basal cell nevus syndrome

step1_excerpts:
1. A 34-year-old primigravid woman at 20 weeks' gestation presents for follow-up after discovering a mass in her left breast two weeks ago.
2. She experienced menarche at age 11, and her menstrual cycles occurred every 30–40 days prior to pregnancy.
3. Her vital signs are normal.
4. Physical examination reveals a 3-cm, firm, nonmobile, nontender mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast, with no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy.
5. Pelvic examination confirms a uterus size consistent with 20 weeks of gestation.
6. Ultrasound and core biopsy confirm infiltrating lobular carcinoma, with the pathological specimen testing positive for estrogen and ERBB2 receptors and negative for progesterone receptors.
7. Staging reveals no evidence of distant metastases.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Radiation therapy followed by surgery  
B. Trastuzumab therapy  
C. Surgical resection and chemotherapy  
D. Hormonal therapy alone  
E. Surgical resection and radiotherapy  
F. Hormonal therapy and trastuzumab  
G. Conservative management with close monitoring  
H. Delay treatment until after delivery  
I. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy alone  
J. Mastectomy with lymph node dissection only

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 60s presented with a 2-year history of an abnormal left second fingernail.
2. A previous biopsy showed a pyogenic granuloma, and she had been treated with curettage and electrodessication.
3. In the few months before presentation, she experienced partial nail loss and her nail had become painful with intermittent drainage.
4. Her medical history was significant for streptococcal glomerulonephritis and 2 prior kidney transplants.
5. Her medications included prednisone, tacrolimus, and mycophenolate mofetil.
6. Physical examination of the left second fingernail showed a tender ulcerated nodule encompassing the nail bed with near-complete nail loss and purulent drainage (Figure 1, left).
7. A nail biopsy was repeated by performing a 4-mm punch through the nail bed.
8. The specimen was analyzed by histopathology with hematoxylin-eosin staining and once again showed a pyogenic granuloma–like response characterized by proliferating blood vessels in a background of fibrosis and reactive plasmacytic infiltration (Figure 1, right).
9. Careful inspection of the pyogenic granulomatous process at higher power demonstrated atypical epithelioid and spindled cells adjacent to blood vessels.Left, Physical examination of left second fingernail.
10. Right, Histopathologic findings under low-power magnification (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×20).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Treat with cryotherapy  
B: Perform immunohistochemical analysis on the biopsy specimen  
C: Perform tissue culture for bacterial and fungal organisms  
D: Provide reassurance

step1_excerpts:
1. A 75-year-old woman presented with horizontal binocular diplopia, right-sided ptosis, and a new headache that was progressive over 3 days.
2. She reported difficulty opening her jaw, pain when chewing, and a 2.3-kg weight loss.
3. The week prior, she experienced left-sided ptosis that persisted for 2 days and subsequently resolved.
4. She denied vision changes, eye pain, scalp tenderness, and myalgias.
5. Past medical history included schizophrenia, hypothyroidism, and supraventricular tachycardia.Her examination demonstrated normal visual acuity in both eyes.
6. Pupils were equal, round, and reactive.
7. There was right upper-eyelid ptosis.
8. Extraocular motility demonstrated limitation of elevation and abduction bilaterally (Figure 1).
9. Results of dilated fundus examination were normal, and the remainder of her neurologic examination results were normal.
10. Her eye movements and ptosis did not change with fatiguability, rest, or an ice-pack test.
11. Investigations revealed a C-reactive protein level of 292 mg/L (normal, <10 mg/L; to convert to milligrams per deciliter, divide by 10) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 93 mm/h (normal, <30 mm/h).
12. A lumbar puncture demonstrated normal opening pressure, cell count, and glucose and protein levels.
13. Magnetic resonance imaging with contrast of the brain demonstrated diffuse edema and enhancement of the scalp, skull base, neck, and paraspinal soft tissues, as well as T2 hyperintensity and enhancement of the extraocular muscles bilaterally.
14. An additional test was obtained, and a diagnosis was made.Extraocular movements on presentation.
15. Examination reveals deficits in elevation and abduction of both eyes not conforming to a cranial nerve distribution.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Giant cell arteritis  
B: Anti–transfer RNA synthetase myositis  
C: Immunoglobulin G4–related disease  
D: Myasthenia gravis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 60-year-old male with a history of COPD arrives at the emergency department via ambulance with severe dyspnea, unable to complete full sentences.
2. Multiple attempts with his tiotropium inhaler have been unsuccessful.
3. His vital signs show: temperature normal, blood pressure 90/60, heart rate 120, respiratory rate 24, and oxygen saturation 86%.
4. The electrocardiogram demonstrates a narrow-complex tachycardia with irregular P waves before each QRS complex and variable PR intervals.
question_options:
What should be the immediate next step in this patient's care?

A. Begin empiric antibiotics for suspected pneumonia  
B. Administer intravenous furosemide  
C. Initiate intravenous amiodarone therapy  
D. Perform synchronized cardioversion  
E. Intubate and admit to intensive care unit  
G. Give verapamil immediately and admit to floor  
H. Administer intravenous corticosteroids  
I. Administer albuterol nebulizer treatment  
J. Give oxygen immediately

step1_excerpts:
1. A 69-year-old man presents to his primary care provider for a general checkup.
2. He has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, depression, obesity, and a myocardial infarction 7 years ago.
3. The patient's prescribed medications are metoprolol, aspirin, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, fluoxetine, metformin, and insulin.
4. The patient has not been filling his prescriptions regularly and can not remember what medications he has been taking.
5. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 180/120 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air.
question_options:
Which of the following cardiac findings would be expected on physical exam?

A. Heart sound after S2  
B. Holosystolic murmur at the apex  
C. Heart sound before S1  
D. Fixed splitting of S1 and S2

step1_excerpts:
1. A 57-year-old woman presents for evaluation of gingival “peeling” associated with pain and bleeding and white patches on the oral mucosa for 7 years.  
2. She reports no new medications, foods, or oral hygiene products.  
3. She reports no involvement of other cutaneous or mucosal surfaces and no family history of oral lesions.  
4. The lesions cause pain and difficulty brushing her teeth.  
5. She has a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, type 2 diabetes, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and seasonal allergies.  
6. Her medications are valsartan-hydrochlorothiazide, levothyroxine sodium, metformin, insulin, and loratadine.  
7. Intraoral examination shows generalized erythema and sloughing of the maxillary and mandibular gingiva, without evidence of dental plaque, calculus, or both, and white striae (Wickham striae) affecting the gingiva and mucosa (Figure 1).  
8. Her physical examination is otherwise normal.  
9. Prescribe valacyclovir (1000 mg 3 times daily) for the next 7 days Order a nutritional assay to evaluate for vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency Recommend increased use of an alcohol-based mouthwash to improve oral hygiene
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Prescribe valacyclovir (1000 mg 3 times daily) for the next 7 days  
B: Order a nutritional assay to evaluate for vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency  
C: Recommend increased use of an alcohol-based mouthwash to improve oral hygiene  
D: Biopsy the affected tissue

step1_excerpts:
1. A 38-year-old man with Down syndrome and severe mental retardation is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of increasing lethargy for the past several hours.  
2. The patient is noncommunicative and you are unable to obtain an initial history of his present illness or a past medical history.  
3. You do not know if he takes any medications.  
4. Vital signs are temperature 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse 90/min, respirations 19/min, and blood pressure 120/60 mm Hg.  
5. On physical examination the patient is awake but lethargic.  
6. Auscultation of the chest discloses clear lungs; cardiac examination discloses a systolic click.  
7. Neurologic examination shows decreased muscle tone.  
8. Serum electrolyte concentrations are normal.  
9. Complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 18,000/mm3 with 23% band neutrophils.  
10. The patient's caregiver, who is also the patient's guardian, cannot be located and staff at the group home where the patient resides cannot be reached by telephone.  
11. The patient refuses lumbar puncture for examination of cerebrospinal fluid.  
12. Toxicologic screening of the urine is negative.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

A. Administer intravenous antibiotics

B. Await contact with the caregiver before proceeding with management

C. Obtain CT scan of the head

D. Obtain echocardiography

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 20s was referred to the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary Neuro-Ophthalmology Service with a 2-month complaint of frequent headaches and 1 week of blurry vision in her left eye.
2. Her ocular history was significant only for refractive error.
3. Her medical history revealed systemic hypertension, depression, and obesity.
4. Her current medications included hydrochlorothiazide and fluoxetine.
5. On review of systems, she endorsed nausea as well as paresthesia in her hands.
6. Neuro-ophthalmic examination revealed visual acuities of 20/20 OD and 20/40 OS, with no pinhole improvement.
7. Color vision (Ishihara pseudoisochromatic plates) was within normal limits bilaterally, although it was noted to be slightly slower in the left eye.
8. With the Amsler grid, she reported significant metamorphopsia in the left eye.
9. Pupils were symmetric with slow responses bilaterally but without afferent defects.
10. Applanation tonometry revealed pressures of 16 mm Hg OD and 17 mm Hg OS.
11. Slitlamp examination revealed no cells in the anterior chamber or the anterior vitreous in either eye.
12. Automated (Humphrey) visual field testing revealed enlargement of the blind spot in the right eye (mean deviation, −2.91 dB) and generalized, nonspecific depression in the left eye (mean deviation, −3.41 dB).
13. Examination of her fundus was notable for bilateral optic disc swelling (Frisén grade 2 in each eye) as well as unilateral macular exudates, subretinal fluid, and subretinal hemorrhages in the left eye (Figure 1).
14. Results from brain magnetic resonance imaging with magnetic resonance venography with and without contrast were normal.
15. A, Color fundus photograph demonstrating Frisén grade 2 optic disc edema.
16. B, Color fundus photograph demonstrating Frisén grade 2 optic disc edema associated with subretinal fluid, exudate, and retinal hemorrhages.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Observe the patient and treat headaches conservatively  
B: Consult surgery for immediate surgical intervention  
C: Perform a lumbar puncture with opening pressure, routine chemistry, and cell count analysis  
D: Begin treatment with high-dose corticosteroids

step1_excerpts:
1. An 82-year-old Chinese woman presented with a 6-month history of a nonhealing ulcer and multiple indurated plaques on the legs.
2. The first lesion appeared as an erythematous papule, which grew and subsequently ulcerated.
3. Within a few months, she developed other indurated plaques on her legs.
4. The ulcer was painful on palpation, but the plaques were mostly asymptomatic.
5. The patient did not have fevers, chills, weight loss, dyspnea, chest pain, cough, or hemoptysis.
6. She had moved to Canada from China 30 years ago and was unsure about tuberculosis (TB) exposure and Bacillus Calmette–Guérin vaccine status.
7. Her medical history included atrial fibrillation, type 2 diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, cerebrovascular disease, hypertension, and Parkinson disease.
8. Physical examination showed a 5 × 4-cm, well-demarcated, oval ulcer with a violaceous, dusky border and central yellow fibrin mixed with granulation tissue on the left lateral aspect of the calf (Figure, A).
9. There were numerous violaceous to dull red, indurated plaques on the posterior aspect of the legs (Figure, B).
10. Wound cultures were negative for bacteria, mycobacteria, and fungi (Figure, C and D).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Infective panniculitides  
B: Erythema nodosum  
C: Erythema induratum  
D: Pyoderma gangrenosum

step1_excerpts:
1. A 50-year-old man was referred for ophthalmoplegia that developed immediately after an 8.5-hour robotic cystectomy for small cell cancer of the bladder.  
2. After recovering from anesthesia in the postanesthesia care unit, he experienced headache, facial numbness, inability to open both his eyes, and inability to move both eyes in any direction.  
3. He had a known enhancing central skull base lesion in sella turcica with compression of the optic chiasm and mild mass effect on the pons that was felt to be a pituitary macroadenoma (Figure).  
4. His baseline examination before the cystectomy showed visual acuity of 20/20 OU with intact extraocular movements and unremarkable confrontational fields, although a mild bitemporal hemianopia was seen on automated visual fields.  
5. T1-weighted coronal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with contrast shows a 4.9 × 4.6 × 5.2-cm sellar/parasellar lobulated mass with homogenous enhancement before symptom onset (A), which became 5.3 × 5.1 × 5.3 cm and had loss of enhancement after symptom onset (B).  
6. The mass caused superior displacement of the optic chiasm and had extension into the cavernous sinus bilaterally.  
7. The mass also extended posteriorly and deformed the anterior aspect of the pons (not shown).  
8. After symptom onset, the mass was hyperintense on T2-weighted images (not shown).  
9. During the bedside examination in the postanesthesia care unit, he was noted to have complete bilateral ptosis.  
10. His visual acuity was 20/20 OU with full visual fields on confrontational visual field testing.  
11. He had decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick in the V1/V2 distribution of the trigeminal nerve bilaterally.  
12. The right and left pupils were 5 mm and 6 mm in size, respectively, in both light and dark.  
13. There was no pupillary response to light or accommodation.  
14. No exophthalmos was noted.  
15. Intraocular pressure was normal in both eyes.  
16. The patient was unable to move either eye in any direction on extraocular motility testing.  
17. Vestibulo-ocular reflex did not overcome the ophthalmoplegia.  
18. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was obtained 12 hours after symptom onset redemonstrating the large sellar mass, which no longer had central enhancement (Figure).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Orbital compartment syndrome  
B: Ocular motor apraxia  
C: Pituitary apoplexy  
D: Cavernous sinus thrombosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 52-year-old G3P3 woman presents to clinic with a 2-year history of urinary incontinence.
2. She has had frequent, involuntary loss of urine over the last 2 years but presented today because of 10 days of dysuria.
3. She has been treated for 2 urinary tract infections over the past 6 months.
4. She does not endorse any loss of urine with coughing or laughter.
5. She has no chronic medical illnesses and no surgical history.
6. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 15/min.
7. Her BMI is 30 kg/m^2.
8. On pelvic examination, the vagina is dry and atrophic with a 2-cm tender, palpable anterior vaginal mass.
9. The mass does not change with Valsava maneuver.
10. Her postvoid residual volume is 60 mL.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Urethral diverticulum  
B. Overflow incontinence  
C. Stress urinary incontinence  
D. Pelvic organ prolapse

step1_excerpts:
1. A 35-year-old man was admitted as an inpatient for altered mental status and experienced acute-onset bilateral decreased vision on the second day of hospitalization.  
2. He denied any medication use and had no previous history of ocular surgery or known ophthalmic disorders.  
3. On examination, visual acuity with correction was 20/400 OD and 20/100 OS.  
4. Intraocular pressure was within normal limits.  
5. Both pupils were briskly reactive without an afferent pupillary defect.  
6. Slitlamp examination was unremarkable.  
7. Dilated fundus examination of both eyes revealed peripapillary retinal whitening emanating from the optic nerve and encroaching into the macula, more pronounced in the right eye (Figure 1A).  
8. Late-phase frames of fluorescein angiogram in both eyes revealed hypofluorescence corresponding to the areas of retinal whitening and obscuring the choroidal fluorescence in these areas, along with nasal peripapillary hyperfluorescence in the areas of retinal whitening (Figure 1B).  
9. Fundus photograph (A) and late-phase frame fluorescein angiography (B) of the right eye.  
10. Arrowheads indicate areas of retinal opacification.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  

A: Order human immunodeficiency virus serologies  
B: Order bacterial and fungal blood cultures  
C: Order a lipase level  
D: Order antinuclear antibodies

step1_excerpts:
1. A healthy 4-year-old girl is brought for a well-child examination.
2. A grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard along the upper left sternal border.
3. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration.
4. A soft mid-diastolic murmur is heard along the lower left sternal border.
5. Examination shows no other abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Aortic stenosis

B. Atrial septal defect

C. Coarctation of the aorta

D. Mitral valve prolapse

step1_excerpts:
1. A 73-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and knee osteoarthritis seeks medical attention for memory concerns.
2. His long-term partner notes that the patient requires frequent reminders about current events and has withdrawn from social activities due to difficulty following conversations.
3. While he maintains independence in basic activities of daily living (showering, dressing, toileting, eating), he relies on his partner for complex tasks such as driving, managing medications, preparing meals, and handling finances.
4. The patient has no history of head trauma and denies depression, sleep disturbances, or hearing problems.
5. His medications include lisinopril, simvastatin, and acetaminophen, with no over-the-counter medications or alcohol use.
6. Physical examination reveals normal vital signs and neurological findings.
7. Depression screening with PHQ-2 scores 1/6.
8. Comprehensive laboratory testing (including CBC, metabolic panel, thyroid function, vitamins D and B12, RPR, and HIV) and head MRI are all normal.
9. Montreal Cognitive Assessment reveals executive function and delayed recall deficits, with a total score of 18/30 (normal ≥26).
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Subjective cognitive decline  
B. Early-stage Alzheimer's disease  
C. Vascular cognitive impairment  
D. Pseudodementia  
E. Major depressive disorder  
F. Normal pressure hydrocephalus  
G. Mixed cognitive impairment  
H. Age-associated memory impairment  
I. Dementia  
J. Mild cognitive impairment

step1_excerpts:
1. A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to the back, accompanied by shortness of breath and pain with swallowing.
2. The symptoms began 30 minutes ago following heavy alcohol consumption and repeated episodes of forceful vomiting.
3. His medical history includes hypertension, alcohol use disorder, and liver cirrhosis.
4. On examination, his temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 142/78 mmHg, and pulse is 75/min.
5. Crepitus is noted on palpation of the upper chest wall, and abdominal examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly.
question_options:
What is the next best step in managing this patient?

A. Initiate broad-spectrum antibiotics  
B. Administer proton pump inhibitors  
C. Order computed tomography of the chest  
D. Perform diagnostic endoscopy  
E. Immediate surgical repair  
F. Perform contrast esophagram  
G. Obtain a barium swallow study  
H. Perform emergent thoracentesis  
I. Administration of octreotide  
J. Perform esophageal manometry

step1_excerpts:
1. A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressive fatigue and ankle swelling.  
2. He had an anterior myocardial infarction 3 years ago and has had shortness of breath with mild exertion since then.  
3. Current medications include labetalol and daily aspirin.  
4. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years.  
5. His pulse is 100/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg.  
6. There are jugular venous pulsations 5 cm above the sternal angle.  
7. Crackles are heard at both lung bases.  
8. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop.  
9. There is edema from the midtibia to the ankle bilaterally.
question_options:
Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?  

A. Decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure  

B. Impaired contractility of the left ventricle  

C. Prolapse of the mitral valve  

D. Thrombosis of the superior vena cava

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her early 40s sought ophthalmological care after a referral from an optometrist for bilateral eye pain, substantial eye watering, bilateral conjunctival lesions, and decreased vision, which she described as dim once the room was darkened.
2. She had little to no improvement over the last few months with an artificial tear solution.
3. She claimed to be in good health and denied any concurrent medical conditions.
4. She had undergone a weight loss procedure known as a duodenal switch the year prior.
5. On ophthalmologic examination with a Snellen eye chart, her visual acuity was best corrected to 20/40 OD and 20/30 OS.
6. Her pupils were normal without afferent pupillary defect.
7. She had a marked uptake of lesions, which were revealed with lissamine green stain on the conjunctivae, and an overall appearance of diffuse punctate keratopathy.
8. She had bilateral conjunctival lesions with a foamy appearance both temporally and nasally (Figure).
9. The lenses were clear, and ophthalmoscopy revealed no abnormal findings.
10. Macular optical coherence tomography revealed normal contour with a bilateral cube volume of 9.4 mm3 and a central subfield thickness of 220 and 222 μm for the right and left eyes, respectively.
11. Visual field testing revealed general constriction bilaterally.
12. Conjunctival lesion stained with lissamine green.
13. The lesions were located on temporal and nasal bulbar conjunctivae bilaterally (arrowhead [original magnification ×2.5]).
14. Biopsy lesions to rule out malignancy or premalignancy Ask the patient if she is taking any antibiotics or anticonvulsants
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Order anti-Ro and anti-La antibody testing  
B: Measure vitamin levels, including vitamin A (retinol)  
C: Biopsy lesions to rule out malignancy or premalignancy  
D: Ask the patient if she is taking any antibiotics or anticonvulsants

step1_excerpts:
1. A 16-year-old male is brought to the clinic by his parents due to a 6-month history of increasing fatigue and worsening shortness of breath during physical activity.
2. His parents note that he has "always seemed to tire more easily than other children." The family recently moved to the United States from rural Bolivia.
3. Oxygen saturation on room air is 96% in both index fingers.
4. Cardiac examination reveals a right parasternal heave and a loud, pronounced S2.
5. Pulses are synchronous in both upper and lower extremities.
6. There is mild bluish discoloration and bulbous enlargement of the distal toes bilaterally.
question_options:
Echocardiography is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?

A. Anomalous shunting of blood through a defect in atrial septum  
B. Positioning of the ascending aorta directly over a ventricular septal defect  
C. Abnormal narrowing of the aorta at the aortic isthmus  
D. A defect in the interventricular septum with overriding of the pulmonary artery  
E. Complete absence of the tricuspid valve with hypoplastic right ventricle  
F. A single arterial trunk arising from the heart supplying both systemic and pulmonary circulation  
G. Persistent blood flow between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta  
H. A patent foramen ovale with left-to-right atrial shunting  
I. Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral during embryogenesis  
J. Anomalous pulmonary venous return into the right atrium

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 60s with a medical history of hypertension, cerebrovascular accident, colon cancer, and remote cocaine use presented with numerous pruritic crusted papules and nodules on the face and genitals.  
2. The eruption presented abruptly over a 2-week course, and the patient attributed it to contact with plants while working in his yard.  
3. He denied having similar lesions in the past.  
4. He had used over-the-counter topical antibiotic and antihistamine creams, which alleviated the pruritus.  
5. He denied recent sexual intercourse, penile discharge, fevers, chills, nausea, or vomiting.  
6. Physical examination of the bilateral cheeks, glabella, dorsal nose, and chin revealed multiple skin-colored papules, nodules, and vegetative plaques ranging in size from 4 to 6 mm in diameter, with central umbilication, erosions, and overlying yellow crust (Figure, A).  
7. There were similar lesions on the scrotum and inner thighs, with sparing of the penis (Figure, B).  
8. There was also a 1-cm ulceration on the left lower lip.  
9. The palms and soles were spared.  
10. There was no lymphadenopathy noted.  
11. One 4-mm punch biopsy specimen was obtained from a nodule on the left medial cheek, bisectioned, and sent for both hematoxylin–eosin staining and tissue cultures for bacteria, fungi, and atypical mycobacteria (Figure, C and D).  
12. A, Multiple crusted and ulcerative papules and nodules on the face.  
13. B, Multiple ulcerated healing papules on the scrotum and umbilicated papules on the left inner thigh.  
14. C, Low-power image (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×40).  
15. D, A Warthin-Starry silver impregnation stain (original magnification ×40).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Atypical mycobacterium infection  
B: Cryptococcal infection  
C: Eruptive keratoacanthomas  
D: Secondary syphilis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for her annual visit.
2. She has no complaints and is asymptomatic.
3. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes.
4. Her medications are lisinopril, amlodipine, atorvastatin, and metformin.
5. There is no family history of malignancy.
6. She is a non-smoker and drinks 3-4 standard drinks per week.
7. Her temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 142/84 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, and respirations are 16/min.
8. On physical exam, a solid, immobile neck mass is palpated inferior to the cricoid cartilage to the left of midline.
9. An ultrasound is obtained and shows a 1.2 cm hypoechoic mass with microcalcifications.
10. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) concentration is 7.2 µU/mL.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Propylthiouracil  
B. Fine needle aspiration  
C. Radioiodine ablation  
D. Surgical removal of the mass

step1_excerpts:
1. A 59-year-old man presents accompanied by his wife with nausea and dizziness.
2. He is unsure when his symptoms started, but they have been affecting him for “a while.” It began as episodes of “unsteadiness” that progressed to a feeling of “spinning.” He cannot tell if his symptoms change with position but reports that if he does not lie down he will become nauseous.
3. He also has worsening hearing loss worse on his right side.
4. The patient’s medical history is significant for hypertension, alcohol use disorder, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
5. His medications include aspirin, amlodipine, and fluticasone-salmeterol.
6. He drinks a glass of red wine every night with dinner and smokes a cigar on the weekends.
7. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 135/91 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 12/min.
8. Examination shows delayed horizontal nystagmus.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?

A. Low-salt diet  
B. Thiamine  
C. Epley maneuver  
D. Meclizine

step1_excerpts:
1. A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because he has had difficulty focusing on tasks at work and at home during the past 2 months.
2. He works as an automobile mechanic.
3. He has had a lot of energy for work but often is distracted to the point that he does not complete assigned tasks.
4. He frequently stops working on his own tasks to attempt to develop greater efficiency in his shop.
5. He states that he is delighted with his newfound energy and reports that he now needs only 4 hours of sleep nightly.
6. He has no history of psychiatric illness.
7. He always performed well in school.
8. He has a history of drinking alcohol excessively and using methamphetamines and cocaine during his 20s, but he has not consumed alcohol or used illicit drugs for the past 3 years.
9. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg.
10. Physical examination shows no abnormalities.
11. On mental status examination, he describes his mood as "good." He has a labile affect.
12. His speech is rapid in rate but normal in rhythm, and his thought process is organized.
13. Short- and long-term memory are intact.
14. Attention and concentration are fair; he makes no errors when performing serial sevens, and he can repeat seven digits forward and five in reverse sequence.
15. He has had no delusions or hallucinations.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Antisocial personality disorder

B. Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

C. Bipolar disorder

D. Borderline personality disorder

step1_excerpts:
1. A 6-hour-old newborn boy is noted to have a “lump on his head” by his mother.
2. She denies that the lump was present at birth and is concerned about an infection.
3. The child was born at 39 weeks gestation to a 34-year-old G2P2 mother by vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery after prolonged labor.
4. His birth weight was 3.8 kg (8.4 lb) and his length and head circumference are at the 40th and 60th percentiles, respectively.
5. The mother was diagnosed during this pregnancy with gestational diabetes mellitus and received prenatal care throughout.
6. All prenatal screening was normal and the 20-week anatomy ultrasound was unremarkable.
7. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 65/42 mmHg, pulse is 131/min, and respirations are 36/min.
8. On physical exam, the child is in no acute distress.
9. He has a 3x3 cm fluctuant swelling over the right parietal bone that does not cross the midline.
10. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Intensive phototherapy  
B. Incision and drainage  
C. Red blood cell transfusion  
D. Observation only

step1_excerpts:
1. A 45-year-old woman was referred to the medical retina service for evaluation of bilateral macular atrophy noted by her general ophthalmologist.
2. Medical history was positive for bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with cochlear origin as determined by an otolaryngologist and headache since age 35 years.
3. She had no history of longer-term use of medications.
4. There was no family history of hearing and vision loss in all immediate family members.
5. Her best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/63 OS.
6. Her pupils were round and reactive.
7. The anterior segment was unremarkable.
8. Fundus examination confirmed the presence of bilateral macular atrophy.
9. Fundus autofluorescence revealed a fairly symmetric loss of autofluorescence in the macula and in the regions surrounding the optic disc (Figure).
10. In proximity of these areas of reduced autofluorescence, a speckled fundus autofluorescence pattern of alternating spots of increased and decreased autofluorescence was also noted.
11. Optical coherence tomography displayed the presence of a bilateral atrophy of the outer retina and retinal pigment epithelium (Figure).
12. The patient’s family underwent a complete ophthalmologic evaluation, which did not display any alteration.A, Fundus photograph of the right eye demonstrates an area of pallor in the fundus (blue arrowheads) corresponding to the region of macular atrophy.
13. B, Structural optical coherence tomography (inset image) and green fundus autofluorescence (main image) of the right eye show a macular atrophy that also involves the peripapillary region.
14. The area of retinal pigment epithelium loss is featured by well-demarcated reduced autofluorescence (pink arrowhead) surrounded by speckled hyperautofluorescent areas (yellow arrowhead).
15. Structural optical coherence tomography confirms the presence of atrophy involving the outer retina and retinal pigment epithelium (red arrowheads in the inset image).Prescribe laboratory testing to investigate causes of intraocular inflammationGenetic testing to rule out a mitochondrial disease
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Prescribe laboratory testing to investigate causes of intraocular inflammation  
B: Genetic testing to rule out pattern dystrophy  
C: Genetic testing to rule out a mitochondrial disease  
D: Genetic testing to rule out Stargardt disease

step1_excerpts:
1. A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive weakness and a purple-red discoloration over his cheeks and upper eyelids over the past 8 weeks.
2. His symptoms began shortly after a camping trip, and he now is unable to climb stairs, walk long distances, comb his hair, or dress himself.
3. His mother says that she was careful to apply his sunscreen on the trip and can recall no tick bites or exposure to poisonous plants.
4. His only medication is a topical corticosteroid for several dry, scaly patches of the skin.
5. He appears weak and lethargic.
6. He is at the 75th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight; he has had no change in his weight since his last examination 9 months ago.
7. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg, pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 28/min.
8. Examination of the skin shows a purple-red discoloration over the cheeks and eyelids, periorbital edema, erythematous plaques and scales over the elbows and knees, and flat-topped red papules over all knuckles.
9. There is generalized weakness and atrophy of the proximal muscles.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Dermatomyositis

B. Duchenne's muscular dystrophy

C. Eczema

D. Lyme disease

step1_excerpts:
1. A 32-year-old man and his 29-year-old wife come to the office for evaluation for infertility.
2. The wife's gynecologist has reported that her anatomic and physiologic evaluation disclosed no abnormalities and that assessment of potential male factors is needed.
3. The husband is 188 cm (6 ft 3 in) tall with fair skin and little facial hair.
4. He has mild gynecomastia and small, firm testicles.
5. No sperm are seen on semen analysis.
question_options:
Which of the following tests is most likely to establish the underlying cause of this couple's infertility?

A. Karyotype from peripheral leukocytes

B. Serum estrogen and testosterone concentrations

C. Serum follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone concentrations

D. Serum prolactin concentration

step1_excerpts:
1. In April 2010, a 19-year-old soccer player presented with a 4-week history of pain after a tap against his right knee.
2. Medical and family histories were unremarkable and no abnormalities were found on physical examination.
3. A radiograph of the right knee showed osteolytic lesions in the distal femur and the head of the tibia.
4. On magnetic resonance imaging, the epiphyseal lesions were visualized as cystic and nonsclerotic and extended to the articular surface of the distal femur and proximal tibia (Figure 1).
5. Soft tissue extension was suspected from the tibia.
6. Laboratory test results showed normal blood cell count, renal function, and concentration of C-reactive protein.
7. Aneurysmatic bone cysts were suspected and a biopsy was performed.
8. Histopathological examination detected spindle cell infiltrates with hemorrhages, fragmented trabecular bone, and numerous osteoclastic giant cells proliferating at a rate of 10% suggesting an aggressive giant cell lesion.
9. Since it was still not determined whether the lesions were malignant, flourodeoxyglucose F 18 positron emission tomography/computed tomography was performed and found additional lesions in the left distal femur and the left mandible.
10. Biopsy of the mandible showed the same type of tissue as seen in the right femur and tibia.
question_options:
What Is the Diagnosis?

A: Malignant bone tumor  
B: Aneurysmatic bone cyst  
C: Primary hyperparathyroidism with multiple brown tumors  
D: Giant cell tumor

step1_excerpts:
1. A 25-year-old man presented to an ophthalmologist outside the authors’ department with acutely decreased visual acuity in both eyes.
2. He had woken up earlier that morning with normal visual acuity, but his visual acuity had progressively worsened to the point that he was unable to work.
3. He denied additional symptoms, other than mild tearing.
4. Per his ophthalmologist, his visual acuity improved with a −10 diopter lens, but his intraocular pressure was elevated to between 30 and 40 mm Hg OU.
5. The patient was sent to the emergency department, where the authors’ consultation team evaluated him.
6. The patient’s medical history was remarkable for hypertension and asthma.
7. He denied smoking, drinking alcohol, and using recreational drugs.
8. A review of symptoms was otherwise negative.
9. His medications included losartan, albuterol, and fluticasone.
10. On examination, his visual acuity was 20/400 OU (while wearing prescription lenses, −2.75 + 1.00 × 090 OD and −2.50 + 1.00 × 081 OS).
11. His best-corrected visual acuity was 20/25 OU (manifest refraction, −12.00 + 1.75 × 097 OD and −10.75 + 0.25 × 050 OS).
