12. His intraocular pressure was 19 OU.
13. Sensorimotor and external examination results were normal.
14. A slitlamp examination revealed mild diffuse vasodilation and temporal chemosis, clear corneas, shallow anterior chambers, and clear lenses in both eyes.
15. A gonioscopic examination showed no angle structures in either eye.
16. Results of an undilated fundus examination was unremarkable.
17. Figure 1 shows ultrasonographic images of his eyes.Images on initial presentation.
18. A, B-scan on initial presentation showed no masses and shallow choroidal effusion.
19. B, Transsectional view of the ciliary processes on ultrasound biomicroscopy showed edema of the ciliary body and anterior uveal effusion (arrowhead).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform peripheral iridotomy  
B: Order magnetic resonance imaging to investigate for masses  
C: Perform a clear lens extraction  
D: Provide patient education and observation

step1_excerpts:
1. A 72-year-old woman visits her primary care provider with complaints of sleep maintenance difficulties and daytime fatigue.  
2. Her medical history includes bilateral knee osteoarthritis and hypertension, with a past surgical history of adenotonsillectomy at age sixteen.  
3. She takes lisinopril and uses acetaminophen as needed.  
4. Her vital signs show: temperature 98.9°F, blood pressure 124/82 mmHg, pulse 80/min, respiratory rate 12/min, and room air oxygen saturation 99%.  
5. Lung examination reveals clear breath sounds bilaterally.
question_options:
Which of the following sleep architecture modifications is most commonly associated with the normal aging process?

A. Reduced REM latency  
B. Prolonged total sleep time  
C. Enhanced sleep efficiency  
D. Increased slow-wave sleep  
E. Reduced rapid eye movement  
F. Preserved sleep architecture  
G. Decreased sleep fragmentation  
H. Increased sleep spindles  
I. Increased delta wave activity  
J. Shortened sleep latency

step1_excerpts:
1. A 63-year-old man with no ocular history and a history of stage 3 cutaneous melanoma of the scalp and chronic lymphocytic leukemia was referred for kaleidoscope vision.  
2. He received nivolumab (anti–programmed cell death 1 checkpoint inhibitor) 9 months prior, obinutuzumab (B-cell lymphoma 2 inhibitor) 3 months later, and 5-mg oral prednisone daily.  
3. On presentation, nivolumab and obinutuzumab treatment was complete.  
4. His visual acuity was 20/125 OD and 20/50 OS.  
5. Ophthalmoscopy revealed bilateral panuveitis with diffuse pigmentary abnormalities.  
6. Fluorescein angiography showed diffuse retinal pigment epithelium loss and late staining of the retinal lesions.  
7. He received 60 mg of oral prednisone daily for 2 weeks with a planned 10-week taper.  
8. However, prednisone was discontinued due to positive Lyme disease exposure 6 weeks later.  
9. At this time, the active anterior and vitreous cells had resolved.  
10. However, 2 weeks later, visual acuity decreased to count fingers in his right eye and hand motions in the left eye.  
11. The anterior and vitreous chambers had grade +0.5 pigmented cells.  
12. The ophthalmoscopic examination showed a leopard-spot pattern (Figure 1), and optical coherence tomography showed substantial retinal pigment epithelium and outer retinal layer loss.  
13. Repeat testing for Treponema pallidum, Lyme disease, and HIV was negative.  
14. Results of magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and orbit were negative for leukemic infiltration.  
15. A, Ultra-widefield fundus photograph of the right eye showing pigmentary abnormalities (arrowhead) within and peripheral to the macula.  
16. This finding was similar in both eyes.  
17. A red-free image is depicted in the bottom left corner of the panel.  
18. B, Ultra-widefield fundus autofluorescence image of the right eye showing hypoautofluorescent (pink arrowhead) and hyperautofluorescent patches (blue arrowhead) within and peripheral to the macula.  
19. This finding was similar in both eyes.  
20. Immunomodulatory therapy with another course of oral steroidsPars plana vitrectomy for vitreous biopsy with or without chorioretinal biopsy for flow cytometry to assess for leukemic cells
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Immunomodulatory therapy with another course of oral steroids  
B: Pars plana vitrectomy for vitreous biopsy with or without chorioretinal biopsy for flow cytometry to assess for leukemic cells  
C: Intravitreal steroid injection  
D: Observation

step1_excerpts:
1. A 57-year-old immigrant from Nigeria presents to the emergency department for sudden, severe pain and swelling in her lower extremity.
2. She was at a rehabilitation hospital when her symptoms started.
3. The patient has a medical history of obesity, diabetes, bipolar disorder, and tonic-clonic seizures.
4. Her current medications include metformin, insulin, lisinopril, and valproic acid.
5. The patient has IV drug and alcohol use disorder and has presented to the ED many times for intoxication.
6. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 115/71 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 12/min.
7. Physical exam reveals anasarca and asymmetric lower extremity swelling.
8. Based on the results of a doppler ultrasound of her swollen lower extremity, heparin is started.
9. The patient is then transferred to the general medicine floor for continued management.
10. Laboratory studies are shown below.

Serum:
Na+: 137 mEq/L
K+: 5.5 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen: 22 mg/dL
Ca2+: 5.7 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.7 mg/dL
Glucose: 70 mg/dL
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Nephrotic syndrome  
B. Factor V Leiden  
C. Liver failure  
D. Antithrombin III deficiency

step1_excerpts:
1. An Asian woman in her 50s with diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia presented with ptosis and intermittent esotropia of the right eye.  
2. Fourteen years earlier, the patient underwent a pituitary adenoma resection and external beam radiation.  
3. Immediately after the resection, she developed slight ptosis and an adduction deficit of the right eye, presumed to be secondary to partial oculomotor nerve III (CNIII) damage.  
4. Four years earlier, she developed intermittent esotropia of the right eye, presumed secondary to cranial nerve VI palsy.  
5. At the present clinic visit, the patient reported the persistence of intermittent diplopia, which had remained unchanged for years, and denied other ocular or systemic complaints.  
6. Visual acuity measured 20/20 OU.  
7. We noted 3 mm of relative right upper eyelid ptosis and anisocoria (3 mm OD and 4.5 mm OS in ambient lighting).  
8. Pupils were round and reactive with no afferent pupillary defect.  
9. The degree of anisocoria was the same in ambient and dim lighting.  
10. Extraocular movements were initially intact; however, a few minutes later, the patient developed an intermittent esotropia of the right eye, with episodes of sustained adduction lasting up to 30 seconds followed by normalization of ductions and alignment (Video; Figure, A).  
11. These episodes occurred more commonly following voluntary adduction.  
12. On infraduction, the right upper eyelid simultaneously retracted, exposing 3 mm of superior sclera (Figure, B).  
13. On adduction, the right pupil constricted slightly.  
14. The remainder of the examination was within normal limits.  
15. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) from 1 year prior showed a small amount of residual tumor within the right cavernous sinus, stable over years (Figure, C).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Topical apraclonidine test  
B: Urgent MRI  
C: Offer carbamazepine and routine MRI  
D: Extraocular muscle surgery

step1_excerpts:
1. A 41-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, presents with heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB), dysmenorrhea, and deep dyspareunia.
2. Menses are regular, occurring once every 25 to 26 days and lasting 8 days, with no intermenstrual bleeding.
3. The patient soaks through one pad per hour for the first 3 days of her cycle, and she rates cramping on her heaviest bleeding days as 9 on a 10-point scale.
4. Her past medical history is significant for 3 prior uncomplicated cesarean births with tubal sterilization during her last birth.
5. Vital signs are within normal limits, and body mass index is 22 kg/m2.
6. Pelvic exam shows a 10-week-sized boggy uterus with smooth contours that is mildly tender to palpation.
7. No discrete masses are palpable, and the adnexa are nontender.
8. A urine pregnancy test is negative, and serum bloodwork shows mild anemia.
9. A pelvic ultrasound is ordered.
question_options:
Which of the following findings would confirm the most likely diagnosis?

A. Multiple hyperechoic foci with posterior shadowing in the myometrium  
B. A focal hypoechoic lesion with irregular borders in the endometrium  
C. Endometrial polypoid structures with central vascularity  
D. Thickened endometrial stripe with irregular vascularity  
E. Symmetrical, homogeneous endometrial thickening  
F. Asymmetrical, irregular endometrial thickening  
G. A large, circular hypoechoic structure within the myometrium with posterior shadowing  
H. Diffuse myometrial calcifications with acoustic shadowing  
I. Symmetrical, homogeneous myometrial thickening  
J. Circular anechoic structures within the myometrium without posterior shadowing

step1_excerpts:
1. A young woman presented with multiple arciform to annular plaques on her extremities, favoring the antecubital and popliteal fossae (Figure, A).  
2. The patient reported that these asymptomatic lesions had been present since her adolescence, and she was easily bruised with minimal trauma since birth.  
3. There was no family history of similar cutaneous findings.  
4. Clinically, arciform to annular plaques surround white atrophic patches on the left antecubital fossa (A), and skin atrophy is apparent on the dorsal aspects of the hands (B).  
5. C, Histopathologically, a punch biopsy specimen from a papule on the left arm was analyzed with Verhoeff–van Gieson stain (original magnification ×100).  
6. On close inspection, the plaques were found to be composed of individual 2- to 4-mm keratotic papules surrounding white atrophic patches.  
7. Physical examination also revealed remarkable skin atrophy on the dorsal aspects of her hands (Figure, B) and feet.  
8. The patient’s skin was generally pale and translucent with visible veins, especially on the chest and abdomen.  
9. The face appeared to be emaciated, with a pinched nose, thin lips, sunken cheeks, and prominent eyes.  
10. A punch biopsy specimen from an individual papule from the left arm was obtained and analyzed under Verhoeff–van Gieson stain (Figure, C).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Annular elastolytic giant cell granuloma  
B: Granuloma annulare  
C: Porokeratosis  
D: Vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome with elastosis perforans serpiginosa

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old man with no significant medical history presented with several weeks of malaise and a 6.8-kg weight loss associated with poor appetite.
2. He reported no fevers, night sweats, abdominal pain, emesis, and diarrhea.
3. Physical examination revealed a thin habitus; no palmar erythema, spider angiomas, or gynecomastia were observed.
4. Laboratory tests showed normal complete blood cell count and chemistry panel findings.
5. Hepatic panel showed an elevated alkaline phosphatase level (209 U/L; upper limit of normal [ULN], 150 U/L [3.49 μkat/L; ULN, 2.5 μkat/L]), normal total bilirubin level (0.4 mg/dL [6.84 μmol/L]), elevated alanine aminotransferase level (41 U/L; ULN, 35 U/L [0.68 μkat/L; ULN, 0.58 μkat/L]), and normal aspartate aminotransferase level (27 U/L [0.45 μkat/L]).
6. A single-phase computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen revealed multiple hypoattenuating masses with rim enhancement throughout the liver, intussusception of the small bowel, and normal liver contour with no signs of portal hypertension (Figure 1, left). α-Fetoprotein (AFP) level was elevated (1252 ng/mL; ULN, 9 ng/mL); levels of carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (<2 U/mL) and carcinoembryonic antigen (2.8 ng/mL) were normal.
7. A triple-phase CT scan was obtained to further evaluate the small bowel, which revealed no small bowel abnormalities but instead demonstrated a 3.3 × 2.8-cm heterogeneously enhancing pancreatic tail mass not seen on the previous single-phase CT (Figure 1, right).
8. Left, Axial view from single-phase computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen revealing bilobar liver masses.
9. Right, Coronal view from venous phase of triple-phase CT scan revealing a pancreatic tail mass (arrowhead) in addition to the bilobar liver masses.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Begin FOLFIRINOX (leucovorin, fluorouracil, irinotecan, and oxaliplatin) chemotherapy  
B: Begin sorafenib  
C: Perform a fludeoxyglucose F 18 (18F-FDG) positron emission tomography (PET) scan  
D: Perform an endoscopic ultrasound of the pancreas with fine-needle aspiration

step1_excerpts:
1. A 20-year-old male presents with a 2-week history of lower back pain that began the day after assisting his grandmother with moving.
2. He denies any direct injury but reports intermittent radiating pain and tingling from his left lateral thigh to the medial leg and foot, which is aggravated by certain positions.
3. On examination, the lumbar paravertebral muscles are hypertonic and tender.
4. A straight leg test is positive on the left.
5. Patellar reflexes are diminished (1+) on the left compared to the right (2+).
6. Lumbar flexion elicits back pain, radiating pain, and burning sensations.
7. The vertebral transverse processes from L1–L5 are posterior and tender on the right.
question_options:
The most likely location of the damaged structure is:

A. At the sacroiliac joint  
B. Between T12 and L1  
C. Between L3 and L5  
D. Between L4 and L5  
E. Between L1 and L2  
F. At the coccygeal plexus  
G. Between L5 and S1  
H. Within the piriformis muscle  
I. Between L2 and L3  
J. Between L3 and L4

step1_excerpts:
1. A previously healthy 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of constant substernal chest pain for 12 hours that is exacerbated by coughing and inspiration.
2. The pain is relieved with sitting up and leaning forward.
3. There is no family history of heart disease.
4. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg.
5. The lungs are clear to auscultation.
6. Cardiac examination shows distant heart sounds.
7. An ECG shows diffuse ST-segment elevation in all leads.
8. An x-ray of the chest shows normal findings.
question_options:
The most likely cause of his condition is injury to which of the following tissues?

A. Aortic intima

B. Esophageal sphincter

C. Myocardium

D. Pericardium

step1_excerpts:
1. A 52-year-old woman comes to the OMT clinic with complaints of right wrist pain, suspecting carpal tunnel syndrome, which she attributes to her 26 years of office work involving extensive keyboard use.  
2. Her medical history includes uterine fibroids, for which she underwent a myomectomy 5 years ago, and menopause last year.  
3. Vital signs are normal.  
4. She reports pain in both wrists, more severe on the right, her dominant hand.  
5. Tinel’s and Phalen’s tests are negative.  
6. An osteopathic structural exam reveals a posterior radial head dysfunction on the right side, as the radial head moves more easily posteriorly compared to the left.
question_options:
What is the appropriate positioning and activating force for treating this dysfunction using muscle energy?

A. With the shoulder relaxed and the elbow bent, bring the patient’s forearm into supination to the edge of the restrictive barrier and have them pronate against resistance.  
B. With the shoulder abducted and the elbow bent, bring the patient’s forearm into supination to the edge of the restrictive barrier and have them pronate against resistance.  
C. With the shoulder relaxed and the elbow extended, bring the patient’s forearm into pronation to the edge of the restrictive barrier and have them supinate against resistance.  
D. With the shoulder abducted and the elbow bent, bring the patient’s forearm into pronation to the edge of the restrictive barrier and have them supinate against resistance.  
E. With the shoulder relaxed and the elbow bent, bring the patient’s forearm into neutral position and have them pronate against resistance.  
F. With the shoulder relaxed and the elbow bent, bring the patient’s forearm into supination to the edge of the restrictive barrier and have them supinate against resistance.  
G. With the shoulder relaxed and the elbow extended, bring the patient’s forearm into supination to the edge of the restrictive barrier and have them pronate against resistance.  
H. With the shoulder relaxed and the elbow fully bent, extend the elbow to the edge of the restrictive barrier and have them flex their elbow against resistance.  
I. With the shoulder relaxed and the elbow bent, bring the patient’s forearm into pronation to the edge of the restrictive barrier and have them supinate against resistance.  
J. With the shoulder relaxed and the elbow bent, bring the patient’s forearm into neutral position and have them supinate against resistance.

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 70s presented for a routine follow-up appointment.
2. He denied any visual or systemic symptoms, and his medical history was significant for hypertension and atrial fibrillation treated with cardiac catheterization and ablation.
3. Medications included amlodipine besylate, 5 mg daily, and aspirin, 81 mg daily.
4. His family and social history were unremarkable.
5. On examination, his visual acuity was 20/20 OU.
6. The intraocular pressure in both eyes was normal, and there was no relative afferent pupillary defect.
7. Extraocular motility and confrontational visual fields were also normal.
8. On physical examination, facial plethora was evident (Figure 1A).
9. Retinal examination of the left eye revealed 2 blot hemorrhages and dilatation of the retinal veins (Figure 1B).
10. Retinal examination of the right eye also revealed dilatation of the retinal veins.
11. These abnormal findings were not present 1 year earlier.
12. Fluorescein angiography revealed a prolonged arm-to-retina transit time of 22.6 seconds (normal, 10-16 seconds).
13. Optical coherence tomography scans of the macula in both eyes were normal.
14. In addition, an area of bruising was noted on the right shoulder in the absence of any history of trauma to the shoulder.A, Facial plethora.
15. B, Ultra widefield retinal imaging of the left eye showing peripheral retinal hemorrhages (black arrowheads) and retinal vein dilatation (white arrowhead).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Order a computed tomography scan of the abdomen  
B: Perform ocular massage  
C: Obtain a complete blood cell count  
D: Perform genetic testing for the VHL gene

step1_excerpts:
1. A 29-year-old white woman presented for a second opinion of left eye pain, blurred vision, and photophobia.  
2. Six weeks before, she received eyebrow laser epilation with an 800-nm diode laser (LightSheer; Lumenis).  
3. During the session, the physician assistant removed the metal eye shield for better exposure, immediately after which the patient developed eye pain and blurred vision.  
4. She was initially treated for acute iritis with difluprednate, 4 times daily, which was tapered to once daily, with minimal improvement in her symptoms.  
5. The patient reported a negative review of systems and denied recent travel, trauma, use of antibiotics, or pregnancy.  
6. Her examination was notable for best-corrected visual acuity of 20/20 OU, anterior chamber (AC) pigment and flare in the left eye, and iris irregularities, including decreased iris reactivity, peripupillary transillumination defects (Figure, A), and posterior synechiae.  
7. She had mild intraocular pressure (IOP) asymmetry of 12 mm Hg OD and 17 mm Hg OS.A, An irregular pupil, iris atrophy, and peripupillary transillumination defects are observed.  
8. B, After discontinuation of the cycloplegic agent, posterior concavity of the iris and iris-lens touch consistent with reverse pupillary block are observed.Gonioscopy revealed increased trabecular meshwork pigmentation in the left eye.  
9. Ultrasonographic biomicroscopy and anterior segment optical coherence tomography demonstrated a normal anterior segment in the right eye and posterior bowing of the iris and lens-iris touch (Figure, B) with a normal AC depth in the left eye.  
10. Optical biometry (Lenstar LS 900; Haag-Streit) was unremarkable bilaterally, with normal axial length, AC depth, and lens thickness.Further taper her corticosteroid dosage and start a cycloplegic agent to break posterior synechiaePerform AC paracentesis and send fluid for viral polymerase chain reaction analysis
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Increase her topical corticosteroid dosage  
B: Further taper her corticosteroid dosage and start a cycloplegic agent to break posterior synechiae  
C: Perform AC paracentesis and send fluid for viral polymerase chain reaction analysis  
D: Perform urgent peripheral iridotomy given IOP asymmetry

step1_excerpts:
1. A 43-year-old male patient attends a routine primary care visit where urinalysis reveals 3+ protein and 1–2 red blood cells per high-power field, with no other abnormalities.
2. He has no symptoms, no relevant family history, and denies smoking or alcohol use.
3. His vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C (98.06°F), blood pressure of 130/82 mm Hg, and a pulse rate of 78/min.
4. Physical examination findings are unremarkable.
question_options:
What is the next best step in managing this patient’s condition?

A. Repeating the urine dipstick test  
B. 24-hour urine collection  
C. Referring to a nephrologist immediately  
D. Ordering a renal biopsy  
E. Performing a kidney ultrasound  
F. Prescribing a low-protein diet  
G. Testing for urinary Bence Jones proteins  
H. Starting captopril  
I. Measuring serum albumin and creatinine  
J. Initiating corticosteroid therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician 1 day after the sudden onset of pain and swelling of her right knee.
2. She has had no injury.
3. Her medications include occasional ibuprofen for mild osteoarthritis of both knees.
4. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 97/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 129/79 mm Hg.
5. Examination of the right knee shows warmth, erythema, and effusion.
6. Exquisite tenderness is produced with minimal range-of-motion testing.
7. Examination of synovial fluid obtained via joint aspiration shows that it is clear, with positively birefringent rhomboids observed under polarized light microscopy.
question_options:
Deposition of which of the following substances is the most likely cause of these findings?

A. Ammonium urate

B. Calcium oxalate

C. Calcium pyrophosphate

D. Calcium urate

step1_excerpts:
1. A 75-year-old man with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) with isolated deletion 5q (del5q) presented with multiple nonhealing skin ulcers on the chest and upper extremities.
2. Four years earlier, he started taking lenalidomide, 10 mg/d (28-day cycle), to treat worsening anemia; after 2 cycles of treatment, he became transfusion independent.
3. Since then, he has remained stable with the same dose and schedule of lenalidomide without significant adverse effects.
4. The presenting skin lesions developed 1 month before presentation and began as small pustules that rapidly transformed into painful ulcers.
5. He was treated with valacyclovir for a presumed diagnosis of shingles, but the lesions did not improve.
6. Because of suspected necrotizing fasciitis, he underwent incision and drainage of the lesions.
7. Cultures from the surgical specimen grew methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus hemolyticus.
8. However, the lesions continued to worsen despite vancomycin and additional debridement.
9. Thus, he was transferred to our facility.
10. Physical examination showed multiple cutaneous ulcers with gray undermined borders and red papules of varying depths involving the chest, back, and upper extremity; lesions were as large as 9 × 15 cm.
11. A complete blood cell count showed a white blood cell count of 16.2 × 103/μL (to convert to 109/L, multiply by 1.0) with an absolute neutrophil count of 12.7 × 103/μL, hemoglobin level of 9.4 g/dL (to convert to g/L, multiply by 10.0), and platelet count of 262 × 103/μL with no circulating blasts.
12. Results of additional laboratory studies, including blood culture and tests for herpes zoster virus (via polymerase chain reaction), antinuclear antibody, rheumatoid factor, and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody were all negative.
13. Additionally, the patient also had hypertension and hypercholesterolemia for which he was taking lisinopril and simvastatin, respectively.
14. Pathologic sampling from skin lesions demonstrated a dense dermal infiltrate with predominantly neutrophils along with reactive histiocytes, fibroblasts, and angioplasia (Figure, A).
15. Immunohistochemical staining showed myeloperoxidase-positive neutrophils (Figure, B), histiocytic markers (CD43, CD63, CD168), and CD117-positive mast cells, but no immature myeloid precursors.
16. Results of Grocott-Gomori methenamine silver staining were unremarkable.A, Hematoxylin-eosin staining shows polymorphonuclear neutrophils admixed with scattered histiocytes and vasculatures with a prominent endothelial lining.
17. B, Immunohistochemical staining shows myeloperoxidase-positive neutrophils peripherally and in aggregates.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Leukemia cutis  
B: Pyoderma gangrenosum  
C: Leukocytoclastic vasculitis  
D: Lymphomatoid papulosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after he was involved in a motor vehicle collision.
2. He was the unrestrained driver.
3. He is conscious.
4. Physical examination shows numerous lacerations and ecchymoses over the face.
5. His vision is normal.
6. Ocular, facial, and lingual movements are intact.
7. The gag reflex is present.
8. Sensation to pinprick is absent over the right side of the face anterior to the right ear, extending down along the full extent of the mandible to the chin.
9. Sensation also is absent over the right side of the tongue.
10. X-rays of the skull show fractures of the orbit, zygomatic arch, and infratemporal fossa.
question_options:
The most likely cause of these findings is a fracture affecting which of the following locations?

A. Foramen lacerum

B. Foramen ovale

C. Foramen rotundum

D. Foramen spinosum

step1_excerpts:
1. A 23-year-old woman presents with a 7-day history of abdominal pain, and now bloody diarrhea that brings her to her primary care physician.
2. Review of systems is notable for a 12-pound unintentional weight loss and intermittent loose stools.
3. She has a family history notable for a father with coronary artery disease and a mother with primary sclerosing cholangitis.
4. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 100/72 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air.
5. Her abdomen is soft, mildly diffusely tender to deep palpation, and non-distended.
6. She is found to have the finding on colonoscopy in Figure A.
7. Serum perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) are positive.
question_options:
Which of the following is most likely to be present in this patient?

A. Continuous lesion beginning in the rectum  
B. Fistulae and stricture formation  
C. Worse disease severity near the ileocecal valve  
D. Perianal disease

step1_excerpts:
1. A 61-year-old man presented to our clinic with a 3-month history of rapidly growing and itchy cutaneous nodules all over the body.
2. He denied systemic complaints such as weakness, fever, night sweats, or weight loss.
3. Oral glucocorticoids did not show any therapeutic effect.
4. His medical history was remarkable for mild anemia because of untreated hemorrhoids.
5. Physical examination revealed numerous symmetrically distributed, well-defined, erythematous skin nodules on his back, buttocks, and limb extensors (Figure, A).
6. Prominent lymphadenopathies on bilateral cervical, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes were noted, with the largest lymph node measuring approximately 5 × 2 cm.
7. Laboratory tests were significant for atypical lymphocytes in the peripheral blood (count up to 6%), an elevated CD4+/CD8+ lymphocyte ratio (9.21; normal range, 0.7-3.1), moderate anemia (hemoglobin level, 8.7 g/dL; normal range, 11.5-15.0 g/dL [to convert to g/L, multiply by 10.0]), a high erythrocyte sedimentation rate (35 mm/h; normal range, 0-25 mm/h), and cryoglobulins composed of mixed polyclonal immunoglobulins.
8. The platelet count (161 × 103/μL; normal range, 125-350 × 103/μL [to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 1.0]) and lactate dehydrogenase (217 U/L; normal range, 100-240 U/L [to convert to μkat/L, multiply by 0.0167]) were normal.
9. Quantification of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) DNA showed high loads of virus in the peripheral blood (846 copies/mL in serum, 27 700 copies/mL in lymphocytes; normal range, <500 copies/mL).
10. A biopsy specimen from a skin nodule was sent for histopathologic examination (Figure, B).A, Physical examination showed widespread, symmetrically distributed, well-defined nodules on the trunk and extremities.
11. B, Skin biopsy sample showed infiltration of atypical lymphocytes and histiocytes with proliferation of high endothelial venules (hematoxylin-eosin).
12. C, In situ hybridization was positive for Epstein-Barr virus in the skin.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Cutaneous sarcoidosis  
B: Lymphomatoid granulomatosis  
C: Blastic plasmacytoid dendritic cell neoplasm  
D: Cutaneous angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 29-year-old primigravida at 23 weeks' gestation presents to emergency care with acute left flank pain that radiates to the groin, accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and increased urinary frequency.
2. She reports no vaginal discharge.
3. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated with regular prenatal care.
4. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she takes only prenatal vitamins.
5. She denies tobacco, alcohol, or drug use.
6. Vital signs show: temperature 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure 114/70 mmHg, pulse 90/min, and respirations 16/min.
7. Physical examination reveals left flank tenderness and visible blood on perineal inspection, with no abdominal guarding.

Urinalysis results:

- Color: Yellow
- pH: 7.1
- Specific gravity: 1.010
- Blood: 3+
- Bilirubin: Negative
- Glucose: Negative
- Ketones: Negative
- Protein: Negative
- Nitrite: Negative
- Leukocyte esterase: Negative
- Red blood cells: Many
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Renal ultrasound  
B. Observation and repeat urinalysis in 24 hours  
C. Trial of empiric antibiotics for presumed urinary tract infection  
D. CT urography with contrast  
E. Magnetic resonance urography  
F. Noncontrast CT scan of abdomen and pelvis  
G. Cystoscopy with retrograde pyelography  
H. Abdominal X-ray to evaluate for nephrolithiasis  
I. Intravenous pyelogram  
J. Renal radiograph

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 70s presented with an enlarged and variegated plaque on her left axilla, which she had had for 4 years.
2. The lesion started as a small eczematous, pink-to-brown plaque.
3. As the lesion was asymptomatic and slow growing, she did not initially seek treatment.
4. Recently, the color of the lesion had changed to an alarming dark brown color (Figure, A).
5. No breast mass or lymphadenopathy was observed.
6. Her medical and family history was unremarkable.
7. A skin biopsy specimen was obtained and submitted for further histopathologic analysis.A, Clinical presentation of pigmented plaque in the axilla with well-demarcated margins.
8. B, Histologic findings revealed an intraepidermal neoplasm consisting of pagetoid cells, characterized by round, pale, vacuolated cytoplasm, and large pleomorphic nuclei (hematoxylin-eosin; original magnification ×200).
9. C, Immunohistochemical findings showed positive staining for EMA (original magnification ×200).
10. D, The lesion was surrounded by numerous reactive dendritic HMB-45–positive melanocytes scattered among the tumor cells (original magnification ×200).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Pagetoid Bowen disease  
B: Inverse lichen planus  
C: Pigmented extramammary Paget disease  
D: Superficial spreading melanoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 67-year-old woman with a history of peripheral T-cell lymphoma after an allogeneic stem cell transplant (SCT) presented with 3 days of fever, weakness, and dyspnea.  
2. She was diagnosed with stage IV peripheral T-cell lymphoma 3 years prior and was initially treated with gemcitabine, vinorelbine, and doxorubicin.  
3. Her disease recurred 1 year later, and she underwent haplotype-matched allogeneic SCT 8 months prior to admission.  
4. Two months prior to admission, she developed graft-vs-host disease requiring high-dose prednisone, rituximab, and intravenous immunoglobulin.  
5. At the time of admission, she was receiving prednisone (40 mg/d) and tacrolimus for graft-vs-host disease and prophylaxis of infection with levofloxacin, valacyclovir, posaconazole, and thrice weekly dapsone.  
6. The patient lived with her family, including her son who recently had a cough.  
7. She was born in the Philippines and immigrated to the United States 3 decades prior.  
8. She denied recent travel.  
9. On examination, her temperature was 38.3° C, pulse of 115 beats/min, blood pressure of 110/50 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths/min, and an oxygen saturation of 90% on room air.  
10. Cardiopulmonary examination revealed tachycardia, increased work of breathing and bibasilar crackles without wheezes.  
11. Her laboratory studies revealed a white blood cell count of 4.2 × 106/mL (normal range, 3.4-10 × 106/mL), hemoglobin of 10.3 g/dL (normal range, 12-15.5 g/dL [to convert g/dL to g/L, multiply by 10]), platelets of 45 × 106/mL (normal range, 140-450 × 106/mL), and creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL (normal range, 0.5-1.0 mg/dL [to convert mg/dL to μmol/L, multiply by 88.4]).  
12. A chest radiograph demonstrated bilateral opacities without pleural effusion or pneumothorax.  
13. Initial empirical treatment included vancomycin, cefepime, azithromycin, and oseltamivir.  
14. On hospital day 2, she was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure.  
15. Computed tomography (CT) of the chest was performed (Figure, A) and compared with a study 2 weeks prior when she was asymptomatic (Figure, B).  
16. A, Computed tomographic (CT) chest image obtained on admission demonstrates diffuse bilateral ground glass opacities with interlobular septal thickening.  
17. B, Computed tomographic chest image from 2 weeks prior demonstrates nearly normal lungs.  
18. Add trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole and corticosteroids for Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia Switch vancomycin to linezolid for refractory methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Add amikacin to cover multidrug-resistant Acinetobacter  
B: Add trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole and corticosteroids for Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia  
C: Switch vancomycin to linezolid for refractory methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia  
D: Add liposomal amphotericin B to cover mucormycosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 32-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for an annual physical examination.
2. He mentions experiencing neck pain since waking up this morning, which he attributes to "sleeping in an awkward position." He denies any other symptoms.
3. His medical history is unremarkable, and he only takes a daily multivitamin.
4. On physical examination, there are no abnormalities in strength, sensation, reflexes, or range of motion.
5. No cervical lymphadenopathy is noted.
6. A tender point is identified anteriorly on the right at the level of C4.
7. Cardiac, respiratory, and abdominal findings are normal.
question_options:
How is the diagnosis determined for this patient?

A. Pressing on the anteromedial aspect of the transverse process of the associated vertebra  
B. Pressing on the anterolateral aspect of the right posterior tubercle of the transverse process of the associated vertebra  
C. Applying pressure directly to the spinous process of the associated vertebra  
D. Translating the associated vertebra to the left by pressing on its articular pillar  
E. Pressing on the posterolateral aspect of the right articular process of the associated vertebra  
F. Translating the associated vertebra to the right by pressing on the contralateral articular pillar  
G. Palpating the posterior aspect of the transverse process and applying an inferomedial force  
H. Pressing on the inferolateral aspect of the right articular pillar of the associated vertebra  
I. Palpating the anterior aspect of the right transverse process and applying a lateral force  
J. Pressing on the lateral aspect of the right portion of the bifid spinous process of the associated vertebra

step1_excerpts:
1. A 76-year-old nursing home resident is brought to the emergency department with a three-day history of watery, non-bloody diarrhea preceded by abdominal cramping.
2. She completed a course of levofloxacin six days ago for recurrent urinary tract infections.
3. She denies unusual food intake, sick contacts, rash, nausea, or vomiting.
4. Her vital signs show: temperature 39.4°C, heart rate 111 bpm, respiratory rate 17/min, and blood pressure 70/43 mm Hg.
5. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes and moderate abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding.
6. Despite initial improvement with IV fluids, she becomes hypotensive after 3 liters of normal saline.
7. Laboratory findings show WBC count of 25,000 cells/uL and creatinine of 2.6 mg/dL.
8. Urinalysis is positive for leukocytes but negative for leukocyte esterase, nitrates, and RBCs.
9. CT abdomen shows generalized colonic wall edema without ileus or perforation.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?

A. Fecal microbiota transplantation + vancomycin 125 mg PO 4 times per day  
B. Vancomycin 500 mg PO 4 times per day + metronidazole 500 mg intravenously every 8 hours  
C. Bezlotoxumab 10 mg/kg IV once + vancomycin 125 mg PO 4 times per day  
D. Fidaxomicin 200 mg PO 2 times per day  
E. Vancomycin 125 mg PO 4 times per day + metronidazole 500 mg PO three times per day  
F. Vancomycin 500 mg PO 4 times per day alone  
G. Metronidazole 500 mg PO three times per day  
H. Vancomycin 125 mg PO 4 times per day  
I. Tigecycline 100 mg IV loading dose, then 50 mg IV twice daily  
J. Rifaximin 550 mg PO three times per day

step1_excerpts:
1. A 56-year-old woman was referred for evaluation of an incidentally discovered adrenal mass.  
2. She experienced no symptoms of weight loss, headache, sweating, palpitations, pallor, anxiety, menstrual abnormalities, or mood changes; had no known history of cancer or hypertension; and was not taking any medications.  
3. On physical examination, her blood pressure was 135/73 mm Hg, and her heart rate was 82/min.  
4. There was no truncal or facial obesity, acne, striae, hirsutism, or proximal muscle weakness.  
5. Laboratory analysis showed normal blood cell counts and levels of electrolytes, liver enzymes, and lactate dehydrogenase.  
6. Further biochemical evaluation revealed normal levels of plasma and urinary cortisol, serum aldosterone and 17-hydroxyprogesterone, and urinary metanephrines.  
7. A computed tomography (CT) scan revealed a 5.5 × 4.3–cm left adrenal tumor with heterogeneous appearance, a hypodense central area, and irregular margins, with a density of 36 Hounsfield units (HU).  
8. Relative and absolute adrenal washout values (a measure of the disappearance of contrast media from a mass after 10 minutes) were 23% and 47%, respectively.  
9. A positron emission tomography (PET)/CT scan using 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (18F-FDG) was performed for further tumor characterization (Figure).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform a biopsy of the mass  
B: Order a repeat CT scan in 3-6 months  
C: Request a surgical consult for adrenalectomy  
D: Perform adrenal magnetic resonance imaging

step1_excerpts:
1. A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician 3 months after she had a blood pressure of 150/95 mm Hg at a routine examination prior to participation in school sports.
2. She is asymptomatic and has no history of serious illness.
3. Twelve months ago, she was diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and treated with oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
4. She currently takes no medications.
5. Subsequent blood pressure measurements on three separate occasions since the last visit have been: 155/94 mm Hg, 145/90 mm Hg, and 150/92 mm Hg.
6. She is at the 50th percentile for height and 95th percentile for weight.
7. Her blood pressure today is 150/90 mm Hg confirmed by a second measurement, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 12/min.
8. Examination shows no other abnormalities.
9. Her hematocrit is 40%.
10. Urinalysis is within normal limits.
11. Cardiac and renal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Exercise and weight reduction program

B. Measurement of urine catecholamine concentrations

C. Measurement of urine corticosteroid concentrations

D. Captopril therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 7-week-old boy presents to the pediatrician for vomiting.
2. Three weeks ago, the patient began vomiting after meals.
3. The vomitus appears to be normal stomach contents without streaks of red or green.
4. His parents have already tried repositioning him during mealtimes and switching his formula to eliminate cow’s milk and soy.
5. Despite these adjustments, the vomiting has become more frequent and forceful.
6. The patient is voiding about 4 times per day and his urine appears dark yellow.
7. He has fallen 1 standard deviation off of the growth curve.
8. The patient's mother reports that the pregnancy was uncomplicated other than an episode of sinusitis in the 3rd trimester, for which she was treated with azithromycin.
9. The patient's temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 58/41 mmHg, pulse is 166/min, and respirations are 16/min.
10. On physical exam, the patient looks small for his age.
11. His abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Abdominal ultrasound  
B. Thickening feeds  
C. MRI of the head  
D. Intravenous hydration

step1_excerpts:
1. A 61-year-old woman with a history of hypertension presented for evaluation of exertional left calf discomfort.
2. Six months prior to presentation, she developed a dull pain in her left calf while climbing stairs.
3. After climbing 2 flights of stairs, she had to stop and rest for approximately 15 seconds.
4. She reported no pain at rest.
5. The patient’s symptoms worsened and began interfering with her work.
6. On physical examination, her heart rate was 82/min and blood pressure was 140/89 mm Hg.
7. Her lower extremities were warm, with strength for femoral, popliteal, dorsalis pedis, and posterior tibial pulses at 2+ bilaterally.
8. She had no history of spinal degenerative disease and did not have lower extremity arterial bruits, wounds, sensory deficits, edema, or hair loss.
9. Results of an exercise treadmill ankle-brachial index (ABI) test are shown in the Table.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Diagnose the patient with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and begin medical management  
B: Order a lower extremity angiogram  
C: Order a lower extremity arterial duplex ultrasound  
D: Reassure the patient that her pain is nonvascular in origin

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 50s with a 2-year history of disseminated dermatosis involving the trunk and limbs was seen in our dermatology department.
2. The dermatosis was characterized by polymorphic erythematous macules and plaques with elevated and indurated borders without evanescence to pressure (Figure, A and B).
3. She was referred from another clinic with the presumptive diagnosis of urticarial vasculitis.
4. Previous treatment included antihistamines and oral corticosteroids for several months without improvement.
5. Dysesthesia was recorded on her lesions.
6. Results from complete blood cell count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and blood chemistry analyses were normal, as was a thyroid profile.
7. A punch biopsy specimen from a trunk plaque was obtained, and histopathological analysis was performed (Figure, C and D).
8. A, Polymorphic erythematous macules and plaques with elevated and indurated borders without in vitro pressure evanescence were noticed during consultation on patient’s back.
9. B, Polymorphic erythematous macules and plaques with elevated and indurated borders without in vitro pressure evanescence on the trunk and abdomen were present.
10. C, Histopathological analysis revealed a chronic dermic granulomatous process, as well as (D) a chronic dermic nonencapsulated granulomatous infiltrate with a perineural distribution formed by mature epitheloid cells and encapsulated by lymphocytes.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Borderline-borderline leprosy  
B: Mycosis fungoides  
C: Disseminated annular granuloma  
D: Sarcoidosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 3-day history of severe right-sided flank pain, fever, and vomiting.  
2. He has a history of gout, benign prostate hyperplasia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with allopurinol, tamsulosin, and metformin.  
3. Urinalysis shows pyuria, leukocyturia, and WBC casts.  
4. Results of blood and urine cultures are pending.  
5. The patient is diagnosed with pyelonephritis and admitted for empiric treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics.  
6. After 4 days, his symptoms have continued to worsen.  
7. He is somnolent and not oriented to person, place, or time.  
8. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg.  
9. He is transferred to the intensive care unit and vasopressor therapy is initiated.  
10. The physician informs the patient's wife that her husband has developed urosepsis as a complication of his urinary tract infection and that advanced life support may become necessary.  
11. A written advance directive provided by the patient's primary care physician includes a do-not-intubate (DNI) order, which was verbally confirmed by the patient upon admission.  
12. There is no medical power of attorney.  
13. The patient's wife says she wants full life support in case of cardiorespiratory arrest.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

A. “I will perform cardiopulmonary resuscitation if needed, but I cannot intubate your husband.”  
B. "I will only provide non-invasive ventilation as a compromise."  
C. "We should obtain an emergency court order to override the DNI order."  
D. "We should attempt to wake him up to confirm his current wishes."  
E. "The advance directive is no longer valid since his condition has changed significantly."  
F. "Let's wait until his condition deteriorates further before making any decisions."  
G. ”I have to respect your husband's wishes and will only provide comfort measures.”  
H. "I will provide full life support including intubation since you are his next of kin."  
I. "Since your husband is incapacitated, you now have the legal authority to override his advance directive."  
J. ”If you can confirm that this decision is in your husband's best interest, I will provide full life support.”

step1_excerpts:
1. A 56-year-old man with hypertension presented with 2 weeks of acute ptosis in the left upper eyelid.  
2. Three weeks prior, the patient had noted severe left-sided facial pain.  
3. He denied any diplopia, decreased vision, or recent trauma.  
4. The patient had previously been evaluated by his primary care physician and referred to a neuroophthalmologist.  
5. During the course of the workup, the patient had undergone computed tomography (CT) of the head and chest, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain, and carotid duplex ultrasonography.  
6. Following a workup with unremarkable results, the patient presented to the Bascom Palmer emergency department for a second opinion.  
7. On initial examination, his best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OU.  
8. Intraocular pressure, ocular motility, and confrontational visual fields were normal.  
9. There was no axial proptosis or enophthalmos by exophthalmometry.  
10. The pupil was 5 mm OD and 4 mm OS.  
11. No afferent pupillary defect was observed.  
12. External examination demonstrated a left-sided ptosis (Figure 1).  
13. Anhidrosis was not observed.  
14. Anterior and posterior examination, including of the optic nerve head, had normal results in both eyes.  
15. The cranial nerve, gross motor, and gross sensory examination had otherwise unremarkable results.  
16. The patient’s blood pressure was 160/79 mm Hg.  
17. External photograph demonstrating ptosis of the left upper eyelid.  
18. Magnetic resonance angiography of the brain and neck
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Edrophonium test  
B: Oculoplastic referral for ptosis repair  
C: Magnetic resonance angiography of the brain and neck  
D: Sumatriptan injection

step1_excerpts:
1. A 76-year-old woman is brought to a primary care physician by her daughter who is concerned about her mother's growing inability to take care of herself.
2. Initially, she attributed her mother's forgetfulness and word-finding difficulties to normal aging, but over the past few years, her mother's memory has worsened, her mood has grown more irritable, and her mother has been found wandering the neighborhood unsure of how to get home.
3. Her medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus which is well-controlled with metformin.
4. On exam, her temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 115/82 mmHg, pulse is 73/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air.
5. Cardiopulmonary exam reveals normal S1 and S2, no murmurs, and clear lungs bilaterally.
6. She scores 16/30 on the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) test.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Normal pressure hydrocephalus  
B. Frontotemporal dementia  
C. Alzheimer dementia  
D. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her late 30s was evaluated by the dermatology inpatient consult service for a 4-day history of perianal pain.
2. Her medical history included systemic lupus erythematosus, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, and external hemorrhoids.
3. Six months before admission, she underwent a deceased donor kidney transplant.
4. One month before presentation, she was hospitalized for acute cellular transplant rejection managed with systemic corticosteroids, belatacept, mycophenolate mofetil, and tacrolimus therapies.
5. Her immunosuppressive regimen at the time of dermatologic evaluation consisted of prednisone, 5 mg daily, and mycophenolate mofetil, 500 mg twice daily.
6. On admission, she was afebrile and normotensive; laboratory results were notable for an elevated creatinine level of 1.43 mg/dL (reference range, 0.40-1.30 mg/dL) (to convert to micromoles per liter, multiply by 88.4) and thrombocytopenia (platelet count, 92 × 103/μL [reference range, 140-440 × 103/μL] [conversion to ×109 per liter is 1:1).
7. She developed diarrhea 1 day after admission.
8. Fecal leukocytes were absent.
9. Stool antigen test results for cryptosporidium, giardia, and rotavirus were negative.
10. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test results for campylobacter, norovirus, salmonella, shigella, Shiga toxin–producing Escherichia coli 1 and 2, Vibrio cholerae, and Yersinia enterocolitica in the stool were negative.
11. Antigen and toxin test results for Clostridium difficile in the stool were positive.
12. Total body skin examination was notable for 1- and 3-cm tender, round perianal ulcers with a clean base.
13. Another 4-mm round ulcer was present at the superior intergluteal cleft (Figure, A).
14. There were no ocular or oral ulcers.
15. A biopsy specimen of a perianal ulcer border was obtained for histopathologic analysis (Figure, B-D).
16. Clinical and histologic images of multiple perianal ulcers.
17. A, Two round ulcers, each with well-demarcated borders, were present perianally.
18. A smaller, third ulcer was also noted in the intergluteal cleft.
19. B, Microscopic examination of the punch biopsy on low magnification reveals epidermal ulceration and mixed dermal inflammation (hemoxylin-eosin.
20. C, On higher magnification, the epidermis lacks viral cytopathic changes but there are enlarged dermal fibroblasts and endothelial cells (hemoxylin-eosin).
21. D, Higher magnification reveals large fibroblasts and endothelial cells with glassy cytoplasm and intranuclear inclusions (hemoxylin-eosin).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Amebiasis cutis  
B: Herpes simplex virus infection  
C: Cytomegalovirus infection  
D: Cutaneous Crohn disease

step1_excerpts:
1. A 44-year-old homeless man presents to the emergency department after being stabbed multiple times in the abdomen.
2. The patient is intoxicated and is unable to offer further history.
3. His temperature is 97.5°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 92/52 mmHg, pulse is 145/min, respirations are 33/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air.
4. He is intubated to protect his airway, given 2 units of packed red blood cells, and sent to the operating room for an exploratory laparotomy.
5. The patient is subsequently admitted to the intensive care unit.
6. He is extubated the next day and appears well.
7. His vitals are within normal limits.
8. Physical exam reveals sparse hair that is falling out throughout the patient’s body.
9. He has a rash by the corners of his mouth.
10. The patient has multiple loose bowel movements and on day 6 the patient’s surgical wound does not appear to be healing.
11. It is held together only by the sutures with minimal underlying healing.
question_options:
Which of the following is most likely deficient in this patient?

A. Thiamine  
B. Vitamin C  
C. Zinc  
D. Riboflavin

step1_excerpts:
1. An elderly male patient, aged 87, resides in a subacute nursing facility with a medical history significant for Parkinson disease and stroke.
2. Over recent months, he has exhibited increasing confusion requiring redirection and social withdrawal.
3. He uses hearing aids that appear functional and clean, and he reports no tinnitus.
4. Upon examination, dark, paste-like debris is observed in both ears, with greater accumulation in the right ear.
5. Tuning fork testing, performed after hearing aid removal, shows Weber test lateralization to the right side, and bilateral positive Rinne tests (air conduction superior to bone conduction).
6. The remainder of his neurological examination is unremarkable.
question_options:
What is the most probable diagnosis for this patient?

A. Bilateral cerumen impaction with greater severity on the right  
B. Presbycusis that is greater on the right  
C. Conductive hearing loss that is greater on the right  
D. Left-sided otosclerosis  
E. Sensorineural hearing loss on the left  
F. Age-related cochlear degeneration  
G. Central auditory processing disorder  
H. Noise-induced hearing loss affecting the left ear  
I. Meniere disease with right-sided predominance  
J. Eustachian tube dysfunction affecting the right ear

step1_excerpts:
1. A 1-hour-old newborn boy is evaluated in the delivery room.
2. He was born at 37 weeks gestation to a 39-year-old G3P3 mother.
3. The mother initially labored at home with a midwife but was transferred to the hospital for failure to progress.
4. The infant was eventually delivered via Caesarean section.
5. The mother declined all prenatal screening tests during this pregnancy.
6. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 63/41 mmHg, pulse is 133/min, and respirations are 39/min.
7. His Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively.
8. His weight is 3.0 kg (6.6 lb), and his height and his head circumference are in the 30th and 40th percentiles, respectively.
9. On physical exam, he is found to have a 3 cm full-thickness defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus with evisceration of a loop of the bowel.
10. The abdominal defect is immediately covered in sterile saline dressings and an orogastric tube and 2 peripheral intravenous lines are placed.
question_options:
This condition is most likely associated with which of the following additional findings?

A. Ventricular septal defect  
B. Bicuspid aortic valve  
C. A normal cardiac exam  
D. Tetralogy of Fallot

step1_excerpts:
1. While you are on rounds at a local nursing facility, the nurse mentions that your patient, a 79-year-old woman, appears to be a "poor eater." She was admitted to the nursing facility 3 months ago from the hospital where she was treated for congestive heart failure.
2. Her daughter had moved away from the area, and nursing home placement was necessary because the patient could no longer function independently.
3. Her present medications include furosemide and digoxin.
4. Physical examination is normal except for a weight loss of 3.5 kg (7 lb) during the past 3 months.
5. In your conversation with the patient, she says, "No, I'm not depressed, I just don't have an appetite anymore.
6. Nothing tastes good to me. I have a little bit of nausea most of the time."
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic study?

A. Chest x-ray

B. Complete blood count

C. Determination of serum albumin concentration

D. Determination of serum digoxin level

step1_excerpts:
1. A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of pain and swelling of his right arm where he scraped it on a tree branch 2 days ago.
2. His temperature is 38.3°C (101°F).
3. Examination of the right forearm shows edema around a fluctuant erythematous lesion at the site of trauma.
4. The area is extremely tender to palpation.
question_options:
Which of the following is most likely the primary mechanism of the development of edema in this patient?

A. Disruption of vascular basement membranes

B. Increased hydrostatic pressure

C. Release of thromboxane

D. Separation of endothelial junctions

step1_excerpts:
1. A school-aged boy experienced generalized erythematous rashes for 4 years.
2. Skin examination showed ichthyosiform brownish plaques on his lower extremities and multiple erythematous confluent papules and plaques on his trunk and face (Figure, A and B).
3. Topical steroid and pimecrolimus were administered, but their effects were limited.
4. In addition, painful distal and proximal interphalangeal joints were noted for 2 years, and the patient could not clench his fists.
5. Uveitis in both eyes was also diagnosed by an ophthalmologist.
6. Microscopic examination of his hair showed no trichorrhexis invaginata or trichorrhexis nodosa.
7. A skin biopsy specimen was obtained and submitted for further histopathologic analysis (Figure, C and D).
8. A, Diffuse erythematous papules and plaques with mild scaling and some confluence on the face, neck, and trunk.
9. B, Ichthyosiform rashes predominantly distributed over the lower extremities.
10. C, Tissue biopsy results revealed multiple circumscribed nests of granulomas that were infiltrating the dermis and subcutis (hematoxylin-eosin).
11. D, At higher magnification, histologic findings showed noncaseating granulomas with multinucleated giant cells and neutrophil infiltration in the dermis and subcutis (hematoxylin-eosin).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Ichthyosis vulgaris  
B: Netherton syndrome  
C: Pityriasis rubra pilaris  
D: Blau syndrome

step1_excerpts:
1. A 25-year-old gravida 3 para 2 female is admitted to the hospital at 39 weeks' gestation in active labor.
2. She had been having regular contractions every 4 minutes, but is now having only a few intermittent, weak contractions.
3. She has received medication for pain twice in the past 6 hours.
4. Examination shows no reason for obstructed labor.
5. The fetal head is engaged, the membranes are intact, the fetal heart tones are normal, and the cervix is 100% effaced and 7 cm dilated.
question_options:
The most appropriate management is to

A. administer an epidural anesthetic

B. administer tocolytic therapy

C. apply cervical topical corticosteroids

D. augment the labor with oxytocin

step1_excerpts:
1. A young man presented to the clinic with large, purple plaques on the left lower extremity.  
2. The plaques had been present for years, but the patient noted enlargement and darkening for the past 5 years.  
3. The lesions were asymptomatic with no associated pruritus, bleeding, or pain.  
4. No treatments or diagnostic workup had been attempted prior to presentation.  
5. The patient was otherwise healthy and was a never-smoker with no history of hypertension, atherosclerotic disease, or HIV.  
6. Physical examination revealed dark violaceous plaques, scattered subcutaneous nodules, and swelling to the mid-shin of the left lower extremity (Figure, A).  
7. There was mild warmth noted, but no palpable bruits.  
8. Complete metabolic panel, complete blood cell count, prothrombin, and serology were negative or within normal limits.  
9. A punch biopsy was performed and submitted for histopathologic analysis (Figure, B).  
10. A, Violaceous papules, plaques, and nodules on the left lower shin.  
11. B, Proliferation of superficial and deep vessels, with thickening of the endothelium (hematoxylin-eosin).  
12. C, Magnetic resonance angiogram demonstrating hypervascular soft tissue mass in the left lower extremity.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Kaposi sarcoma  
B: Stewart-Bluefarb syndrome  
C: Acroangiodermatitis of Mali  
D: Lichen planus

step1_excerpts:
1. A young child presented to clinic with a 6-month history of an asymptomatic expanding erythematous eruption on the lower legs, abdomen, and buttocks (Figure, A).
2. The eruption would wax and wane, with each episode lasting for approximately 1 week, without residual pigmentation.
3. Clinical examination was significant for faint, nonscaling annular serpiginous, erythematous plaques with central clearing, and barely elevated borders.
4. Test results for erythrocyte sedimentation rate, complete blood cell count, antinuclear antibodies, anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB antibodies, and Borrelia burgdorferi antibodies were within normal limits.
5. There was no family history of autoimmune disease, and the child had not experienced any fevers or exposures to ticks or other arthropods.
6. A punch biopsy specimen from the left thigh was obtained, and histopathological analysis was subsequently performed (Figure, B and C).A, Annular serpiginous plaques with areas of central clearing on the patient’s right thigh and buttocks.
7. B and C, Histopathologic images (hematoxylin-eosin).
8. B, Perivascular and inflammatory infiltrate.
9. C, Perivascular and inflammatory infiltrate that includes eosinophils.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Tinea corporis  
B: Erythema marginatum  
C: Annular erythema of infancy  
D: Erythema migrans

step1_excerpts:
1. A 72-year-old female patient presents for follow-up of hypertension and reports noticing a swelling in the anterior triangle of her neck over the past 12 to 18 months.
2. She denies symptoms such as weight changes, palpitations, muscle weakness, skin or voice changes, or neck pain.
3. She has no history of radiation exposure or family history of thyroid cancer.
4. On examination, her blood pressure is 142/87 mm Hg, heart rate is 92 beats per minute, and temperature is 36.5°C.
5. A 2- to 3-cm swelling is observed at the base of the neck, just to the right of the trachea, which moves upward with swallowing.
6. The swelling is non-tender, not tethered to the skin, and there is no lymphadenopathy.
7. The palms are slightly diaphoretic, but no other signs of thyroid dysfunction are noted.
8. Laboratory results are as follows:

|  | Patient value | Reference range |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL) | 0.03 | 0.5–4.7 |
| Calcium (mg/dL) | 9.4 | 9.0–10.5 |
| Phosphorus (mg/dL) | 3.6 | 3.0–4.5 |
| Albumin (g/dL) | 3.8 | 3.5–5.5 |

The complete blood count is within normal limits.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?

A. Surgical excision of the nodule for histopathology  
B. PET scan to evaluate for malignancy  
C. Thyroid ultrasound and fine-needle aspiration of the nodule  
D. Repeat TSH measurement in 6 weeks  
E. Empirical treatment with antithyroid medication  
F. Measurement of thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin  
G. CT scan of the neck and chest  
H. Radionuclide scanning with iodine-123  
I. Measurement of free T4 and total T3 levels  
J. Fine-needle aspiration without imaging guidance

step1_excerpts:
1. A study is being conducted to assess mesothelioma in shipyard workers.
2. A large shipyard firm has provided the asbestos exposure records of all employees during the past 50 years.
3. The health insurer for the workers has provided claims data that documents all chest x-rays and diagnoses of mesothelioma among current workers and retirees.
4. The study enrolled shipyard workers who were diagnosed with mesothelioma and shipyard workers who were not diagnosed with mesothelioma.
5. All subjects in the study had to have chest xrays.
question_options:
Which of the following is the best rationale for selecting a comparison group that had chest x-rays?

A. Address confounding

B. Demonstrate causality

C. Minimize ascertainment bias

D. Reduce recall bias

step1_excerpts:
1. A 68-year-old white woman was referred for worsening floaters in both eyes starting 2 years before presentation.  
2. Her medical history included hypertension and right-sided trigeminal neuralgia.  
3. On examination, her visual acuity with habitual correction had decreased to 20/60 OD and 20/40 OS from 20/30 OU 2 years prior.  
4. A slitlamp examination revealed normal conjunctivae, nuclear sclerosis cataracts in both eyes, and deep and quiet anterior chambers.  
5. On a dilated fundus examination, there was 2+ vitreous cell and floaters in both eyes and a blonde fundus in both eyes.  
6. Optical coherence tomography imaging confirmed cystoid macular edema (CME) in both eyes; the right eye had cystoid spaces in the inner nuclear, outer plexiform, and outer nuclear layers, and the left eye had small cystoid spaces in the inner nuclear layer (Figure, A and B).  
7. Fluorescein angiography showed leakage of the optic nerve in the right eye, with petaloid leakage in the macular right eye worse than in the left eye.  
8. A uveitis workup had unremarkable or negative results for a basic metabolic panel, a complete blood cell count with a differential, Quantiferon gold test, Lyme antibody tests, an angiotensin-converting enzyme level, a serum erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and chest radiography.  
9. Additionally, 4 months prior, the patient developed trigeminal neuralgia, with a magnetic resonance image with contrast of the brain revealing an enhancing mass in the right middle cranial fossa, extending into the Meckel cave and abutting the right trigeminal nerve (Figure, C).  
10. A, Optical coherence tomography (OCT) image showing the right eye had cystoid spaces in the inner nuclear, outer plexiform, and outer nuclear layers.  
11. B, OCT image showing that the left eye had trace cystoid spaces in the inner nuclear layer.  
12. C, Axial T1 postcontrast magnetic resonance image showing an enhancing mass filling and expanding the Meckel cave (asterisk).  
13. The other, normal, fluid-filled Meckel cave is noted for comparison (plus sign).  
14. Recommend a temporal craniotomy with a brain biopsy
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  
A: Reassure her and do nothing  
B: Give an intravitreal anti-VEGF injection  
C: Perform a vitrectomy with cytology and immunohistochemistry  
D: Recommend a temporal craniotomy with a brain biopsy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 71-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter for evaluation of her mental status.
2. The daughter says, "I visited Mom today for the first time in 6 months; her memory has worsened, her bills are unpaid, and her house is unusually messy." The patient says, "I'm perfectly healthy." Medical history is significant for hypertension diagnosed more than 25 years ago, and two small strokes occurring 3 years and 7 months ago.
3. The daughter gives you three empty medicine bottles from her mother's home: metoprolol, hydrochlorothiazide, and aspirin.
4. The patient is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 59 kg (130 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2 .
5. Vital signs are temperature 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse 76/min, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 196/112 mm Hg.
6. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%.
7. Muscle strength in her left hand is 1/5.
8. Strength in the right extremities is 4/5.
9. The patient is oriented only to self; she does not know the day of the week or today's date.
10. She recalls 0 of 3 words at 5 minutes, and she is unable to name 2 objects, correctly draw interlocking pentagons, or count backwards by serial sevens.
11. Complete blood count, renal function studies, liver function studies, and urinalysis are all within the reference ranges.
12. ECG shows no abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's symptoms?

A. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

B. Cortical basal ganglionic degeneration

C. Neurosyphilis

D. Vascular dementia

step1_excerpts:
1. A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for right knee pain and swelling.  
2. The patient participated in a soccer match when she jumped and landed on her right foot with her right knee partially flexed.  
3. She subsequently heard a “pop” and developed swelling around her knee.  
4. Past medical history is significant for recent urinary tract infections treated with ciprofloxacin.  
5. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or other recreational drugs.  
6. Vitals are within normal limits.  
7. Physical examination shows a large effusion over the right knee.  
8. The patient is unable to bear weight or extend the knee.  
9. X-ray of the knee shows a large effusion with a low-lying patella.
question_options:
Which of the following additional findings will likely be seen on physical examination?

A. Anterior translation of the tibia against a fixed femur  
B. Inability to perform a straight-leg raise without pain  
C. Palpable defect superior to the patella  
D. Posterior knee and calf swelling  
E. Crepitus with passive knee flexion and extension  
F. Medial joint line tenderness with valgus stress testing  
G. Tenderness over the patellar tendon with no palpable defect  
H. Posterior translation of the tibia against a fixed femur  
I. Palpable defect inferior to the patella  
J. Lateral deviation of the patella with resisted knee extension

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 20s presented with rapidly growing, severely painful oral lesions on the left hard palate of 2 months’ duration.
2. His medical history was significant for Philadelphia chromosome-negative B-cell acute lymphocytic leukemia refractory to multiple treatments, including chimeric antigen receptor T-cell therapy, with transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML) status posttreatment.
3. At the time of evaluation, he had been hospitalized for 5 months with severe protein-calorie malnutrition, pancytopenia, and recurrent neutropenic fevers.
4. The patient was febrile (38.3°C), with a white blood cell count of 0.5/μL (absolute neutrophil count 0.00; to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001), hemoglobin levels of 7.6g/dL (to convert to g/L, multiply by 10.0), hematocrit 21%, and platelet count 9/μL (to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 1.0).
5. He was not receiving active cancer treatment.
6. He appeared cachectic and pale.
7. Intraoral examination revealed poor oral hygiene.
8. The left hard palate exhibited a large swelling with a 5×3-cm indurated area of ulceration, central necrosis, and desquamation (Figure, A).
9. The patient was treated palliatively with dexamethasone solution and nystatin rinse.
10. A biopsy was not recommended owing to medical instability.
11. However, the patient retained a sloughed fragment of the affected tissue, which was submitted for histologic evaluation.
12. A maxillofacial computed tomography (CT) scan completed the etiological investigation.A, The left hard palate shows enlargement with a large, focal, necrotic lesion.
13. B, Hematoxylin-eosin stain of palatal tissue (original magnification ×1000).
14. C, Grocott methenamine silver stain of palatal tissue (original magnification ×1000).
15. D, Computed tomographic image of the maxillofacial complex shows tissue enlargement in the left hard palate and maxillary sinus.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Squamous cell carcinoma  
B: Mucormycosis  
C: Aspergillosis  
D: Myeloid sarcoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A young adult presented with a progressively growing abdominal lump that left him feeling a dull ache and heavy.
2. Ten weeks previously, he was hospitalized and conservatively managed for acute pancreatitis.
3. He had a history of prolonged alcohol abuse.
4. A physical examination revealed stable vital signs and a normothermic, nontender, nonpulsatile, fixed lump in his upper abdomen (Figure, A).
5. A routine blood test revealed leukocytosis (white blood cell count of 12 000/μL[to convert to ×109 per liter, multiply by 0.001]), and his liver and kidney function test results were unremarkable.
6. His serum amylase level was 487 U/L (normal range, 28-100 U/L [to convert to microkatals per liter, multiply by 0.0167]).
7. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of his abdomen was performed (Figure, B).Fixed and nonpulsatile abdominal lump (A) and contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen (B) (axial view).
8. The scan reveals a homogeneous collection of fluid (black arrowhead) encysted by a well-defined enhancing wall (yellow arrowhead).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Mesenteric cyst  
B: Gastric duplication cyst  
C: Pancreatic pseudocyst  
D: Walled-off pancreatic necrosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 65-year-old man underwent a dipstick urine analysis.  
2. Results are shown in the Table.  
3. The patient had a history of hypertension and laminectomy, and he never smoked.  
4. Family history was notable for prostate cancer in his father, but the patient’s prostate-specific antigen and digital rectal examination results were normal.  
5. Perform a computed tomographic scan to evaluate for source of hematuria.  
6. Perform microscopic urinalysis to confirm the presence of blood in the urine.  
7. Refer to urology for cystoscopy to evaluate the source of hematuria.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform a computed tomographic scan to evaluate for source of hematuria.  
B: Perform microscopic urinalysis to confirm the presence of blood in the urine.  
C: Refer to urology for cystoscopy to evaluate the source of hematuria.  
D: Perform urine cytology to evaluate for malignancy.

step1_excerpts:
1. A 15-year-old girl presents with a 7-month history of absent menstrual periods.  
2. She reached menarche at age 13 and denies any significant medical history, medication use, or sexual activity.  
3. She reports no fevers, night sweats, skin changes, or gastrointestinal complaints but mentions cold intolerance and thinning hair.  
4. She is a ninth-grade student performing well academically.  
5. Over the past year, she has become highly active in her school’s track team and has eliminated gluten and processed sugars from her diet to "stay healthy." She runs regularly and swims for 2 hours three times a week.  
6. On examination, her BMI is at the third percentile, with a weight loss of 4.5 kg since her last visit 9 months ago.  
7. Her temperature is 36.1°C, heart rate is 55 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute.  
8. Pubic hair and breast development correspond to Tanner stage 4.  
9. The rest of the physical exam is unremarkable.  
10. A urine pregnancy test is negative, and screening blood tests are ordered.
question_options:
Which laboratory result is most likely to explain this patient’s amenorrhea?

A. Low follicle-stimulating hormone level  
B. Elevated cortisol level  
C. Elevated prolactin level  
D. Normal gonadotropin levels  
E. Elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone level  
F. Increased androgens  
G. Increased thyroid-stimulating hormone level  
H. Elevated free T4 level  
I. Decreased leptin level  
J. Low estradiol level

step1_excerpts:
1. A 35-year-old woman presented with painless ptosis of the left upper eyelid and intermittent diplopia in all gazes (Figure 1).
2. Her new-onset acquired ptosis began 10 months prior.
3. She had no history of ocular disease or trauma, and her medical history was notable for resection of a benign thyroid mass 3 years prior.
4. Family and social history were unremarkable.
5. Her vision was 20/30 OD and 20/25 OS.
6. Intraocular pressures were normal.
7. She had mild anisocoria with the right and left pupils reacting from 6 to 4 mm and from 5 to 3 mm, respectively.
8. The pupils were equal in light and dark, with no reversal after apraclonidine hydrochloride treatment.
9. No relative afferent pupillary defect was noted.
10. Results of the Hertel testing at a base measurement of 100 mm were 20.5 mm OD and 21.0 mm OS.
11. She had full ductions and versions, mild fullness of the left superior sulcus, and no sensory deficits in her facial cranial nerves.
12. Her vertical palpebral fissure measured 10 mm OD and 7 mm OS.
13. Her margin-to-reflex distance was 4 mm OD and 2 mm OS.
14. With phenylephrine hydrochloride, her margin-to-reflex distance became equal at 4 mm OS.
15. She had no lagophthalmos.
16. Results of anterior slitlamp and dilated ophthalmoscopic examinations were unremarkable.Preoperative photograph of the patient showing ptosis of the left upper eyelid.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Check myasthenia laboratory findings and commence pyridostigmine trial  
B: Magnetic resonance imaging and/or computed tomographic imaging of the orbits  
C: Müller muscle conjunctival resection  
D: External levator advancement

step1_excerpts:
1. A 74-year-old woman with a history of hyperlipidemia presents with a 6-month history of activity-induced right-arm pain and achiness accompanied by localized muscle fatigue, which has progressively worsened.
2. She also reports generalized fatigue for the past 4 months.
3. The pain is triggered by activity and resolves with rest.
4. She denies any smoking history.
5. Two weeks ago, she experienced transient vision loss in her right eye and underwent an unremarkable MRI of the brain and ophthalmologic evaluation.
6. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 106/74 mm Hg in the right arm and 132/86 mm Hg in the left arm.
7. A diminished radial pulse is noted in the right arm.
