7. Immediately after the angiography, the patient developed left-sided hemiplegia and hemianopsia.
8. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain revealed an extensive ischemic posterior circulation stroke involving the right occipital lobe, lower cerebellar peduncle, and pontomedullary boundary (Figure, B).
9. Clinical and radiological findings in a man aged 66 years.
10. A, Multiple ulcers limited to the right half of the face.
11. B, Magnetic resonance image showing brainstem involvement by the stroke (diffusion-weighted sequence).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Giant cell arteritis  
B: Trigeminal herpes zoster  
C: Trigeminal trophic syndrome  
D: Pyoderma gangrenosum

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 70s was referred to our tertiary care center for an asymptomatic mass of the gastric fundus.
2. Her medical history was significant for chronic gastritis, which was being treated with esomeprazole 20 mg; a laparoscopic cholecystectomy 18 years prior; and excision of a 26-mm Merkel cell carcinoma of the left knee with negative results of the sentinel lymph node biopsy (stage II) 19 months prior.
3. Results of the patient’s follow-up examinations were negative until a high-resolution computed tomographic scan showed a 45 × 40-mm intraluminal protruding mass with slightly enlarged lymph nodes along the lesser curvature of the gastric fundus (Figure, A).
4. Results of fluorine 18–labeled fluorodeoxyglucose and gallium citrate Ga 68–labeled 1,4,7,10-tetraazacyclododecane-N,N',N'',N'''-tetraacetic (DOTA)-D-Phe1-Try3-octreotide (DOTATOC) positron emission tomography confirmed the presence of a metabolically active mass in the gastric fundus (maximum standardized uptake value, 6) with intense 68Ga–DOTATOC uptake (maximum standardized uptake value, 24) as well as mild 68Ga–DOTATOC uptake in 2 lymph nodes of the lesser curvature.A, Multislice computed tomographic scan showing the 45 × 40-mm mass in the gastric fundus.
5. B, Endoscopic image showing the endophytic lesion in the posterior wall of the gastric fundus at the esophagogastric junction.Preoperative workup was completed via esophagogastroduodenoscopy, which showed the presence of the polypoid lesion in the posterior wall of the gastric fundus at the level of the esophagogastric junction (Figure, B).
6. Multiple biopsies were performed at the time of the endoscopy.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor  
B: Type III neuroendocrine tumor of the stomach  
C: Gastric metastasis of Merkel cell carcinoma  
D: Gastric adenocarcinoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 60s with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), status post–nonallogenic bone marrow transplant and subsequent relapse, was admitted to the hospital with blast crisis (white blood cell count, 72 500/μL; 72% blasts) and tumor lysis syndrome.
2. Flow cytometry showed myeloid blasts, most of which (≥90%) expressed CD13, CD33, CD117, and partial CD11b (≥50%).
3. Blasts were also “highly positive” for myeloperoxidase.
4. Stains were weak for CD4 and were negative for CD34 and HLA-DR.
5. Cytogenetic studies revealed a normal karyotype with NPM1 and FLT3-ITD mutations.
6. Dermatology was consulted for evaluation of 5-day history of new tender lesions on the scalp.
7. The patient did not have a history of recent travel or trauma.
8. Physical examination revealed several tender purpuric papules and plaques with central necrosis and hemorrhagic crusting on the scalp (Figure, A).
9. Similar lesions were present on the right dorsal hand and left lower leg.
10. On the right forearm, there was a tender erythematous plaque with overlying vesicles and mild hemorrhagic crusting.
11. On the left medial thigh, there was a large indurated, tender red-brown plaque.
12. Wound cultures and polymerase chain reaction studies from the right forearm were negative for herpes simplex virus and varicella zoster virus infections.
13. Punch biopsy specimens from lesions on the scalp, right forearm, and left thigh were sent for histopathological and immunohistochemical assessment and tissue culture (Figure, B-D).
14. A, Clinical image of tender purpuric papules and plaques with central necrosis on the scalp.
15. B-D, Histologic images of a punch biopsy specimen from a scalp lesion.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Disseminated intravascular coagulation  
B: Leukocytoclastic vasculitis  
C: Leukemia cutis with leukemic vasculitis  
D: Cutaneous mucormycosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 43-year-old African American woman with medical history of hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection was seen for a 2-year history of painful skin lesions on her legs and arms.  
2. Her lesions improved with prednisone but recurred when treatment was discontinued.  
3. No inciting factors were identified except a possible relation to her menstrual cycle.  
4. She also reported concurrent painful oral lesions.  
5. Erythematous, hyperpigmented, annular papules with dusky centers and bullae were observed on her arms and legs bilaterally (Figure, A, B, C).  
6. Oral lesions were also observed and consisted of erythematous, crusted papules with superficial ulceration, gingival hyperplasia, and superimposed thrush (Figure, D).  
7. The patient had no history of oral or genital herpes lesions.  
8. Results of herpes simplex virus (HSV) 1 and 2 IgG serologic testing were positive.  
9. Test results for pemphigus antibody panel, antinuclear antibodies, human immunodeficiency virus, and rapid plasma reagin were negative.  
10. Biopsy findings were consistent with erythema multiforme.  
11. Prescribe oral prednisone and HSV viral suppression therapy
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Check serum cryoglobulin level  
B: Administer intradermal progesterone challenge  
C: Prescribe interferon, ribavirin, and telaprevir  
D: Prescribe oral prednisone and HSV viral suppression therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 36-year-old healthy gravida 3, para 3 woman with a history of asthma and elective cesarean delivery 11 days prior presented to the emergency department with 3 days of exertional chest pain.
2. The pain was described as crushing and substernal, but she denied radiation or associated dyspnea, nausea, vomiting, or diaphoresis.
3. On physical examination, her blood pressure was 167/105 mm Hg bilaterally, heart rate was 71/min, respiratory rate 18/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air.
4. Initial laboratory evaluation revealed a troponin I level of 0.12 ng/mL (reference range, 0.00-0.04 ng/mL).
5. An electrocardiogram showed normal sinus rhythm with diffuse ST-segment depressions but without q waves or ST-segment elevation (Figure, left).
6. Computed tomography angiography did not show pulmonary embolism or aortic dissection.
7. Echocardiography demonstrated a left ventricular ejection fraction of 53%, with apical akinesis and no valvular disease.
8. Clinical findings from 12-lead electrocardiography (left) and right anterior oblique cranial angiography of the left anterior descending artery during diastole (right).
9. The patient was started on aspirin and ticagrelor, heparin infusion, and metoprolol tartrate for treatment of non–ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction.
10. She underwent coronary angiography (Figure, right; Video).
11. Continue medical therapy alone, with a β-blocker and antiplatelet therapy Refer for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery
question_options:
What to Do Next

A: Administer thrombolytic therapy  
B: Continue medical therapy alone, with a β-blocker and antiplatelet therapy  
C: Perform percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)  
D: Refer for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery

step1_excerpts:
1. A 31-year-old man with insidious onset of limited mobility of joints visited our clinic for evaluation.
2. Six months prior, he found his palms could not make full contact with each other (the “prayer sign”).
3. He had not been able to fully clench his fists for 2 months or squat for the past 10 days.
4. No erythema, edema, or sclerotic skin plaque had been found on his limbs or trunk.
5. No Raynaud phenomenon had occurred.
6. His medical and family histories were unremarkable.
7. On examination, he showed bilateral limited mobility of interphalangeal (hands), metacarpophalangeal, wrist, interphalangeal (feet), metatarsophalangeal, and ankle joints (Video).
8. No muscular atrophy or sclerodactyly was found.
9. The prayer sign (Figure 1A) and the “groove sign” (Figure 1B) were observed.
10. Blood test results indicated eosinophilia (absolute eosinophil count, 1300 μL; reference, <500μL [to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001]), elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR, 31 mm/h; reference, <15 mm/h) and C-reactive protein (CRP, 3.01 mg/dL; reference, <0.8 mg/dL [to convert to mg/L, multiply by 10]).
11. Liver and kidney function tests, creatine kinase level, electrolyte level, thyroid function, globulin concentration, and antinuclear antibody (ANA) level were unremarkable.
12. Electrocardiogram, cervical spine magnetic resonance imaging, and plain radiographs of hands, wrists, feet, and ankles were normal.
13. Nerve conduction studies performed in all 4 limbs were normal.
14. Electromyography (EMG) showed spontaneous activities in muscles of limbs, including fibrillation potentials and positive sharp waves (1+ or 2+).
15. Myotonic discharges were seen in bilateral extensor digitorum.A, The patient’s bilateral palms and fingers could not make full contact due to the limited mobility of interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints.
16. B, Linear depression (arrowheads) was seen along the course of superficial vein when limb was elevated.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Myotonic dystrophy  
B: Systemic sclerosis  
C: Deep morphea (morphea profunda)  
D: Eosinophilic fasciitis

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 30s presented with 3 weeks of distorted vision in her right eye and a visual field defect in the left eye.  
2. This was her first episode, and she denied any pain.  
3. Visual acuity was 20/25 + 2 OD and 20/20 OS.  
4. Confrontation visual fields detected a superior field defect in the left eye.  
5. Pupils, intraocular pressures, and anterior segment examination results were within normal limits.  
6. Dilated fundus examination revealed whitening and attenuation of a small arteriole in the inferior arcade of the right eye (Figure, A).  
7. Examination of the left eye revealed an inferior branch retinal artery occlusion and a patch of retinal whitening superior to the optic disc approximately one-third disc diameter in size (Figure, B).  
8. No Hollenhorst plaques were identified.  
9. Fluorescein angiography demonstrated segments of arteriole hyperfluorescence with distal nonperfusion in both eyes (Figure, C).  
10. This hyperfluorescence and nonperfusion occurred within straight arteriole segments, not at arteriole bifurcations.  
11. The differential diagnosis included systemic lupus erythematosis, polyarteritis nodosa, Behçet disease, granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener disease), acute retinal necrosis, syphilis, and hypercoagulability.  
12. An outpatient workup composed of fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption, QuantiFERON–TB Gold (Quest Diagnostics), erythrocyte sedimentation rate, antinuclear antibody, complete blood cell count, prothrombin time, and partial thromboplastin time was ordered.A, Fundus photograph of the right eye shows subtle whitening and attenuation of an arteriole.  
13. B, Left eye illustrates an inferior branch retinal artery occlusion and retinal whitening superior to the optic disc.  
14. C, Fluorescein angiography demonstrates hyperfluorescence of an arterial midsegment with distal nonperfusion.  
15. The next day, the patient developed severe headaches and presented to the local emergency department.  
16. She retained normal sensorium but had decreased hearing bilaterally.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Consult otolaryngology for hearing evaluation  
B: Order an echocardiogram  
C: Order brain magnetic resonance imaging  
D: Order carotid ultrasonography

step1_excerpts:
1. An 83-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter due to confusion over the last 2 weeks.
2. The patient initially became less talkative than usual before starting to confuse her with her sister.
3. The patient also could not remember what day of the week it was and he was out of groceries and likely had been for several days when visited.
4. While she was talking to him, he fell asleep and was difficult to rouse.
5. The patient is unable to provide a clear history.
6. He has a medical history of hypertension, glaucoma, and osteoarthritis in his left knee that requires him to walk with a cane.
7. He takes hydrochlorothiazide, timolol eyedrops, and occasional acetaminophen.
8. His temperature is 98.5° F (36.9° C), blood pressure is 122/74 mmHg, pulse is 75/min, and respirations are 14/min.
9. The patient is lethargic but arousable, oriented only to person, and disheveled.
10. Neurologic exam reveals intact cranial nerves, 1+ deep tendon reflexes throughout, and 4/5 strength in all extremities.
11. There is a 3 x 5 cm green-blue area of ecchymosis on the lateral aspect of his left knee.
12. A CT of the head without contrast is performed and shown in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following factors plays the earliest role in the progression towards this patient’s presentation?

A. Increased cerebrospinal fluid  
B. Aneurysmal rupture  
C. Cerebral atrophy  
D. Hypertension

step1_excerpts:
1. A 48-year-old woman with diet-controlled diabetes presented with a 6-month history of arthralgias in her hands, feet, elbows, and knees; 3 weeks of a purpuric rash and foot paresthesias; and 2 weeks of bilateral eye pain and redness.
2. She had been prescribed 4 days of prednisone (10 mg/d) without improvement.
3. She had no fevers, epistaxis, rhinorrhea, cough, shortness of breath, or hematuria.
4. She had no history of recent travel or illicit drug use and was not taking any medications.
5. On examination, her vital signs were normal.
6. She had bilateral scleral injection and swelling and tenderness over the proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally.
7. Hemorrhagic vesicles and violaceous papules were present on her ears, nose, arms, and legs (Figure).
8. Laboratory studies revealed normal complete blood cell count, serum electrolyte levels, and liver enzyme levels.
9. Urinalysis findings were normal and urine toxicology screen was negative.
10. Punch biopsy of a papule on the right arm demonstrated a superficial perivascular infiltrate of neutrophils with leukocytoclasia, extravasation of erythrocytes, and fibrin in small blood vessel walls.
11. Direct immunofluorescence testing was negative for in situ deposits of IgG, IgA, IgM, and C3.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Check antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) titers  
B: Check chikungunya serology  
C: Obtain a transthoracic echocardiogram  
D: Order a urine nucleic acid amplification test for Chlamydia trachomatis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 2-day-old boy has an episode of vomiting in the hospital nursery.
2. The vomitus was described as “bright green” without any traces of blood.
3. The patient has urinated several times since he was born but has not passed any stool.
4. He was born at 37 weeks of gestation to a 38-year-old G3P3 woman.
5. The pregnancy was uncomplicated and the patient’s mother refused all prenatal testing.
6. The patient’s 2 older siblings are both healthy.
7. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 67/43 mmHg, pulse is 135/min, and respirations are 34/min.
8. On physical exam, the patient has upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, and a single transverse palmar crease.
9. His abdomen is non-tender, firm, and distended.
10. Bowel sounds are hypoactive.
11. Digital rectal exam evacuates a small amount of stool and flatulence.
12. A nasogastric tube is placed to decompress the stomach.
13. The patient’s abdominal radiograph can be seen in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pyloric stenosis  
B. Intestinal malrotation  
C. Hirschsprung disease  
D. Meconium ileus

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 50s was referred to the dermatology clinic for a chronic, painful nonhealing ulcer on the right forearm following a ground-level fall 3 months previously.
2. He reported subjective fevers, as well as increasing erythema and tenderness immediately around the right forearm lesion.
3. He stated that he did not have a history of poor wound healing or painful skin ulcers.
4. He had a history of type 2 diabetes and an allogenic bone marrow transplant 1 year prior for myelodysplastic syndrome complicated by pancytopenia and chronic graft-vs-host disease.
5. Physical examination revealed an isolated slightly erythematous, edematous plaque with a prominent central eschar on the right forearm (Figure, A).
6. An incisional biopsy at the edge of the eschar was performed, and a specimen was sent for pathological evaluation (Figure, B-D).A, Clinical photograph of a nonhealing ulcer with central eschar on the right forearm.
7. B-D, Histopathologic images.
8. B, Necrotic debris and fat necrosis with saponification (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×40).
9. C, Saponification and needle-like clefts within necrotic adipocytes (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×200).
10. D, Numerous nonseptate, thick-walled fungal hyphae in the dermis (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×400).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Pyoderma gangrenosum  
B: Squamous cell carcinoma  
C: Cutaneous aspergillosis  
D: Cutaneous mucormycosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 40s with newly diagnosed acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) arising from myelodysplasia presented with fever, cough, abdominal pain, difficulty swallowing, and 1 month of neutropenia.
2. He had abruptly developed a painful eruption on his scalp, face, and left leg 24 hours prior to presentation after being scratched in these areas by his pet cat.
3. The patient had not received any chemotherapy or antimicrobial prophylaxis.
4. Physical examination revealed an ill-appearing, diaphoretic, thin man with multiple erythematous to violaceous, tender, edematous, targetoid nodules and plaques with central dusky appearance on the left forearm and right upper thigh (Figure, A).
5. Vital signs included temperature of 39.7° C, blood pressure of 141/69 mm Hg, and pulse of 122 bpm.
6. His white blood cell count was 1.8 × 103/µL (reference range, 4.5-11 × 103/µL; to convert to ×109/L, multiply by .001), and absolute neutrophil count was 246 cells/µL (reference range, 1520-6370 cells/µL).
7. Other laboratory values were remarkable for a red blood cell count of 2.13 × 106/µL (reference range, 3.9-5.5 × 106/µL; to convert to ×1012/L, multiply by 1), hemoglobin of 6.1 g/dL (reference range, 14-17.5 g/dL; to convert to g/L, multiply by 10), and platelet count of 14 × 103/µL (reference range 150-350 × 103/µL, to convert to ×109/L, multiply 1).
8. Cellular cytogenetics of his AML were notable for a 5q deletion and p53 mutation.
9. Punch biopsy specimens from the right arm and left thigh were performed for histopathologic evaluation and tissue culture.
10. A brisk neutrophilic infiltrate was seen on histopathology (Figure, B).A, 1.5 cm-long, edematous plaque with dusky central erythema on upper thigh.
11. B, Punch biopsy specimen with hematoxylin-eosin staining (original magnification ×40); arrowhead indicates brisk dermal neutrophilic infiltrate.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Fusarium species infection  
B: Bartonella henselae infection  
C: Leukemia cutis  
D: Sweet syndrome

step1_excerpts:
1. A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department by ambulance for evaluation of hematemesis.
2. His wife states that he began vomiting bright red blood this evening while eating dinner, and has produced about 5 cups total.
3. He has a history of alcohol use disorder and has vomited small streaks of blood in the past, but has never undergone formal medical workup for it.
4. On exam, he has bright red blood in his mouth and pharynx, and also displays a distended abdomen with a fluid wave, jaundice, scattered spider angiomas, and multiple ecchymoses.
5. His temperature is 98.4°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 98/68 mmHg, pulse is 125/min, and respirations are 22/min.
6. A rapid point-of-care hemoglobin and platelet count is 8.8 g/dL and 80,000/mm^3, respectively.
7. The patient is given 1L of normal saline.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

A. Octreotide  
B. Ceftriaxone  
C. Nadolol  
D. Platelet transfusion

step1_excerpts:
1. A 35-year-old man presented to the emergency department with 4 days of fever (temperature up to 39°C), extreme weakness, fatigue, and 1 to 2 days of progressive confusion.
2. He was born in the United States but had traveled to Sierra Leone for a period of 3 weeks and had returned 1 week prior to presentation.
3. He did not take any form of malaria prophylaxis, nor did he use insect repellent while traveling.
4. He previously received the yellow fever vaccine but not hepatitis A or typhoid vaccination.
5. Physical examination revealed a temperature of 39.3°C, heart rate of 120/min, blood pressure of 119/60 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 32/min, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air.
6. The patient was jaundiced, with scleral icterus, and was alert and oriented, although he had a fluctuating attention span and was unable to complete basic tasks.
7. He was able to localize painful stimuli.
8. No retinal lesions were present on dilated ophthalmologic examination.
9. Laboratory tests were notable for a white blood cell count of 5000/μL with 88% polymorphonuclear leukocytes, 1% bands, 5% lymphocytes, 5% monocytes, and 0% eosinophils; hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL, and platelet count of 25 ×103/μL.
10. Sodium level was 132 mEq/L; potassium, 4.0 mEq/L; chloride, 100 mEq/L; carbon dioxide, 15 mEq/L; blood urea nitrogen, 40 mg/dL; and creatinine, 1.5 mg/dL.
11. Total bilirubin level was 23.9 mg/dL; aspartate aminotransferase, 252 U/L; and alanine aminotransferase, 100 U/L.
12. Venous lactate level was 49.6 mg/dL.
13. A computed tomography scan of the head was unremarkable.
14. A thin preparation blood smear was obtained (Figure).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Start artemether-lumefantrine  
B: Start chloroquine  
C: Start intravenous quinidine gluconate and doxycycline  
D: Perform an exchange transfusion

step1_excerpts:
1. A primigravid woman in her 20s who had been pregnant for 16 weeks presented with significant abdominal pain.
2. A noncontrast computed tomographic (CT) scan revealed a 15 × 13 × 11-cm heterogeneous cystic mass that appeared to originate from the body of the pancreas and protrude into the gastric wall (Figure 1, A).
3. Results of CT scan also revealed a 3-cm hypodense lesion on the left lobe of the liver, ascites, and splenomegaly.
4. Further evaluation with endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography and endoscopic ultrasonography revealed extrinsic compression of the gastric wall from a large mixed solid/cystic lesion with septations and well-defined margins with no clear involvement of the gastric wall.
5. A thin, reddish-brown fluid (700 mL) was aspirated from the cystic component.
6. Analysis of the aspirate showed no tumor cells or mucinous material, and normal carcinoembryonic antigen, CA19-9, and amylase.
7. Fine-needle aspiration was performed on the solid component of the cystic tumor (Figure 1, B-E).
8. A, Coronal view CT scan showing a 15 × 13 × 11-cm complex heterogeneous mass originating from the body of the pancreas (white arrowhead) and protruding into the gastric wall.
9. A hypodense lesion in segment 3 of the liver is observed (black arrowhead) and also moderate ascites (yellow arrowhead).
10. B, Hematoxylin-eosin stain (original magnification ×20); C, α-smooth muscle actin immunostain (original magnification ×40); D, CD117 immunostain (original magnification ×40); and D, CD34 immunostain (original magnification ×40).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Solid pseudopapillary neoplasia of the pancreas  
B: Atypical mucinous cystic neoplasia of the pancreas  
C: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor  
D: Pancreatic pseudocyst

step1_excerpts:
1. An 18-year-old man presented with an upper respiratory tract infection that persisted for a week without improvement.
2. Because of this infection, he went to an emergency department and was prescribed antibiotics for presumed sinusitis.
3. Five days later, he developed painless horizontal diplopia and returned to the emergency department.
4. Findings from a computed tomographic scan showed diffuse sinusitis that was procedurally drained by an otolaryngologist.
5. However, this treatment did not resolve the diplopia and he was subsequently referred to a neurologist.
6. Additional evaluation included a repeated computed tomographic scan that showed no infectious involvement of the orbits or petromastoid complexes (Figure).
7. Findings from magnetic resonance imaging of the patient’s brain and orbits did not reveal intracranial lesions or extraocular muscle myositis.
8. Results of lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid testing, including opening pressure, cell count, and glucose and protein levels, were in the reference range.
9. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein levels were also in the reference range.
10. Findings from neurologic examination did not reveal paresthesias, difficulty with gait, or abnormal tendon reflexes.A, A computed tomographic scan of the face and orbits in coronal sections demonstrating inflammatory changes in the maxillary and ethmoid sinuses without orbital involvement.
11. B, An axial computed tomographic scan does not show inflammatory involvement of the petrous apices (digitally processed image).
12. A indicates anterior.The patient was then referred for neuro-ophthalmic evaluation.
13. His best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OU.
14. Positive findings were limited to a −2.5 bilateral abduction deficit.
15. Alternate cover testing revealed a 30 prism diopters (∆) esotropia on primary gaze that increased to 45∆ on lateral gaze.
16. His pupils, intraocular pressure, visual fields, and findings from external examination were normal.
17. Findings from anterior segment and dilated fundus examinations were also normal.
18. The angle of esotropia was not improved with a 30-minute sleep test.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform a serum test for autoantibodies  
B: Perform a tensilon test  
C: Perform magnetic resonance venography  
D: Restart antibiotic treatment and arrange for an otorhinolaryngology follow-up examination

step1_excerpts:
1. A 66-year-old woman with chronic hepatitis B infection and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) presented with subacute epigastric pain.
2. Three years prior, she was diagnosed with a solitary HCC and underwent surgical resection with curative intent.
3. Pathology revealed poorly differentiated HCC, 16 cm in largest dimension, with large vein involvement (T3bNXM0, R0 resection).
4. The patient underwent expectant observation.
5. One and a half years prior to the current presentation, laboratory results revealed an elevated α-fetoprotein (AFP), and cross-sectional imaging revealed multiple lung nodules consistent with metastases.
6. She was treated with nivolumab every other week and attained a biochemical (baseline, 212.2 ng/dL; best response, 3.3 ng/dL) and radiographic complete response.In the current presentation, the patient reported nonradiating epigastric pain of moderate intensity for 1 month.
7. Associated symptoms included nausea, anorexia, and water brash without emesis.
8. Review of systems was positive for unchanged chronic abdominal bloating and negative for other constitutional or gastrointestinal symptoms.
9. Laboratory results, including liver function tests, amylase, lipase, and AFP, were within normal limits, and hepatitis B virus polymerase chain reaction was undetectable.
10. Computed tomography with multiphasic liver protocol showed new enlarged mesenteric nodes and diffuse thickening of the gastric body (Figure, A).
11. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) identified diffuse inflammation and ulcerations in the gastric body and antrum (Figure, B).
12. Biopsy specimens showed chronic and active mixed inflammatory infiltrate, including intraepithelial lymphocytosis (Figure, C).
13. No overt viral cytopathic effects were observed, and immunostaining results for Helicobacter pylori, cytomegalovirus, and adenovirus were negative.A, Coronal view of restaging computed tomography of chest, abdomen, and pelvis with contrast.
14. The yellow circle notes borderline enlarged mesenteric nodes inferior to the stomach, and the yellow arrowheads show thickened gastric body wall.
15. B, Gross appearance of the gastric mucosa visualized via upper endoscopy, which showed diffuse inflammation and ulceration in the gastric body and antrum.
16. C, Biopsy of the gastric mucosa showed marked chronic and active intraepithelial infiltration of lymphocytes (blue arrowheads) and neutrophils (yellow arrowhead) and associated glandular epithelial injury with withered glands and gland dropout (red circle) (original magnification ×100).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Portal hypertensive gastropathy  
B: Immunotherapy-related gastritis  
C: Infectious gastritis  
D: Liver cancer progression

step1_excerpts:
1. A 95-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with 24 hours of abdominal pain, 2 weeks of diarrhea, and 3 months of intermittent abdominal bloating and anorexia.
2. She was a farmer in rural Japan who did not drink alcohol and had been diagnosed with bullous pemphigoid 8 months prior, initially treated with prednisolone (15 mg daily).
3. Her medications at presentation were prednisolone (8 mg daily) and lansoprazole.
4. She had experienced 1 episode of dyspnea on exertion 2 weeks before presentation but reported no fevers, cough, wheeze, nausea or vomiting, hematochezia, or melena.
5. In the emergency department, her temperature was 37.7 °C (99.9 °F); blood pressure, 110/56 mm Hg; heart rate, 125/min; and oxygen saturation, 95% on room air.
6. On physical examination her lungs were clear to auscultation, and her abdomen was diffusely tender to palpation without rebound.
7. Skin examination revealed purpuric macules and small thumbprint-like patches on the upper abdomen and central chest (Figure 1).
8. Purpuric macules and thumbprint-like patches (arrowheads) on patient’s upper abdomen and central chest.
9. Laboratory testing showed white blood cell count, 13 600/μL (89.9% neutrophils, 0.2% eosinophils); hemoglobin, 10.9 g/dL; serum sodium, 130 mEq/L (reference, 138-145 mEq/L); creatinine, 0.82 mg/dL (72.49 μmol/L); aspartate aminotransferase, 55 U/L (0.92 μkat/L) (reference, 13-30 U/L [0.22-0.50 μkat/L]); alanine aminotransferase, 54 U/L (0.90 μkat/L) (reference, 7-23 U/L [0.12-0.38 μkat/L]); and erythrocyte sedimentation rate, 31 mm/h (reference, 3-15 mm/h).
10. Platelet count and prothrombin time were normal.
11. Abdominal computed tomography with intravenous contrast revealed inflammation of the small intestine.
12. The patient was treated with ampicillin/sulbactam, and her blood cultures grew Klebsiella pneumoniae after hospital admission.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Check stool for ova and parasites  
B: Obtain a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) panel for gastrointestinal pathogens  
C: Order measurement of antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) level  
D: Send blood for fungal culture

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his late 60s was referred to the dermatologic clinic with a 10-day history of fever up to 38.5 °C and tender lesions on the neck and trunk.
2. In the previous month, he had received the first cycle of a chemotherapeutic regimen of ixazomib, lenalidomide, and dexamethasone to treat a recurrence of IgG-κ multiple myeloma with a 10-year history.
3. Physical examination showed annular erythematous plaques of up to 2 cm in diameter, with violaceous and crusted centers on the neck and trunk.
4. On the right chest, an annular erythematous lesion with 2 zones of color—a central area of purpura and an outer erythematous and edematous ring—was present (Figure, A).
5. Laboratory investigations found pancytopenia: a white blood cell count of 2.3 × 103/μL (reference range, 3.5-9.8 × 103/μL), hemoglobin levels of 12.1 g/dL (reference range, 13.5-17.6 g/dL), platelet count of 29 × 103/μL (reference range, 130-400 × 103μL), and elevated serum C-reactive protein levels of 3.31 mg/dL (reference range, <0.30 mg/dL).
6. Blood culture results were negative.
7. Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor analogs had not been prescribed to the patient.
8. Skin biopsy from a lesion on the left chest was performed for histopathological and immunohistochemical analyses (Figure, B-D).
9. A, Clinical image of annular erythematous plaques on the chest.
10. B, A histopathologic image revealing inflammatory infiltrate of predominantly mononuclear cells in the superficial and mid dermis (hematoxylin-eosin stain).
11. C, The predominantly infiltrated cells showing large, elongated, vesicular nuclei, single inconspicuous nucleoli, and scant, slightly eosinophilic cytoplasm (hematoxylin-eosin stain).
12. D, An immunohistochemical image showing myeloperoxidase-positive cells.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Cutaneous involvement of multiple myeloma  
B: Erythema multiforme  
C: Histiocytoid Sweet syndrome  
D: Cutaneous cryptococcosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 79-year-old man with a history of hypertension, stroke, and glaucoma was brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive by a caregiver.
2. He was cold to the touch; blood pressure was 85/55 mm Hg, heart rate was 36/min, respiratory rate was 14/min, and pulse oximetry was 100% on ambient air.
3. Multiple temperature measurements, including a core temperature assessment via the rectal method, did not yield a detectable temperature.
4. His chest examination was clear to bilateral auscultation.
5. Chest radiographs and computed tomography of the head were negative for any acute pathology.
6. Routine laboratory tests were ordered, and he was started on an intravenous fluid.
7. His electrocardiogram (ECG) on presentation is shown in Figure 1.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Order an emergency coronary angiogram  
B: Order urgent temporary transvenous pacemaker placement  
C: Order active rewarming  
D: Order urgent hemodialysis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 58-year-old man presented with a 1-year history of severe and progressive action tremor in his dominant hand when writing.  
2. When questioned, he described subtle balance problems without falls developing over the past 3 years.  
3. With the exception of profound difficulties with handwriting, motor symptoms did not affect livelihood or activities of daily living.  
4. There was no tremor reported in the nondominant hand or other limbs or symptoms of autonomic dysfunction.  
5. Neither he nor his wife reported any changes in cognitive function.  
6. His medical history comprised surgeries of the hand (laceration repair), leg (fracture repair), knee (reconstruction), and ear (stapedectomy); these were not related to the presenting symptoms.  
7. He had a family history of ischemic heart disease (both parents) but no family history of neurological disorder.  
8. He exercised regularly (5 times per week) and consumed 2 to 4 standard drinks per week.  
9. He was a former smoker with a 2-year pack history and denied any illicit drug use.  
10. Cognitive testing revealed deficits in executive function and speed of information processing.  
11. Examination of eye movements and speech revealed jerky eye pursuit, saccadic dysmetria, and moderate slurring of speech.  
12. Additional motor signs included abnormal handwriting (Figure 1A), bilateral intention tremor, mild rigidity (upper extremities), and moderately impaired heel tapping.  
13. Facial expression was normal.  
14. There was no head or resting tremor.  
15. He demonstrated moderate body sway while standing, was unable to stand on 1 foot for more than 10 seconds, and had impaired tandem walking.  
16. Gait, posture, and walking capacities during a timed 6-m walk were normal.  
17. A, Handwriting task from the motor examination showing abnormal handwriting.  
18. B, T2-weighted fluid-attenuated inversion recovery image from brain magnetic resonance imaging showing white matter hyperintensities in the middle cerebellar peduncles.  
19. Routine blood test results were normal.  
20. Brain magnetic resonance imaging showed moderate volume loss in the cerebral hemispheres bilaterally as well as the cerebellum and brainstem.  
21. Abnormal signal intensity was noted in the cerebral hemispheric white matter bilaterally, the middle cerebellar peduncles (Figure 1B), the cerebellar white matter, and the pons.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Multiple system atrophy  
B: Vascular dementia  
C: Fragile X–associated tremor ataxia syndrome  
D: Essential tremor

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his mid-50s with refractory atrial fibrillation who underwent a thoracoscopic ablative procedure presented to a hospital 4 weeks later with acute-onset aphasia, right-sided hemiplegia, and a temperature of 39°C.  
2. Laboratory studies were significant for elevated white blood cell count of 9500/μL (to convert to 109 per liter, multiply by 0.001).  
3. Cerebrospinal fluid revealed white blood cell count 0 cells/μL, red blood cell count 28 cells/μL, glucose level 76 mg/dL, and protein level 48 mg/dL.  
4. Magnetic resonance imaging showed left-hemisphere watershed areas of diffusion restriction.  
5. With fever, change in mental status, and a recent cardiac procedure, there was concern for infective endocarditis and septic emboli and he was transferred to our facility.  
6. On examination, the patient was drowsy with transient eye opening and significant expressive aphasia with mild receptive aphasia; he intermittently followed commands.  
7. Examination revealed right-sided facial droop, right hemiparesis, and an up-going right toe.  
8. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus mitis.  
9. A second magnetic resonance image revealed worsening in both hemispheres with perivenular and leptomeningeal enhancement, areas of cortical diffusion restriction not typical of ischemic injury, and significant T2 changes (Figure 1A).  
10. A, Magnetic resonance imaging findings.  
11. B, Pneumocephalus on head computed tomography (CT), highlighted by white arrowheads.  
12. C, Sagittal computed tomography imaging of the chest with contrast.  
13. Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) showed no vegetation.  
14. While in the supine position for nursing care, he became abruptly hypotensive, bradycardic, hypoxic/cyanotic, and nonresponsive; an electrocardiogram demonstrated inferior ST-segment elevations.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Cardioembolic stroke from atrial fibrillation  
B: Atrioesophageal fistula  
C: Patent foramen ovale and paradoxical embolus  
D: Bacterial endocarditis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 53-year-old male visits his primary care provider due to central, dull chest pain that began 30 minutes ago while attempting to nap after lunch.
2. He recalls experiencing a similar, milder pain last week while sleeping at night.
3. He reports a mild cough over the past 2 weeks, which he attributes to a cold, along with a sour taste in his mouth.
4. He denies difficulty swallowing or bad breath.
5. His medical history includes hyperlipidemia, obesity, and type 2 diabetes, and his medications are atorvastatin and metformin.
6. His family history includes myocardial infarction in his father at age 51 and breast cancer in his mother at age 70.
7. On examination, his temperature is 98.4°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 147/92 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 14/min.
8. He appears slightly uncomfortable but is not diaphoretic, and his physical exam is otherwise unremarkable.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Proton pump inhibitor  
B. Lifestyle modification counseling  
C. Upper endoscopy  
D. Nitroglycerin  
E. Beta-blocker  
F. Cardiac stress test  
G. H2 receptor antagonist  
H. Antacid  
I. Aspirin therapy  
J. Barium swallow

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her mid-30s pregnant with twins at 13 weeks’ gestation presented with a tender right-flank mass, which she noticed after falling and sustaining trauma to the area 1 week previously.
2. Medical history was significant for a total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer 7 years before as well as a strong family history of malignant breast cancer on the maternal side and colon and liver cancer on the paternal side.
3. Physical examination revealed an 8 × 8-cm, tender, firm posterior right-flank mass that was mobile but fixed to the abdominal wall musculature.
4. Laboratory examination revealed no abnormalities.
5. Ultrasonography demonstrated a hypoechoic lesion measuring 3.3 × 3.6 cm with internal echoes and no significant flow (Figure 1A).
6. A noncontrast magnetic resonance image (MRI) revealed this to be a well-circumscribed T2 hyperintense lesion with diffuse surrounding soft tissue edema within the adjacent muscular and subcutaneous tissues abutting the posterior margin of the right chest wall and external oblique muscle at the level of the T11 to T12 intercostal space (Figure 1B and C).
7. A, Ultrasonography demonstrating a hypoechoic mass in the musculature of the right flank.
8. B and C, T1- and T2-weighted images demonstrating an enhancing right-flank mass within the right-flank musculature.
9. Because of the concern of malignancy, an ultrasonography-guided core biopsy was performed and demonstrated a myofibroblastic proliferation with immunostains positive for actin and negative for S100 and desmin.
10. Her case was presented at the soft tissue tumor board, and given that the patient was asymptomatic and pregnant, the decision was made to closely watch the progression of this lesion with serial imaging with a planned resection after delivery.
11. Unfortunately, she developed premature rupture of membranes and lost the pregnancy.
12. Follow-up computed tomography was not able to identify the lesion but MRI showed that it was still present but decreased in size (2.4 × 1 cm) with interval resolution of surrounding inflammatory changes.
13. She subsequently underwent wide local resection of the lesion.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Desmoid fibromatosis  
B: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor  
C: Nodular fasciitis  
D: Leiomyosarcoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A young man in his late teens presented with numerous atrophic papules and plaques on his trunk and extremities that developed gradually over several years.
2. Although most were asymptomatic, the patient was concerned about the ongoing appearance of new lesions and the associated pain that some lesions were causing.
3. His medical history was significant for adenosine deaminase–deficient severe combined immunodeficiency (ADA-SCID), which had been managed since childhood with twice weekly intramuscular injections of pegademase bovine enzyme replacement, thrice weekly trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for Pneumocystis prophylaxis, and monthly infusions of intravenous immunoglobulin.
4. Physical examination revealed 9 smooth-surfaced, skin-colored to hyperpigmented, 0.5- to 1.5-cm atrophic papules and plaques that exhibited the buttonhole sign on palpation (Figure, A).
5. The multicentric lesions were located on the left knee, left thigh, bilateral chest, and back.
6. Punch biopsies of lesions on his trunk and extremities were sent for histopathological examination with hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) staining (Figure, B and C), immunohistochemical (IHC) studies, and molecular evaluation with reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction.A, The patient presented with 2 distinct, smooth-surfaced, 0.5- to 1.0-cm atrophic plaques with overlying hyperpigmentation on the left thigh.
7. Both lesions exhibited the buttonhole sign on palpation.
8. B and C, Histopathology shows poorly circumscribed hypercellular proliferation of spindle cells occupying the lower reticular dermis with lacelike infiltration of the subcutaneous fat (hematoxylin-eosin).
9. The somewhat whorled, uniform appearing spindle cells with mildly hyperchromatic, elongated, wavy nuclei surrounded by pale cytoplasm.
10. Mitotic figures and nuclear pleomorphism are uncommon.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Neurofibroma  
B: Anetoderma  
C: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans, atrophic variant  
D: Medallionlike dermal dendrocyte hamartoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 51-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of fever and a cough with yellow-green sputum for the past 3 days.
2. He denies any hemoptysis, facial pain, rhinorrhea, or night sweats.
3. The patient reported similar symptoms 2 months ago.
4. Chest radiograph performed at the time was notable for a right middle lobe consolidation.
5. He was diagnosed with lobar pneumonia and completed a 7-day course of antibiotics with complete resolution of his symptoms.
6. He has no other significant medical history and does not take any medications.
7. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes a day for 35 years and drinks 3 beers per week.
8. He is sexually active with his wife.
9. His temperature is 101.7°F (38.7°C), blood pressure is 127/85, pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 22/min.
10. Physical exam is notable for decreased breath sounds on the right side without wheezing and increased dullness to percussion on the right side.
11. A chest radiograph is ordered and reveals a consolidation in the right middle lobe.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Interferon-gamma release assay  
B. CT of the chest without contrast  
C. Barium swallow  
D. Serum immunoglobulin levels

step1_excerpts:
1. A 27-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with pain in her hands, shoulders, and knees.
2. The pain has lasted for several months but seems to have worsened recently.
3. Any activity such as opening jars, walking, or brushing her teeth is painful.
4. The patient has a medical history of a suicide attempt in college, constipation, anxiety, depression, and a sunburn associated with surfing which was treated with aloe vera gel.
5. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 137/78 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
6. Laboratory values are obtained and shown below.

Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL Hematocrit: 33% Leukocyte count: 2,500/mm^3 with normal differential Platelet count: 107,000/mm^3 Serum: Na+: 139 mEq/L Cl-: 102 mEq/L K+: 4.4 mEq/L HCO3-: 24 mEq/L BUN: 21 mg/dL Glucose: 90 mg/dL Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL AST: 12 U/L ALT: 10 U/L
question_options:
Which of the following findings is the most likely to be positive in this patient?

A. Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies  
B. Degenerated cartilage in weight bearing joints  
C. Anti-dsDNA antibodies  
D. Anti-histone antibodies

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 50s with a history of hypercholesterolemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus was referred for diarrhea (5-6 times per day) and a 27-kg weight loss in the preceding 5 months.  
2. The patient did not have abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or a history of abdominal surgical procedures and did not use alcohol or tobacco.  
3. On physical examination, the patient’s abdomen was soft, nontender, and nondistended, with no palpable masses, and he did not appear jaundiced.  
4. Results of laboratory testing demonstrated a carbohydrate antigen 19-9 level of less than 1 U/mL and a carcinoembryonic antigen level of 6.0 ng/mL (to convert to micrograms per liter, multiply by 1.0).  
5. A duodenal mass was found using esophagogastroduodenoscopy and biopsies were taken.  
6. To further evaluate the lesion, the patient underwent a computed tomographic scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast dye (Figure 1).  
7. A, Cross-sectional computed tomographic scan demonstrating a 4.7 × 2.9-cm, heterogeneous, solid mass involving the ampulla of Vater and the head of the pancreas.  
8. A heterogeneous soft-tissue nodule can be seen (arrowhead).  
9. The common bile duct (CBD), duct of Santorini (S), and duct of Wirsung (W) can all be identified traversing the mass compressing the duodenum (D).  
10. B, Coronal computed tomographic scan demonstrating a polypoid pedunculated ampullary tumor extending into the duodenal lumen.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Mucinous cystic neoplasm  
B: Primary duodenal carcinoid tumor  
C: Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm  
D: Serous cystadenoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 5-year-old girl was referred to a pediatric gastroenterology clinic for chronic constipation and poor weight gain.  
2. During her first week of life, she developed diarrhea and vomiting.  
3. With initiation of solid food, she developed laxative-dependent constipation.  
4. She underwent newborn genetic screening before routine cystic fibrosis (CF) screening.  
5. Results were normal.  
6. At the time of presentation to the gastroenterology clinic, she had no respiratory symptoms.  
7. Results of anorectal manometry, spinal magnetic resonance imaging, and thyroid studies were normal.  
8. Family history included constipation in a sister and a great aunt with CF.  
9. Her body mass index (BMI) was below the third percentile (eFigureA in the Supplement).  
10. Physical examination findings were unremarkable, including normal respiratory examination.  
11. Fecal elastase level was within reference range (>500 μg/g); abdominal computed tomographic image revealed a dilated, tortuous sigmoid colon; and full-thickness rectal biopsy was negative for Hirschsprung disease.  
12. She was referred for sweat chloride testing to assess for CF.  
13. Results of 3 separate sweat chloride tests were indeterminate (Table), prompting pulmonology referral.  
14. A 97-mutation CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) analysis panel was negative.  
15. Whole-genome sequence analysis revealed 1 CF-causing mutation (c.2249C>T) and 2 likely benign variants (c.1408A>G and c.2562T>G).  
16. No further testing; the patient does not have CF
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  
A: Additional genetic testing  
B: Alternative CFTR functional testing  
C: Repeat sweat chloride analysis  
D: No further testing; the patient does not have CF

step1_excerpts:
1. A 47-year-old woman presented with a 7-month history of multiple painful erythematous plaques on her lower legs.
2. The lesions appeared as erythematous nodules on the left leg with tenderness and pruritus and rapidly progressed to both legs.
3. Marked lower-leg edema was noted 20 days prior to the visit.
4. She also had an intermittent fever during the past 3 months that did not respond to antibiotic therapy.
5. The patient’s medical history was unremarkable.
6. Physical examination revealed ill-defined, indurated erythematous-violaceous plaques on the lower extremities with substantial edema (Figure, A and B).
7. Complete blood cell count revealed a normal white blood cell count with moderate anemia (hemoglobin level, 87 g/L; normal range 115-150 g/L).
8. Additional laboratory tests demonstrated an elevated level of serum lactate dehydrogenase (749 U/L; normal range 100-240 U/L) (to convert to μkat/L, multiply by 0.0167).
9. Quantification of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) DNA in sera showed a high viral load of EBV in peripheral blood (1 800 000 copies/mL, normal range <500 copies/mL).
10. A skin biopsy specimen was obtained from a violaceous plaque (Figure, C).
11. A and B, Ill-defined, irregular erythematous plaques with substantial edema of lower extremities.
12. C, Lesional skin biopsy specimen revealed dilated vessels filled with atypical large lymphoid cells throughout the dermis (hematoxylin-eosin).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Erysipelas  
B: Intravascular large B-cell lymphoma  
C: Intravascular natural killer/T-cell lymphoma  
D: Cutaneous leukocytoclastic vasculitis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 77-year-old man presents to the emergency department acutely obtunded.
2. The patient lives alone and was found unresponsive by his son.
3. Generally, the patient manages his own finances, medications, and works part-time.
4. He has not been responding to phone calls for the past 3 days.
5. The patient is unable to offer a history.
6. He has a past medical history of hypothyroidism, depression, and diabetes.
7. His temperature is 88.0°F (31.1°C), blood pressure is 92/62 mmHg, pulse is 35/min, respirations are 9/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air.
8. The patient is cold to the touch and moves all extremities to painful stimuli.
9. His pupils are reactive and sluggish, and he does not follow commands.
10. There are no signs of trauma or skin infections.
11. The patient is started on IV fluids and hydrocortisone, is externally warmed, and is started on a norepinephrine drip.
12. An ECG is performed as seen in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Levothyroxine administration  
B. Free T4 level  
C. Thyroid stimulating hormone and free T4 level  
D. Triiodothyronine administration

step1_excerpts:
1. A 3-week-old female infant is brought to the pediatrician due to new-onset vomiting after feedings.
2. She and her monozygotic twin were born at 36 weeks via spontaneous vaginal delivery without complications.
3. Both received pertussis prophylaxis before discharge due to a school-aged sibling at home being treated for pertussis.
4. The family history includes ulcerative colitis in the father and asthma in a sibling.
5. The infant has been exclusively breastfed, is afebrile, and shows no respiratory symptoms.
6. Over the past 1–2 days, she has experienced white, forceful vomiting after every feeding but continues to feed eagerly despite this.
7. On examination, she has dry mucous membranes and a capillary refill time of 4 seconds.
8. Her abdominal exam is unremarkable.
question_options:
Which aspect of this patient’s history is most likely linked to her current condition?

A. Lack of prenatal complications  
B. Pertussis prophylaxis  
C. Female sex  
D. Family history of ulcerative colitis  
E. Exposure to a sibling with pertussis  
F. Monozygotic twinning  
G. Maternal diet  
H. Prematurity  
I. Breastfeeding  
J. Twin birth

step1_excerpts:
1. A 6-year-old girl is evaluated for a left-sided neck mass that has been draining to the skin and has not resolved after a 2-week course of clindamycin.
2. The patient has a pet cat at home and no recent travel history.
3. She appears well, with a temperature of 37.2°C and a heart rate of 86 beats per minute.
4. Other vital signs are normal.
5. The neck mass measures 2 cm by 3 cm, is nontender, and has a purple discoloration of the overlying skin with a fistula present.
6. No fluctuance is observed.
7. There is no additional lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly noted on examination.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate management approach for this patient?

A. Order CT scan with contrast of the neck  
B. Perform needle aspiration for culture  
C. Perform incision and drainage of the lesion  
D. Refer for surgical evaluation and excision of the lesion  
E. Start empiric treatment with azithromycin  
F. Obtain Bartonella henselae titers  
G. Initiate combination therapy with rifampin and doxycycline  
H. Order interferon-gamma release assay testing  
I. Submit an aspirate of the lesion for pathologic evaluation  
J. Continue clindamycin for an additional 2 weeks

step1_excerpts:
1. A 61-year-old woman with a history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus presented with progressive right upper quadrant abdominal pain of 1 month’s duration.  
2. The pain was sharp, intermittent without radiation, and not exacerbated by eating.  
3. She had no subjective fevers, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or weight loss.  
4. She had immigrated from Chuuk, Micronesia, to Hawaii 10 years ago and had not traveled overseas since.  
5. She denied alcohol use or contact with animals such as pigs.  
6. On examination, her temperature was 38.5°C (101.3°F); pulse rate, 104/min; blood pressure, 205/92 mm Hg; and respiratory rate, 33/min with normal saturation.  
7. Mild conjunctival icterus and a positive Murphy sign were noted.  
8. Laboratory evaluation showed a white blood cell count of 16.4 × 109/L (neutrophils, 87.4%; eosinophils, 0.5% [absolute count, 82/μL]); hemoglobin level, 14.9 g/dL; platelet count, 254 × 109/L; aspartate aminotransferase level, 514 U/L; alanine aminotransferase level, 236 U/L; alkaline phosphatase level, 208 IU/L; total bilirubin level, 2.5 mg/dL; direct bilirubin level, 1.1 mg/dL; and lipase level, 247 U/L.  
9. Results of serologic testing for hepatitis A, B, and C were negative.  
10. Abdominal ultrasound showed no cholecystitis or pancreatohepatobiliary abnormalities.  
11. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography was notable for a linear filling defect within the common bile duct extending through the left hepatic duct (Figure, left panel).  
12. During endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), numerous worms were discovered within the biliary trees, with 1 visible outside the ampulla of Vater (Figure, right panel).  
13. Left, Findings on magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography.  
14. Right, Findings on endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Prescribe anthelminthic therapy alone  
B: Prescribe antibiotics followed by anthelminthic therapy  
C: Order polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay for Ascaris  
D: Order serum serologic testing for Ascaris

step1_excerpts:
1. An 18-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department in October due to a 1-day history of wheezing.  
2. His mother reports that he has had a runny nose and occasional dry cough for the past 3 days but has been otherwise healthy and feeding well.  
3. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy and has no significant medical history.  
4. His immunizations are up-to-date.  
5. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg.  
6. Oxygen saturation on room air is 93%, and capillary refill time is 1 second.  
7. Lung examination reveals scattered rhonchi and end-expiratory wheezing bilaterally.  
8. No other abnormalities are noted.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Intramuscular dexamethasone  
B. High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy  
C. Titrated oxygen therapy  
D. Oral azithromycin therapy  
E. Nebulized racemic epinephrine therapy  
F. Inhaled ipratropium bromide  
G. Nebulized albuterol and oral prednisone therapy  
H. Intravenous antibiotics and chest physiotherapy  
I. Nebulized hypertonic saline solution  
J. No therapy is indicated at this time

step1_excerpts:
1. Five years after being shot in the right thigh, a 21-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a buzzing sensation adjacent to the scar.
2. At the time of the initial wound, he was discharged after 6 hours of observation with no fractures or soft-tissue swelling.
3. A loud murmur is heard on auscultation; there is a thrill.
4. He has dilated varicose veins with incompetent valves in the lower leg.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Arterial spasm

B. Arteriovenous fistula

C. Deep venous thrombosis

D. Occlusion of the superficial femoral artery

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 50s with a history of nasal-type natural killer (NK)/T-cell lymphoma (diagnosed 2 years prior; treated with pembrolizumab and methotrexate, ifosfamide, etoposide, dexamethasone, and pegaspargase) and chronic pulmonary coccidiomycosis being treated with fluconazole was admitted for fever, hypotension, and rash.
2. Three months prior, pembrolizumab treatment was stopped because of a widespread morbilliform reaction, which had resolved completely 6 to 8 weeks before admission.
3. The new widespread, asymptomatic skin eruption had been ongoing for 1 to 2 weeks and appeared different from her pembrolizumab reaction.
4. A complete blood cell count was notable for a normal white blood cell count of 4100/μL, normal absolute neutrophil count of 2940/μL, chronic normocytic anemia (hemoglobin level of 8.2 g/dL), and chronic thrombocytopenia (platelet count of 62 ×103/μL).
5. Blood culture results showed no growth at 1 week.
6. Serum β-D-glucan, galactomannan, Coccidioides antibody by complement fixation, and immunodiffusion results were negative.
7. Respiratory viral panel and SARS-CoV-2 test results were negative.
8. Total body skin examination findings were notable for widespread, nontender, erythematous patches and thin plaques, some with prominent overlying telangiectases and hyperpigmentation (Figure, A).
9. A punch biopsy of a representative lesion was performed (Figure, B-D).
10. A, Physical examination findings were notable for widespread erythematous patches and thin plaques, some with prominent overlying telangiectases.
11. B and C, Hematoxylin-eosin stained section.
12. D, CD56 immunostaining labels intravascular atypical cells.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Malignant neoplasm–associated microscopic polyangiitis  
B: Intravascular involvement by NK/T-cell lymphoma  
C: Cutaneous coccidiomycosis  
D: Erythema nodosum

step1_excerpts:
1. A girl in her teens presented with a unilateral itchy nodule on her right labium majus of 4 months’ duration.
2. The patient was born and lived in a rural village in Malawi.
3. Her medical and family history were unremarkable.
4. She did not report fever or malaise.
5. Physical examination revealed a polypoid, rubbery tumor measuring 1.5 cm located on her right labium majus, which obliterated the right labium minus (Figure, A).
6. She did not present with enlarged lymph nodes, and results of the physical examination were otherwise unremarkable.
7. An incisional lesional biopsy was taken (Figure, B and C).
8. A, Polypoid nodule on the right labium majus obliterating the labium minus.
9. B-D, Hematoxylin-eosin–stained lesional specimens.
10. B, Histopathologic analysis of the nodule showed pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia with transepidermal elimination of basophilic oval-shaped structures in the epidermis and a dense acute and chronic dermal infiltrate in the dermis.
11. C, Numerous dermal structures surrounded by a dense acute and chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate with granuloma formation.
12. D, High-power magnification of the oval parasitic structures with a typical terminal spine.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Onchocerciasis  
B: Late cutaneous bilharziasis  
C: Periorificial cutaneous tuberculosis  
D: Granuloma inguinale

step1_excerpts:
1. A 35-year-old woman arrives at the emergency department with complaints of fatigue, shortness of breath, and palpitations.
2. She underwent an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy a week ago, during which she received a prophylactic dose of cefotetan.
3. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she denies any family history of genetic conditions.
4. On examination, her temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 20/min.
5. Physical findings include jaundice and splenomegaly.
6. Laboratory results show a hemoglobin level of 7.1 g/dL (previously 13.2 g/dL one week ago).
7. Additional tests reveal:  

Leukocyte count: 7,000/mm³  
Platelet count: 300,000/mm³  
Mean corpuscular volume: 90 µm³  
Reticulocyte count: 9%  
Lactate dehydrogenase: 480 U/L (Normal: 140-280 U/L)  
Haptoglobin: 10 mg/dL (Normal: 41-165 mg/dL)  
Indirect bilirubin: 2.7 mg/dL  
D-dimer: <250 ng/mL (Normal: <250 ng/mL)  

A peripheral blood smear shows reticulocytosis and microspherocytes.
question_options:
Following appropriate initial management, which of the following is the most suitable next diagnostic test?

A. Cold agglutinin titer  
B. Bone marrow biopsy  
C. Peripheral blood smear for Heinz bodies  
D. Hemoglobin electrophoresis  
G. Indirect Coombs test  
H. Serum free hemoglobin level  
I. Direct Coombs test  
J. Osmotic fragility test

step1_excerpts:
1. A 69-year-old man presents to clinic due to shortness of breath, worsening pain in his right shoulder, and episodes of hemoptysis.
2. His symptoms began 3 months ago.
3. He has also lost 18 pounds.
4. He has a history of coronary artery disease and underwent an uncomplicated coronary angioplasty with stent placement 2 years ago.
5. He routinely travels both domestically and internationally as a senior shipyard worker and has a 30-pack-year smoking history.
6. He used to drink 4 cocktails a week.
7. He has not smoke or drank alcohol in over 7 years.
8. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.7°C), blood pressure is 140/60 mmHg, pulse is 97/min, and respirations are 13/min.
9. Physical exam is notable for right pupillary constriction as well as paresthesias in his right fourth and fifth digits.
10. There is no pain with active shoulder rotation.
11. His chest imaging is shown in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is most likely responsible for the patient’s symptoms?

A. Lung adenocarcinoma  
B. Mesothelioma  
C. Rotator cuff tendinopathy  
D. Tuberculosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 34-year-old Indian woman seeks fertility consultation with her spouse due to difficulty conceiving.
2. She met her current husband during humanitarian work in Nepal a decade ago.
3. Her symptoms include chronic vague lower abdominal discomfort and menstrual irregularities, including spotting and passage of blood clots over recent months.
4. She reports no dyspareunia, post-coital bleeding, malodorous vaginal discharge, fever, or weight loss.
5. Physical examination reveals mild cervical bleeding and slight tenderness on bimanual examination without palpable masses.
6. A hysterosalpingogram reveals sinus tract formation and peritubal adhesions.
7. A menstrual fluid sample is sent for microbiological analysis.
question_options:
Which pathogen is the most probable cause of her presentation?

A. *Mycoplasma genitalium*  
B. *Klebsiella granulomatis*  
C. *Treponema pallidum*  
D. *Chlamydia trachomatis*  
E. *Escherichia coli*  
F. *Ureaplasma urealyticum*  
G. *Actinomyces israelii*  
H. *Trichomonas vaginalis*  
I. *Mycobacterium tuberculosis*  
J. *Neisseria gonorrhoeae*

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of severe epigastric pain and vomiting.
2. Past medical history is negative for any similar episodes.
3. He does not take any medications.
4. He smokes cigarettes, has a 40 pack-year history, and consumes more than 8 cans of beer per day.
5. Abdominal examination reveals epigastric tenderness.
6. Laboratory studies reveal a serum amylase level of 467 U/L (reference range: 28-100 U/L) and a γ-glutamyltransferase level of 212 U/L (reference range: < 55 U/L).
question_options:
Referred pain in this patient is transmitted to the spinal cord by which of the following nerves?

A. anterior rami of T1-T5

B. anterior rami of T6-T10

C. anterior rami of T11-T12

D. posterior rami of T1-T5

step1_excerpts:
1. A 50-year-old female patient with myelodysplastic syndrome who underwent bone marrow transplantation from an unrelated donor shows persistent severe thrombocytopenia.
2. Despite multiple transfusions with apheresis platelets, her platelet count remains at 6000 per mm3 (normal range: 150,000–350,000).
3. The patient has no fever, and laboratory tests show no evidence of disseminated intravascular coagulation or thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.
question_options:
Which of the following represents the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Initiate intravenous immunoglobulin therapy  
B. Switch to pooled platelet transfusions  
C. Initiate glucocorticoid therapy at 1 mg/kg of body weight  
D. Begin plasmapheresis treatment  
E. Observe the patient without initiating further platelet transfusions  
F. Perform bone marrow biopsy to assess engraftment  
G. Test for cytomegalovirus infection  
H. Perform human leukocyte antigen antibody testing  
I. Perform platelet-specific antibody testing  
J. Administer recombinant thrombopoietin

step1_excerpts:
1. A black man in his 30s presented for evaluation of papules and plaques on his bilateral lower extremities.
2. Nine months before the current presentation, he was treated with intramuscular penicillin for syphilis.
3. His medical history was also significant for HIV, for which he was receiving highly active antiretroviral therapy, and metastatic programmed cell death ligand 1–positive squamous non–small cell lung cancer.
4. Four months before the current presentation, the patient had started pembrolizumab monotherapy as a first-line treatment for his cancer.
5. One month before this presentation, multiple ulcers developed on his buccal mucosa, as well as a nonpainful shallow penile ulcer and pruritic, mildly painful, hyperpigmented papules and plaques on the bilateral soles of his feet in a pattern identical to previous syphilitic eruption.
6. The patient denied fever, chills, and weight loss.
7. Physical examination revealed multiple hyperpigmented papules and plaques with violaceous borders on his bilateral soles and lateral feet (Figure, A) and scattered, violaceous papules and nodules with overlying scale on his bilateral lower extremities.
8. He was referred to the dermatology service, and a punch biopsy specimen was obtained from the right medial sole (Figure, B).
9. A, Right foot with multiple hyperpigmented, lichenified papules, and plaques with violaceous borders.
10. B, A punch biopsy specimen from the right medial sole.
11. Lymphocytes, eosinophils, and plasma cells can be seen within the infiltrate (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×40).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Secondary syphilis  
B: Lichen planus  
C: Lichenoid drug reaction  
D: Janeway lesions secondary to endocarditis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 72-year-old man presents to the office with a 5-month history of persistent lower back pain.
2. He describes the pain as dull and as worsening with prolonged standing or when lifting heavy objects.
3. The patient denies any trauma.
4. He requests osteopathic manipulative treatment with high-velocity low-amplitude (HVLA) because the technique helped him with pain relief in the past.
5. Past medical history is significant for prostate cancer that was diagnosed 3 years ago and treated with radiation therapy.
6. Further review of records reveals multiple metastatic lesions to the spine.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?

A. Recommend craniosacral therapy to address lumbar dysfunction  
B. Refer the patient to physical therapy for spinal traction  
C. Recommend counterstrain to the lumbar spine  
D. Recommend indirect myofascial release to the lumbar spine  
E. Advise against osteopathic manipulative treatment and prescribe opioid pain medication  
F. Perform facilitated positional release to the lumbar spine  
G. Recommend balanced ligamentous tension to the lumbar spine  
H. Recommend HVLA to the lumbar spine  
I. Recommend muscle energy to the lumbar spine  
J. Perform direct myofascial release to the lumbar spine

step1_excerpts:
1. An 84-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and a transient ischemic attack 4 years earlier presented to the University of Illinois at Chicago emergency department for evaluation of 1 day of decreased vision in his left eye.
2. He described it as a central “band” of absent vision just below center.
3. On examination, visual acuity measured 20/40 OD and 20/60 OS, improving to 20/40 with pinhole.
4. A complete blood cell count, results of a comprehensive metabolic panel, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein level, and computed tomography of the head without contrast were all normal.
5. Review of systems was negative.
6. Ocular history included penetrating keratoplasty with intraocular lens exchange and Descemet stripping automated endothelial keratoplasty in the right eye.
7. Four days later in the Retina Clinic, visual acuity was unchanged.
8. Slitlamp examination of the anterior segment was normal.
9. Ophthalmoscopy revealed no vitreous cells, a posterior vitreous separation, cup-disc ratio of 0.3, normal retinal vessels, and a superior parafoveal crescent of translucent retina without associated edema or hemorrhage.
10. The peripheral retina was normal.
11. Fundus autofluorescence and fluorescein angiogram showed abnormalities in the superior macula (Figure 1).A, Fundus autofluorescence shows a superior parafoveal and perifoveal dark crescent at presentation, corresponding to the hypofluorescent region in part B.
12. B, Fluorescein angiography at presentation revealed delayed perfusion with hypofluorescence in the superior parafoveal and perifoveal regions without leakage.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform ocular ultrasonography  
B: Obtain optical coherence tomography  
C: Obtain blood tests for vasculitis workup  
D: Administer intravitreal injection of an anti–vascular endothelial growth factor agent

step1_excerpts:
1. A 56-year-old woman with a history of ovarian cancer and surgical colostomy presented with a nontender nodule adjacent to her stoma.
2. She was diagnosed 6 years ago with recurrent poorly differentiated serous ovarian carcinoma and underwent total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, with multiple regimens of chemotherapy, most recently with ixabepilone and bevacizumab.
3. Complications included a large bowel obstruction, for which she underwent a transverse loop colostomy 3 years ago.
4. The nodule first appeared 1 year prior.
5. It appeared to increase in size after contact with fecal matter and decrease in size after cleaning of the ostomy site, although it never resolved completely.
6. She reported no pain at the site but described mild burning with fecal-induced irritation.
7. She noted “pus-like” drainage from the nodule and received several courses of antibiotics.
8. Examination revealed a 3-cm firm, pink to violaceous, irregularly shaped multilobulated nodule with a central 1-cm ulcer with undermined borders, overlying an erythematous base (Figure).
9. The nodule was rock-hard, with a friable yellow-red plaque between the nodule and ostomy site.
10. The stoma was red, moist, and well-perfused.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Swab and send for cultures  
B: Obtain a biopsy of the nodule  
C: Consult wound care for barrier protection  
D: Prescribe topical steroids

step1_excerpts:
1. A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department with several days of malaise, weakness, and night sweats.
2. Today, he experienced a headache with blurry vision, thus prompting his presentation.
3. The patient has a history of diabetes and is followed closely by an endocrinologist.
4. Otherwise, he has lost 10 pounds over the past month.
5. His temperature is 100°F (37.8°C), blood pressure is 122/90 mmHg, pulse is 84/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air.
6. Physical exam is notable for a thin man but is otherwise unremarkable.
7. His visual acuity is 20/100 in both eyes, though he says that he normally has 20/20 vision.
8. His gait is mildly ataxic as well, but his neurological exam is otherwise nonfocal.
9. Laboratory studies are ordered as seen below.

Hemoglobin: 10 g/dL  
Hematocrit: 31%  
Leukocyte count: 57,500/mm^3 with 35% blasts  
Platelet count: 109,000/mm^3  

Serum:  
Na+: 139 mEq/L  
Cl-: 100 mEq/L  
K+: 4.1 Eq/L  
HCO3-: 22 mEq/L  
BUN: 20 mg/dL  
Glucose: 99 mg/dL  
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL  
Calcium: 10.0 mEq/L
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia  
B. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia  
C. Multiple myeloma  
D. Chronic myelogenous leukemia

step1_excerpts:
1. A 15-year-old girl presented with a 2-month history of decreased vision and a dark spot in the central vision in her right eye.
2. She had a history of optometric examinations with no known ocular disease.
3. Visual acuity with correction was 20/40 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye.
4. Anterior segment examination of both eyes was unremarkable, and the retina in the left eye appeared normal.
5. In the right eye, there was an area of superior macular whitening with associated intraretinal hemorrhages and exudates.
6. Fluorescein angiography showed abnormally dilated and tortuous retinal vessels, irregular capillary branching patterns, and bulblike telangiectasis with late leakage in the superior macula.
7. Optical coherence tomography showed disorganized and hyperreflective inner retinal thickening (Figure, A) and intraretinal and subretinal fluid in the central macula.
8. On review of systems, the patient noted a long-standing growth on her cheek, which on examination was a 4 × 3-mm exophytic, brownish-red vascular papule (Figure, B), as well as a history of lightly pigmented patches of skin and multiple subungual fibromas on her toes.
9. Systemic blood pressure was normal.
10. Features of tuberous sclerosis complex.
11. A, An area of superior macular whitening following the superior arterial arcade with associated intraretinal hemorrhages and exudate.
12. Two optical coherence tomography line scans inset through the main lesion (orange) and through the fovea (blue) with relative location marked with dotted lines, demonstrating disorganized and hyperreflective inner retinal thickening consistent with type 1 astrocytic hamartoma of the retina and associated macular edema.
13. Arrowhead indicates bulblike telangiectasis on fluorescein angiography and blocking from intraretinal hemorrhage.
14. B, Elevated papule.
15. The lesion is a well-demarcated, exophytic, brownish-red vascular papule with an irregular surface.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Initiate anti–vascular endothelial growth factor treatment  
B: Order brain magnetic resonance imaging to look for associated central nervous system tumors  
C: Perform hypercoagulable workup  
D: Order echocardiogram and carotid ultrasonography

step1_excerpts:
1. A 15-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician after an appendectomy 1 week ago.
2. The patient denies any abdominal pain, fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation.
3. He eats solids and drinks liquids without difficulty.
4. He is back to playing basketball for his school team without any difficulty.
5. His urine appears more amber than usual but he suspects dehydration.
6. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 15/min.
7. His physical exam is unremarkable.
8. The laparoscopic incision sites are all clean without erythema.
9. The pediatrician orders a urinalysis, which is notable for the following.
10. Urine: Epithelial cells: Scant Glucose: Negative Protein: 3+ WBC: 3/hpf Bacteria: None Leukocyte esterase: Negative Nitrites: Negative The patient is told to return in 3 days for a follow-up appointment; however, his urinalysis at that time is similar.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. CT scan abdomen and pelvis with contrast  
B. Renal biopsy  
C. Repeat urinalysis
