D. Urine dipstick in the morning and in the afternoon

step1_excerpts:
1. An 18-month-old girl is brought in for an acute outpatient visit.
2. Her father reports that she has had 6 to 10 watery, nonbloody, nonmucus-containing bowel movements per day for the past 4 days, her physical activity is diminished, and her urine output is declining.
3. She initially had two episodes of nonbloody, nonbilious emesis, but this has resolved.
4. Although she refuses to eat, she has been drinking sips of apple juice and water at home and has appeared thirsty.
5. She has not had any fevers.
6. Her last wet diaper was about 12 hours ago.
7. She has no travel history and had no changes in her diet before the onset of symptoms.
8. Her father reports having loose stools himself one day last week.
9. On physical examination, the girl has a temperature of 37.2°C, a heart rate of 115 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg.
10. She weighs 12 kg.
11. She is fussy but easily consoled by her father.
12. She has diminished tear production and dry lips.
13. A quiet, grade II/VI systolic ejection murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border without radiation.
14. Her lungs are clear.
15. Her abdomen is soft, nondistended, and diffusely tender to palpation.
16. Capillary nail refill time is 3 seconds.
17. A check for skin turgor reveals a recoil time of about 2 seconds.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

A. NPO status with IV hydration  
B. Oral rehydration with a hypo-osmolar solution  
C. Oral rehydration with hyperosmolar solution  
D. Bolus infusion of normal saline  
E. Immediate hospitalization for IV antibiotics  
F. Intravenous maintenance fluids with D5 1/2NS  
G. Oral rehydration with a standard-osmolar solution  
H. Small frequent feeds of breast milk or formula  
I. Oral zinc supplementation with rehydration  
J. Clear liquid diet with sports drinks

step1_excerpts:
1. A 75-year-old woman presenting with decreased visual acuity and metamorphopsia in the right eye was referred for further evaluation of a pigmented epiretinal membrane.
2. She had a history of cutaneous nodular melanoma in the right arm.
3. Tumor staging was classified as T3N0M0 in August 2017, at the time of diagnosis and excision.
4. In April 2018, axillary lymphadenectomy was performed for local recurrence and the patient started treatment with an immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) pembrolizumab, without further local or metastatic evidence of the tumor.
5. Ocular history was positive for cataract surgery bilaterally.
6. After cataract surgery in the right eye, an asymptomatic vision loss was noted and the cause was attributed to the presence of choroidal neovascularization (CNV), for which the patient underwent intravitreal anti–vascular endothelial growth factor (anti-VEGF) injections.
7. Examination showed a best-corrected visual acuity of 20/60 OD and 20/20 OS, unremarkable anterior segment findings, and intraocular pressures of 12 mm Hg OU.
8. A fundus examination in the right eye revealed scarce pigmented cells in the anterior vitreous, a dark-pigmented epiretinal membrane, and an area of retinal hyperpigmentation in the inferior temporal arcade corresponding to the CNV.
9. Optical coherence tomography imaging revealed a hyperreflective structure on the surface of the inner retina with increased macular thickness, compatible with the described epiretinal membrane.
10. Fundus examination in the right eye revealed scarce pigmented cells in the anterior vitreous, a dark-pigmented epiretinal membrane, and an area of retinal hyperpigmentation in the inferior temporal arcade corresponding to the choroidal neovascularization.
11. Inset, Optical coherence tomography of a hyperreflective structure on the surface of the inner retina with increased macular thickness.
12. Recommend intravitreal anti-VEGF injections for exudative age-related macular degeneration.
13. Perform pars plana vitrectomy and excisional biopsy of the membrane
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Recommend intravitreal anti-VEGF injections for exudative age-related macular degeneration  
B: Provide reassurance and recommend close observation  
C: Perform pars plana vitrectomy and excisional biopsy of the membrane  
D: Prescribe topical and systemic steroids

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 50s with a history of hypertension and sleep apnea presented with a 6-week history of progressive, bilateral vision loss while receiving treatment with oral steroids and amoxicillin-clavulanate from his primary care physician.  
2. He also had associated ear pain, hearing loss, and severe headaches.  
3. On presentation, his visual acuity was light perception OD and 20/600 at 1 m OS.  
4. The right eye had a 1+ afferent pupillary defect.  
5. He also had ear drainage with inflamed tympanic membranes and ear tubes in place bilaterally.  
6. A dilated fundus examination revealed grade 2 optic disc edema with an inferior disc hemorrhage in the right eye and grade 1 edema in the left eye.  
7. The remainder of the examination was unremarkable.  
8. Laboratory results revealed elevated C-reactive protein levels and erythrocyte sedimentation rates at 78 mg/L and 77 mm/h, respectively, with negative antinuclear antibody test results (to convert C-reactive protein to nanomoles per liter, multiply by 9.524).  
9. His white blood cell count was elevated at 14 910/μL without eosinophilia (to convert to × 109/L, multiply by 0.001).  
10. Cerebrospinal fluid studies were remarkable only for an elevated white blood cell count of 72/μL (79% lymphocytes) and elevated protein level at 97 mg/L, while Gram stain and culture were negative.  
11. Opening pressure was 17 cm H2O.  
12. A magnetic resonance venogram with and without contrast ruled out venous occlusions.  
13. Finally, magnetic resonance imaging demonstrated diffuse pachymeningeal (dural-arachnoid) enhancement (Figure) without leptomeningeal (pial) enhancement, left-sided mastoiditis, and subtle optic nerve enhancement.  
14. Coronal T1 with gadolinium showing dural enhancement (blue arrowhead) and optic nerve enhancement (white arrowheads).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Quantiferon gold  
B: Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody testing  
C: Rapid plasma reagin  
D: Angiotensin-converting enzyme level

step1_excerpts:
1. A 42-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic with low back pain.
2. He was working on a home improvement project the day prior to presentation when the pain started.
3. He describes the pain as "achy and sore." It is not positional and does not radiate.
4. He denies fevers, chills, paresthesias, and bowel or bladder incontinence.
5. He has a history of a distal radius fracture 2 years ago from falling off a ladder.
6. He drinks 3 alcoholic beverages weekly and denies illicit drug use.
7. The patient’s temperature is 98.4°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 16/min.
8. His body mass index (BMI) is 22.4 kg/m^2.
9. There is tenderness to palpation of his paravertebral lumbar region bilaterally.
10. Perineal and dermatomal sensation is symmetric and intact.
11. Strength is 5/5 to knee flexion/extension and ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion.
12. Patellar and Achilles reflexes are 2+ bilaterally.
13. Raising either leg while the patient is in the supine position does not elicit any pain.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Osteoarthritis  
B. Vertebral compression fracture  
C. Lumbar strain  
D. Disc herniation

step1_excerpts:
1. A mother brings her 4-week-old male infant for a routine health maintenance visit.
2. She reports an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery.
3. Upon obtaining consent and performing an osteopathic structural examination, you observe a parallelogram-shaped head with unilateral flattening.
4. During the vault hold examination, you note that your index fingers shift leftward while your little fingers move rightward.
question_options:
Which sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) dysfunction most likely explains these findings?

A. Vertical strain superior  
B. Flexion dysfunction  
C. Compression  
D. Vertical strain inferior  
E. Left sidebending rotation  
F. Left torsion  
G. Right torsion  
H. Right sidebending rotation  
I. Left lateral strain  
J. Right lateral strain

step1_excerpts:
1. A 22-year-old woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus was readmitted with fever and a generalized eruption.
2. Six days prior to this admission, she had been hospitalized for a photo-induced flare of acute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (ACLE).
3. At readmission, she was febrile with a temperature of 101.5°F, and on examination, she had a worsening, exquisitely tender rash with several blisters across her right arm.
4. Physical examination revealed erythematous plaques with superficial desquamation in the malar distribution of the face, nose, ears, and medial forehead (Figure, A), as well as bilateral extensor arms, chest, posterior neck, and upper back.
5. Several large bullae were located on the right arm (Figure, B).
6. Numerous flat and raised 2-zoned atypical targets with dusky centers were appreciated on the forearms, abdomen, back (Figure, C), thighs, legs, palms and soles.A, Dusky malar erythema with focal heme crusting.
7. B, Flaccid bullae and target lesions.
8. C, Diffuse typical and atypical target lesions of the back.
9. D, High-power view (original magnification 100×) of punch biopsy obtained from left abdomen demonstrating dyskeratosis with superficial perivascular inflammation and interface changes.Hemogram test results revealed a normocytic anemia (mean corpuscular volume, 99 fL; hemoglobin, 11.7 g/dL [to convert to g/L, multiply by 10.0]; hematocrit, 33.4%), in addition to thrombocytopenia (platelet count, 81 K/μL).
10. Other pertinent laboratories included hypocomplementemia (C3 of 42 mg/dL; C4 of 3 mg/dL), a speckled antinuclear antibody titer of 1:1280, and an antidouble-stranded DNA titer of 1:80, along with positive anti-Smith, antiribonucleoprotein, and SSA/anti-Ro antibodies.
11. Bacterial blood, urine, stool and cerebrospinal fluid cultures, and a hepatitis panel revealed no infectious source.
12. Punch biopsy of an abdominal atypical target lesion was performed (Figure, D).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Pemphigus erythematosus  
B: Generalized fixed drug eruption  
C: Rowell syndrome  
D: Toxic epidermal necrolysis

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 60s with a history of bilateral proliferative diabetic retinopathy complicated by a recent vitreous hemorrhage in her left eye presented with an acute onset of redness, irritation, and blurred vision in her left eye.
2. Her symptoms started 1 day after she rubbed her left eye with her hands after handling the milky latex (a fluid found in 10% of flowering plants) of a plant in her garden.
3. She had no recent history of recent eye surgery, eye trauma, cold sores, or new illnesses.
4. On presentation, her visual acuity was 20/40 OD and 20/200 OS.
5. Her pupils were equal, round, and reactive in both eyes.
6. Her intraocular pressures were 16 mm Hg OD and 19 mm Hg OS.
7. On anterior segment examination, she was found to have pinpoint epithelial defects, thickened stroma, and dense Descemet folds, along with a nuclear sclerotic cataract (Figure 1).
8. Central pachymetry in the left eye measured 706 μm, which was elevated from the mean expected pachymetry values of 540 to 560 μm.
9. A posterior pole examination was limited by corneal edema, but there was evidence of a vitreous hemorrhage.
10. The fellow eye had no corneal edema and was pseudophakic, with prior panretinal photocoagulation scars in the peripheral retina.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Intrastromal injection of anti–vascular endothelial growth factor  
B: Start topical corticosteroid eyedrops  
C: Begin oral and/or topical antiviral medications  
D: Perform an endothelial keratoplasty

step1_excerpts:
1. A 78-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for replacement of her left knee joint due to degenerative joint disease.
2. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, a long history of hypertension, and chronic renal failure presumed secondary to diabetes mellitus and hypertension.
3. Reversible causes of renal failure have been excluded.
4. She underwent a tonsillectomy at age 9 years and a laparoscopic cholecystectomy at age 68 years.
5. Serum creatinine concentration on admission was 6.0 mg/dL.
6. Her current therapy includes a low-sodium, low-protein American Diabetes Association (ADA) diet, enalapril, and acetaminophen.
7. She is a retired seamstress.
8. She and her husband live on a farm 90 miles from the nearest dialysis facility.
question_options:
In considering longterm treatment options for this patient, which of the following is the most appropriate factor to consider?

A. Her eligibility to receive Medicare

B. Her history of an abdominal operation

C. Her history of arthritis

D. Her suitability for home dialysis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 12-year-old boy with sickle cell disease and type 1 diabetes mellitus is brought to the office by his mother for an initial visit.
2. The family recently moved to the area.
3. Type 1 diabetes mellitus was diagnosed in the patient 6 years ago.
4. Since that time, he has been treated with insulin and dietary management.
5. His insulin regimen has not changed during the past year; however, his mother says he has been only marginally compliant with his insulin and dietary regimens.
6. His diabetic diary shows home fingerstick blood glucose concentrations ranging from 140–200 mg/dL during the past 3 months.
7. He admits to checking his glucose concentrations infrequently.
8. Measurement of hemoglobin A1c obtained last week was 5.4%.
9. The patient's vital signs are temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse 72/min, respirations 24/min, and blood pressure 110/64 mm Hg.
10. Physical examination shows no abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the discrepancy between the patient's home fingerstick blood glucose concentrations and his hemoglobin A1c?

A. His daily glucose control is better than recorded

B. His glucometer is reading falsely high and should be replaced

C. His hemoglobin A1c is likely a result of laboratory error and should be repeated

D. His sickle cell disease is affecting his hemoglobin A1c

step1_excerpts:
1. A 24-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with left groin pain.
2. The pain started a year ago and has progressed.
3. He now has 8/10 pain when climbing stairs or rising from a seated position.
4. He localizes the pain to the front of his groin.
5. He denies any erythema or swelling.
6. He has a history of hypertension, sickle cell anemia, and a splenectomy.
7. He drinks a glass of wine with dinner every night and took up scuba diving 2 months ago but otherwise does not exercise.
8. His temperature is 97.5°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 124/68 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, and respirations are 16/min.
9. His body mass index (BMI) is 18.1 kg/m^2.
10. Physical exam reveals left groin pain at the terminal ranges of hip abduction and internal rotation.
11. There is no point tenderness.
12. A radiograph is obtained as in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following components of this patient’s history most strongly predisposed him to this condition?

A. Low BMI  
B. Scuba diving  
C. Alcohol use  
D. History of sickle cell disease

step1_excerpts:
1. A 32-year-old male with a history of end-stage liver disease secondary to alcoholic cirrhosis was transferred to our hospital with a 2-week history of a skin rash that developed at an outside facility where he was being treated for hepatic encephalopathy.
2. He reported that the lesions began on his face, then spread to his thighs and were mildly pruritic.
3. He did not have any other involvement and was in no pain.
4. On physical exam, multiple 1 to 3 cm purple papules with central black and hemorrhagic crusting were noted on his forehead, bilateral cheeks, and anterior thighs (Figure 1, A and B).
5. On his left flank, he had a large polycyclic, atrophic hyperpigmented plaque with a slightly erythematous and scaly border (Figure 1C).
6. The scalp, oral mucosa, back, chest, abdomen, arms, palms and soles were all spared.
7. Multiple toenails were noted to be dystrophic with hyperkeratotic subungual debris.
8. Over the next few days, the crusted papules and nodules eroded leaving smooth erythematous plaques with punched-out centers.
9. Testing for the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and hepatitis was negative.
10. Punch biopsy specimens from the left anterior thigh were taken for histopathologic analysis and fungal, bacterial, and atypical mycobacterial tissue cultures.
11. A skin culture was obtained of the polycyclic plaque on his left flank.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Kaposi sarcoma  
B: Disseminated tinea infection  
C: Bacillary angiomatosis  
D: Leukemia cutis

step1_excerpts:
1. A healthy man in his 60s presented with a 4-month history of blurred vision in his left eye.  
2. On examination, his visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/40 OS.  
3. Intraocular pressures were normal in each eye.  
4. Anterior segment and fundus examination results were normal in the right eye.  
5. In the left eye, the media were clear, and there were multiple patchy, yellow choroidal lesions with obliteration of the normal choroidal vasculature throughout the entire fundus (Figure 1A).  
6. There was no sign of vitritis or retinitis and no history of previous trauma, uveitis, sarcoidosis, or cancer.  
7. Ocular ultrasonography revealed diffuse ciliochoroidal thickening measuring 2.9 mm in elevation.  
8. Optical coherence tomography disclosed generalized, undulating choroidal infiltration in a seasick pattern, so to speak, given its resemblance to a stormy ocean surface, with overlying draping of the retina in the foveal region (Figure 1B).  
9. A relook at the anterior segment in the left eye revealed a faint conjunctival thickening at the limbus suggestive of lymphoid tumor.  
10. Incisional biopsy of the epibulbar lesion revealed sheetlike infiltration of small monomorphic lymphocytes with irregular nuclear contours and Dutcher bodies.  
11. Initiate an oral corticosteroid plus intravitreal anti–vascular endothelial growth factor therapy Administer topical interferon 4 times a day for 3 months Complete serum immunoglobulin level tests, DNA molecular analysis, and bone marrow biopsy
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Initiate an oral corticosteroid plus intravitreal anti–vascular endothelial growth factor therapy  
B: Administer topical interferon 4 times a day for 3 months  
C: Complete serum immunoglobulin level tests, DNA molecular analysis, and bone marrow biopsy  
D: Begin systemic intravenous rituximab

step1_excerpts:
1. A preadolescent girl presented to the pediatric ophthalmology clinic for evaluation and treatment of possible papilledema, discovered by an outside eye care professional during routine eye examination.
2. Aside from mild hyperopic astigmatism, there was no significant ocular, medical, or family history.
3. The patient denied any change in vision, scotomas, transient visual obscurations, dimming of light, photophobia, or pain.
4. She denied headache, pulsatile tinnitus, weight gain, joint pain, lethargy, decreased appetite, fever, or chills.
5. The patient was not taking any prescription or over-the-counter medicines; however, she had recently used a short-term course of oral antibiotics for a tooth infection.
6. On examination, Snellen visual acuity with correction was 20/20 OD and 20/25 OS.
7. Confrontation visual fields and ocular motility were normal.
8. External examination was unremarkable, and slitlamp examination revealed normal eyelids, conjunctiva, and sclera.
9. There were 1+ anterior chamber white blood cells and trace anterior vitreous cells bilaterally.
10. Posterior segment examination revealed 360° nerve hyperemia with elevation of nasal disc borders bilaterally (Figure 1), without vitreous haze, snowballs, or snowbanks.
11. There was no vascular sheathing, choroidal granulomas, or chorioretinal scarring in the periphery.
12. Fundus photography from initial consultation showing 360° nerve hyperemia with mild elevation of the nasal disc border bilaterally.
13. A, Right eye.
14. B, Left eye.
15. Serum and urine testing for various inflammatory and infectious processes
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Observation with close follow-up  
B: Lumbar puncture  
C: Serum and urine testing for various inflammatory and infectious processes  
D: Orbital and brain magnetic resonance imaging

step1_excerpts:
1. A 35-year-old man comes to the office for follow-up of sarcoidosis.
2. His only new complaint is pain in his legs that increases with weight-bearing.
3. He has been taking glucocorticoid therapy for the past 6 months.
4. Vital signs now are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 78/min, respirations 14/min, and blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg.
5. The patient is thin and is in no acute distress.
6. Auscultation of the chest discloses scattered bilateral basilar crackles.
7. There is mild left hip pain present with both active and passive range of motion.
8. Dorsalis pedis pulse is intact.
9. Neurologic examination is normal.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

A. Avascular necrosis of the femoral head

B. Herniated nucleus pulposus

C. Narrowing of the hip joint

D. Osteoporosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 20s presented with a 6-year history of multiple growing papules superimposed on an asymptomatic firm plaque on the occipital scalp.
2. The lesions were never ulcerated or inflamed, but hemorrhage occurred occasionally after rubbing.
3. At 3 years of age, scarlike macules appeared on the occipital scalp and coalesced to form a larger plaque with sparse hair.
4. Simultaneously, multiple brown-red, dome-shaped papules developed on the nose and gradually evolved to involve the cheeks.
5. Rubbery plaques also developed on the sacrococcygeal area, along with hypopigmented patches on the right buttock.
6. The patient has no systemic symptoms or mental impairment and denied a family history of genetic disease.
7. Physical examination revealed a group of unevenly distributed skin–colored-to-pink, discrete, coalescing papules superimposed on a firm plaque on the occipital scalp (Figure, A).
8. A biopsy specimen was obtained from one of these papules (Figure, B, C, and D).
9. Another biopsy from a facial papule demonstrated features of angiofibroma.
10. A, Clinical photograph shows a firm plaque with superimposed papules and decreased hair density.
11. Biopsy specimens from one of the papules demonstrate diffuse dense fibrosis (B), capillary vessel proliferation with some ectasia (C) (hematoxylin-eosin), and perifollicular fibroblastic proliferation (D).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Sclerotic neurofibroma  
B: Familial cutaneous collagenoma  
C: Shagreen patch  
D: Fibrous cephalic plaque

step1_excerpts:
1. A visually asymptomatic Hispanic man in his early 20s was referred to the vitreoretinal clinic for a posterior segment abnormality in his left eye found on routine ocular examination.  
2. The patient recalled that the lesion was initially discovered 4 years prior to presentation at a different facility.  
3. He denied any previous ocular trauma and his medical and surgical histories were noncontributory.  
4. Results of a complete review of systems were otherwise negative.  
5. At presentation, his visual acuity was 20/20 OU.  
6. Pupils and extraocular motility were intact.  
7. Intraocular pressures were 11 mm Hg OU.  
8. The anterior segment slitlamp examination was unremarkable in both eyes.  
9. A dilated retinal examination of the left eye revealed the findings depicted in the Figure, A.  
10. No retinal traction was noted.  
11. Spectral-domain optical coherence tomography was subsequently performed (Figure, B).  
12. No retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) atrophy, macular edema, retinal exudation, or subretinal fluid was noted.  
13. Posterior segment examination and imaging of the right eye demonstrated no abnormalities.  
14. A, Fundus photograph of the left eye demonstrating a nodular, darkly pigmented lesion with well-defined margins located inferonasal to the foveola.  
15. B, Spectral-domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT) image of the macula demonstrating an abruptly elevated retinal mass characterized by significant protrusion into the vitreous cavity with enhanced surface reflectivity and deep optical shadowing.  
16. Staging workup (eg, total-body positron emission tomography/computed tomography imaging)
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Genetic testing  
B: Observation with normal follow-up  
C: Surgical excision and histopathologic analysis  
D: Staging workup (eg, total-body positron emission tomography/computed tomography imaging)

step1_excerpts:
1. A 21-year-old woman presented with a 3-year history of progressive depression, bradyphrenia, dyscalculia, and fatigue, necessitating withdrawal from college.
2. She had an ovarian cyst, but her medical history was otherwise unremarkable.
3. There was no history of recreational drug use, tobacco or alcohol consumption, or sexually transmitted diseases.
4. Her mother had died at 32 years of age, after having a chronic neuropsychiatric illness, culminating in a rapidly progressive dementia.
5. A postmortem brain examination reported the presence of multitudinous corpora amylacea, but no specific neuropathological diagnosis was made.Neurologic examination of the patient during the initial consultation revealed a Mini-Mental State Examination score of 24 of 30 (points were missed on attention, calculation, and abstraction), and the patient was abulic, but it was otherwise unremarkable.
6. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain showed scattered small foci of T2 hyperintensity in the white matter affecting the corpus callosum, bifrontal, and biparietal regions, associated with bifrontal and bitemporal atrophy (Figure1A).
7. No lesions were identified in the cerebellum or brainstem.
8. There was no abnormal enhancement.
9. Laboratory investigations including complete blood cell count with differential; electrolytes; liver, renal, and thyroid function tests; vitamin B12 and folate levels; vitamin E; cholesterol and triglycerides; amino acids (serum and urine); syphilis and human immunodeficiency virus serologies; a paraneoplastic panel; and erythrocyte sedimentation rate were unrevealing.
10. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis showed a slight protein elevation, but no pleocytosis, oligoclonal bands, or elevated immunoglobulin G synthesis rate.
11. Arylsulfatase activity was normal.A, Axial T2 sequence showing bifrontal cerebral convexity sulcal enlargement greater than expected for patient's age, punctate bifrontal subcortical fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) hyperintense foci (right greater than left) are noted.
12. B, Brain magnetic resonance imaging axial and coronal T2 FLAIR sequence showing more pronounced global cerebral atrophy, progression of the subcortical FLAIR hyperintense lesions in the frontal predominant distribution, and also affecting the periventricular and deep white matter into the subcortical areas.
13. Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy  
B: Adrenoleukodystrophy  
C: Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes  
D: Hereditary diffuse leukoencephalopathy with axonal spheroids

step1_excerpts:
1. A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department 1 hour after sudden-onset weakness and double vision.
2. His medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia and poorly controlled hypertension.
3. His current medications include atorvastatin and amlodipine.
4. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure is 175/95 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min.
5. On cranial nerve exam, his left pupil is 6 mm in diameter compared to 3 mm on the right.
6. His left eye is displaced laterally and downward and he also has left-sided ptosis.
7. Strength is 2/5 in the right upper and right lower extremities and 5/5 in the left upper and left lower extremities.
8. He has marked right-sided dysdiadochokinesia.
9. Sensation is intact throughout.
question_options:
Which of the following regions of his brain is most likely affected?

A. Lateral medulla  
B. Lateral pons  
C. Posterior limb of internal capsule  
D. Midbrain

step1_excerpts:
1. A 60-year-old man had a total thyroidectomy and excision of enlarged left jugular lymph nodes for follicular carcinoma.
2. The operation was uncomplicated.
3. He is receiving intravenous 5% dextrose and 0.45% saline with potassium.
4. Twelve hours after the operation he develops circumoral numbness and paresthesias in his fingertips, and he becomes very anxious.
5. Vital signs are temperature 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse 90/min, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 140/90 mm Hg.
6. Physical examination discloses a dry neck dressing and no stridor.
7. Extremities are warm, with brisk capillary refill time.
question_options:
Additional physical examination is most likely to show which of the following?

A. Babinski sign present bilaterally

B. Chvostek sign

C. Deviation of the tongue to the left side

D. A drooping left shoulder

step1_excerpts:
1. A 65-year-old male patient seeks medical attention for episodes of retrosternal pain and dyspnea occurring over the past 10 days.
2. These symptoms manifest during stair climbing or brisk treadmill walking and subside with rest.
3. The previous night, he experienced dizziness and weakness during one such episode.
4. He reports having had a cold 2 weeks prior.
5. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 4 years ago, managed with glyburide.
6. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing patient with a weak pulse of 62/min, respiratory rate of 20/min, and blood pressure of 134/90 mm Hg.
7. A late systolic ejection murmur is detected at the second right intercostal space during cardiovascular examination.
8. Lung auscultation is normal.
question_options:
What is the most likely pathophysiologic mechanism causing this patient's clinical presentation?

A. Microvascular dysfunction  
B. Impaired diastolic relaxation  
C. Increased left ventricular oxygen demand  
D. Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction  
E. Narrowing of the coronary arterial lumen  
F. Endothelial dysfunction due to diabetes  
G. Decreased coronary perfusion pressure  
H. Coronary artery vasospasm  
I. Autonomic dysfunction affecting coronary blood flow  
J. Lymphocytic infiltration of the myocardium

step1_excerpts:
1. A 27-year-old G1P0000 woman presents to her obstetrician’s office at 24 weeks gestation complaining of new hair growth on her upper lip.
2. She now needs to shave her face every day or else thick hair appears.
3. She also has worsening acne that started several weeks ago.
4. Her pregnancy thus far has been complicated by gestational diabetes, which is managed by diet and exercise.
5. She has a male fetus based on her 20 week anatomy ultrasound.
6. The patient has a medical history of polycystic ovary syndrome.
7. The patient’s temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 121/76 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 13/min.
8. The cardiopulmonary exam is normal, and the patient’s abdomen has a fundal height of 31 cm.
9. A pelvic exam reveals an unremarkable closed cervix and a right-sided adnexal mass without tenderness.
10. Transvaginal ultrasound is performed and shown in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Spironolactone to treat hirsutism and acne  
B. Laparoscopy to remove a malignancy  
C. Reassurance  
D. Percutaneous umbilical blood sampling to determine prognosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician for genetic counseling prior to conception.
2. Her brother and maternal uncle had Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) and died at the ages of 28 and 17 years, respectively.
3. Genetic analysis was not performed on either relative prior to death.
4. Serum studies show a muscle creatine kinase concentration of 120 U/L (N=22– 198).
5. The patient's 50-year-old mother has a serum muscle creatine kinase concentration of 300 U/L.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate assessment of this patient's carrier status for this disease?

A. The patient has a 50% risk of having a child with DMD

B. The patient is a carrier of the disease based on her family history of DMD

C. The patient is not a carrier of the DMD based on her normal creatine kinase concentration

D. The patient's DMD carrier status is uncertain because of random X inactivation

step1_excerpts:
1. A 3-year-old is brought to the GP as he has been walking funny the last month and also has started to limp the previous week.
2. He has had some bluish nodules in the skin previous two months.
3. Otherwise, he has been doing well.
4. Growing and developing typically.
5. Has not had any hospitalizations, no surgeries—vaccines up to date.
6. In the examination, the child seems well in general, but he is limping on the R leg.
7. His vitals are normal, indicating healthy growth and BP and pulse.
8. No pain in the examination.
9. There are 3-4 raised, well defined dark lesions almost bluish on the back of the child; they vary from 0.5-1 cm in diameter and do not seem to be tender.
question_options:
Choose the best option:

A. Elevated catecholamine metabolites are not typically seen in this condition  
B. Leg weakness and limping are not related to bluish skin nodules in this child  
C. VMA and HVA levels are useful in diagnosis and follow up for response to treatment in these patients  
D. The skin nodules suggest a benign dermatological condition unrelated to the limp  
E. The child’s symptoms are most consistent with an infectious etiology affecting the musculoskeletal system  
F. Imaging studies are unnecessary as the diagnosis can be confirmed clinically  
G. This is a tumor that is one of the less common solid tumors outside of the central nervous system in children  
H. Best prognosis is in children that are 2 years old and above  
I. This child is having a tumor originating in the bladder  
J. This is likely a vascular malformation unrelated to systemic disease

step1_excerpts:
1. A 15-year-old girl with no prior medical conditions seeks medical attention for increasing upper back pain and muscle tightness, which has worsened since joining her school's gymnastics team.  
2. During the osteopathic structural examination, the following findings are noted: left midthoracic paraspinal muscles are hypertonic, and the transverse processes from T2 to T8 are more anterior on the left side.  
3. These findings remain consistent during both flexion and extension movements.
question_options:
What is the most accurate diagnosis?

A. T2-8 NSRRR  
B. T2-8 ESRRR  
C. T2-8 FSRRL  
D. T2-8 FSLRR  
E. T2-8 NSRLL  
F. T2-8 ESRRL  
G. T2-8 FSRRR  
H. T2-8 NSLRR  
I. T2-8 NSRRL  
J. T2-8 ESLRR

step1_excerpts:
1. A preschool-age girl presented for evaluation of an asymptomatic plaque on the right lower extremity that had been present for 1 year.
2. Prior treatments included triamcinolone ointment and frankincense with no improvement.
3. A potassium hydroxide preparation had negative results for fungal elements.
4. Her medical history and family history were unremarkable.
5. An examination found a 1-cm nummular plaque with centralized micaceous scale and a smooth erythematous border on the right lateral lower leg (Figure, A).
6. A tangential-shave biopsy was performed to characterize the lesion.
7. Histopathological testing revealed an epidermis featuring elongated rete ridges, keratinocyte enlargement, and a few Civatte bodies, with overlying parakeratotic crust and neutrophilic cell debris.
8. Marked epidermotropism of atypical lymphocytes with irregular nuclear contours and halos, both singly and in small collections (Pautrier microabscesses) were also observed (Figure, B and C).
9. Also, lymphocytes were present along the epidermal side of the dermoepidermal junction.
10. Periodic acid–Schiff stained sections failed to show fungal or yeast elements.
11. Immunohistochemical staining was markedly positive for CD3, CD5, and CD8 (Figure, D); CD4 reactivity was less robust and mainly restricted to dermal lymphocytes.
12. Also, CD20 was present in 5% of dermal lymphocytes, and CD30 showed variable staining of 5% of lymphocytes.A, Image of a solitary plaque on the right lateral lower leg.
13. B, Scanning view with hyperkeratosis, epidermal hyperplasia, and a lichenoid-like lymphoid infiltrate (hematoxylin-eosin).
14. C, Biopsy results with marked epidermotropism of atypical lymphocytes (hematoxylin-eosin).
15. D, Biopsy results with robust CD8 signal (magnification ×100).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Langerhans cell histiocytosis  
B: Lymphomatoid contact dermatitis  
C: Mycosis fungoides  
D: Pagetoid reticulosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 44-year-old woman with a 10-year history of arthritis comes to the office because she has had increasing pain and stiffness in her hands, wrists, and knees during the past several months.
2. She also has had increasing fatigue for the past month, along with a weight loss of 1.8 to 2.2 kg (4 to 5 lb).
3. She has seen numerous physicians for her arthritis in the past and has tried various medications and devices, including copper bracelets from Mexico given to her by friends.
4. Review of her medical records confirms that the initial diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis is correct.
5. She says, "I had several drop attacks during the past 3 months." She characterizes these attacks as episodes of weakness and loss of feeling in her legs for several minutes.
6. During one of these episodes, she became incontinent.
7. She currently takes aspirin approximately four times daily and ibuprofen occasionally.
8. Physical examination shows facial plethora and swollen and painful metacarpophalangeal and knee joints, bilaterally.
9. There is moderate ulnar deviation of the fingers.
10. The remainder of the examination discloses no abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely cause of her "drop attacks?"

A. Adrenal insufficiency

B. Anxiety

C. Atlanto-axial instability

D. Cardiac arrhythmia

step1_excerpts:
1. A 46-year-old man presented with a left shoulder mass.
2. It began with a quarter-size maculopapular lesion and continued to progress during the next 3 years.
3. He reported limited shoulder movements and denied other symptoms.
4. There was no medical or surgical history, and he had a negative personal or familial oncologic history.
5. The patient was a construction worker and used tobacco daily.
6. On physical examination, there was a 24 × 15-cm fungating, necrotic, and ulcerated left shoulder mass (Figure 1A).
7. A punch biopsy showed sheets of highly pleomorphic atypical spindle and epithelial cells within the superficial and deep dermis, extending into the subcutaneous tissue, and with 18 mitoses/mm2.
8. Immunohistochemistry demonstrated SOX10-positive and pankeratin-negative tumor cells.
9. A whole-body positron emission tomographic and computed tomographic scan revealed an intensely hypermetabolic left shoulder mass and multiple hypermetabolic enlarged left axillary lymph nodes, with no distant metastases (Figure 1B).
10. Brain magnetic resonance imaging was negative for intracranial metastasis.A, Left shoulder giant fungating mass in a 46-year-old man.
11. B, Positron emission tomographic and computed tomographic (PET-CT) scan shows the hypermetabolic left shoulder mass and no distant metastases.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Squamous cell carcinoma  
B: Basal cell carcinoma  
C: Melanoma  
D: Merkel cell carcinoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A previously healthy 27-year-old man comes to the physician 4 weeks after noticing three nontender lesions on his penis.
2. He says they have not changed in size.
3. He is sexually active with multiple male and female partners and uses condoms inconsistently.
4. He takes no medications.
5. He drinks two to five beers on social occasions.
6. He occasionally smokes marijuana.
7. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F).
8. There is no lymphadenopathy.
9. Examination shows three sessile, flesh-colored lesions on the shaft of the penis that are 10 mm in diameter.
10. On application of a dilute solution of acetic acid, the lesions turn white.
11. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Oral acyclovir therapy

B. Oral doxycycline therapy

C. Intramuscular penicillin therapy

D. Cryotherapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 56-year-old male patient presents with severe right leg pain and swelling four days after undergoing a craniotomy with evacuation of a subdural hematoma.
2. He experiences chills and nausea.
3. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease requiring hemodialysis for the past 2 years.
4. His pre-admission medications included insulin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and sevelamer.
5. On examination, his temperature is 38.3°C (101.0°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg.
6. The right calf appears swollen, warm, and erythematous.
7. Pain is elicited in the right calf upon dorsiflexion of the right foot.
8. Peripheral pulses are palpable bilaterally, and cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

A. Surgical thrombectomy  
B. Inferior vena cava filter  
C. Unfractionated heparin therapy  
E. Aspirin therapy only  
F. Prophylactic antibiotics for cellulitis  
G. Oral warfarin therapy  
H. Compression stockings and observation  
J. Low molecular weight heparin therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 15-year-old adolescent girl who was taking an oral contraceptive presented to the emergency department with left lower quadrant abdominal pain that had developed gradually over a 3-day period.
2. She had no associated nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, hematochezia, bloating, or anorexia.
3. She reported no precipitating factors for the pain and had no history of pregnancy, abdominal surgery, or abdominal trauma.
4. Over the previous 2 years, the patient had experienced similar intermittent episodes of abdominal pain lasting approximately 1 week.
5. Results from laboratory tests, upper endoscopy, colonoscopy, and an abdominal computed tomography scan performed 1 year prior to presentation were normal.In the emergency department, her vital signs were normal and her body mass index was 20.4 (calculated as weight in kilograms divided by the square of height in meters).
6. Abdominal examination revealed no rigidity or guarding; however, a 1-cm point of maximal tenderness was identified in the left lower abdominal quadrant (Figure).
7. During palpation of this 1-cm area, the pain increased when she lifted her head and tensed her abdominal muscles.
8. She experienced cold hypoesthesia when an alcohol gauze pad was applied to this area and severe pain when the skin was pinched.Point of maximal tenderness (black “X”), confined to an area no larger than a fingertip on the left side of the abdomen.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Administer gabapentin  
B: Assess celiac artery flow  
C: Inject a local anesthetic into the area of maximal tenderness  
D: Measure urine porphobilinogen level

step1_excerpts:
1. A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath that he experienced while barbecuing.
2. The pain is over his chest and in his left arm.
3. The patient has a medical history of obesity, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension.
4. His current medications include insulin, metformin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide.
5. An ECG is performed and is seen in Figure A.
6. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air.
7. The patient is appropriately managed and is admitted to the step-down unit.
8. 2 days later, he complains of chest pain.
9. A repeat ECG is performed and is seen in Figure B.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient's underlying condition?

A. Prednisone  
B. Aspirin  
C. Stenting  
D. Ibuprofen

step1_excerpts:
1. At birth, a full-term newborn was noted to have numerous hypopigmented skin macules on the trunk, scalp, neck, face, back, and limbs after an uncomplicated pregnancy (Figure 1A).
2. The family history was negative for any dermatologic or genetic diseases.
3. A shave biopsy specimen of the right leg was interpreted as papillomatous epidermal hyperplasia consistent with an epidermal nevus.
4. Because of the constellation of findings, an initial diagnosis of linear epidermal nevus syndrome was made.
5. At age 3 months, the patient was referred for ophthalmologic examination owing to a flat, hypopigmented lesion in the left temporal iris noted by the patient’s father.
6. On examination, the patient fixed and followed with both eyes.
7. Pupils, motility, and binocular alignment were normal.
8. Dilated ophthalmoscopic examination revealed a well-demarcated hypopigmented lesion originating from the retinal nerve fiber layer and protruding into the vitreous cavity of the right eye (Figure 1B).
9. A similar lesion was seen along the left inferotemporal arcade (Figure 1C).
10. B-scan ultrasonography revealed a 4.0 × 2.9 × 2.2-mm lesion with no calcification, no retinal detachment, and no choroidal involvement (Figure 1D).
11. Given the suspected iris hamartoma and retinal astrocytic hamartoma, a systemic workup was commenced.A, Dermatologic manifestations.
12. The patient had multiple hypopigmented macules on his scalp, face, neck, back, limbs, and torso (arrowheads).
13. B, A lesion was discovered in the right eye consistent with a retinal astrocytic hamartoma.
14. C, A similar smaller lesion was seen in the left eye.
15. D, B-scan ultrasonography revealed an elevated lesion emanating from the retina with no calcification or choroidal involvement.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Renal ultrasonography and lumbar puncture  
B: Brain imaging and echocardiography  
C: Metastatic workup  
D: Fine-needle aspiration biopsy of ocular lesion

step1_excerpts:
1. A 3-year-old boy with no significant medical history is evaluated for dehydration and refusal to eat or drink.  
2. Seven days ago, he developed a fever of 38.9°C, which resolved within 2 days.  
3. As the fever resolved, the child’s mother noticed fluid-filled bumps on his tongue and in his mouth.  
4. The bumps have spread and seem to be causing pain.  
5. The child is currently afebrile with mild tachycardia for his age and a capillary refill of about 2 seconds.  
6. He has dry mucous membranes and halitosis.  
7. Many painful, shallow ulcerations are evident on his tongue, buccal mucosa, and gingiva with areas of crusting, and there is tender submandibular lymphadenopathy.  
8. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.
question_options:
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

A. Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis  
B. Hand, foot, and mouth disease  
C. Erythema multiforme  
D. Stevens-Johnson syndrome  
E. Herpetic gingivostomatitis  
F. Viral pharyngitis with secondary bacterial infection  
G. Recurrent aphthous stomatitis  
H. Acute lymphonodular pharyngitis  
I. Herpangina  
J. Candidal stomatitis

step1_excerpts:
1. A Chinese woman in her late 20s presented with a 20-year history of progressive skin laxity.  
2. In early childhood, she had developed asymptomatic yellowish coalesced papules confined to flexural areas.  
3. Subsequently, severe skin sagging occurred on her abdomen with loss of elasticity, then spread extensively with developmental growth.  
4. The results of a physical examination showed thick and leathery skinfolds on the neck, axillae, inguinal regions, abdomen, and limbs (Figure, A), with yellowish papules scattered on the dorsal neck.  
5. The patient had no extracutaneous involvement and was born to healthy nonconsanguineous parents.  
6. However, her younger sister had developed the same skin symptoms.  
7. Coagulation-related tests indicated a low clotting activity of factor X (52.2%; reference range, 77%-131%) and a prolonged prothrombin time (12.8 seconds; reference range, 10.4-12.6 seconds).  
8. The results of other laboratory investigations were unremarkable.  
9. Echocardiographic and fundoscopic examination results were normal.  
10. A skin biopsy specimen was obtained from her neck for histopathologic examination (Figure, B).A, Clinical image of the neck, axillae, and abdomen.  
11. Severe skin laxity with deep cutaneous folds on the cervical, axillary, and abdominal regions.  
12. B, Skin biopsy specimen taken from the neck shows excessive calcification of elastic fiber fragments scattered in the reticular dermis (von Kossa).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Pseudoxanthoma elasticum  
B: Inherited cutis laxa syndrome  
C: Pseudoxanthoma elasticum–like disorder with coagulation deficiency  
D: Pseudoxanthoma elasticum/pseudoxanthoma elasticum–like overlap syndrome

step1_excerpts:
1. A 71-year-old woman with non-Hodgkin lymphoma receiving maintenance obinutuzumab (anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody) infusions underwent uneventful pars plana vitrectomy of the right eye for vitreomacular traction.  
2. Diluted triamcinolone acetonide (TA) was used to stain the posterior hyaloid.  
3. After removal of 25-gauge trocar cannulas, subconjunctival TA and ceftazidime was injected.  
4. Owing to cystoid changes in the central macula, a short-acting gas tamponade with sulfur hexafluoride was used to tamponade any cystoid abnormalities that may have been unroofed.  
5. Despite unremarkable postoperative day 1 (POD1) examination findings, the patient presented on postoperative week 3 with a painless central scotoma and worsening floaters.  
6. Her visual acuity was 20/400 OD and intraocular pressure was normal.  
7. There was no external hyperemia or chemosis, and the anterior chamber was deep and quiet with no cells or flare.  
8. On dilated fundus examination, there were 15 to 20 cells per high-power field (using a 1 × 1-mm2 high-intensity incidental slit beam) and a white macular lesion with disc edema and scattered intraretinal and peripapillary hemorrhages and mixed venous and arterial sheathing.  
9. Optical coherence tomography of the macula showed atrophy, full-thickness hyperreflectivity, and a residual epiretinal membrane (Figure).  
10. Color fundus photograph (A) of the right eye demonstrating white macular lesion and optic disc edema with scattered intraretinal and peripapillary hemorrhages and vascular sheathing (white arrowheads).  
11. The dashed yellow line shows the location of spectral-domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT) (B), which shows full-thickness hyperreflectivity and atrophy, epiretinal membrane (yellow arrowheads), and vitreous cells and debris (red arrowheads).  
12. Perform vitreous tap and injection of intravitreal antibiotics Review medical records to see if gentamicin was given intraoperatively Urgently refer patient to emergency department for embolic stroke workup Begin valganciclovir hydrochloride therapy and sample intraocular fluid for polymerase chain reaction testing
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform vitreous tap and injection of intravitreal antibiotics  
B: Review medical records to see if gentamicin was given intraoperatively  
C: Urgently refer patient to emergency department for embolic stroke workup  
D: Begin valganciclovir hydrochloride therapy and sample intraocular fluid for polymerase chain reaction testing

step1_excerpts:
1. A 67-year-old man visits his primary care provider reporting burning sensations, numbness, and tingling in his left thigh.
2. He notes that these symptoms worsen with light touch, making even wearing jeans uncomfortable.
3. The symptoms began approximately one month ago and have progressively intensified.
4. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, managed with oral antidiabetics and insulin (both long-acting and mealtime).
5. His vital signs show: temperature 98.4°F, blood pressure 140/90 mmHg, pulse 92/min, respiratory rate 15/min, and BMI 35.5 kg/m2.
6. Physical examination reveals intact, clean, and dry skin on the lower extremities.
7. A 4.5 x 2.5-cm area on the anterolateral left thigh shows diminished sensation to both light touch and pinprick.
8. The bilateral plantar surfaces of both feet demonstrate symmetric decreased pinprick sensation.
9. Muscle strength testing shows 5/5 in bilateral hip, knee, and ankle.
10. Deep tendon reflexes are +1 bilaterally, and straight leg raise testing is negative.
question_options:
What is the most probable mechanism causing the patient's upper leg paresthesia?

A. Obturator nerve compression at the obturator canal  
B. Microvascular ischemia of vasa nervorum  
C. Peripheral entrapment by inguinal ligament  
D. Radiculopathy of L3-L4 nerve roots  
E. Femoral nerve entrapment at the iliacus tunnel  
F. Sciatic nerve compression at the piriformis muscle  
G. Compression of lateral femoral cutaneous nerve by adipose tissue  
H. Direct nerve compression by herniated disc  
I. Inflammatory demyelination of peripheral nerves  
J. Diabetic polyradiculopathy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 51-year-old man diagnosed as having acute promyelocytic leukemia, undergoing induction therapy with all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA) and arsenic trioxide that were started 2 weeks prior, presented with sudden loss of vision.
2. Hospital course was complicated by neutropenic fever, receiving cefepime, acyclovir, vancomycin, and voriconazole for prophylaxis.
3. Laboratory test results were remarkable for pancytopenia.
4. On initial examination, his visual acuity was count fingers at 3 ft in both eyes.
5. Intraocular pressures were 10 mm Hg OD and 11 mm Hg OS.
6. Pupils were round and reactive without a relative afferent pupillary defect.
7. Color plates were 1 of 8 OU, with 50% brightness desaturation in the right eye and no red desaturation.
8. Extraocular movements were full.
9. Slitlamp examination was negative for any signs of inflammation.
10. Dilated fundus examination demonstrated bilateral choroidal effusions with diffuse serous retinal detachments (RD) involving the macula without vitritis as well as white centered intraretinal hemorrhages along peripapillary and superior and inferior arcade distributions in both eyes (Figure, A).
11. Optical coherence tomography demonstrated irregular inner retinal surface and subretinal fluid with septae with loss of the ellipsoid zone (Figure, B).
12. Review of systems was positive for fever, tachycardia, odynophagia, productive cough with wheezing, and marked peripheral edema in upper extremities and negative for headache, nausea, vomiting, dysacusis, meningismus, or skin changes.Fundus photographs and optical coherence tomography 4 days from presentation demonstrating bilateral choroidal effusions with serous retinal detachment and white centered intraretinal hemorrhages.
13. Left eye results shown.
14. A, Left eye color fundus photograph demonstrates peripheral choroidal effusion with areas of stippled subretinal fluid in the macula, areas of intraretinal hemorrhages scattered throughout the posterior pole as well as far temporal periphery.
15. B, Optical coherence tomography of the left eye demonstrating corrugated inner retina with intraretinal and subretinal fluid with septae from further separation of the external limiting membrane and ellipsoid zone as well as some loss of the ellipsoid zone.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Continue chemotherapy therapy and observe  
B: Order magnetic resonance imaging of brain and orbits with and without contrast and lumbar puncture  
C: Stop the ATRA and start steroids  
D: Send HLA-B51 and start steroids

step1_excerpts:
1. A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 4-month history of chest pain that occurs on exertion.
2. The pain is dull, and she has retrosternal pressure when she walks up the stairs to her apartment on the fifth floor.
3. The pain disappears shortly after stopping for one minute.
4. She has hypertension, for which she takes lisinopril and metoprolol daily.
5. She does not smoke or drink alcohol.
6. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2.
7. Her pulse is 72/min and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg.
8. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
9. Fasting lipid studies show:




| Total cholesterol | 196 mg/dL |
| --- | --- |
| LDL | 110 mg/dL |
| HDL | 50 mg/dL |


A resting ECG shows no abnormalities.
10. A week after uneventful initiation of aspirin, the patient is started on atorvastatin.
question_options:
This patient is most likely to develop which of the following adverse effects?

A. Myositis  
B. QT prolongation  
C. Peripheral neuropathy  
D. Rhabdomyolysis  
E. Hyperkalemia  
F. Acute kidney injury  
G. Elevated transaminases  
H. Drug-induced lupus  
I. Bloating  
J. Pancreatitis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and stage 4 chronic kidney disease reports that he completely lost vision in his right eye shortly after waking up this morning.
2. He had no pain at the time and gradually regained his vision about one hour after the initial loss.
3. His current blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 75 beats per minute.
4. His vision appears normal on visual-acuity and visual-field testing.
5. He has a normal head and neck examination without carotid bruits.
6. He has no murmurs, and his lungs are clear to auscultation.
7. He has a normal neurologic examination, including normal strength and sensation.
8. Laboratory results are notable for a creatinine concentration of 3.3.
9. mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3).
10. He has a normal electrocardiogram.
11. CT of the brain without contrast shows no abnormalities.
question_options:
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate to further evaluate this patient’s vision loss?

A. Serum homocysteine level measurement  
B. Retinal fluorescein angiography  
C. CT angiogram of the brain  
D. Visual evoked potential testing  
E. Transcranial Doppler ultrasound  
F. Magnetic resonance angiogram of the brain with gadolinium  
G. Electroretinography  
H. Dilated ophthalmoscopy  
I. Echocardiography with bubble study  
J. Carotid Doppler ultrasound

step1_excerpts:
1. A 44-year-old White man presented with a 15-year history of dull midline lower back pain associated with bilateral hip pain.
2. He also noted bilateral hand pain along the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints and prolonged morning stiffness lasting approximately 45 minutes.
3. Family history was notable for a brother with osteoarthritis, hypogonadism, and type 2 diabetes.
4. Vital signs were within normal limits (heart rate, 92/min; blood pressure, 136/84 mm Hg; respiratory rate, 16/min; oxygen saturation, 97%; temperature, 37.0 °C).
5. Musculoskeletal examination revealed swelling of the second, third, and fifth MCP joints and second and third PIP joints bilaterally as well as decreased knee and hip range of motion with minimal knee effusions.
6. Lower back flexion was decreased with only 4-mm excursion on the modified Schober test.
7. Results of cardiopulmonary, abdominal, neurologic, and dermatologic examinations were unremarkable.
8. Results of laboratory testing, including complete blood cell count, basic metabolic panel, and liver function tests, were within normal limits, and results for HLA-B27 were negative.
9. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 8 mm/h and C-reactive protein level was 0.5 mg/dL.
10. A plain radiograph of the hands (Figure, left panel) showed hook-like osteophytes at the second and third MCP joints bilaterally as well as asymmetric joint swelling in multiple MCP and PIP joints.
11. A plain radiograph of the pelvis (Figure, right panel) showed sclerosis and joint narrowing at both sacroiliac joints as well as joint narrowing and osteophytes in the hip joints bilaterally.
12. Plain radiographs of the hands and pelvis at presentation.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Check ferritin and transferrin saturation  
B: Check rheumatoid factor (RF)  
C: Order magnetic resonance imaging of the sacroiliac joint  
D: Refer for surgical consultation

step1_excerpts:
1. A 26-year-old man arrives at the emergency department with complaints of fatigue and dark-colored urine over the past day.
2. He was recently prescribed trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for cellulitis of his left leg.
3. He denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea and has no significant medical history or current medications.
4. His vital signs include a temperature of 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure of 115/72 mmHg, pulse of 98/min, and respiratory rate of 14/min.
5. On examination, there is conjunctival icterus, bilateral flank tenderness, and left leg erythema.
question_options:
What is the most likely finding on this patient’s peripheral blood smear?

A. Acanthocytes  
B. Sickle cells  
C. Degmacytes  
D. Heinz bodies  
E. Target cells  
F. Howell-Jolly bodies  
G. Codocytes  
H. Elliptocytes  
I. Spherocytes  
J. Schistocytes

step1_excerpts:
1. A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department with dizziness.
2. He states he has a constant sensation that the room is spinning.
3. He is now having trouble walking and has been vomiting intermittently.
4. He has no past medical history and takes no medications.
5. His temperature is 98.0°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
6. Physical exam reveals a young man who is vomiting.
7. His gait is ataxic and he exhibits rightward nystagmus.
8. His dizziness is constant and unchanged with performance of the Dix-Hallpike maneuver.
9. The head impulse test reveals a corrective saccade and there is no skew deviation.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Prednisone  
B. Epley maneuver  
C. MRI brain  
D. CT head

step1_excerpts:
1. A 59-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for trouble sleeping.
2. When she goes to bed at night, she has an urge to get up out of bed and walk around.
3. The patient often wakes her husband when she does this which irritates him.
4. There is a perpetual uneasiness and feeling of a need to move at night which is relieved by getting up and walking around.
5. The patient denies symptoms during the day.
6. She works as a mail carrier and is nearing retirement.
7. She has a medical history of anxiety, depression, irritable bowel syndrome, and dysmenorrhea.
8. She is not currently taking any medications.
9. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 157/98 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
10. Physical exam reveals 5/5 strength in the upper and lower extremities, 2+ reflexes in the upper and lower extremities, a stable gait pattern, and normal sensation.
11. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are within normal limits.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

A. Alprazolam  
B. Iron studies  
C. Pramipexole  
D. Supportive therapy and an exercise routine

step1_excerpts:
1. A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with pain upon defecation.
2. His symptoms started a few weeks ago but have been worsening.
3. Sometimes he notes blood on the toilet paper.
4. He has to strain to have bowel movements and has trouble defecating secondary to pain.
5. He is generally healthy and does not smoke.
6. The patient is a software engineer and enjoys hiking, going to nightclubs, and dancing.
7. His temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 112/83 mmHg, pulse is 83/min, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
8. Physical exam reveals a small, superficial fissure that is lateral to the anus and lateral to the midline.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A. Testing for HIV, fecal occult blood, and sexually transmitted diseases  
B. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis  
C. Surgical excision  
D. Topical lidocaine, sitz baths, and fiber supplements

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 40s with a history of sinusitis presented with a 2-month history of worsening pain and redness of the right eye and nasal congestion.  
2. He was previously diagnosed with conjunctivitis and treated empirically with artificial tears, ofloxacin drops (0.3%), and prednisolone acetate drops (1%) 4 times a day, without improvement.  
3. His visual acuity was 20/20 OD.  
4. Examination findings of the anterior segment of the right eye revealed a raised, nonmobile, engorged perilimbal nodule in the inferotemporal sclera that was tender to palpation and did not blanch with phenylephrine drops (2.5%) (Figure, A).  
5. The ultrasonogram demonstrated a noncystic, regular, dome-shaped lesion with medium to high reflectivity localized to the sclera without intraocular involvement (Figure, B).  
6. The remaining results of the right-eye examination and the entire left-eye examination were within the reference range.  
7. In addition, the patient had a right-sided intranasal mass.  
8. A, Slitlamp photograph of the patient’s right eye at presentation.  
9. B, Anterior segment ultrasonography of the right eye at presentation.  
10. Laboratory test results demonstrated elevated inflammatory markers, with an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 38 mm/h (reference range, 0-20 mm/h) and a C-reactive protein level of 190 mg/L (reference range, 0.08-3.1 mg/L) (to convert to nanomoles per liter, multiply by 9.524).  
11. Results of serum antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA), rheumatoid factor, antinuclear antibody, angiotensin-converting enzyme, fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption, rapid plasma reagin, and tuberculosis skin testing were within their reference ranges.  
12. Results of urine microscopy had 4+ red blood cells per high-power field.  
13. His blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels were within their reference ranges.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Increase topical corticosteroid frequency  
B: Inject sub–Tenon capsule triamcinolone acetonide  
C: Give oral prednisone  
D: Refer to otolaryngologist for nasal mass biopsy

step1_excerpts:
1. A Japanese man in his 50s presented with a 6-month history of worsening pruritic hand dermatitis that progressed to involve his face, trunk, upper extremities, and feet.
2. He had emigrated from Japan more than 10 years earlier but had no history of recent travel.
3. He took no medications, had no significant medical or surgical history, and denied personal and family history of atopy.
4. While he worked as a biomedical researcher, he denied any caustic exposures.
5. On physical examination, his face, trunk, upper extremities, palms, and soles were marked by 1- to 2-mm erythematous papules and pustules coalescing into large, partially indurated and polycyclic plaques with centrifugal extension and occasional central clearing (Figure, A and B).
6. Treatment with potent topical corticosteroids was ineffective.
7. Punch biopsies of lesions on the shoulder (Figure, C) and foot (Figure, D) were performed.A, Annular erythematous plaque studded with papules and pustules on the cheek and temple.
8. B, Erythematous plaques studded with papules and pustules on the shoulder.
9. C and D, Lesional specimens under hematoxylin-eosin stain taken from the shoulder (C, original magnification ×400) and plantar foot (D, original magnification ×40).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Folliculotropic mycosis fungoides  
B: Papulopustular rosacea  
C: Eosinophilic pustular folliculitis  
D: Majocchi granuloma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 33-year-old male physician reports for a shift in the emergency department.
2. A nurse alerts you that he noticed a faint odor of alcohol near the physician.
3. When approached, the physician appears tired and more disheveled than usual.
4. There is an odor of alcohol on his breath.
5. He is a skilled and talented physician with no known history of substance or alcohol use disorder.
6. He is married with three children, and his wife is pregnant with twins.
7. The physician was recently hired and has had no actions on his license by any state medical board.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

A. Ask the physician if he is sober, and if he says yes, allow him to complete his shift

B. Explain to the physician that you suspect he is intoxicated and ask him to submit to a blood sample to check his blood alcohol concentration

C. Relieve the physician of duty and alert the hospital's patient safety officer

D. Tell the physician that you can cover the remainder of the shift alone, so that he can sleep in his office

step1_excerpts:
1. A 34-year-old G1P1 woman at 36 weeks of gestation attends a routine prenatal visit with no specific complaints.
2. Her medical history includes mild asthma controlled with a rescue albuterol inhaler and a large submucosal uterine leiomyoma surgically removed via open myomectomy two years ago.
3. She has received regular prenatal care but missed some appointments during the second trimester.
4. Her temperature is 99.0°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 136/79 mmHg, pulse is 91/min, and respirations are 18/min.
5. She experiences mild shortness of breath while speaking, but no crackles or wheezing are noted on lung examination.
6. A grade 2/6 systolic flow murmur is present on cardiac examination.
7. The uterine fundal height measures 36 cm, and fetal heart rate is 150 beats/min by Doppler.
8. The patient reports occasional contractions over the past week without fluid leakage.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

A. Perform a biophysical profile to assess fetal well-being  
B. Induce labor with oxytocin infusion  
C. Perform an amniocentesis to assess fetal lung maturity  
D. Administer corticosteroids to promote fetal lung development  
E. Continue with routine prenatal care while awaiting spontaneous labor  
F. Schedule an elective cesarean section at 39 weeks gestation  
G. Perform a trial of labor despite prior uterine surgery  
H. Initiate magnesium sulfate for neuroprotection

step1_excerpts:
1. A previously healthy 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of exercise-induced cough and nasal congestion.
2. She plays field hockey and has noticed she coughs when running up and down the field.
3. The cough is nonproductive and resolves with rest.
4. She has not had chest pain or palpitations.
5. She takes no medications and does not smoke.
6. Her sister has asthma.
7. The patient appears well.
8. Her pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/75 mm Hg.
9. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%.
10. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities.
11. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities.
12. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 90% and an FEV1 of 90% of predicted.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Asthma

B. Chronic bronchitis

C. Gastroesophageal reflux disease

D. Postnasal drip syndrome

step1_excerpts:
1. A 74-year-old white man of British descent with a medical history of atrial fibrillation treated with warfarin presented to a dermatology clinic with multiple dark skin lesions on his neck, chest, abdomen, and upper extremities, as well as dark red lesions in his mouth of 4 months’ duration.
2. During this period, he had been seen by his primary care physician as well as by hematology, dermatology, and cardiology specialists, who had told the patient his lesions were ecchymoses secondary to warfarin anticoagulation.
3. The patient had no history of malignancy or exposure to communicable diseases.
4. He experienced a 15.8-kg weight loss during the past few months but denied any fevers or night sweats.
5. Physical examination revealed numerous slightly raised erythematous nodules throughout the neck, torso, and bilateral upper extremities (Figure, left).
6. Inspection of the oral cavity demonstrated 2 discrete erythematous patches with sharply demarcated borders on the soft palate (Figure, right).
7. The remainder of the physical examination was unremarkable.
8. Laboratory results revealed a prothrombin time of 11.6 seconds, an international normalized ratio of 1.0, a hemoglobin level of 12.1 g/dL, and a platelet count of 106 cells ×103/μL; results of a basic chemistry panel with liver function tests were within normal limits.
9. The skin lesion was biopsied, and results are pending.
10. Left, Erythematous nodules on neck and torso (inset, close view).
11. Right, Erythematous patches with sharply demarcated borders.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Initiate empirical treatment with a topical steroid  
B: Initiate photodynamic therapy  
C: Order computed tomography imaging of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis  
D: Order a human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) test

step1_excerpts:
1. A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain.
2. He states that the pain is dull in quality, started 30 minutes ago, has been gradually worsening, and is worse with exertion.
3. He also endorses some shortness of breath.
4. He also believes the pain is worse when leaning back and improved when leaning forward.
5. His wife noticed he fainted after the pain started but regained consciousness shortly after.
6. He has a medical history of diabetes and hypertension for which he is on metformin and losartan.
7. His temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 130/87 mmHg, pulse is 99/min, respirations are 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air.
8. Physical exam reveals an overweight man.
9. A normal S1 and S2 are auscultated with clear breath sounds.
10. An ECG is performed as seen in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy  
B. Hypokalemia  
C. Myocardial infarction  
D. Hyperkalemia

step1_excerpts:
1. A 48-year-old male with no prior medical history or medications is brought to the emergency department following a 3-minute seizure episode.
2. His roommate discovered him unresponsive in bed with rhythmic movements of all extremities.
3. Upon evaluation, the patient is lethargic but oriented.
4. His vital signs show: temperature 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure 130/90 mmHg, pulse 89/min, and respirations 16/min.
5. Neurological examination reveals equal and reactive pupils, full strength in all extremities, and normal deep-tendon reflexes.
6. Basic laboratory tests including electrolytes, glucose, and complete blood count have been ordered.
question_options:
What should be the next step in this patient's management?

A. Urine toxicology  
B. Lumbar puncture  
C. Start antiepileptic medication  
D. Neurology consultation  
E. Sleep-deprived EEG  
G. Serum alcohol level

step1_excerpts:
1. A 38-year-old female presents to the emergency department with left leg pain and swelling that started the previous day.
2. She has no fever or recent trauma.
3. Her medical history includes osteosarcoma of the right distal femur at age 13.
4. Her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 52, and her grandfather had bronchioloalveolar carcinoma at age 45.
5. Physical examination reveals a warm, tender, erythematous left leg with edema and positive Homan's sign.
6. Abdominal examination identifies a firm, fixed mass with irregular borders in the left lower quadrant.
7. Left leg ultrasonography shows a non-compressible femoral vein with thrombus confirmed by color flow Doppler.
8. A contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan reveals a large left abdominopelvic cystic mass with thick septae, consistent with ovarian cancer, along with localized lymphadenopathy and ascites.
question_options:
Which gene mutation is most likely present in this patient?

A. *PTEN*  
B. *KRAS*  
C. *RB1*  
D. *BRCA2*  
E. *BRCA1*  
F. *PALB2*  
G. *CDH1*  
H. *APC*  
I. *TP53*  
J. *MLH1*

step1_excerpts:
1. A 22-year-old woman comes to the office because of urticaria.
2. This is her first episode of urticaria and it has occurred and then resolved several times in the past week.
3. The history and physical examination disclose no abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?

A. Determine the serum IgE concentration

B. Determine the total eosinophil count

C. Refer her to an allergist

D. Treat the symptoms

step1_excerpts:
1. A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician after her mother learned that she began having sexual intercourse with various partners 1 month ago.  
2. She does not use condoms or other contraception.  
3. The mother is concerned about her behavior.  
4. The patient's parents separated 3 months ago.  
5. She had been an honor student and excelled in sports and leadership positions at school before the separation.  
6. Since the separation, however, she has become sullen, defiant, and rebellious.  
7. She has begun smoking cigarettes, disobeying her curfew, and being truant from school.
question_options:
This patient is most likely using which of the following defense mechanisms?  
A. Acting out  
B. Displacement  
C. Projection  
D. Reaction formation

step1_excerpts:
1. A 30-year-old man is evaluated in the post-anesthesia care unit for neck pain.
2. He underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy and was treated for post-operative nausea and vomiting with metoclopramide.
3. Approximately 20 minutes after receiving the medication, he developed pain and stiffness in his neck and eventually was unable to move his neck.
4. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), pulse is 90/min, blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
5. Examination reveals an uncomfortable appearing man.
6. His neck is rotated to the right and is unable to return to midline.
7. Examination of the patient is shown in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Botulinum toxin injection  
B. Ondansetron  
C. Diphenhydramine  
D. Observation

step1_excerpts:
1. A 40-year-old man arrives at the emergency department presenting with gastrointestinal symptoms including abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and profuse watery diarrhea.
2. He also reports experiencing a metallic taste and a dry, persistent cough.
3. The patient recently returned from camping where he consumed well water exclusively.
4. He takes multiple homeopathic supplements but no prescription medications.
5. His vital signs show: temperature 98.7°F, blood pressure 100/60 mmHg, heart rate 100/min, and respiratory rate 16/min.
6. Clinical examination reveals a garlic-like breath odor and skin pigmentation changes.
7. The ECG shows QT interval prolongation across all leads.
