9. Physical examination revealed 2- to 3-mm grouped vesicles on an erythematous base in a discrete area of the sole of the right foot (Figure) and no additional rashes elsewhere on the body.
10. Vesicular fluid was sent for analysis.Left, Grouped vesicles on sole of patient’s right foot.
11. Right, Closer view of vesicles.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Obtain blood cultures  
B: Initiate antiviral therapy with valacyclovir  
C: Prescribe an oral antihistamine agent  
D: Prescribe a topical corticosteroid cream

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old US-born man with a history of cataract surgery in both eyes 3 years ago presented with worsening blurriness, photopsia, floaters, and intermittent eye redness for the past year, worse in the left eye.
2. He was otherwise well.
3. The referring physician was treating him with prednisolone eye drops for cystoid macular edema after recent left Nd:YAG capsulotomy.
4. His best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/30 OS with intraocular pressures of 20 mm Hg OD and 26 mm Hg OS.
5. The anterior segments showed well-positioned posterior chamber intraocular lens implants with open posterior capsules.
6. Dilated fundus examination revealed a small peripheral hypoautofluorescent chorioretinal scar in the right eye.
7. In the left eye, there was trace vitreous haze and 2+ anterior vitreous cell.
8. Multifocal chorioretinal scars extended from the left optic nerve into the macula in each quadrant (Figure 1).
9. These lesions showed variable hypoautofluorescence and hyperautofluorescence.
10. On indocyanine green angiography (ICGA), the confluent hypoautofluorescent lesions showed loss of the choriocapillaris and prominent large choroidal vessels, whereas the mottled hypoautofluorescence and hyperautofluorescent lesions appeared to block the underlying fluorescence.
11. Routine laboratory testing was unremarkable except for a positive interferon-gamma release assay for Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
12. A chest radiograph was normal.Fundus photograph of the left eye demonstrating multifocal outer retinal lesions with variable pigmentation extending from the optic nerve to the equator with sparing of the foveal center.
13. Lesions are surrounded by yellow borders with a patch of prominent choriocapillary atrophy nasal and superior to the nerve.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Reassure patient and observe this self-limited condition  
B: Initiate systemic steroids before starting immunosuppression  
C: Refer to the health department for 4-drug antituberculous treatment  
D: Order magnetic resonance imaging of the brain with contrast and perform lumbar puncture

step1_excerpts:
1. A young man presented to the emergency department with a 1-day history of vision loss in the left eye.
2. He had experienced eye redness for 1 week, which resolved with use of artificial tears; a mild posterior headache; and paresthesias of the left thumb and index and middle fingers.
3. His medical history was significant for epilepsy as a child, although he had been seizure free for more than 10 years without medication.
4. He had no ocular history, was not taking any medications, and had no known drug allergies.
5. He smoked 2 to 4 packs of cigarettes per day, consumed 1 to 3 alcoholic drinks per day, and denied illicit drug use.
6. He denied recent travel, vaccinations, systemic illnesses, or influenza-like symptoms.
7. His best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/100 OS.
8. Amsler grid testing revealed a central scotoma in the left eye.
9. No afferent papillary defect was apparent.
10. Intraocular pressures were 16 mm Hg OU.
11. Results of the external and anterior segment examinations were unremarkable, and no vitreous inflammation was noted.
12. Figure 1 shows findings of the posterior segment examination.
13. Results of the neurologic examination revealed decreased sensation to light touch, vibration, and temperature in his left upper and lower extremities.
14. A, Subretinal and retinal pigment epithelial lesions (arrowheads) are visible in the left eye.
15. B, Late staining of the macular lesion.
16. The arrowheads outline the border of the area that was hypofluorescent in the early frames (not shown).
17. The right eye showed similar findings.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Initiate high-dose corticosteroid therapy  
B: Obtain magnetic resonance imaging of the brain  
C: Perform a retinal biopsy  
D: Obtain computed tomography of the chest

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 20s presented with a 2-month history of vague, right upper-quadrant abdominal pain, with associated 5-kg weight loss, loss of appetite, and increasing abdominal distension.
2. He reported a small mass in the right scrotum that was evaluated 5 years previously and was reassured to be a nonmalignant lesion.
3. Physical examination was notable for a distended abdomen with a palpable left abdominal mass.
4. Testicular examination revealed an approximately 1-cm firm right spermatic cord nodule.
5. Laboratory tests showed lactate dehydrogenase levels of 818 U/L (to convert to μkat/L, multiply by 0.0167), with no significant β-human chorionic gonadotropin and α-fetoprotein levels.
6. Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen (Figure, A and B) revealed innumerable masses throughout the abdomen and pelvis, with the largest measuring 17.5 × 14 × 14 cm and a 3.9-cm enhancing lesion in the left hepatic lobe, and a small amount of ascites.
7. Testicular sonogram disclosed a 1.5-cm right epididymal cyst.
8. Percutaneous biopsy and histologic examination of the dominant left abdominal mass revealed neoplastic cells (Figure, C) that were positive for cytokeratin, desmin but negative for S100.
9. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) was positive for EWS-WT1 rearrangement.A, Coronal view and B, sagittal view contrast-enhanced computed tomographic imaging revealed innumerable abdominopelvic masses.
10. Blue arrowheads indicate the dominant mass and the red arrowhead indicates the liver mass.
11. C, Hematoxylin-eosin stain (original magnification ×40).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Metastatic neuroendocrine carcinoma  
B: Metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor  
C: Metastatic testicular carcinoma  
D: Advanced desmoplastic small round cell tumor

step1_excerpts:
1. A 27-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for an abnormal vaginal discharge.
2. The patient has engaged in unprotected intercourse with 12 different partners.
3. She has a medical history of asthma, IV drug abuse, and depression.
4. She has 1 to 2 alcoholic drinks per day.
5. She feels ashamed of her behavior and is requesting treatment for her condition and advice for safe sex.
6. The patient is given antibiotics and is advised on safe sex practices.
7. The patient presents to the emergency department 3 days later with a complaint of a rash.
8. She states that every time she has sex a rash has emerged on her skin.
9. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 91/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
10. A physical exam is notable for the finding in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

A. Photosensitivity  
B. Antigen exposure  
C. IV drug use  
D. Infection

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old man has had crushing substernal chest pain on exertion over the past 6 weeks.
2. He had a myocardial infarction 2 months ago.
3. He takes nitroglycerin as needed and one aspirin daily.
4. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years.
5. Examination shows normal heart sounds and no carotid or femoral bruits.
question_options:
Treatment with a β-adrenergic blocking agent is most likely to improve his symptoms due to which of the following mechanisms?

A. Decreasing myocardial contractility

B. Dilating the coronary arteries

C. Peripheral vasodilation

D. Preventing fibrin and platelet plugs

step1_excerpts:
1. A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain.
2. The pain starts in his chest and moves into his back, arms, and abdomen.
3. He describes the pain as tearing.
4. He has no known medical history and takes no medications.
5. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 130/min, blood pressure is 210/145 mmHg, respirations are 22/min, and pulse oximetry is 98% on room air.
6. Exam reveals a diaphoretic, anxious-appearing man.
7. Pulses are diminished over the left wrist when compared to the right.
8. A chest radiograph is obtained as shown in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Aspirin  
B. CT angiography of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis  
C. Echocardiography  
D. Lorazepam

step1_excerpts:
1. A 24-year-old man with epilepsy refractory to valproic acid, phenytoin, and levetiracetam undergoes magnetic resonance imaging of his brain while monitored by anesthetic care.
2. He wakes up screaming in pain due to an electrocardiogram lead having caused a significant thermal burn circumferentially around his left leg.
3. He is admitted to the medical intensive care unit for continuous electroencephalogram monitoring while on a midazolam infusion for seizure suppression and supportive care for his burn.
4. Overnight, the nurse continued to increase the patient's midazolam infusion rate, but she also noticed that his left toes were cold to the touch with significant edema.
5. His temperature is now 100°F (37.8°C), blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 10/min and oxygen saturation is 95% on 2 liters nasal cannula.
6. No dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses are detected on the left lower extremity.
7. A delta pressure of 25 mmHg is obtained in the left leg.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Amputation  
B. Escharotomy  
C. Fasciotomy  
D. Intravenous fluid infusion based on Parkland formula

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 30s presented for assessment of long-standing iris lesions in both eyes.
2. He was unaware of any recent changes in the size or number of these lesions.
3. His visual acuity measured 20/25 (6/7.5) OU, and his intraocular pressures were 14 mm Hg OU.
4. The patient had noticed progressive visual obscuration in his left eye.
5. He was not taking any ocular medications, and his only systemic medication was an oral β-blocker.
6. He was otherwise healthy, and his family history was noncontributory.
7. On a slitlamp examination, multiple brown masses were noted at the pupillary margin in both eyes, encroaching on the central visual axis (Figure).
8. There was no inflammation in the anterior chamber or vitreous.
9. The findings of the posterior pole examination were unremarkable bilaterally.
10. Computed tomography scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Surgical iridectomy  
B: Kidney ultrasonography  
C: Positron emission tomography scan  
D: Computed tomography scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis

step1_excerpts:
1. A recent clinical trial evaluated a novel biomedical device for treating congenital talipes equinovarus (club foot) in infants.
2. The study included 20 participants and found that the new device was significantly less effective than traditional serial casting (p < 0.001).
3. The authors noted that this result might be attributed to a single outlier case where the foot deformity remained uncorrected at study completion.
question_options:
Among the following measures of central tendency and dispersion, which statistical measure would be least affected by outliers?

A. Standard Deviation  
B. Mode  
C. Variance  
D. Geometric Mean  
E. Mean  
F. Interquartile Range  
G. Standard deviation  
H. Root Mean Square  
I. Harmonic Mean  
J. Median

step1_excerpts:
1. A 54-year-old woman presented with a 7-year history of a painful subungual mass of the right thumb.
2. The lesion was initially believed to be an infection; however, results of both mycological and bacteriologic examinations were unremarkable.
3. The patient had no notable medical history, including dyskeratosis congenita, trauma, sun exposure, radiation exposure, chemical exposure to tar or arsenic or exposure to minerals, chronic immunosuppression, or chronic infection.
4. Physical examination revealed a subungual nodule with some exudation and crusts.
5. The distal nail plate had been destroyed and showed onycholysis with obvious separation from the nail bed (Figure, A).
6. Pertinent laboratory results (complete blood cell count, liver panel, kidney panel) were within normal limits.
7. Lesional biopsy was also performed (Figure, B and C).
8. A, Clinical photograph shows a subungual nodule with exudation and crusts as well as destruction of the distal nail plate with onycholysis.
9. B, Lesional biopsy results show proliferation of atypical squamous cells invading the dermis.
10. C, Large atypical squamous cells with hyperchromatic, pleomorphic, and atypical mitosis (B and C, hematoxylin-eosin).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Onychomycosis  
B: Subungual squamous cell carcinoma  
C: Subungual verruca vulgaris  
D: Subungual exostosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 60s presented for evaluation of multiple painful cutaneous nodules that had developed over the previous 2 months.
2. The patient had a history of IgGκ multiple myeloma, diagnosed approximately 6 months earlier.
3. At that time, flow cytometry showed a κ-restricted plasma cell population positive for CD38 and CD138 but negative for CD3, CD20, and CD45 expression.
4. Cytogenetic analysis with fluorescent in situ hybridization did not reveal high-risk genetic markers.
5. The patient demonstrated no evidence of end organ disease, and her myeloma was classified as stage II.
6. Since her initial diagnosis, she had completed 4 cycles of lenalidomide, bortezomib, and dexamethasone (RVD) therapy in addition to irradiation for lytic lesions of the thoracic and lumbar spine.
7. Physical examination revealed scattered red-violaceous nodules, with the largest measuring approximately 6.0 × 5.5 × 2.5 cm (Figure, A).
8. They were found in the mouth, the trunk, and on all 4 extremities.
9. The lesions were nonulcerated, round with a smooth surface, fixed, and firm and tender to touch.
10. Serum protein levels were normal.
11. An ultrasound-guided needle biopsy and immunohistochemical analysis of the largest lesion on the patient’s right shoulder were performed
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Hemangioma  
B: Neutrophilic dermatoses  
C: Plasmacytoma  
D: Leukemia cutis

step1_excerpts:
1. A healthy white man in his late 70s was referred to the retina clinic for evaluation of nerve fiber layer infarcts (cotton-wool spots).  
2. He had been experiencing nonprogressive diminished vision in his left eye for 6 weeks.  
3. He denied any history of diabetes or past ocular problems and reported having mild hypertension for which he was taking lisinopril.  
4. Review of systems was positive for fatigue of his tongue while eating but he denied any jaw claudication, fevers, malaise, joint pain, or weight loss.  
5. His best-corrected visual acuity was 20/25 OD and 20/30 OS.  
6. Pupillary and anterior segment examination in both eyes were unremarkable with the exception of bilateral nuclear sclerotic cataracts.  
7. Dilated fundus examination of the right eye showed a nerve fiber layer infarct (NFLI) inferior to the optic nerve (Figure 1A).  
8. In the left eye, there were several scattered NFLIs in the peripapillary region (Figure 1B).  
9. Fluorescein angiography (FA) showed relatively normal flow without evidence of occlusion or vasculitis.  
10. An extensive inflammatory and infectious laboratory workup revealed a hemoglobin level of 12.6 g/dL and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level of 54 mm/h and 6.16 mg/L, respectively (to convert hemoglobin to grams per liter, multiply by 10, and C-reactive protein to nanomoles per liter, multiply by 9.524).  
11. Antinuclear antibody testing was positive (1:80 with homogenous pattern).  
12. Further workup including human immunodeficiency virus testing was nonrevealing.Fundus photographs of the right and left eye demonstrating nerve fiber layer infarcts in the peripapillary region.  
13. Media clarity is affected by nuclear sclerotic cataracts in both eyes.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  
A: Proceed with temporal artery biopsy  
B: Refer patient to primary care physician for management of his hypertension  
C: Refer for rheumatologic workup  
D: Observe and reevaluate in 2 months

step1_excerpts:
1. A 9-year-old girl was referred to the pediatric retina service to evaluate progressive vision loss.  
2. Her medical history included neonatal seizures.  
3. She was initially evaluated at an outside institution and was found to have bilateral symmetric vision loss with nyctalopia.  
4. The onset of the symptoms was unknown.  
5. At that time, her best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was 20/70 OU.  
6. The patient did not receive any ophthalmological care until 2 years later, when she was seen for marked vision loss and was noted to have a BCVA of light perception in both eyes.  
7. When she presented to the pediatric retina service, she demonstrated poor mentation and was unable to recall simple things such as the name of her siblings.  
8. Her BCVA was light perception.  
9. Her pupils were round and reactive.  
10. The anterior segment examination and intraocular pressures were within normal limits.  
11. Fundus autofluorescence disclosed attenuated, narrow vasculature and diffuse peripheral patchy hypoautofluorescence (Figure 1A).  
12. Color fundus photography showed optic disc pallor, attenuated retinal vasculature, prominent choroidal markings, and central retinal atrophy with diffusely mottled pigmentation (Figure 1B).  
13. Optical coherence tomography displayed decreased retinal thickness, more prominent in the inner layers, and hyper-reflective dots in the outer retinal layers.  
14. Family history included unilateral vision loss in her paternal grandmother in her late 20s.  
15. Both parents were healthy and denied consanguinity.  
16. The patient has 3 half sisters, all of whom are healthy.  
17. A, Fundus autofluorescence discloses attenuated, narrow vasculature and diffuse peripheral patchy hypoautofluorescence.  
18. B, Color fundus photograph displays optic disc pallor, attenuated retinal vasculature, prominent choroidal markings, and central retinal atrophy with diffusely mottled pigmentation.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Electroretinogram  
B: Genetic testing  
C: Observation  
D: Muscle biopsy

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her mid-50s with a history of hyperlipidemia and arthritis presented with recurrent subconjunctival hemorrhages and retinal vascular abnormalities as noted by her general ophthalmologist.
2. Best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OU.
3. Results of the pupillary examination, intraocular pressure measurements, motility, and confrontatiol visual field testing were normal in each eye.
4. Findings on the anterior slitlamp examination demonstrated rare anterior chamber cells and mild nuclear sclerotic cataracts in both eyes.
5. Results of the dilated fundus examination (Figure 1) demonstrated bilateral vitreous cells that were not dense enough to obscure retinal vessel details, as well as optic disc hyperemia, arterial attenuation, arterial and venous sheathing, hard exudates, and focal areas of retinal thinning.
6. There was no macular edema in either eye.
7. Results of a complete blood cell count were normal.Fundus photograph of the patient’s left eye at presentation.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Check blood pressure  
B: Check antinuclear antibody level  
C: Check hemoglobin A1c level  
D: Check erythrocyte sedimentation rate

step1_excerpts:
1. A 2-week-old boy is evaluated by his pediatrician for abnormal feet.
2. The patient was born at 39 weeks via vaginal delivery to a G1P1 29-year-old woman.
3. The patient has been breastfeeding and producing 5 stools/day.
4. He is otherwise healthy.
5. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 60/38 mmHg, pulse is 150/min, respirations are 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
6. A cardiopulmonary exam is notable for a benign flow murmur.
7. A musculoskeletal exam reveals the findings shown in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Botulinum toxin injections  
B. Reassurance and reassessment in 1 month  
C. Serial casting  
D. Surgical pinning

step1_excerpts:
1. A 7-month-old boy was referred for monocular nystagmus and failure to thrive.
2. He was born at full term weighing 3.63 kg after a normal pregnancy, labor, and delivery.
3. He grew appropriately until 3 months of age, after which his weight dropped from the 50th percentile to the fifth percentile in 2 months despite maintenance of a fairly adequate caloric intake.
4. The patient had multiple episodes of emesis.
5. Results of his gastrointestinal evaluation were normal.
6. At 6 months of age, he developed a constant rapid nystagmus of the right eye.
7. On presentation, he was a happy, engaged, alert child with an emaciated appearance (Figure, A).
8. His head was of normal size, although it appeared large relative to his small body size.
9. During the examination, the patient was socially interactive and visually attentive.
10. He had normal, optokinetic responses and brisk pupillary responses with no relative afferent pupillary defect.
11. He had a rapid pendular horizontal nystagmus, with no associated strabismus, head nodding, or torticollis (Video).
12. The patient looked readily toward objects held in the peripheral visual field of either eye.
13. The retinal examination showed normal-sized optic discs without swelling or pallor.
14. The patient had no history or findings suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 1.
15. A, On presentation, the patient appeared emaciated but alert.
16. B, T1 fluid-attenuated inversion recovery sagittal magnetic resonance (MR) image showing large globular suprasellar mass enveloping the optic chiasm (arrows).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform electrooculography  
B: Perform visual evoked potential test  
C: Perform magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and spine  
D: Perform blood culture

step1_excerpts:
1. A 2-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her mother for a follow-up visit.
2. The patient was born at 29 weeks gestation to a G1P1 mother.
3. Her postnatal course was complicated by a prolonged neonatal intensive care unit stay for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS).
4. Since discharge from the hospital, her mother reports that the patient has been doing well without health problems.
5. She has been gaining weight appropriately.
6. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 25/min.
7. The patient's mother asks the pediatrician about potentially delaying the 2-month vaccine doses due to the baby's medical history.
question_options:
8. Which of the following is the correct vaccination plan for this infant in terms of the vaccinations below?

- Diphtheria, Tetanus, and acellular Pertussis - DTaP
- Hepatitis A - HAV
- Hepatitis B - HBV
- Haemophilus influenzae type B conjugate - HiB
- Pneumococcal conjugate - PCV 13

A. Delay all vaccines for 2 months due to the infant's history of NRDS  
B. Administer DTaP, HAV, HBV, HiB, PCV 13, poliovirus, and rotavirus vaccines  
C. Administer DTaP, HBV, HiB, PCV 13, poliovirus, and rotavirus vaccines  
D. Delay all vaccines for 2 months because the infant was born 2 months premature

step1_excerpts:
1. A 68-year-old woman presented 1 year after noticing a flank bulge that developed following a forceful coughing episode.
2. Her medical history included gastroesophageal reflux disease, irritable bowel syndrome, hypothyroidism, hypertension, asthma, and obesity.
3. On palpation, the mass extended superiorly to the costal margins and inferiorly to the anterior-superior iliac spine; no fascial edge was palpable medially.
4. A computed tomographic (CT) scan demonstrated abdominal contents—including liver, ascending colon, and omental fat—protruding through a 12-cm defect.
5. Weight loss was counseled and 8 weeks allowed for optimization before exploration.
6. On incision, we encountered this view (Figure 1).
7. Right thoracotomy with primary closure and mesh placement
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Video-assisted thoracic surgery reduction  
B: Transabdominal laparoscopic reduction and mesh placement  
C: Video-assisted thoracic surgery reduction with primary closure  
D: Right thoracotomy with primary closure and mesh placement

step1_excerpts:
1. A 62-year-old woman with a history of chronic angle-closure glaucoma and bilateral peripheral iridotomies sought a second opinion for worsening visual acuity in the left eye for 2 months.
2. She had been treated for glaucoma for approximately 1 year.
3. Review of systems was negative for previous episodes of eye pain, redness, or emesis.
4. Her medical history included hyperlipidemia, obesity, and prior cataract surgery in both eyes.
5. On examination, best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/80 OS.
6. The patient’s pupils were equal, round, and reactive to light without a relative afferent pupillary defect.
7. Intraocular pressure was 11 mm Hg bilaterally without medication.
8. Slitlamp findings were notable for patent peripheral iridotomies, open angles on gonioscopy, and an asymmetrically enlarged cup-disc ratio with mild pallor of the left optic nerve.
9. Color vision was decreased in the left eye.
10. Visual field (VF) testing as well as ganglion cell layer (GCL) segmentation by optical coherence tomography (OCT) were obtained for both eyes (Figure 1).
11. Optical coherence tomography ganglion cell layer thickness map shows nasal thinning of the right eye (A) and diffuse thinning of the left eye (B).
12. In the right eye, the relative thinning within the nasal macula compared with the temporal macula suggests injury to the papillomacular bundle.
13. In the left eye, the diffuse thinning suggests diffuse optic nerve injury (Heidelberg Spectralis; Heidelberg).
14. Insets show Humphrey 24-2 perimetry with minimal nonspecific defects in the right eye and a temporal scotoma in the left eye.
15. Refer to a retina specialist owing to retinal thinning Start intraocular pressure–lowering medications owing to GCL loss
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Refer to a retina specialist owing to retinal thinning  
B: Start intraocular pressure–lowering medications owing to GCL loss  
C: Order a carotid doppler  
D: Order brain magnetic resonance imaging

step1_excerpts:
1. An investigator is studying the incidence of the common cold among medical students at various time points during the school year.
2. Results show an increased incidence of upper respiratory tract infections among these students during finals week.
3. It is hypothesized that the stress of studying for examinations adversely affects the immune system, making the students more susceptible to infection.
question_options:
Which of the following laboratory findings in these students during examination week is most likely to support this hypothesis?

A. Decreased AM serum cortisol concentration

B. Decreased macrophage activity

C. Increased basophil count

D. Increased lymphocyte count

step1_excerpts:
1. A 27-year-old female presents with a generalized rash of 5 days' duration, accompanied by mild fever, headache, and muscle aches over the past month.
2. She has no significant medical history.
3. Her social history includes smoking one pack of cigarettes daily, weekend binge drinking, and occasional cocaine use.
4. Her vital signs are normal.
5. Physical findings include a widespread, symmetric, reddish-brown papular rash on her trunk, upper extremities, and palms, along with generalized non-tender lymphadenopathy.
6. She also exhibits patchy scalp alopecia and multiple flat, broad-based, wartlike papules in the anogenital region.
7. Both rapid plasma reagin and fluorescent treponemal antibody tests are positive.
question_options:
After initiating appropriate treatment, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Hepatitis B surface antigen test  
B. Dark-field microscopy  
C. Herpes simplex virus PCR  
D. Liver function tests  
E. CD4+ T-cell count  
F. HIV-1/HIV-2 differentiation immunoassay  
G. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis  
H. Complete blood count with differential  
I. Darkfield microscopy of lesions  
J. NAAT for C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhea

step1_excerpts:
1. A 50-year-old white woman presents with subungual and acral pigmentation of the left middle finger.  
2. She first noticed a black streak down the middle of her nail 10 years prior to presentation.  
3. Subsequently, the pigmented band on the nail plate widened and darkened, with pigment spreading to the proximal nail fold and distal acral hyponychial skin.  
4. She has no associated symptoms, including nail splitting, bleeding, or pain, and no history of acute or recurrent trauma.  
5. Several years previously, she was reassured that her nail pigmentation was benign.  
6. The nail examination is illustrated in the Figure.  
7. Examination of all other nails is unremarkable.  
8. Past medical history and family history are unrevealing.Distal left middle finger.  
9. A, Dorsal clinical view.  
10. B, Dorsal dermoscopic view.  
11. C, Distal clinical view.  
12. D, Distal dermoscopic view.Reassure patient that this is benign nail pigmentationRecommend punch biopsy of the nail bed through intact nail plateRecommend removal of the entire nail plate with representative biopsy of all areas of pigmentSend clippings of the free edge of the nail plate for histopathology and culture.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Reassure patient that this is benign nail pigmentation  
B: Recommend punch biopsy of the nail bed through intact nail plate  
C: Recommend removal of the entire nail plate with representative biopsy of all areas of pigment  
D: Send clippings of the free edge of the nail plate for histopathology and culture.

step1_excerpts:
1. An 82-year-old man with an ocular history significant for bilateral nuclear sclerotic cataracts presented to the Cornea Service at Bascom Palmer Eye Institute, Miami, Florida, with a history of blurred vision in the right eye after phacoemulsification cataract extraction 8 weeks earlier.
2. Current ophthalmic medications included topical prednisolone acetate, 1%, in the right eye 6 times per day.
3. The patient reported no improvement with the treatment.
4. On examination, his best-corrected visual acuity was 20/80 OD and 20/20 OS.
5. Pupils were reactive without relative afferent pupillary defect, and intraocular pressures were 18 mm Hg in the right eye and 11 mm Hg in the left eye.
6. A slitlamp biomicroscopic examination of the right eye revealed grade 2 to 3 diffuse central corneal edema and folds (Figure 1).
7. The anterior chamber was deep and the posterior chamber intraocular lens was in good position within the capsular bag.
8. Although the view to the posterior pole of the right eye was hazy owing to corneal edema, dilated fundus examination findings were unremarkable.
9. Examination of the left eye revealed a few guttate.
10. The central corneal thickness by ultrasound pachymetry was 957 μm in the right eye and 547 μm in the left eye.Slitlamp biomicroscopic photographs of the right eye show central corneal edema with diffuse illumination (A) and with slitbeam illumination (B).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform penetrating keratoplasty  
B: Provide medical management with topical corticosteroids and hypertonic saline solution for an additional 3 months  
C: Obtain an anterior-segment optical coherence tomogram  
D: Perform an endothelial keratoplasty (Descemet stripping and endothelial keratoplasty or Descemet membrane endothelial keratoplasty)

step1_excerpts:
1. A healthy woman in her 50s presented with a large annular erythematous plaque on her lower back that had appeared in June (1 month previously) and had centrifugally expanded.
2. She complained about mild pruritus that had not responded to conventional antihistamine therapy or topical steroids.
3. She could not recall an arthropod bite prior to the skin eruption and denied having traveled outside Spain in the past few years.
4. She reported a 20-year history of the same annular plaques recurring on the trunk every single year by the beginning of summer and spontaneously resolving by the beginning of autumn.
5. Such lesions had never appeared on the face, hands, or feet.
6. She did not relate these lesions to any particular hobby or application of any skin care product.
7. Physical examination revealed a large, 35-cm semicircular erythematous plaque on her lower back with central clearing and a distinctive, well-demarcated papular border (Figure, A and B).
8. After obtaining informed consent, 2 biopsy specimens were taken from the papular border of the plaque for both hematoxylin-eosin stain and direct immunofluorescence (Figure, C).
9. A, Large erythematous semicircular plaque with central postinflammatory hyperpigmentation on the lower back.
10. B, Absence of epidermal changes, mild edema of the papillary dermis, and a superficial sparse perivascular inflammatory infiltrate.
11. C, Inflammatory infiltrate composed mainly by lymphocytes and few neutrophils.
12. D, Follow-up visit showing clinical resolution in October.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Granuloma annulare  
B: Erythema papulosa semicircularis recidivans  
C: Deep erythema annulare centrifugum  
D: Erythema chronicum migrans

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 30s with a history of chronic hepatitis B was found on computed tomography to have a 13-cm retroperitoneal mass on her left side with a significant mass effect.
2. The patient was symptomatic with intermittent left upper quadrant abdominal pain that was associated with nausea and constipation.
3. She reported no other gastrointestinal, genitourinary, or overall symptoms.
4. In addition to chronic hepatitis B, her medical history was notable for hypertension and her surgical history was significant for a recent liver biopsy.
5. Physical examination revealed a soft, nontender, minimally distended abdomen with no palpable masses and no costovertebral angle tenderness.
6. Laboratory test results at presentation revealed complete blood cell count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and amylase values within the reference ranges and a hepatitis B virus quantification level of 1590 IU/mL.
7. A computed tomographic scan of the abdomen and pelvis using intravenous contrast was obtained (Figure 1).
8. Coronal computed tomographic imaging on initial presentation.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Serous cystadenoma of the pancreas  
B: Endothelial adrenal cyst  
C: Retroperitoneal abscess  
D: Pheochromocytoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 32-year-old Nigerian woman presented with dull pain, pruritus, and discoloration of the dorsal aspect of both feet for 18 months.
2. Her medical history included a red blood cell transfusion as a child and 2 uncomplicated pregnancies.
3. The lesions started as small papules on the dorsal right great toe and left third toe that gradually spread across the dorsum of her feet over the following 12 months.
4. An over-the-counter antifungal ointment was unhelpful.
5. Her primary care physician completed a biopsy, diagnosed verruca plantaris, and prescribed topical salicylic acid twice daily for 4 weeks.
6. The lesions did not improve, and her foot pain worsened.
7. Subsequent treatment with topical liquid nitrogen cryotherapy was ineffective.
8. Three months after cryotherapy, the patient presented to the dermatology clinic regarding the lesions on her feet.
9. The patient stated that the lesions had been stable in size for the previous 6 months, without bleeding, discharge, or change in color.
10. She continued to have 6 of 10, dull, constant pain that was nonradiating, improved when she soaked her feet in water, and worsened with any type of topical pressure or wrapping.
11. Physical examination revealed multiple well-circumscribed, scaly plaques with cobblestone surfaces on the dorsal aspects of the forefoot and midfoot bilaterally.
12. Findings were more severe on the right and left hindfoot (Figure, left panel).
13. On serologic testing, the patient was negative for HIV and positive for hepatitis C virus (HCV).
14. A punch biopsy of the right foot lesion revealed psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia, parakeratosis, eosinophils, papillary dermal inflammation, and intraepidermal necrosis (Figure, right panel).
15. Left, Dorsal aspects of bilateral forefoot and midfoot of a 32-year-old Nigerian woman.
16. Right, Punch biopsy of the patient’s right foot lesion (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×40).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform incisional biopsy  
B: Prescribe amoxicillin/clavulanic acid  
C: Order computed tomography (CT) scan of abdomen and pelvis  
D: Prescribe oral zinc therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 75-year-old woman of white race/ethnicity was referred for bilateral choroidal lesions.
2. She described her vision as being blurred in the left eye, with areas of her vision being “blocked.” Her review of systems was unremarkable.
3. Her medical and ocular histories were significant for pseudophakia of both eyes, obstructive sleep apnea, and hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide.
4. On examination, visual acuity was 20/40 OD and 20/64 OS.
5. Intraocular pressure, pupillary reaction, and ocular motility were normal.
6. Confrontation visual fields revealed a deficit in the inferotemporal quadrant of the left eye.
7. External and slitlamp examinations were unremarkable.
8. Dilated fundus examination revealed an epiretinal membrane, as well as extramacular, elevated, hypopigmented, yellow lesions with retinal pigment epithelium changes in both eyes, along with overlying subretinal fluid, subretinal hemorrhage, and exudates in the left eye (Figure, A).
9. Optical coherence tomography showed an epiretinal membrane with cystoid macular edema and drusen in both eyes, along with subretinal fluid extending into the left macula, explaining her decreased vision.
10. B-scan ultrasonography demonstrated hyperechoic, plaquelike, solid lesions with posterior acoustic shadowing corresponding anatomically to the lesions seen on clinical examination (Figure, B).
11. Fluorescein and indocyanine angiography demonstrated leakage in the area of subretinal hemorrhage in the left eye (Figure, C).
12. A, A yellowish lesion is located in the superonasal quadrant with nasal subretinal hemorrhage (asterisk).
13. B, B-scan ultrasonography (transverse at the 11-o’clock equator) reveals a hyperechoic, plaquelike, solid lesion with posterior acoustic shadowing, consistent with calcification corresponding to the clinically visible lesion.
14. C, Superonasal leakage corresponding to the area of clinically visible subretinal hemorrhage.
15. Check parathyroid hormone, vitamin D, and calcium levels
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform transvitreous biopsy  
B: Begin oral corticosteroid therapy  
C: Check parathyroid hormone, vitamin D, and calcium levels  
D: Treat with plaque brachytherapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her early 50s with hypothyroidism and a 10-month history of painless lumps in her neck presented with achiness and decreased visual acuity in her right eye for 2 months.
2. Associated symptoms included dysphagia and fever and chills.
3. A previous otolaryngology evaluation revealed an intranasal mass with enlargement of multiple submandibular lymph nodes.
4. A needle aspiration biopsy of 1 of the submandibular lymph nodes revealed atypical cells with mature lymphocytes.
5. Computed tomography of the sinus confirmed a nasal polyp and a soft tissue mass in the right lacrimal gland region.
6. The excised nasal polyp was benign.
7. Incisional biopsy of the lacrimal gland lesion revealed chronic inflammatory infiltrate composed of predominantly T cells with scattered B cells and mature plasma cells, but no evidence of a lymphoproliferative process.
8. The patient was referred for evaluation in our clinic.Ocular history was noncontributory.
9. On examination, visual acuity was 20/40 OD and 20/25 OS.
10. Intraocular pressure was unremarkable and ocular motility was intact in both eyes.
11. Clinical evaluation revealed a firm mass of 5 × 4 × 3 cm fixed to the superotemporal orbital rim in the right lacrimal gland region (Figure 1) with intact overlying skin.
12. Slitlamp examination was unremarkable in both eyes without evidence of conjunctival inflammatory signs.
13. Ophthalmoscopic examination was unremarkable in both eyes without compression of the optic nerve or disc edema.Color photograph depicting swelling over the right lacrimal gland region with intact epidermis and absence of inflammatory signs.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Treat with oral corticosteroids  
B: Treat with methotrexate sodium  
C: Perform external beam radiotherapy to the orbit  
D: Perform a second lacrimal gland biopsy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 29-year-old male presents to the office with the complaints of a pounding heart, poor sleep, and a generalized feeling of restlessness.
2. He relocated 2 months ago to take a promotion and has found himself unable to concentrate on his new duties.
3. He worries about his ability to adapt to his increase in responsibility at work and states that he has called in sick 3 days within the past 2 weeks.
question_options:
The most likely diagnosis is

A. adjustment disorder with anxious mood

B. generalized anxiety disorder

C. major depressive disorder, single episode, moderate

D. obsessive-compulsive personality disorder

step1_excerpts:
1. A 63-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of copious watery diarrhea, nausea, and weakness, accompanied by a two-day history of not eating.
2. His medical history includes gastroesophageal reflux disease and a recent dental infection.
3. His medications include famotidine, omeprazole, and he recently completed a 10-day course of clindamycin.
4. Physical examination reveals a temperature of 39.3 ºC (102.7 ºF), heart rate of 120/min, respiratory rate of 22/min, and SpO2 of 99% on room air.
5. Despite receiving 2 liters of 0.9% sodium chloride, his blood pressure remains at 78/41 mmHg.
6. Abdominal examination shows rigidity with hypoactive bowel sounds.
7. Laboratory results indicate a white blood cell count of 28,000/mL, creatinine of 2.6 mg/dL, and lactic acid of 3.8 mmol/L.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

A. Administer intravenous metronidazole  
B. Obtain stool culture and sensitivity  
C. Begin oral vancomycin and metronidazole combination therapy  
D. Administer oral metronidazole  
E. Repeat lactic acid level  
F. Start intravenous vancomycin  
G. Computed tomography of abdomen  
H. Perform flexible sigmoidoscopy  
I. Initiate droplet precautions  
J. Initiate total parenteral nutrition

step1_excerpts:
1. A young man presented for a second opinion regarding acquired color blindness and visual loss.  
2. He was recently hospitalized for confusion, short-term memory loss, vomiting, and diarrhea.  
3. He also experienced hair loss (Figure 1), a facial rash, hoarseness, and painful peripheral neuropathy in his feet.  
4. His blood pressure on admission was 150/102 mm Hg, his pulse was 118 beats/min, and ophthalmic examination findings demonstrated decreased visual acuity and dyschromatopsia.  
5. He reported difficulty opening his eyelids during hospitalization but denied any history of diplopia.  
6. Results of a complete blood cell count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate were within reference limits, and computed tomography of the head without contrast showed no abnormalities.  
7. A lumbar puncture showed normal opening pressure with a mildly elevated protein level in the cerebrospinal fluid.  
8. Alopecia was noted in our patient in addition to temporal thinning of the lateral half of the eyebrows.  
9. On our examination, best-corrected visual acuity was 20/70 OU.  
10. Extraocular motility was full in both eyes, and confrontational visual field test findings were full in all quadrants.  
11. The patient missed 4 color plates on Ishihara pseudoisochromatic testing.  
12. The slitlamp examination revealed an unremarkable anterior segment, and results of dilated ophthalmoscopy showed temporal optic nerve pallor in both eyes.  
13. The macula, vessels, and retinal periphery were unremarkable on examination.  
14. Automated perimetry showed bilateral central scotomas, and results of a multifocal electroretinogram were normal.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Test for mitochondrial optic neuropathies  
B: Check blood and urine for heavy metals  
C: Check vitamin B12 levels and ask about smoking history  
D: Rule out an underlying neoplastic process

step1_excerpts:
1. An adolescent girl with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) presented for evaluation of hyperpigmented skin lesions affecting her neck, upper limbs, and trunk.
2. The lesions had started about 6 months previously as recurrent crops of pruritic erythematous papules that subsided leaving behind brownish-bluish black hyperpigmentation after each episode.
3. On examination, there were multiple, brown, hyperpigmented patches symmetrically affecting her neck, axillae, antecubital fossa, and intermammary and inframammary areas (Figure, A).
4. The patches showed a reticulate pattern at the peripheries.
5. Intermammary patches had central erythema and a few subsiding papules.
6. Additionally, there were dark brown to bluish-gray patches with reticulation on the lower back and dorsum of the neck (Figure, B).
7. These patches also had a few resolving erythematous papules in the periphery.
8. There was no history suggestive of allergic rhinitis or bronchial asthma.
9. Her IgE levels and thyroid status were normal.
10. Her fasting blood glucose and basal insulin levels were not raised.
11. There was no family history of similar lesions.
12. The rest of the skin, nails, and mucosae were all normal.
13. Potassium hydroxide mount analysis from skin scrapings did not reveal fungal hyphae or spores.
14. A skin biopsy was performed from lesions on the lower back, and the specimen was submitted for histopathologic analysis (Figure, C and D).
15. A, Illustrated are multiple brown hyperpigmented patches symmetrically affecting the neck, axillae, antecubital fossa, and intermammary and inframammary areas.
16. The patches show a reticulate pattern at the peripheries.
17. The intermammary patches have central erythema and a few overlying edematous papules.
18. B, Bluish-gray pigmented patches with prominent reticulation on lower back.
19. C, Histopathologic lesional specimen shows mild epidermal hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, multiple foci of spongiosis, and an enhanced basal layer pigmentation.
20. There is scant lichenoid and moderate perivascular lymphomononuclear and polymorphonuclear infiltrate, basal cell vacuolization, and melanin incontinence (hematoxylin-eosin).
21. D, Histopathologic lesional specimen at higher power reveals spongiosis, occasional neutrophilic exocytosis (yellow arrowheads), basal cell vacuolar degeneration, and necrotic keratinocytes (black arrowheads) (hematoxylin-eosin).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Confluent and reticulated papillomatosis  
B: Prurigo pigmentosa  
C: Dowling-Degos disease  
D: Lichen planus pigmentosus

step1_excerpts:
1. A 22-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-day history of cold symptoms and a 1-week history of progressive fatigue.
2. Six weeks ago, she received a kidney transplant from a living, related donor.
3. Immediately after the operation, she received monoclonal anti-CD3 therapy.
4. Current medications are azathioprine, cyclosporine, and prednisone.
5. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F).
6. Physical examination shows a well-healed surgical scar.
7. Serum studies show that her urea nitrogen and creatinine concentrations have tripled.
8. A diagnosis of allograft rejection is suspected.
question_options:
In addition, this patient's clinical presentation is best explained by an infection with which of the following agents?

A. Adenovirus

B. BK virus

C. Epstein-Barr virus

D. Herpes simplex virus

step1_excerpts:
1. A 70-year-old woman presents with a 2-month history of worsening leg swelling, mild intermittent abdominal discomfort, fatigue, unintentional weight loss of 3.2 kg, and occasional visible hematuria.
2. She denies experiencing chest pain or shortness of breath.
3. Her vital signs and cardiopulmonary examination are normal, with no elevation in jugular venous pressure.
4. The abdomen is non-distended, and no masses are palpable.
5. Mild right-sided mid-abdominal tenderness is noted on palpation, without rebound or guarding.
6. Examination of the extremities reveals 2+ edema extending to the hips, with intact peripheral pulses.
7. Urine dipstick testing is negative for proteinuria but 1+ positive for blood.
8. Urine sediment analysis shows 10 to 15 red blood cells per high-power field.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Renal vein thrombosis  
B. Congestive heart failure  
C. Acute glomerulonephritis  
D. Renal-cell carcinoma  
E. Membranous nephropathy  
F. Nephrotic syndrome  
G. Immunoglobulin A nephropathy  
H. IgA nephropathy  
I. Polycystic kidney disease  
J. Renal-vein thrombosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 3-month-old boy presents to the pediatrician with his mother for a well-child visit.
2. The patient drinks 4 ounces of cow’s milk formula every 3 hours.
3. He usually stools 1 time per day and urinates up to 6 times per day.
4. He regurgitates a moderate amount of formula through his nose and mouth after most feeds.
5. He does not seem interested in additional feeding after these episodes of regurgitation and he has become progressively more irritable around meal times.
6. The patient is starting to refuse some feeds.
7. His mother denies seeing blood or streaks of red in his stool and she denies any family history of food allergies or dermatological problems.
8. The patient’s weight was in the 62nd percentile 4 weeks ago and he is now in the 48th percentile.
9. His height and head circumference have followed similar trends.
10. His temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 72/47 mmHg, pulse is 125/min, and respirations are 27/min.
11. On physical exam, the patient smiles reciprocally and can lift his head and chest when in the prone position.
12. His abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Provide reassurance  
B. Counsel on positioning and thickening feeds  
C. Obtain abdominal ultrasound  
D. Initiate proton pump inhibitor

step1_excerpts:
1. A 37-year-old man arrives at the emergency department accompanied by his wife, reporting a 3-day history of severe pain in his right arm and inability to move it.  
2. The symptoms began after he woke up one morning having slept on his side.  
3. He is otherwise healthy but mentions feeling extremely fatigued from working multiple night shifts.  
4. He describes struggling to stay awake while caring for his daughter during the day.  
5. Since the onset of symptoms, he has been unable to work and is now fully reliant on his wife, who has taken on extra work to cover their expenses.  
6. The patient appears calm but only consents to examination after his wife persuades him.  
7. Vital signs are normal.  
8. On examination, he has 1/5 muscle strength in the right arm, normal reflexes, and no sensation to light touch across the right arm and forearm.  
9. However, he withdraws the arm quickly during a pinprick test.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Munchausen syndrome  
B. Radiculopathy  
C. Neuropraxia  
D. Malingering  
E. Anxiety disorder  
F. Factitious disorder  
G. Psychogenic paresis  
H. Functional neurological symptom disorder  
I. Somatic symptom disorder  
J. Conversion disorder

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 40s presented with painful erythematous plaques on her trunk (Figure, A).
2. Skin lesions developed 2 months earlier and progressively spread.
3. She reported abdominal discomfort, weight loss, and vaginal bleeding.
4. A solid mass on her lower abdomen that had been palpable about 10 years prior had rapidly increased in size within the past few months.
5. Physical examination revealed erythematous plaques on the right chest and flank without warmth.
6. Punch biopsy of a lesion from the chest was sent for histopathological examination (Figure, B and C).
7. A, Erythematous plaques involving the right chest and flank at the initial presentation.
8. B and C, Large atypical cells with clear or eosinophilic cytoplasm forming papillary and glandular architectures are present in the deep dermis; lymphovascular invasion was observed in the superficial and deep dermis (hematoxylin-eosin).
9. D, Contrast-enhanced computed tomographic scan of the abdomen and pelvis showing a large heterogeneous mass in the right rectus abdominis muscle (blue arrowhead) and cystic lesion in the left ovary (pink arrowhead).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Interstitial granulomatous dermatitis  
B: Wolf isotopic response  
C: Metastatic carcinoma  
D: Cutaneous endometriosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 61-year-old female presents with severe pain in her right knee, which has been warm, swollen, and red for the past day.
2. She recalls a similar episode two years ago in her left toe that resolved on its own.
3. Her medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, and she takes pravastatin and hydrochlorothiazide.
4. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/92 mmHg.
5. On examination, the right knee is swollen, erythematous, warm, tender to palpation, and exhibits reduced range of motion.
6. Arthrocentesis reveals turbid fluid with a leukocyte count of 19,200/mm³, a negative Gram stain, and yellow, negatively birefringent crystals under polarized light microscopy.
question_options:
Which of the following best explains the mechanism of action of the most appropriate treatment for her current condition?

A. Inhibitor of xanthine oxidase  
B. Reversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes  
C. Antagonism of interleukin-1 receptors  
D. Suppression of neutrophil chemotaxis  
E. Inhibition of transcription factors  
F. Irreversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes  
G. Stabilization of lysosomal membranes  
H. Inhibition of leukotriene synthesis  
I. Blockade of tumor necrosis factor-alpha  
J. Inhibition of microtubule polymerization

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old woman with a history of poorly controlled hyperlipidemia and obesity visits her primary care physician for a routine follow-up.
2. She reports feeling well and has no complaints.
3. She is currently taking atorvastatin.
4. Her temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 135/80 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 16/min.
5. Her BMI is 31 kg/m².
6. Laboratory results show a total cholesterol level of 290 mg/dl, triglycerides of 120 mg/dl, and LDL cholesterol of 215 mg/dl.
7. Her physician considers prescribing a medication that promotes cholesterol consumption by the liver for bile salt synthesis.
question_options:
Which of the following adverse effects is this patient most likely to experience after starting the medication?

A. Hepatic steatosis  
B. Gallstones  
C. Acute pancreatitis  
D. Metabolic acidosis  
E. Hyperkalemia  
F. Renal insufficiency  
G. Gastrointestinal bleeding  
H. Facial flushing  
I. Vitamin K deficiency  
J. Fat malabsorption

step1_excerpts:
1. A 44-year-old female presents to the office for evaluation of a lump on her neck that she noted 1 week ago.
2. She denies any tenderness, fever, weight loss, or fatigue.
3. Physical examination reveals a 2-cm freely movable mass in the lower left lobe of the thyroid.
question_options:
In addition to thyroid-stimulating hormone and free thyroxine levels, the most appropriate initial method to investigate this lesion is

A. a nuclear thyroid scan

B. an iodine131 scan

C. fine-needle aspiration

D. ultrasonography of the thyroid gland

step1_excerpts:
1. A 22-year-old woman with no significant medical history presented with a 2-month history of fevers, shortness of breath, and right-sided pleuritic chest pain.
2. She reported a 2-day history of skin lesions on her ears without trauma.
3. She also reported no recent sick contacts, travel, illicit drug use, or use of oral contraceptive pills or other medications.
4. Vital signs included a blood pressure of 140/70 mm Hg, heart rate of 168/min, respiratory rate of 30/min, temperature of 40.9°C, and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air.
5. Physical examination revealed decreased right basilar breath sounds with dullness to percussion, tachycardia without murmurs or rubs, lower extremity edema, and bilateral cutaneous necrosis of her pinnae (Figure 1).
6. Laboratory findings showed a white blood cell count of 7700 cells/µL (neutrophils, 82.4%; lymphocytes, 10.6%; monocytes, 6%; eosinophils, 0.2%; basophils, 0.8%), hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL (mean corpuscular volume, 84 fL), platelet count of 151 ×103/µL, partial thromboplastin time of 61 seconds (reference range, 22-32), and an international normalized ratio (INR) of 1.4.
7. An ultrasound showed a right above-the-knee deep venous thrombosis (DVT), and a chest computed tomography angiogram showed a large right pleural effusion without evidence of pulmonary embolism.
8. Pleural fluid was exudative; Gram stain and culture were negative.
9. Blood cultures were drawn and empirical antibiotics begun.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform a skin biopsy with indirect immunofluorescence  
B: Obtain serum antinuclear antibody and lupus anticoagulant assay  
C: Obtain a bacterial culture of the skin lesions  
D: Obtain a urine drug screen

step1_excerpts:
1. A 27-year-old female with no prior medical history presents to the clinic with tightness in her neck.  
2. The patient states that she started feeling the tightness immediately after a stretching exercise yesterday.  
3. On initial exam, the patient is in no acute distress.  
4. There is decreased range of motion of the neck and increased hypertonicity in the paraspinal muscles on the right from C2–C7.
question_options:
What are the characteristics of motion at these spinal levels?  
A. Coupled movements occur only during extension  
B. Pure rotation occurs without associated sidebending  
C. Sidebending occurs with equal translation  
D. Sidebending is limited while rotation remains unrestricted  
E. Sidebending and rotation occur in the same direction.  
F. Rotation precedes sidebending in all movements  
G. Sidebending occurs independently of rotation  
H. Only flexion and extension occur in the specified levels.  
I. Sidebending and rotation occur in opposite directions.  
J. Rotation is limited to 45 degrees bilaterally

step1_excerpts:
1. A 72-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit for pain management and observation of ventricular ectopy 4 hours after undergoing uncomplicated left total knee replacement.
2. He is receiving fentanyl via systemic patient-controlled analgesic pump for pain management.
3. Medical history is remarkable for coronary artery disease, for which he takes atorvastatin, furosemide, carvedilol, lisinopril, and 81-mg aspirin.
4. Baseline echocardiogram showed an ejection fraction of 0.20.
5. Vital signs now are temperature 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse 90/min, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 130/90 mm Hg.
6. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%.
7. Physical examination discloses no unexpected abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following regimens for prophylaxis of deep venous thrombosis will likely be most beneficial in this patient?

A. Continuous application of bilateral lower extremity pneumatic compression devices

B. Continuous intravenous infusion of heparin titrated to a PTT of 1.5 to 2.0 times the control value

C. Oral warfarin

D. Subcutaneous enoxaparin

step1_excerpts:
1. An elderly woman was transferred from an extended care facility with lower abdominal pain.
2. She was afebrile with a heart rate of 120 beats/min on admission and leukocytosis (white blood cell count, 23 000/μL [to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001]).
3. Computed tomography of the abdomen and pelvis and transvaginal ultrasonography revealed a large intrauterine abscess.
4. An attempt to insert a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) into the right basilic vein was unsuccessful.
5. An intravenous catheter in the left hand was established for the administration of antibiotics.
6. The following day, the patient developed right upper extremity pain and swelling.
7. Physical examination revealed tense and tender swelling of the right upper extremity that was more marked in the upper arm and caused significant impairment in motor function, but sensation to touch and pin prick was intact (Figure 1A).
8. The right radial pulse was absent, but biphasic Doppler arterial signals were present in the right radial and ulnar artery.
9. Duplex ultrasonographic imaging of the right upper extremity demonstrated a 12.8 × 2.6-cm heterogeneous fluid collection with active color flow (Figure 1B).Patient presentation (A) and ultrasonographic imaging (B) of the upper arm.Extensive deep vein thrombosis of the upper extremityCompartment syndrome resulting from infiltration of intravenous infusion therapy into the soft tissues of the upper extremity
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Extensive deep vein thrombosis of the upper extremity  
B: Compartment syndrome resulting from infiltration of intravenous infusion therapy into the soft tissues of the upper extremity  
C: Secondary lymphedema of the upper extremity  
D: Brachial artery pseudoaneurysm

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 30s presented with a 3-year history of painful nodules on her lower extremities, neck, and jawline.  
2. Her medical history included seasonal allergies, and she did not take any prescription medications.  
3. She felt well and denied weight loss, night sweats, and any other systemic symptoms.  
4. Physical examination revealed scattered skin-colored papules on the right neck, a solitary 8-mm skin-colored nodule on the right jawline, and three 2- to 3-cm pink firm nodules on the right thigh (Figure, A and B).  
5. A shave biopsy was obtained from the nodule on the right jawline (Figure, C), and the thigh nodules were excised.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Neurofibromatosis type I  
B: Reed syndrome  
C: Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome  
D: Tuberous sclerosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 50-year-old woman is admitted to the emergency room for facial pain, weakness, and malaise.
2. She also has a throbbing headache.
3. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and HIV infection.
4. Home medications include zidovudine, lamivudine, lopinavir, ritonavir and metformin.
5. However, she admits to poor compliance with the medications.
6. The patient’s CD4 count is 121 cells/mm3, and viral load is 50,000.
7. Physical examination shows exquisite tenderness to palpation over the right maxillary sinus.
8. Additionally, there is a black eschar over her nares and palate.
question_options:
Which of the following symptoms would suggest a severe complication of the patient’s condition?

A. Impaired extraocular eye movements  
B. Unilateral ptosis  
C. Retro-orbital pain  
D. Proptosis with chemosis  
E. Reduced ability to detect odors  
F. Blood-tinged nasal discharge  
G. Diplopia with lateral gaze  
H. Decreased corneal reflex  
I. Altered mental status  
J. Facial numbness in V2 distribution

step1_excerpts:
1. A 79-year-old female presents for evaluation of a two-month history of nonproductive cough, fatigue, dyspnea on mild exertion, and a 4.5-kg weight loss.
2. Her medical history includes congestive heart failure, hypertension, a 47 pack-year smoking history, and 50 years of employment as a seamstress in a textile factory.
3. She recently traveled to India.
4. Current medications include enalapril, digoxin, isosorbide, spironolactone, and metoprolol.
5. Physical examination reveals a thin woman with dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds at the right lung base.
6. Vital signs show temperature 37.0°C, pulse 90/min, respirations 25/min, blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation 94% on room air.
7. Chest x-ray demonstrates right-sided nodular pleural lesions with moderate pleural effusion.
question_options:
What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's pleural effusion?

A. Pulmonary embolism with infarction  
B. Metastatic breast cancer  
C. Bacterial empyema  
D. Tuberculosis  
E. Rheumatoid pleuritis  
F. Asbestos-related benign pleural effusion  
G. Mesothelioma  
H. Bronchial adenocarcinoma  
I. Viral pleuritis  
J. Congestive heart failure-related transudate

step1_excerpts:
1. A 42-year-old African American male presented with a 7-month history of fatigue, exertional dyspnea, arthralgias, hand swelling, tender ulcerations, hair loss, and a 50-pound weight loss.
2. He had been hospitalized 6 months prior for hypoxia.
3. Chest computed tomography (CT) showed hilar lymphadenopathy, interstitial thickening, and perilymphatic ground glass opacities.
4. Bronchoscopy revealed plaquelike lesions, and transbronchial nodal aspiration of mediastinal nodes was negative for carcinomas and/or granulomas.
5. Prednisone was initiated for presumed sarcoidosis.
6. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, antinuclear antibodies, angiotensin-converting enzyme, rheumatoid factor, and Aspergillosis antigen were negative and/or normal.
7. The patient was referred for a second opinion.
8. On presentation he had symmetric swelling of metacarpophalangeal joints (MCPs) and interphalangeal joints (IPs), preventing fist formation.
9. Dorsal MCPs had ulcers distal fingers were dyspigmented and atrophic, capillaroscopy was normal, and palmar IP creases had ulcerated lichenoid papules (Figure, A and B).
10. Oxford Scale muscle strength was 5 of 5 throughout.
11. Auscultation revealed bibasilar rales.
12. He had normal aldolase levels (4.5 U/L [to convert to μkat/L, multiply by 0.0167]), depressed creatine kinase (32 U/L), hyperferritinemia (1543 ng/mL), and T lymphocytopenia (absolute CD3, CD4, and CD8 counts, 328 μL, 233 μL, and 85 μL, respectively); the patient also had anti-SSA (Ro) antibodies, and immunoglobulin G anticardiolipin antibodies (19.5 units).
13. The patient tested negative for HIV, anti–Scl-70 antibodies, anti–β2-glycoprotein 1 antibodies, lupus anticoagulant, cryoglobulins, and anti–Mi-2 antibodies; prothrombin time, partial thromboplastin time, and tissue thromboplastin were normal.
14. A, Edematous hands with crusted ulcers and surrounding hyperpigmentation overlying dorsal metacarpophalangeal joints and interphalangeal joints.
15. B, Ulcerating papules with crust located in the palmar creases of the priximal interphalangeal joints and distal interphalangeal joints.
16. C, Histopathology.
17. D, Chest computed tomography.
18. Antimelanoma differentiation associated gene 5 clinically amyopathic dermatomyositis
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Sarcoidosis and/or lymphoma syndrome  
B: Immunoglobulin G4-related disease  
C: Antimelanoma differentiation associated gene 5 clinically amyopathic dermatomyositis  
D: Systemic lupus erythematosus

step1_excerpts:
1. A 70-year old man with a history of soft contact lens wear presented for a general eye examination.
2. Visual acuity was 20/20 OU with normal intraocular pressure.
3. Several giant follicles were noted on the right inferior palpebral conjunctiva, and a few smaller follicles were noted in the left inferior fornix.
4. Papillae were also noted bilaterally on the superior palpebral conjunctiva.
5. He did not report any redness or discharge but did note mildly increased irritation mainly from soft contact lens wear.
6. He had endorsed proper contact lens care and hygiene.
7. He also noted an upper respiratory tract illness 4 weeks before presentation.
8. Initially, he received a giant papillary conjunctivitis diagnosis because of soft contact lens intolerance and a recommendation to take a contact lens break.
9. Because of the papillary reaction, prednisolone acetate, 1%, twice a day for 2 weeks was prescribed.
10. After 3 months, the symptoms had improved in the left eye, but conjunctival follicles were still present in the right inferior palpebral conjunctiva (Figure 1).
11. The patient subsequently underwent testing for chlamydia and gonorrhea, and the result was negative.
12. At the 1-year follow-up, the examination findings were unchanged.
13. During this follow-up, Lyme disease and Epstein-Barr virus serologic tests were performed in addition to repeated chlamydia testing.
14. The results were negative, except for a positive Epstein-Barr virus IgG.
15. Slitlamp photograph showing prominent large follicles (arrowhead) in the right inferior palpebral conjunctiva.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Start an empirical trial of oral azithromycin  
B: Start a longer trial of topical steroid with topical antihistamine  
C: Proceed with conjunctival biopsy  
D: Order chest radiography and an angiotensin-converting enzyme serum level test

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 50s presented to our dermatology department with an asymptomatic, arc-shaped, depressed skin groove on the left side of his forehead, frontal scalp, and vertex area.
2. Localized linear hair loss and hair thinning on the left scalp area were observed.
3. The patient reported that when the lesion had begun to appear, approximately 10 years earlier, he had received 2 doses of intralesional steroid via injection on a small bald patch on the vertex.
4. Thereafter, the lesion gradually progressed to the frontal scalp and eventually made a linear furrow on the left side of his forehead.
5. Physical examination revealed 2 long, curved-line, depressed, alopecic patches on the left side of the vertex and frontal scalp area extending to the left eyebrow (Figure, A and B).
6. The lesions measured (length × width) 7 × 2 cm and 6 × 1 cm, respectively.
7. Dermoscopic examination of the alopecic area revealed several short vellus hairs, yellow dots, and honeycomb hyperpigmentation; however, broken hairs were not seen.
8. The result of a hair pull test was negative.
9. The patient denied any trauma history and had no history of connective tissue disease nor any evidence of systemic involvement, such as arthralgia, photosensitivity, or skin rashes.
10. Skin biopsies were performed on the left side of the vertex and the forehead.
11. Histopathologic findings of the 2 biopsy specimens were identical (Figure, C and D).
12. A, Clinical image of annular arc from a longitudinally furrowed skin lesion on the left eyebrow and forehead to an alopecic lesion.
13. B, Clinical image of the bandlike grooved alopecic lesion on the left side of the frontal scalp and vertex.
14. C, Scanning view shows predominant lymphocytic infiltrates in perifollicular and periappendageal regions of the dermis and lobular panniculitis (hematoxylin-eosin staining).
15. D, High-power view shows inflammatory infiltrates between adipocytes with hyaline fat necrosis in the subcutis (hematoxylin-eosin staining).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Linear atrophoderma of Moulin  
B: Linear discoid lupus erythematosus  
C: Linear or annular lupus erythematosus panniculitis of the scalp  
D: Localized lipodystrophy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 36-year-old man presented with 2 weeks of episodic numbness and paresthesias in both feet, with symptom-free intervals between episodes.
2. Episodes progressed in frequency and duration, occurring several times daily and lasting for hours.
3. His symptoms were prominent after activity and reliably triggered by straining with urination and terminated by lying supine.
4. The patient also reported a 1-week history of urinary retention requiring intermittent self-catheterization.
5. Neurological examinations both during and between episodes revealed symmetric patellar and Achilles hyperreflexia with bilateral crossed adductor response, but otherwise the results were normal.
6. A thoracic spine magnetic resonance imaging scan with fast imaging employing steady-state acquisition (FIESTA) sequences was obtained (Figure).
7. A dynamic computed tomographic myelogram demonstrated a lesion compressing the dorsal spinal cord at the T7 level (Video).Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thoracic spine using fast imaging employing steady-state acquisition (FIESTA) sequences.
8. The MRI scan with FIESTA sequences revealed a blurry spinal cord signal alteration at the T7-T8 level with deformation of the cord posteriorly (arrowhead).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Anterior thoracolumbar spinal cord herniation  
B: Malignant neoplasm of the spinal cord  
C: Spinal dural arteriovenous fistula  
D: Spinal extradural arachnoid cyst

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 60s presented with a 1-year history of a pruritic, dark red plaque on his right upper eyelid.
2. No remarkable medical history was noted.
3. Physical examination findings revealed a 4 × 2-cm erythematous, violaceous, indurated, scaly plaque with some papules on his right upper eyelid (Figure, A).
4. Results of routine blood tests and biochemistry analysis were within normal limits.
5. A biopsy sample was obtained for histopathologic examination (Figure, B).A, A 4 × 2-cm erythematous, violaceous, indurated, scaly plaque with some papules on the right upper eyelid.
6. B, Lesional specimen (original magnification ×50).
7. C, High-power magnification of histopathologic examination; arrows indicate atypical lymphocytes (hematoxylin-eosin).
8. D, Lymphocytic infiltrates predominantly positive for CD4.Histopathologic analysis revealed perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrates around cystically dilated follicular infundibula and exocytosis of atypical lymphocytes into the epithelium, with admixed plasma cells, eosinophils, and multinucleate giant cells (Figure, C).
9. Alcian blue staining showed focal mild follicular mucin deposition.
10. Immunohistochemical analysis showed lymphocytic infiltrates positive for CD3, CD4, CD5, and CD7 and negative for CD8, CD20, CD30, CD79a, and CD56 (Figure, D).
11. The ratio of CD4 to CD8 cells within hair follicles was greater than 7:1.
12. Monoclonal T-cell gene rearrangement was demonstrated.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Discoid lupus erythematosus  
B: Facial papules in frontal fibrosing alopecia  
C: Unilesional folliculotropic mycosis fungoides  
D: Jessner lymphocytic infiltrate

step1_excerpts:
1. A 49-year-old man presents with 3 months of generalized weakness.
2. He has had a chronic cough and a 20 pound unintentional weight loss over the past 6 months.
3. He has a medical history significant for high blood pressure, hyperlipidemia, and seasonal allergies with no prior surgical history.
4. He has no history of tobacco use.
5. He moved from India 7 years prior to presentation.
6. He currently lives in Oregon and has not left the west coast since moving.
7. His temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 16/min.
8. His physical exam is significant for hyperpigmentation of the oral mucosa and temporal muscle wasting.
9. Radiography of the abdomen demonstrates bilateral adrenal calcifications.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Prednisone taper  
B. Bilateral adrenalectomy, prednisone, and fludrocortisone  
C. Rifamycin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, ethambutol, and hydrocortisone therapy  
D. Hydrocortisone and immunoglobulin therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A healthy 29-year-old pregnant woman, with 34 weeks’ gestational age, presented to the emergency department with diffused acute abdominal pain and vomiting.  
2. The pain was located in the periumbilical region and intensified within a few hours.  
3. The patient felt normal fetal movements during this time.  
4. An initial surgical evaluation was done, and the cause for the abdominal pain was assumed to be not of surgical condition.  
5. Next, the patient was evaluated by an obstetrician-gynecologist, and although the gynecologic examination, ultrasonography, and monitoring were all normal, the patient was admitted for further supervision in the obstetrics department.  
6. The next day, when the abdominal pain and vomiting persisted and an elevated leukocyte blood count of 14 200/mL was noted (to convert to ×109 per liter, multiply by 0.001), a second surgical consultation was done.  
7. The physical examination was significant for diffuse abdominal tenderness.  
8. Although the patient was pregnant, and owing to nonavailability of magnetic resonance imaging at that time, a contrast-enhanced abdominopelvic computed tomography was performed (Figure 1).  
9. Coronal computed tomographic image showing an edematous small intestinal loop on the left abdomen, with uterus and head of fetus in the pelvis.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Crohn ileitis  
B: Foreign body ingestion  
C: Ileo-colic intussusception  
D: Adenocarcinoma of small intestine

step1_excerpts:
1. A 25-year-old woman presents for evaluation of primary amenorrhea.
2. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications.
3. She reports that she is not sexually active.
4. On physical examination, she is 132 cm tall and weighs 49 kg.
5. Her blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 80 beats per minute.
6. She has a webbed neck without thyromegaly.
7. She has a broad chest with widely spaced nipples.
8. Breast development and pubic hair are consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 2.
9. Cardiac auscultation reveals an early systolic ejection click.
question_options:
Which one of the following cardiac anomalies is most likely to be found on an echocardiogram in this patient?

A. Bicuspid aortic valve  
B. Ventricular septal defect  
C. Tricuspid valve regurgitation  
D. Atrial septal defect  
E. Pulmonary valve stenosis  
F. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome  
G. Mitral valve prolapse  
H. Pulmonary stenosis  
I. Coarctation of the aorta  
J. Aortic root dilation

step1_excerpts:
1. A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency room with a laceration over the 4th metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint of his right hand.
2. He reports that he is a mailman, and his closed fist was bitten by a dog while he was delivering mail yesterday.
3. He reports pain but denies fevers, chills, drainage, or any other symptoms.
4. The dog is up to date on vaccinations.
5. His last tetanus vaccine was 3 years ago.
6. He has no medical history and takes no medications.
7. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg, and respirations are 16/min.
8. Examination of the patient's right hand is shown in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Clindamycin
