J. Initiate methotrexate therapy for suspected inflammatory arthritis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 30-year-old man was referred with progressive quadriplegia for 2 months.
2. The muscle weakness started from the right lower limb and gradually spread to the upper limb and contralateral side.
3. Urinary retention developed 1 month later.
4. Because he was suspected of having tubercular meningomyelitis, he received an antituberculosis regimen plus dexamethasone (10 mg daily) for 10 days.
5. The symptoms ameliorated in the first week but thereafter deteriorated with fever.
6. He had no history of central nervous system injury or drug overuse.
7. He was a construction supervisor and had daily contact with moist earth.
8. No relevant family history was reported.
9. On physical examination, he was alert and well oriented.
10. The cranial nerve was intact, but he had quadriplegia with a Medical Research Council muscle scale grade of 0 of 5 power, decreased tendon reflexes, and bilateral positive Babinski sign.
11. Pinprick and vibration sensation were markedly impaired below the nipples.
12. Multiple enlarged cervical lymph nodes could be palpitated.
13. The skin was extraordinarily dry, and a pigmentation of 10 mm in diameter at the T2 vertebrae, just on the midline of the back, was noticed.
14. Total blood T-cell count (CD3+) was 1643/uL (to convert to ×109 per liter, multiply by 0.001), and the patient had a CD4+/CD8+ ratio of 0.89.
15. Results of blood testing for human immunodeficiency virus, syphilis, and tuberculosis were negative.
16. Cerebrospinal fluid testing revealed pleocytosis (72 cells/uL; mononuclear cells, 59 of 72), elevated protein concentration (200 mg/dL), and a decreased glucose level (36.0 mg/dL [to convert to millimoles per liter, multiply by 0.0555]), but no organisms were identified on Gram stain or on stain for acid-fast bacilli.
17. Pulmonary computed tomography showed enlarged lymph nodes in mediastinum and axillary regions.
18. Results from magnetic resonance imaging of the brain were normal, while magnetic resonance imaging of the cervical spine revealed multiple intramedullary lesions with enhancement (Figure 1).Magnetic resonance imaging of the cervical spine.
19. Multiple intramedullary lesions and enlarged lymph nodes with strong enhancement were revealed.
20. A, Lateral view of the cervical cord.
21. The subcutaneous abscess beneath the pigmentation on the back is also shown.
22. Inset, photograph of the skin lesion on the back.
23. B, Coronal view of the cervical cord.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Tubercular meningomyelitis  
B: Mycotic meningomyelitis  
C: Neurosarcoidosis  
D: Central nervous system lymphoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 62-year-old patient presented to the ophthalmology department with sudden painless vision loss in her right eye that occurred 24 hours ago.  
2. She also reported a 4-week history of right ear pain and fullness, discomfort over her frontal and maxillary sinuses, and nasal congestion without discharge.  
3. Over the past 2 weeks, she had experienced drenching night sweats, cramps in her quadriceps, and weight loss of 3 kg.  
4. She denied respiratory symptoms, headaches, scalp tenderness, or jaw claudication.  
5. She took no regular medication and did not smoke.  
6. At presentation, her visual acuities were perception of light OD and 20/20 OS.  
7. There was a right relative afferent pupillary defect.  
8. Dilated fundus examination showed a cherry red spot in the right macula with hyperreflectivity and thickening of the inner retinal layers on optical coherence tomography (Figure 1A and B).  
9. External eye examination results and ocular motility were normal.  
10. Examination by an otolaryngologist revealed normal tympanic membranes and a dry but otherwise normal nasal mucosa on flexible endoscopy.  
11. Blood tests showed leukocytosis (white blood cell count, 15 000 /µL; to convert to 109 per liter, multiply by 0.001) with neutrophilia (white blood cell count, 12 500 /µL), elevated C-reactive protein (19.4 mg/dL; to convert to milligrams per liter, multiply by 10), elevated plasma viscosity (2.06 mPas), and thrombocytosis (467 ×103/µL; to convert to ×109 per liter, multiply by 1).  
12. Kidney function was within normal limits.  
13. Chest radiograph results were unremarkable.  
14. False-color and red-free (inset) fundus photograph of the right eye shows retinal pallor (white arrowheads) with a cherry red spot (yellow arrowhead) in the macula (A).  
15. Optical coherence tomography of the right macula shows hyperreflectivity and thickening of the inner retinal layers (yellow arrowheads) and hyporeflectivity of the outer retinal layers (blue arrowheads), except for increased signal intensity in the outer retinal layers of the fovea (white arrowhead) (B).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  

A: Request a magnetic resonance image of orbits and sinuses  
B: Commence high-dose corticosteroids  
C: Commence broad-spectrum antibiotics  
D: Request urgent stroke consult

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 30s was referred to the retina clinic with a diagnosis of bilateral branch retinal vein occlusions.  
2. He reported flashes and progressive blurry vision in both eyes over a period of 6 days.  
3. He had no history of eye problems.  
4. His medical history was negative for diabetes and hypertension, and review of systems was positive for recent easy bruising and progressive fatigue.  
5. His initial best-corrected visual acuity was 20/25 OD and 20/50 OS.  
6. Results from examination of his pupils, motility, intraocular pressures, confrontational visual fields, and anterior segments were normal.  
7. A dilated fundus examination was conducted (Figure).  
8. He had bilateral flame-shaped and intraretinal hemorrhages in both maculae along the superior arcades and some scattered peripheral hemorrhages.  
9. There was no vessel tortuosity, and there were hard exudates in the left macula.  
10. Spectral-domain optical coherence tomography showed areas of hyperreflectivity in the middle and outer retina.  
11. Fluorescein angiography of both eyes showed blocking in the areas of hemorrhage, good venous filling, no leakage, and no neovascularization.Wide-field scanning laser image of the left eye showed superficial and intraretinal hemorrhages and hard exudates.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Obtain an infectious and inflammatory panel  
B: Observe  
C: Obtain a complete blood cell count  
D: Inject an anti–vascular endothelial growth factor

step1_excerpts:
1. A 31-year-old woman with a 2-year history of anorexia nervosa presents for follow-up.
2. She reports some improvement with cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) but continues to struggle with body image and fear of weight gain.
3. Over the past three weeks, she has noticed morning ankle swelling.
4. She also reports intermittent menstruation, with her last period occurring four months ago.
5. She denies suicidal ideations, smoking, alcohol use, or recreational drug use.
6. Her vital signs include a temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 55/min, blood pressure 100/69 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 18/min.
7. Her BMI is 17.1 kg/m², up from 16.9 kg/m² six months ago.
8. Physical examination reveals an irregular heart rhythm and 3+ pitting edema in both lower extremities.
9. ECG findings show multiple isolated premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) and a 10-second episode of bigeminy.
question_options:
Which aspect of this patient’s presentation most strongly indicates the need for inpatient hospitalization?

A. Isolated premature ventricular contractions on ECG  
B. BMI of 17.1 kg/m2  
C. Fear of weight gain despite CBT progress  
D. History of intermittent menstruation  
E. Pitting edema without other systemic findings  
F. Lower extremity edema  
G. Recent weight gain  
H. History of anorexia nervosa  
I. Abnormal ECG  
J. Pulse of 55/min

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever and worsening low back pain.
2. He has a history of chronic lower back pain and underwent a lumbar facet joint injection three months ago.
3. Six weeks ago, he began experiencing persistent pain in the lower back that was different from his usual symptoms and did not improve with rest or medication.
4. A fever developed the day before his visit.
5. His medical history includes diabetes managed with Metformin and rheumatoid arthritis treated with daily prednisone.
6. On examination, his temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 134/82 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air.
7. Physical examination reveals midline tenderness over L1, and a neurological exam is nonfocal.
8. X-ray findings show destructive changes in the L1 and L2 vertebral bodies with collapse of the intervening disc space.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the likely diagnosis?

B. Lumbar puncture  
C. Magnetic resonance imaging  
E. Repeat X-ray imaging in 2 weeks  
F. Blood cultures  
G. Image-guided biopsy and culture  
H. Bone scintigraphy  
I. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein  
J. Operative exploration

step1_excerpts:
1. A previously healthy 24-year-old woman who is a college student comes to the office because of a 6-month history of abdominal bloating, upper abdominal discomfort, and constipation.
2. The symptoms are more severe when she is preparing for examinations but improve after bowel movements.
3. She takes no medications.
4. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs.
5. She drinks alcoholic beverages occasionally.
6. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 57 kg (125 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2 .
7. Her pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 100/72 mm Hg.
8. Physical examination, including digital rectal examination, shows no other abnormalities.
9. A complete blood count and serum electrolyte concentrations are within the reference ranges.
10. A urease breath test result is negative.
11. Upper and lower endoscopies show no abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?

A. Azathioprine

B. Infliximab

C. Lubiprostone

D. Mesalamine

step1_excerpts:
1. An 18-year-old man presents to his primary care provider with his parents for a sports physical.
2. He was last seen in the clinic several months ago when he was diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).
3. He was started on methylphenidate at that time and the patient now reports improvement in his ability to concentrate in school and at home.
4. He hopes to play baseball in college and has begun lifting weights daily in preparation for baseball season.
5. The patient has a healthy diet to fuel his exercise regimen.
6. His parents have no concerns and are pleased with the recent improvement in his grades.
7. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 115/71 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 12/min.
8. On physical exam, the patient has tall stature with average muscle mass for his age.
9. He has no dysmorphic features.
10. His chest has a normal appearance other than mild gynecomastia.
11. The patient has sparse facial hair and a moderate amount of coarse pubic hair that extends across the pubis and spares the medial thighs.
12. His testes are small and firm.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s presentation?

A. CGG trinucleotide repeat disorder  
B. Anabolic steroid use  
C. Failure of neuronal migration  
D. Meiotic nondisjunction

step1_excerpts:
1. A 41-year-old man presents to his primary care provider after seeing bright red blood in the toilet bowl after his last 2 bowel movements.
2. He reports that he also noticed some blood mixed with his stool.
3. The patient denies abdominal pain or any changes in his stool habits.
4. He notes a weight loss of 8 pounds in the last 2 months with no changes in his diet or exercise habits.
5. His medical history is significant for an episode of pancreatitis 2 years ago for which he was hospitalized for several days.
6. He drinks 2-3 beers on the weekend and he has never smoked.
7. He has no family history of colon cancer.
8. His temperature is 97.6°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 135/78 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 14/min.
9. On physical exam, his abdomen is soft and non-tender to palpation.
10. Bowel sounds are present, and there is no hepatomegaly.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Abdominal CT  
B. Colonoscopy  
C. Ultrasound of abdomen  
D. Barium enema

step1_excerpts:
1. A previously healthy 4-year-old girl with a history of prematurity (31 weeks’ gestational age) presented as a transfer from an outside facility with abdominal pain.  
2. She had presented to an outside emergency department 2 days prior with lower abdominal pain that subsequently localized to the right lower quadrant.  
3. Her pain was accompanied by anorexia and nonbloody, nonbilious emesis.  
4. She denied fevers or chills.  
5. She was noted to have voluntary guarding and focal right lower quadrant tenderness to palpation.  
6. Laboratory analyses demonstrated a mild leukocytosis (white blood cell count = 14 × 103/μL [to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001]) and normal urinalysis results.  
7. Abdominal ultrasonography images were obtained that failed to show her appendix and demonstrated no secondary signs of inflammation.  
8. Because of her notable tenderness, she was admitted for observation at the referring facility.  
9. No antibiotics were initiated, and her activity improved with intravenous hydration.  
10. However, her right lower abdominal pain persisted, prompting further evaluation.  
11. Computed tomography images of the abdomen and pelvis were obtained, and the representative images are shown in Figure 1.  
12. She was transferred to our facility for surgical evaluation.  
13. In our emergency department, pelvic ultrasonography images were obtained that failed to show both the appendix and right adnexal structures.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?  
A: Perforated appendicitis  
B: Meckel diverticulitis  
C: Crohn disease  
D: Ectopic ovarian torsion

step1_excerpts:
1. A 36-year-old G3P2002 woman presents to her obstetrician’s office for her 1st prenatal visit at 10 weeks and 2 days gestation.
2. She has felt nauseous the last several mornings and has been tired for a few weeks.
3. The patient has had 2 uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal deliveries at full term with her last child born 6 years ago.
4. She is concerned about the risk of Down syndrome in this fetus, as her sister gave birth to an affected child at age 43.
5. She has a history of generalized anxiety disorder, atopic dermatitis, and she is currently on escitalopram.
6. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), pulse is 70/min, blood pressure is 121/67 mmHg, and respirations are 13/min.
7. The patient appears anxious, but overall comfortable, and cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable.
8. Pelvic exam reveals normal external genitalia, a closed and soft cervix, a 10-week-sized uterus, and no adnexal masses.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for definitively determining whether this patient’s fetus has Down syndrome?

A. Anatomy ultrasound  
B. Genetic testing of patient’s sister  
C. Nuchal translucency test  
D. Chorionic villus sampling

step1_excerpts:
1. A 44-year-old man presented with a 4-month history of gradual vision loss in both eyes.
2. He had a medical history of hypertension, anxiety, and posttraumatic stress disorder, for which he took amlodipine, lorazepam, citalopram, and quetiapine.
3. He smoked 1.5 packs of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years and had a history of substantial alcohol use, drinking 2 to 3 L of wine per day.
4. Because of excessive alcohol intake, he only ate 1 meal per day.
5. His family history was unremarkable for optic nerve conditions or unexplained blindness.
6. On examination, his visual acuity was 20/400 OU, there was no relative afferent pupillary defect, and his anterior segment examination results were normal.
7. Dilated fundus examination results revealed bilateral optic nerve hyperemia, blurred margins, and subtle telangiectatic vessels on the surface of the optic nerve bilaterally.
8. Humphrey 24-2 Swedish Interactive Testing Algorithm fast visual field testing showed central scotomas in both eyes (Figure).
9. Optical coherence tomography results of the macula were normal in both eyes.
10. Neurological examination results revealed otherwise normal cranial nerves, normal sensation in the extremities, normal reflexes, and normal strength.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Liver function tests  
B: Assess serum vitamin B12 and folate levels  
C: Treatment with disulfiram  
D: Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain

step1_excerpts:
1. A 53-year-old woman with stage IV renal cell carcinoma was treated with pembrolizumab, a PD-1 inhibitor, for 20 months before developing a diffuse pruritic eruption recalcitrant to topical and oral corticosteroids.  
2. After 1 month of ongoing rash, pembrolizumab was discontinued.  
3. Her pruritic eruption persisted over the next 5 months despite treatment with up to 80 mg/d of oral prednisone.  
4. She did not report fever during this period.  
5. A shave biopsy performed while the patient was receiving systemic corticosteroids demonstrated spongiotic dermatitis with a mixed-cell infiltrate suggesting an incipient autoimmune bullous process.  
6. Results of follow-up direct immunofluorescence (DIF) performed on a sample taken 15 days after steroid discontinuation were negative.  
7. The eruption continued to worsen when the patient was not receiving systemic corticosteroids, with blisters developing 7.5 weeks after their discontinuation, prompting her presentation to the emergency department.  
8. On examination, the patient was afebrile and hemodynamically stable.  
9. Blood pressure was elevated to 136/98 mm Hg; other vital signs were within normal limits.  
10. She had tense bullae and indurated papules and plaques involving the face, trunk, and extremities (Figure, left), and oral mucosal erosions (Figure, right).  
11. Laboratory findings were notable for erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level being elevated to 25 mm/h and 16.8 mg/dL, respectively, with a normal white blood cell count.  
12. Patient presentation.  
13. Left, Bullae on bilateral lower extremities.  
14. Right, Oral mucosal erosions.  
15. Provide intravenous fluids and wound care in a burn unit Repeat punch biopsy for hematoxylin-eosin staining and DIF
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Start a different PD-1 inhibitor  
B: Provide intravenous fluids and wound care in a burn unit  
C: Repeat punch biopsy for hematoxylin-eosin staining and DIF  
D: Discharge with topical triamcinolone 0.5% cream

step1_excerpts:
1. A 27-year-old woman presents with a rapidly progressing painful ulceration on the left leg (Figure) with intermittent high fevers.  
2. The lesion began as 2 sesame seed–sized violaceous, papulovesicular rashes with an erythematous halo on her left medial malleolus 12 days prior to presentation.  
3. Within 1 week, more papulovesicles appeared, merged, and ulcerated spontaneously (Figure, A and B).  
4. The ulceration expanded outwardly at a rapid pace, with increasing pain and a hemorrhagic exudative discharge (Figure, C [left panel]).  
5. The lesion did not respond to treatment with systemic antibiotics, including vancomycin and meropenem.  
6. During the prior 5 months, she experienced mild diarrhea, which was ultimately diagnosed as Crohn disease by colonoscopy with biopsy.Skin lesion progression and histopathological changes (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×200).Physical examination reveals a pale, febrile patient with left leg edema and a rounded, swollen, and tender 10 × 10-cm ulceration on her left medial malleolus.  
7. The ulceration has a raised rugged surface with thick hemorrhagic exudates and a surrounding violaceous-greyish necrotic border (Figure, C [left panel]).Laboratory tests show moderate anemia, hypoalbuminemia, and fecal occult blood.  
8. Histopathology of skin lesions shows dermal edema with dense infiltration of neutrophils and vascular fibrinoid necrosis (Figure, C [right panel]).  
9. Results of acid-fast staining, periodic acid–Schiff staining, bacterial and mycological cultures of skin biopsy specimens, and blood cultures are negative.  
10. Doppler studies of lower-limb arteries and deep veins are unremarkable, and serum autoantibodies, including antiphospholipid autoantibodies, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, antinuclear antibodies, and extractable nuclear antigen antibodies, are not detected.Change dressings daily and implement hyperbaric oxygen therapySurgically excise the lesion, followed by skin grafting
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Change dressings daily and implement hyperbaric oxygen therapy  
B: Prescribe systemic corticosteroids  
C: Surgically excise the lesion, followed by skin grafting  
D: Continue with broad-spectrum antibiotics

step1_excerpts:
1. A 69-year-old man with a history of relapsed acute myeloid leukemia (AML) monocytic type presented with intermittent fever and fatigue 2 months after allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT).
2. Post-SCT bone marrow biopsy specimen analysis at day 30 showed no evidence of leukemic cells and 99.5% donor cells.
3. His home medications included acyclovir, fluconazole, and cyclosporine.
4. Temperature on admission was 103.1° F, and other vital signs were unremarkable.
5. Vancomycin and cefepime were started for possible infection.
6. Complete blood cell counts with differential counts showed no evidence of peripheral blasts.
7. Laboratory and imaging work-up—including chest radiographs, blood culture, fungal culture, urinalysis, sputum culture, respiratory viral panel, fungitell and galactomannan assay, coccidioidomycosis serology, and cytomegalovirus and human herpesvirus 6 polymerase chain reaction assays—were all negative.
8. The patient was discharged with oral antibiotics after being afebrile for 72 hours.
9. Thereafter, he had 2 more emergency department visits and was readmitted for recurrent fever.
10. A thorough physical examination revealed 2 nonpruritic skin bumps on the right forearm and left calf that both measured 1.0 cm × 1.5 cm.
11. Both bumps were soft without pigmentation or ulceration.
12. Pathologic sampling of the respective lesions revealed a diffuse infiltration of large mononuclear cells with high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio (Figure, A and B).
13. Immunohistochemistry staining was positive for CD4 cells and myeloperoxidase (Figure, C and D)A and B, Histologic evaluation of the skin biopsy specimens.
14. C and D, Immunohistochemical analysis.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus skin infection  
B: Candida tropicalis  
C: Leukemia cutis  
D: Disseminated coccidioidomycosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after an episode of jerking his extremities followed by confusion.
2. This has happened in the past, but his mother thought he was fabricating his symptoms.
3. She has taken him to a free health clinic to have him seen by a doctor who prescribed medication; however, she has been unable to fill the prescription.
4. He has had an MRI of the brain with no acute findings in the past.
5. The mother states this episode lasted about 3 minutes and involved full-body jerking.
6. After the episode, the child was non-responsive but was breathing on his own.
7. The child has a history of migraine headaches with aura that resolve with ibuprofen.
8. He is otherwise healthy and has no medical problems or recent illness and is up to date on his vaccinations.
9. His temperature is 97.6°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 100/64 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air.
10. The patient is protecting his airway but is unable to answer questions.
11. He is able to move the right upper and lower extremity.
12. He initially is unable to move his left upper and lower extremity and has a left facial droop; however, after a few minutes, he has 4/5 strength in the affected side with resolution of his facial weakness.
13. The mother notes that this is similar to his past episodes.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A. Diazepam  
B. Observation  
C. Sumatriptan  
D. CT head

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old female patient is evaluated for a 3-month history of difficulty walking.
2. She reports a lifelong history of recurrent left ankle sprains.
3. Her medical history includes hypertension, for which she is prescribed lisinopril.
4. Vital signs include a blood pressure of 136/90 mm Hg, heart rate of 88/min, respiratory rate of 14/min, and temperature of 37.6°C (99.7°F).
5. The patient is alert and oriented.
6. Cardiac auscultation reveals a grade 1/6 systolic murmur at the left sternal border, and her lungs are clear bilaterally.
7. Examination of the distal fibula shows external rotation of the talus.
question_options:
What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A. Cuboid somatic dysfunction  
B. Medial tibial torsion  
C. Talus anterior somatic dysfunction  
D. Subtalar joint dysfunction  
E. Distal fibular fracture without displacement  
F. Posterior fibular head dysfunction  
G. Navicular somatic dysfunction  
H. Lateral tibial torsion  
I. Anterior fibular head dysfunction  
J. Plantar fascia strain

step1_excerpts:
1. A 22-year-old man presented with an 8-year history of painful and slightly pruritic skin lesions on his right flank.
2. The number of lesions and degree of pain had alternately increased and decreased over the years.
3. Occasionally the lesions would rupture and leak clear fluid.
4. One year prior, he was hospitalized for a “skin infection” on his right flank and treated with intravenous antibiotics.
5. The patient, a construction demolition worker, was otherwise healthy and took no medications.
6. He had 1 lifetime female sexual partner with whom he used barrier contraception.
7. Physical examination revealed an asymmetric cluster of lesions on the right flank measuring 14 × 12 cm at the widest margins (Figure 1).
8. The cluster contained verrucous papules and plaques in the center and vesicles filled with clear and milky-white fluid in the periphery.
9. Crust was partially covering some of the lesions.
10. The surrounding skin was erythematous without warmth or induration.
11. The remainder of the physical examination was normal except for stretch marks on the lateral abdomen.Left, Vesicular and verrucous skin lesions on patient’s right flank.
12. Right, Close-up view of lesions.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Biopsy the lesions  
B: Prescribe oral valacyclovir  
C: Prescribe topical cantharadin  
D: Recommend a gluten-free diet

step1_excerpts:
1. An African American woman in her early to mid-60s presented to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of flashes and occasional floaters in her left eye for the past 2 weeks.  
2. She had been seen 7 months prior to presentation for a comprehensive eye evaluation.  
3. She was found to have a bilateral posterior vitreous detachment, and the results of her retinal examination at that time were normal.  
4. Her best-corrected vision was 20/20 OU, and the intraocular pressure in each eye was normal.  
5. An anterior segment examination of the left eye revealed trace keratic precipitates on the inferior cornea and 1+ cell.  
6. A posterior segment examination revealed 1+ vitreous cell.  
7. A photograph from a fundus examination is shown in Figure 1.  
8. The right eye was normal.  
9. Color fundus photograph of the left eye demonstrating notably clear media and whitish-yellow periarterial lesions.  
10. Observe, because her symptoms are likely from her prior posterior vitreous detachment Fluorescein angiography and workup for infectious and inflammatory etiologies Treat with oral prednisone 60 mg daily followed by a slow taper
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Observe, because her symptoms are likely from her prior posterior vitreous detachment  
B: Cardiology consultation and workup for hypercoagulability  
C: Fluorescein angiography and workup for infectious and inflammatory etiologies  
D: Treat with oral prednisone 60 mg daily followed by a slow taper

step1_excerpts:
1. A 48-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a biking accident in which he fell over the handlebars onto the ground while riding on uneven terrain.
2. His medical history includes hypercholesterolemia and a recent diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis, for which he is currently on apixaban therapy.
3. On arrival, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 102/63 mmHg, pulse is 109/min, and hemoglobin is 10.3 g/dL.
4. Physical examination reveals a large, painful, non-pulsatile mass in the right rectus abdominis region with overlying ecchymoses.
5. The mass does not shift position when the abdominal muscles are contracted.
question_options:
What is the next best step in managing this patient?

A. Call a consult for emergent angioembolization of the epigastric arteries  
B. Transfuse fresh frozen plasma  
C. Administer intravenous fluid bolus  
D. Discontinue apixaban immediately and monitor clinically  
E. Obtain CT abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast  
F. Administer packed red blood cells immediately  
G. Administer intravenous vitamin K  
H. Initiate broad-spectrum antibiotics for potential infection  
I. Follow serial complete blood counts  
J. Perform bedside ultrasound of the abdomen

step1_excerpts:
1. A 75-year old woman with a history of follicular lymphoma and breast cancer presented with a 3-month history of gradual vision loss and 1-month history of confusion and difficulty with word finding.
2. She had been diagnosed with hormone receptor–positive right breast cancer 8 years prior and underwent lumpectomy and treatment with an aromatase inhibitor, with remission since.
3. Five years later, she subsequently developed left inguinal adenopathy, which biopsy results showed was follicular lymphoma.
4. At that time, she was treated with a course of bendamustine and rituximab with subsequent maintenance treatment with rituximab for 2 years.
5. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain was performed, demonstrating T2 fluid-attenuated inversion recovery hyperintensity in the left occipital and temporal lobes, crossing the corpus callosum and extending into the right occipital lobe without enhancement (Figure).A, Axial T2 fluid-attenuated inversion recovery precontrast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain.
6. B, Axial T1 magnetization-prepared rapid acquisition gradient-echo postcontrast MRI of the brain.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Metastatic breast cancer  
B: Central nervous system lymphoma  
C: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy  
D: Glioma

step1_excerpts:
1. A previously healthy 19-year-old college student comes to student health services 24 hours after the onset of headache, stiff neck, and sensitivity to light.  
2. She does not recall any sick contacts.  
3. She had chickenpox at the age of 7 years.  
4. Her most recent examination 1 year ago included PPD skin testing and showed no abnormalities.  
5. She takes a daily multivitamin and an herbal weight-loss preparation.  
6. She received all appropriate immunizations during childhood but has not received any since then.  
7. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs.  
8. There is no family history of serious illness.  
9. She appears lethargic.  
10. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg.  
11. Examination shows diffuse petechiae.  
12. Kernig and Brudzinski signs are present.  
13. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.  
14. A lumbar puncture is performed.  
15. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows numerous segmented neutrophils and a decreased glucose concentration.  
16. A Gram stain of the CSF shows gram-negative cocci.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

A. Ceftriaxone

B. Clindamycin

C. Erythromycin

D. Metronidazole

step1_excerpts:
1. A 15-year-old male presents to the office with the complaint of painless swelling in the left testicle that has varied in size over the past several months.  
2. There is no history of trauma.  
3. The lesion transilluminates well, and no inguinal nodes are palpable.  
4. Findings from a testicular scan are normal.
question_options:
The most appropriate management includes  

A. injection with a sclerosing agent  

B. needle aspiration  

C. needle biopsy  

D. surgical repair

step1_excerpts:
1. A 26-year-old male police officer comes to the office for an annual health maintenance examination.
2. He is physically active and feels well, but he notes that his asthma has been more active during the past month.
3. He says that he has had to use his albuterol inhaler one to two times daily for wheezing and chest tightness.
4. He has not had gastroesophageal reflux symptoms, productive cough, or fever.
5. Medical history is remarkable for atopic allergies, especially to pollen and cats.
6. He has had coldand exercise-induced asthma for the past 14 years.
7. He takes no other medications.
8. He is 188 cm (6 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (200 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2 .
9. Vital signs are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 70/min, respirations 12/min, and blood pressure 120/76 mm Hg.
10. Physical examination shows no abnormalities except for scattered rhonchi and wheezes with forced expiration.
11. Peak expiratory flow rate is 240 L/min.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A. Chest x-ray

B. Fexofenadine therapy

C. Increased use of the albuterol inhaler

D. Initiation of a daily corticosteroid inhaler

step1_excerpts:
1. A 19-year-old male presents with a 4-week history of recurrent headaches.  
2. He denies any history of head trauma but mentions experiencing increased stress at school, which worsens the headaches.  
3. On physical examination, the patient appears comfortable, and cranial nerves II-XII are intact.  
4. During an osteopathic structural exam, while performing the vault hold, you note that the left greater wing of the sphenoid is positioned more superiorly compared to the right.
question_options:
Which axis is associated with this dysfunction?

A. One transverse axis and one anteroposterior axis  
B. One vertical and one transverse axis  
C. Two vertical axes  
D. Two transverse axes  
E. One anteroposterior axis  
F. One transverse axis and two vertical axes  
G. One anteroposterior axis and two vertical axes  
H. One oblique axis and one anteroposterior axis  
I. Two oblique axes  
J. A single sagittal axis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 43-year-old construction worker experienced bilateral lower extremity crush injuries after a large heavy object fell onto his thighs, traumatically amputating his right leg.  
2. He also had a left leg degloving injury, distal femur fracture, and posterior knee dislocation with bleeding through the open fractures and wounds.  
3. He was profoundly hypotensive (blood pressure, 70/40 mm Hg) and anemic (hemoglobin level, 5.6 g/dL [to convert to grams per liter, multiply by 10]) from extensive blood loss.  
4. He was urgently transfused and taken to the operating room for bilateral lower extremity irrigation and drainage and reconstruction of the left leg.  
5. Unfortunately, postoperative infection necessitated a left leg above-knee amputation.  
6. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit, intubated, and sedated for 1 month.  
7. On awakening, he reported that he was unable to see out of each eye.  
8. Bedside examination revealed no light perception vision with 7-mm pupils that were nonreactive bilaterally.  
9. Extraocular movements were full and there was no ptosis.  
10. Slitlamp examination findings were normal, and fundus photographs of the posterior pole in each eye are presented in the Figure.  
11. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain performed earlier in the hospitalization was normal.  
12. The patient was previously healthy and did not take any medications.  
13. Appearance of the optic nerves in fundus photographs taken 4 weeks after the patient’s injury at work.  
14. The optic discs are characterized by diffuse pallor, with no evidence of edema or hemorrhages.  
15. The remainder of the posterior pole, including macula and vessels, appear normal bilaterally.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Test patient with optokinetic nystagmus drum  
B: Repeat magnetic resonance imaging of the brain  
C: Counsel the patient on the prognosis of his condition  
D: Test pupils with dilute pilocarpine

step1_excerpts:
1. A man with a 3-year history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presented with increasing dyspnea on exertion, requiring increasing flow rates of oxygen.
2. He was a former smoker with a 50–pack-year history.
3. He had been diagnosed with stage I low-grade prostate cancer several years previously.
4. Lung examination showed no wheezing.
5. Cardiac examination showed a prominent pulmonary component (P2) of the second heart sound.
6. Noncontrast computed tomography of the chest was unremarkable.
7. An echocardiogram revealed dilated right atrium and ventricle.
8. Spirometry showed mild airway obstruction.
9. Duplex ultrasound showed a nonocclusive thrombus in the left femoral and popliteal veins.
10. Catheterization of the right side of the heart showed a pulmonary arterial pressure of 79/32 mm Hg (mean, 48 mm Hg) with a normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.
11. A ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan was obtained (Figure, panel A), followed by pulmonary angiography (Figure, panel B).
12. A, Ventilation/perfusion scan, right anterior oblique view.
13. B, Pulmonary angiography.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Start parenteral corticosteroids and nebulized bronchodilators  
B: Start heparin treatment followed by an oral anticoagulant for 6 months  
C: Start anticoagulation and refer the patient for surgical embolectomy  
D: Start anticoagulation and refer the patient for evaluation for pulmonary thromboendarterectomy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 3-year-old boy with chronic granulomatous disease is brought to the physician because of a 3-week history of fever and warm, red lumps under both arms.
2. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F).
3. Physical examination shows enlarged, 3-cm, erythematous axillary lymph nodes bilaterally.
4. On palpation, the nodes are tender, fluctuant, and movable.
5. Examination of a fine-needle aspirate from one of the nodes shows gram-positive cocci in clusters.
6. Cultures of the aspirate grow yellow, βhemolytic colonies that are catalase and coagulase positive.
7. A polymerase chain reaction test shows mecA-positive organisms.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?

A. Ciprofloxacin

B. Penicillin G

C. Rifampin

D. Vancomycin

step1_excerpts:
1. A 4-week-old girl is brought to primary care for evaluation of upper extremity abnormalities that her parents describe as short and appearing different.
2. She was delivered at home via spontaneous vaginal delivery and has not received prior medical care.
3. The patient is feeding well with normal urine and stool output, is vigorous, and independently wakes for feeds.
4. She takes no medications.
5. The pregnancy was reportedly uncomplicated despite limited prenatal care.
6. Her three siblings are healthy.
7. Vital signs show: temperature 98.5°F, blood pressure 94/70 mmHg, pulse 144/min, and respiratory rate 24/min.
8. Physical examination reveals bilateral shortened upper extremities with intact elbows, wrists, and hands.
9. Imaging demonstrates bilateral absence of radii in the upper extremities.
question_options:
What is the most significant risk associated with this patient's condition?

A. Hemorrhage  
B. Sepsis  
C. Chronic anemia  
D. Cardiac malformations  
E. Thrombosis  
F. Developmental delay  
G. Fractures  
H. Renal failure  
I. Pulmonary embolism  
J. Immunodeficiency

step1_excerpts:
1. A 5-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician for a well child visit.
2. He is meeting his developmental milestones and is in the 15th percentile for height and 70th percentile for weight.
3. His parents note that he fatigues easily and has trouble participating in sports.
4. They are concerned he is not getting enough sleep and state that sometimes they hear him snore.
5. The patient has a medical history of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus, which was appropriately treated.
6. He is doing well in school but is sometimes bullied for being small.
7. The patient eats a diet of milk, fruit, and some vegetables.
8. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 90/48 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
9. On physical exam, the patient appears well.
10. HEENT exam is notable for conjunctival pallor and a unilateral clear middle ear effusion.
11. Cardiac exam reveals a benign flow murmur.
12. Pulmonary exam is clear to auscultation bilaterally.
13. The patient's gait is stable and he is able to jump up and down.
14. A full set of labs are ordered as requested by the parents including a serum vitamin D level, B12 level, and IGF level.
question_options:
Which of the following would be found in this patient?

A. Decreased total iron binding capacity with normal ferritin  
B. Normal RDW with decreased serum iron  
C. Elevated reticulocyte count with normal iron studies  
D. Increased MCV  
E. Decreased oxygen saturation when the patient sleeps  
F. Decreased serum ferritin with normal transferrin saturation  
G. Decreased insulin-like growth factor levels  
H. Increased serum hepcidin levels  
I. Increased RDW and TIBC  
J. Microcytic anemia with normal iron studies

step1_excerpts:
1. A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with altered mental status.
2. He has become gradually more confused over the past several days.
3. His wife also notes he has had diarrhea, nausea and vomiting, and abdominal pain for the past week.
4. The patient has a history of depression and multiple suicide attempts.
5. He takes fluoxetine as well as over-the-counter pain medications for a recent muscle strain.
6. He works in a large industrial compound that manufactures semiconductors.
7. He exercises regularly and recently has started making his own beer at home.
8. His temperature is 98.3°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 107/75 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air.
9. Physical exam reveals a confused man with a garlic odor on his breath and the finding in Figure A.
10. Cardiopulmonary exam reveals a rapid heart rate with no murmurs and clear breath sounds.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's symptoms?

A. Arsenic  
B. Cyanide  
C. Acetaminophen  
D. Iron

step1_excerpts:
1. A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by helicopter after a high speed motorcycle crash.
2. He was intubated and 2 large bore IVs were placed in the field with administration of 2 liters of lactated ringer's solution while en route.
3. On arrival to the emergency department, his temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), pulse is 130/min, blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, respirations are 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 97%.
4. Examination reveals an ill-appearing intubated patient.
5. Endotracheal tube placement is confirmed with end tidal CO2, and bilateral breath sounds are present.
6. No external bleeding or wounds are noted on exam.
7. Pulses are present in all extremities but are weak and rapid.
8. Significant bruising is noted over the abdomen.
9. The pelvis is stable.
10. Infusion of packed red blood cells is initiated.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast  
B. FAST exam  
C. Norepinephrine infusion  
D. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage

step1_excerpts:
1. A newborn girl with a nodular lesion on the scalp present since birth was seen at the dermatology clinic.  
2. The parents reported occasional erosions and crusting that resolved with topical mupirocin, 2%, cream, but with no continued growth.  
3. The mother had had a normal pregnancy.  
4. Physical examination revealed a firm, exophytic, and flat-topped nodule, with superficial erosion and crust on the right parietal side of the scalp measuring 3 cm in diameter and 1 cm thick (Figure, A).  
5. No other skin lesions were found.  
6. A 4-mm punch skin biopsy was performed, and tissue was sent for pathologic analysis (Figure, B and C).  
7. Cerebral and abdominal ultrasonography revealed no evidence of visceral involvement.  
8. The lesion regressed without treatment over a period of 8 months.  
9. Close follow-up every 3 months was scheduled, and complete involution of the tumor was noted at 10 months of age (Figure, D).  
10. A, Nodular lesion on the right parietal scalp at initial presentation.  
11. B, Histopathologic image of a biopsy specimen (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×200).  
12. C, Immunohistochemical image of a biopsy specimen (actin stain, original magnification ×100).  
13. D, Complete regression of tumor at 10 months of age.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?  

A: Giant cell fibroblastoma  
B: Infantile myofibromatosis  
C: Dermoid cyst  
D: Keratoacanthoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 61-year-old man seeks medical attention for lower back pain following a backward fall in his driveway two days ago.
2. He broke his fall with his left hand and landed on his buttocks, with no head injury or loss of consciousness.
3. His only medical condition is well-controlled hypertension treated with ramipril.
4. Physical examination reveals bruising on the left buttock, with pain radiating to the left buttock and posterior thigh during lumbar flexion and extension.
5. During a seated flexion test, the left posterior superior iliac spine is elevated.
6. Additional findings include a shallow left sacral sulcus, an anterior right inferior lateral angle, increased sacral asymmetry in sphinx position, and L5 segment showing flexion with right side-bending and rotation.
question_options:
What sacral somatic dysfunction best describes these findings?

A. Left-on-right backward sacral torsion  
B. Right-on-left forward sacral torsion  
C. Left-on-right forward sacral torsion  
D. Right sacral shear  
E. Bilateral sacral extension  
F. Right unilateral sacral flexion  
G. Left sacral shear  
H. Bilateral sacral flexion  
I. Left-on-left forward sacral torsion  
J. Right-on-left backward sacral torsion

step1_excerpts:
1. A patient in their 60s with a medical history of hypertension was referred for new-onset fluctuating diplopia and worsening right upper eyelid ptosis.
2. The patient underwent right-sided ptosis repair at another hospital less than 1 year earlier without improvement.
3. Best-corrected visual acuity was 20/30 OU, and pupil examination revealed no anisocoria or afferent pupillary defect.
4. Color vision was full in both eyes.
5. External examination revealed a margin reflex distance 1 (MRD1) of 0 mm OD, 4 mm OS without fatigability in extended upgaze (Figure 1A).
6. The patient had a small exotropia in primary gaze with a −2 supraduction deficit.
7. No proptosis was observed.
8. An ice pack was applied in the clinic to the ptotic eyelid for 2 minutes, which led to a 1.5-mm improvement (Figure 1B) in ptosis and no appreciable change in strabismus.
9. The patient reported no associated headache, weakness, or difficulty swallowing.
10. External photographs demonstrate ptosis of the right upper eyelid with a margin reflex distance 1 of 0 mm (A) that improved by 1.5 mm after application of an ice pack for 2 minutes (B).
11. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and orbit
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Serum testing for autoantibodies  
B: Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and orbit  
C: Revision ptosis repair  
D: Begin symptomatic management with cholinesterase inhibitor

step1_excerpts:
1. A 32-year-old G1P0 woman delivers a boy at 40 weeks and 3 days of gestation.
2. The delivery is uncomplicated and the neonate has Apgar scores of 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes respectively.
3. After 15 minutes, he attempts to nurse for the 1st time.
4. His mother notices that his face, chest, and extremities turn dusky blue during nursing.
5. She also notes that he seems to be snoring loudly and breathing very quickly.
6. When she removes him from her breast, he begins to cry and his color improves.
7. The neonate’s prenatal course was unremarkable, and his mother has a medical history of asthma with occasional albuterol inhaler use.
8. As the infant is resting, vital signs are taken.
9. His temperature is 98.2°F (36.7°C), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 45/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air.
10. A physical exam demonstrates well-perfused skin but is notable for the facial features shown in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is most likely to be observed in this neonate?

A. Digital clubbing  
B. Patent foramen ovale  
C. Inability to pass a nasogastric tube  
D. Areflexia in all extremities

step1_excerpts:
1. A 19-year-old college student presents with a one-week history of fever, malaise, and severe headache accompanied by nausea.
2. She developed a rash four days ago and reports hiking in North Carolina two weeks prior.
3. She is sexually active with inconsistent barrier contraception use and lives in university housing.
4. Her vital signs show a temperature of 100.8°F (38.2°C), blood pressure 130/90 mmHg, pulse 86/min, and respirations 18/min.
5. Physical examination reveals an alert patient with conjunctival erythema, negative meningeal signs, and a bilateral blanching, macular, erythematous rash with petechiae on wrists and ankles.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?

A. Ceftriaxone  
B. Penicillin G  
C. Ampicillin  
D. Intravenous immunoglobulin  
E. Acyclovir  
F. Vancomycin plus Piperacillin-Tazobactam  
G. Doxycycline  
H. Ciprofloxacin  
I. Rifampin  
J. Azithromycin

step1_excerpts:
1. A 46-year-old man presented with acute-onset weakness of his bilateral lower limbs for 3 days, accompanied by ascending numbness to just below his nipples.
2. Three weeks prior, he had developed acute urinary retention.
3. Neurological examination revealed weakness in bilateral lower limbs (Medical Research Council grade 4 on the right and grade 3 on the left), extensor plantar responses, and a sensory level at T6.
4. Magnetic resonance imaging of his thoracic spine was performed 10 days after the onset of weakness and did not show any signal abnormalities or restricted diffusion.
5. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis findings were remarkable for elevated protein (0.14 g/dL [to convert to grams per liter, multiply by 10]) but white cell count (5 cells/mm3) and glucose levels (54.05 mg/dL [to convert to millimoles per liter, multiply by 0.0555]) were normal.
6. Cytology and flow cytometry were negative for malignancy.
7. Antibodies to aquaporin 4 and myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein were not detected.
8. The patient developed a sudden worsening of weakness in his legs 2 weeks after initial presentation.
9. Repeated thoracic spine imaging showed an area of T2 hyperintensity in the left posterolateral cord at T7, which did not enhance with contrast or show restricted diffusion (Figure 1A).
10. Notably, he had a 4-year history of an asymptomatic papular skin eruption with more lesions developing in the last 4 months.
11. These were distributed on the neck, trunk, and limbs, sparing his face, scalp, and genitalia (Figure 1B).
12. Findings of extensive workup for malignancy, including full-body computed tomography scan, paraneoplastic antibody panel, and systemic autoimmune diseases (antinuclear antibody, antidouble stranded DNA, and myositis antibody panel), were negative.
13. The skin papules were biopsied.T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thoracic spine showing an area of hyperintensity in the left posterolateral cord at T7 (A) (arrowhead).
14. Multiple papules were seen on the patient’s abdomen.
15. These consisted of hypopigmented papules with central hyperpigmented umbilication and larger papules with typical central atrophic porcelain white scarring (B).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Malignant atrophic papulosis  
B: Disseminated discoid lupus  
C: Scleromyxoedema  
D: Secondary syphilis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension and obstructive sleep apnea presented with a 2-year history of nasal congestion, persistent rhinorrhea, postnasal drip, and chronic cough.  
2. Over the same period, he also developed thickened, brittle, and discolored fingernails and toenails.  
3. More recently, he developed progressive exertional dyspnea and edema of both lower extremities.  
4. He had no joint pain or swelling and no chest pain.  
5. He was taking amlodipine (5 mg daily) and ipratropium bromide nasal spray twice daily.  
6. On examination, he was afebrile.  
7. Heart rate was 66/min; blood pressure, 132/72 mm Hg; respiratory rate, 18/min; and oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry, 97% on room air.  
8. He had yellow discoloration and thickening of his fingernails and toenails (Figure 1A).  
9. A few nails showed distal onycholysis.  
10. He had partially nonpitting edema of the lower extremities (Figure 1B).  
11. Auscultation revealed diminished breath sounds at the lung bases but no rhonchi or crackles.  
12. Percussion of the lung bases and vocal resonance were normal.  
13. Cardiac and abdominal examination findings were unremarkable.  
14. A, Yellow discoloration and thickening of fingernails and toenails.  
15. Few nails showed distal onycholysis.  
16. B, Partially nonpitting edema of the lower extremities with a positive Stemmer sign (difficulty pinching the skin on the dorsum of the toes), suggestive of lymphedema.  
17. Laboratory testing revealed normal complete blood cell count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and thyrotropin level.  
18. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 2 mm/h; C-reactive protein level was 0.1 mg/dL.  
19. Antinuclear antibody (ANA) was positive (1:160, nucleolar pattern), but results of testing for antibodies to extractable nuclear antigens and double-stranded DNA were negative.  
20. He had mildly low C3 complement level (63 mg/dL [reference range, 79-152 mg/dL]), but normal C4 complement level (20 mg/dL [reference range, 16-38 mg/dL]).  
21. Immunoglobulin levels were normal.  
22. A chest radiograph performed within the last 6 months to evaluate his chronic cough did not reveal any obvious cardiopulmonary disease.  
23. His electrocardiogram was normal.  
24. An echocardiogram revealed normal left and right ventricular systolic and diastolic function and a small to moderate pericardial effusion without evidence of tamponade.  
25. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the sinuses showed bilateral maxillary and posterior ethmoidal sinusitis.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform microscopy of nail scrapings after keratolysis with potassium hydroxide solution  
B: Order radiographs of hands and feet  
C: Order a thoracic CT scan  
D: Order measurement of serum ferritin level, serum iron level, and serum total iron-binding capacity

step1_excerpts:
1. A 6-year-old girl was incidentally discovered to have fundus lesions after presenting with head trauma that resolved without permanent intracranial pathology.
2. She had no significant medical history or prior ocular problems.
3. Best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/25 OS, with eccentric fixation and trace exophoria in the left eye.
4. Pupils were equally round and reactive.
5. Anterior segment examination revealed an enlarged right corneal nerve.
6. The left macula had a fibrotic-appearing epiretinal membrane (Figure 1A).
7. There were 2 small, flat, pigmented lesions along the arcades of the right fundus (Figure 1B), likely atypical congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) lesions, or pigmented ocular fundus lesions (POFLs).
8. Observation was elected.
9. On follow-up, optical coherence tomography showed focal macular thickening in the left eye, most likely a retinal hamartoma (Figure 1C), and intraretinal abnormalities between the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and photoreceptor layer in the right eye, consistent with POFLs and likely representing combined retina-RPE hamartomas (Figure 1D).
10. B-scan ultrasonography and biometric A-scan showed bilaterally clear vitreous without retinal detachment.
11. Fluorescein angiography showed hyperfluorescence around the macula lesion without leakage, consistent with staining (Figure 1E), in the left eye.
12. There was no leakage or hyperfluorescence of the POFLs in the right eye (Figure 1F).
13. Fundus lesions near the macular in the patient’s left eye (A), pigmented ocular fundus lesions (asterisks) in the right eye (B), optical coherence tomography of the left (C) and right (D) eyes, and fluorescein angiography of the left (E) and right (F) eyes.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Inquire about family cancer history and order genetic testing  
B: Pars plana vitrectomy and retinal biopsy  
C: Diode laser treatment to lesions  
D: Metastatic workup

step1_excerpts:
1. A 16-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department after falling from a second-story window.
2. Emergency personnel found her unconscious with slow, irregular breathing and intubated her on the scene.
3. Upon arrival, her temperature is 37°C, heart rate is 72 beats per minute, blood pressure is 159/90 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% while intubated.
4. She remains unconscious, with ecchymosis noted behind the left ear and a visibly deformed distal left upper extremity.
5. Her pupils are unequal in size (right larger than left) and sluggish to react.
6. She is wearing a cervical collar for neck stabilization.
7. Lungs are clear bilaterally, her heart rate is regular, and her abdomen is soft, nontender, and nondistended with no signs of organomegaly.
8. A neurosurgical consultation has been initiated.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

A. Perform immediate burr hole decompression  
B. Perform a lumbar puncture  
C. Obtain a CT scan of the head  
E. Administer a mannitol bolus  
F. Delay imaging until neurosurgical evaluation  
G. Initiate therapeutic hypothermia  
H. Administer anticonvulsant prophylaxis  
I. Administer hypertonic saline infusion  
J. Administer a bolus of IV corticosteroids

step1_excerpts:
1. A 63-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of dysphagia and worsening "heartburn" over the past year.  
2. His medical history includes primary hypertension.  
3. On examination, his abdomen is mildly tender to palpation.  
4. Vital signs are: temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F), blood pressure 126/74 mm Hg, heart rate 74/min, and respiratory rate 14/min.  
5. Barium swallow fluoroscopy reveals a subdiaphragmatic gastroesophageal junction with herniation of the gastric fundus into the left hemithorax.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient’s underlying condition?

A. Upper endoscopy with biopsy  
B. Lifestyle modification  
C. Calcium channel blocker therapy  
D. Omeprazole  
E. H2 receptor antagonist therapy  
F. Metoclopramide  
G. Laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication  
H. Surgical gastropexy  
I. Watchful waiting with annual follow-up  
J. Lifestyle modifications and weight loss

step1_excerpts:
1. A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of nonradiating low back pain for 3 days.
2. The pain began after he worked in his yard.
3. He has not had any change in bowel movements or urination.
4. He had one similar episode 3 years ago that resolved spontaneously.
5. Vital signs are within normal limits.
6. Examination of the back shows bilateral paravertebral muscle spasm.
7. Range of motion is limited by pain.
8. Straight-leg raising is negative.
question_options:
In addition to analgesia, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Bed rest

B. Regular activity

C. X-rays of the spine

D. MRI of the spine

step1_excerpts:
1. A 29-year-old female presents with a 10-day history of upper back pain on the right side.  
2. She denies any recent trauma but mentions that her new job requires prolonged sitting.  
3. Her medical history includes intermittent tension headaches.  
4. Vital signs are normal.  
5. On physical examination, heart and lung sounds are normal, but there is localized tenderness over the right anterior rib cage and restricted sidebending of T1–T6 to the right.  
6. Ribs 2–5 on the right show poor elevation during inhalation but descend normally with exhalation.
question_options:
Which muscle should be activated to address this patient's rib somatic dysfunction?

A. Levator scapulae  
B. Pectoralis minor  
C. Sternocleidomastoid  
D. Trapezius  
E. Rhomboid major  
F. Posterior scalene  
G. Intercostal muscles  
H. Serratus anterior  
I. External oblique  
J. Anterior scalene

step1_excerpts:
1. A 14-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician with a 2-month history of intermittent arm and leg spasms.  
2. He says that the spasms usually occur after he wakes up as he is getting ready for school, and consist of disorganized jerking motions that stop after a few minutes.  
3. He has also noticed that they occur when he stays up late to cram last minute for exams.  
4. He has not noticed any other symptoms.  
5. He has no medical history and takes no medications.  
6. He recently started experimenting with alcohol and marijuana that one of his friends has been stealing from their parents.  
7. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 12/min.  
8. Physical exam reveals a healthy child.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

A. Alcohol intoxication  
B. Cannabinoid use  
C. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy  
D. Absence seizures

step1_excerpts:
1. A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of a low-grade fever, cough, and runny nose.
2. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F).
3. Examination findings are consistent with a diagnosis of a common cold.
4. The physician refers to a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial that evaluated the effectiveness of a new drug for the treatment of the common cold.
5. The mean time for resolution of symptoms for patients receiving the new drug was 6.4 days, compared with a mean time of 6.7 days for patients receiving the placebo (p=0.04).
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation of these study results?

A. The findings are clinically and statistically significant

B. The findings are clinically insignificant but statistically significant

C. The findings are clinically significant but statistically insignificant

D. The findings are neither clinically nor statistically significant

step1_excerpts:
1. A 29-year-old Hispanic woman, gravida 3, para 3, comes to the office because of recurrent low back pain during the past year.
2. Rest and analgesics usually eradicate the pain within 2 weeks.
3. However, the pain seems to recur every 2 to 3 months.
4. Medical history is remarkable for gestational diabetes mellitus during her pregnancies.
5. She takes no medications except for an oral contraceptive.
6. She walks 3 miles daily for exercise and works as a sales representative for a computer software company.
7. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 37 kg/m2 .
8. Vital signs are normal, and physical examination discloses no abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

A. Administer an epidural injection of methylprednisolone

B. Order MRI of the lumbosacral spine

C. Order x-rays of the lumbosacral spine

D. Recommend beginning a weight loss program

step1_excerpts:
1. A 64-year-old man presented with 3 weeks of bilateral anterior uveitis unresponsive to treatment with topical steroids.
2. He was referred to our clinic for worsening uveitis and ocular hypertension.
3. The patient had no ocular history.
4. His medical history was significant for 8 months of bilateral recurrent gingivitis with persistent reactive lymphadenopathy of the head and neck unresponsive to treatment with systemic antibiotics.
5. He denied any constitutional symptoms.
6. His visual acuity was 20/40 OD and 20/200 OS, and intraocular pressures were 17 and 32 mm Hg, respectively.
7. On slitlamp examination, both eyes were markedly hyperemic with diffuse corneal stromal edema, and his anterior chambers were deep with 3+ OD and 4+ OS cell and mixed hypopyon and hyphema in each eye (Figure, A and B).
8. His dilated fundus examination findings were remarkable only for an area of retinal pigment epithelial stippling inferonasal to the macula in the left eye, without any vitritis in either eye.
9. He did not have any skin or mucocutaneous lesions, but he had extensive bilateral preauricular, submental, posterior occipital, and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.
10. Gram stain and culture of aqueous and vitreous biopsy sample results were negative for infectious and cytologic studies, as were serum human leukocyte antigen B27, tuberculosis, syphilis, and sarcoidosis test results (Figure, C).Slitlamp examination findings of the left eye with hypopyon (A) and iris nodules (B).
11. C, Aqueous cytology (Wright stain).
12. Note the scant cytoplasm containing small, irregular nuclei with inconspicuous nucleoli.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Biopsy of iris nodule  
B: Lymph node biopsy  
C: Prescribe intravitreal vancomycin and ceftrazidime  
D: Obtain bacterial and fungal blood cultures

step1_excerpts:
1. A male neonate, aged 2 weeks, is brought to primary care with symptoms of excessive sleepiness, feeding difficulties, and grunting.
2. The infant was delivered at home at approximately 38 weeks gestation without prenatal care.
3. Initially healthy, the infant's condition has gradually deteriorated since birth.
4. The mother, aged 30, reports no significant medical history, hereditary conditions, or drug use during pregnancy.
5. Current vital signs show: temperature 98.6 ºF, blood pressure 80/40 mmHg, heart rate 200/min, and respiratory rate 70/min.
6. Physical examination reveals nasal flaring, costosternal retractions, and perioral cyanosis.
7. Cardiac auscultation demonstrates a single S2 and a systolic ejection murmur.
8. The liver is enlarged on abdominal palpation, and all peripheral pulses are bounding.
9. Chest imaging shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette with increased pulmonary vasculature.
question_options:
What is the most likely underlying pathology in this case?

A. Tetralogy of Fallot  
B. Patent ductus arteriosus  
C. Double outlet right ventricle  
D. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome  
E. Ebstein anomaly  
F. Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection  
G. Tricuspid atresia  
H. Transposition of the great arteries  
I. Atrioventricular septal defect  
J. Truncus arteriosus

step1_excerpts:
1. A 39-year-old woman had an acute onset of headache, increasing right-side hemiparesis, and numbness with fever.
2. Computed tomography (CT) of the brain showed a ring-enhanced lesion with surrounding edema on the left frontoparietal lobe.
3. Multiple red papules on the tongue (Figure 1), trunk, and limbs were noted during the physical examination.
4. The patient stated she had not noticed the red papules before.
5. There was no suggestion of otitis media or parasinusitis and no history of craniotomy, open head injury, or cyanotic heart disease.
6. The patient did relate having many prior episodes of epistaxis since childhood.
7. Blood cultures were obtained when the patient was first seen, and the patient received ampicillin/sulbactam empirically.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Consult a neurosurgeon to evaluate the brain CT finding; obtain a CT scan of the lung and abdomen and offer genetic counseling for the patient and her family.  
B: Consult a neurosurgeon to evaluate the brain CT finding; obtain a dermatology consultation and refer the patient to interventional radiology.  
C: Continue intravenous antibiotics only.  
D: Obtain a biopsy of the tongue lesions.

step1_excerpts:
1. A 42-year-old man presented with spontaneous ecchymoses of the extremities for the past 2 days and spontaneous epistaxis for the past 2 hours.
2. He had a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and allergic rhinitis.
3. His medications included esomeprazole, fluticasone nasal spray, and supplemental cholecalciferol.
4. Physical examination revealed multiple ecchymoses on the extremities and abdomen but was otherwise unremarkable.
5. Laboratory evaluation showed a white blood cell count of 2.4 × 103/µL, with 13% neutrophils, 32% lymphocytes, 1% monocytes, 0% eosinophils, 0% basophils, and 54% blasts.
6. Hemoglobin level was 10.3 g/dL, and platelet count was 20 × 103/µL.
7. Prothrombin time was 14.5 seconds; international normalized ratio, 1.4; partial thromboplastin time, 27 seconds; D-dimer level, 2.524 μg/mL (13.82 nmol/L); and fibrinogen level, 68 mg/dL (2 μmol/L).
8. A peripheral blood smear was obtained (Figure).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Administer all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) after consulting a hematologist  
B: Administer cytarabine and daunorubicin chemotherapy after consulting a hematologist  
C: Perform a bone marrow biopsy  
D: Place a central venous catheter in preparation for replacing blood products

step1_excerpts:
1. A 37-year-old Anglo-American man is admitted to the hospital for treatment for cocaine dependency.  
2. He says he has tried repeatedly to abstain from cocaine use but lives in a part of town where there are heavy drug sales.  
3. He did not like his hospital outpatient group but liked his single session at Cocaine Anonymous.  
4. Vital signs are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 70/min, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 125/85 mm Hg.  
5. Physical examination shows a thin man with good muscle strength and no focal neurologic deficits.  
6. The patient is using insurance coverage through his wife but does not wish for his diagnosis to be disclosed to anyone.  
7. He is on probation after a conviction for aggravated robbery 3 years ago.  
8. There is also a warrant for his arrest for assault and battery.
question_options:
After listening to his requests and weighing your obligations, you should disclose this patient's diagnosis only to which of the following?  

A. His Cocaine Anonymous sponsor  
B. His probation officer  
C. His wife  
D. Insurance company

step1_excerpts:
1. A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her co-workers after being found unconscious in her cubicle shortly after lunch.
2. They report that she has diabetes but are unaware of the specifics of her condition.
3. Her vital signs include a pulse of 110/min, respiratory rate of 24/min, temperature of 36.7°C (98°F), and blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg.
4. On examination, she is breathing heavily and provides nonsensical responses to questions.
5. Her skin and mucous membranes are dry, and abdominal palpation reveals mild diffuse tenderness.
6. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally.
7. Laboratory results are as follows:

| **Finger-stick glucose** | **630 mg/dL** |
| --- | --- |
| **Arterial blood gas** | |
| pH | 7.1 |
| PO2 | 90 mm Hg |
| PCO2 | 33 mm Hg |
| HCO3 | 8 mEq/L |
| **Serum chemistry** | |
| Sodium | 135 mEq/L |
| Potassium | 3.1 mEq/L |
| Chloride | 136 mEq/L |
| Blood urea nitrogen | 20 mg/dL |
| Creatinine | 1.2 mg/dL |

| **Urinalysis** | |
| --- | --- |
| Glucose | Positive |
| Ketones | Positive |
| Leukocytes | Negative |
| Nitrite | Negative |
| RBCs | Negative |
| Casts | Negative |

The patient is started on an intravenous bolus of normal saline (0.9% NaCl).
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in her management?

A. Administer sodium bicarbonate.  
B. Administer a diuretic to correct hyperglycemia.  
C. Administer dextrose 5% in water.  
D. Perform hemodialysis.  
E. Administer calcium gluconate.  
F. Replace potassium intravenously.  
G. Start IV 5% dextrose.  
H. Administer subcutaneous insulin.  
I. Start IV insulin infusion.  
J. Start continuous bicarbonate infusion.

step1_excerpts:
1. A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department after slamming his finger in the car door 5 hours ago.
2. He initially experienced pain which is currently well controlled with acetaminophen.
3. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications.
4. His temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 123/79 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 11/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air.
5. Physical exam is notable for the finding in Figure A.
6. A radiograph of the affected digits shows a smooth cortex without disruption of the bone.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A. Fingernail removal  
B. Trephination  
C. Excision and histological examination  
D. Operative repair

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her late 50s presented to the clinic with severe right eye pain and a headache for the past 2 days.
2. Her ophthalmic history was significant for mixed-mechanism glaucoma due to uveitis and chronic angle closure with prior implantation of bilateral superotemporal Baerveldt drainage implants.
3. Her intraocular pressure (IOP) was controlled with topical brinzolamide.
4. In addition, she had Fuchs corneal dystrophy.
5. A month earlier, she had undergone Baerveldt implant repositioning from the anterior chamber to the sulcus in the right eye in preparation for future Descemet stripping endothelial keratoplasty owing to severe corneal decompensation.
6. At that time, visual acuity was counting fingers at 1 ft OD.
7. She was discharged with therapy including topical steroids, antibiotics, and atropine sulfate.
8. On the first postoperative visit, IOP was 14 mm Hg OD by Goldmann applanation.
9. On postoperative day 11, IOP remained stable at 7 mm Hg OD by Goldmann applanation and topical atropine was discontinued.
10. At presentation 3 weeks postoperatively, IOP was 30 mm Hg OD by Goldmann applanation.
11. Her visual acuity worsened from counting fingers to hand motions.
12. Slitlamp examination of the right eye revealed a superotemporal Baerveldt drainage implant with fluid over the plate.
13. High-resolution ultrasonography was performed (Figure).High-resolution B-scan ultrasonographic image of the right eye.
14. White arrowheads indicate the anterior and posterior borders of the tube; magenta arrowhead, the lumen of the tube; AC, anterior chamber; and C, cornea.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Apply digital pressure over the plate to dislodge the obstruction  
B: Reposition the tube  
C: Perform laser iridotomy or iridoplasty  
D: Perform vitrectomy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 60-year-old man with advanced melanoma presented with headaches and increasing fatigue during treatment with ipilimumab.
2. Several months earlier, he presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath.
3. Imaging revealed pulmonary emboli and incidental groin lymphadenopathy.
4. Biopsy of a lymph node showed melanoma.
5. He then underwent inguinal lymph node dissection and was found to have 9 lymph nodes involved with melanoma (stage IIIC melanoma).He was then treated with ipilimumab (3 mg/kg), a monoclonal antibody to cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4), every 3 weeks, as part of an investigational adjuvant therapy clinical trial.
6. When presenting for his fourth and final dose of ipilimumab, he reported central headaches, severe fatigue, poor appetite, intermittent nausea, and a mild rash.
7. On examination, vital signs were within normal limits.
8. Physical examination had largely unremarkable results except for a slightly red, raised rash over his chest and proximal extremities.Laboratory testing showed the following: thyrotropin, 0.02 mIU/L (reference range, 0.3-5.0 mIU/L), and free thyroxine, less than 0.25 ng/dL (reference range, 0.5-1.2 ng/dL; to convert to picomoles per liter, multiply by 12.871).
9. Cosyntropin stimulation test showed a cortisol peak level of 0.9 µg/dL (reference range, >20 µg/dL; to convert to nanomoles per liter, multiply by 27.588).
10. He had low corticotropin (<5 pg/mL; reference range, 7-51 pg/mL; to convert to picomoles per liter, multiply by 0.22) and testosterone levels (<0.1 ng/mL; reference range, 2-11 ng/mL; to convert to nanomoles per liter, multiply by 0.0347).
11. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain is shown in the Figure.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Neurosarcoid  
B: Melanoma metastasis  
C: Hypophysitis  
D: Pituitary macroadenoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 71-year-old woman arrives to clinic with sudden vision loss.
2. She was in her usual state of health until waking up this morning unable to see out of her right eye.
3. She denies pain, but reports her right eye “feels funny.” The patient’s medical history is significant for a previous myocardial infarction, hypertension, and osteoporosis.
4. Her current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, rosuvastatin, lisinopril, and alendronate.
5. Her temperature is 98°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 145/86 mmHg, pulse is 62/min, and respirations are 12/min with an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air.
6. The patient's pupils are symmetric in size and equally reactive to light with accommodation.
7. A fundoscopic exam of the right eye is shown in Figure A.
8. The left optic fundus is unremarkable.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Papilledema  
B. Retinal vein occlusion  
C. Retinal detachment  
D. Closed angle glaucoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 29-year-old first-time pregnant woman at 36 weeks' gestation presents for a prenatal visit.
2. She reports feeling somewhat tired but otherwise has no complaints.
3. She was treated successfully with fosfomycin for asymptomatic group B Streptococcus (GBS) bacteriuria during her first trimester.
4. Since moving to another state, she has not attended further routine prenatal visits.
5. She recalls developing a rash on her chest last year while taking amoxicillin for bacterial sinusitis, which resolved on its own.
6. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she is currently taking only a prenatal vitamin.
7. Her vital signs are normal, and pelvic examination findings are consistent with a 36-week pregnancy.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Repeat urine culture at 37 weeks  
B. Administration of intrapartum cefazolin  
C. Collection of rectovaginal swab for culture  
D. Administration of oral amoxicillin for remainder of pregnancy  
E. Administration of intrapartum penicillin  
F. Collection of urine culture only  
G. No antibiotic prophylaxis needed  
H. Administration of intrapartum vancomycin  
I. Administration of intrapartum clindamycin
