J. Administration of intrapartum erythromycin

step1_excerpts:
1. A 31-year-old man presented with left cervical and left inguinal masses.
2. He reported intermittent itching and night sweats for 2 years.
3. He denied fever, weight loss, shortness of breath, rashes, diarrhea, and neurological symptoms.
4. On a preemployment evaluation, the patient was told he had a high white blood cell count 2 years ago.
5. On examination, there was left cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy and no other organomegaly.
6. Complete blood cell count and peripheral blood smear showed marked leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 22 340/μL, an absolute neutrophil count of 5360/μL, and 55% eosinophils with an absolute eosinophil count of 12 290/μL (to convert all to cells ×109/L, multiply by 0.001).
7. Vitamin B12 was markedly elevated at more than 4000 pg/mL (to convert to pmol/L, multiply by 0.7378).
8. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 5 mm/h.
9. Lactate dehydrogenase was 180 U/L, and alkaline phosphatase was 81 U/L (to convert both to μkat/L, multiply by 0.0167).
10. Evaluations for HIV and hepatitis B and C were all negative.
11. Serum creatinine was 0.76 mg/dL (to convert to μmol/L, multiply by 88.4); alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase were 11 U/L and 9.9 U/L, respectively (to convert to μkat/L, multiply by 0.0167); and total bilirubin was 0.35 mg/dL (to convert to μmol/L, multiply by 17.104).
12. Bone marrow biopsy showed hypercellular marrow (cellularity of 100%), myeloid hyperplasia, increased eosinophils with some dysplasia, and a blast count of 2%.
13. Positron emission tomographic–computed tomographic scan showed a left upper cervical lymph node of 2.6 cm and a left inguinal lymph node of 3.1 × 2.3 cm with an standardized uptake value max of 5.7 (Figure, A).
14. Left inguinal lymph node biopsy showed partial involvement by atypical cells with high proliferation index (Ki-67 >95%) that were positive for CD3, CD4, CD8, BCL2, and TDT, suggestive of T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma/leukemia (Figure, B).A, Positron emission tomographic–computed tomographic (PET/CT) scan of the head and neck at presentation showing a left upper cervical lymph node of 2.6 cm (arrowhead).
15. B, Lymph node biopsy immunohistochemical stain with terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase.
16. The inset shows interphase fluorescence in situ hybridization for FIP1L1::PDGFRA rearrangement (positive).
17. C, PET/CT 12 weeks after treatment initiation.Myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with eosinophilia and tyrosine kinase gene fusions
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Kimura disease  
B: Classic Hodgkin lymphoma  
C: T-cell acute lymphoblastic lymphoma/leukemia  
D: Myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with eosinophilia and tyrosine kinase gene fusions

step1_excerpts:
1. A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fatigue and dark urine over the past day.
2. He was recently diagnosed with cellulitis of his left leg, for which he was prescribed trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
3. He denies having nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
4. He has no significant medical history and does not currently take any medications.
5. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 115/72 mmHg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 14/min.
6. Physical exam reveals conjunctival icterus, bilateral flank tenderness, and erythema of the left leg.
question_options:
Which of the following would most likely be seen on a peripheral blood smear in this patient?

A. Schistocytes  
B. Codocytes  
C. Acanthocytes  
D. Degmacytes

step1_excerpts:
1. A 41-year-old man who had immigrated to the United States from Costa Rica 10 years prior presented with a 2-year history of tingling and pain in his hands and feet.  
2. He had no other symptoms and reported taking no medications.  
3. Findings on skin examination included near-complete loss of eyebrows and eyelashes, a scaly plaque on the right shin, and mild bilateral erythema of the earlobes, distal fingers, and toes (Figure).  
4. He also had right axillary and bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy.  
5. Check rapid plasma reagin, thyroid-stimulating hormone level, and lead level.  
6. Empirically treat patient and close contacts with dapsone
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform a biopsy of skin lesion  
B: Check rapid plasma reagin, thyroid-stimulating hormone level, and lead level  
C: Empirically treat with a topical steroid  
D: Empirically treat patient and close contacts with dapsone

step1_excerpts:
1. An otherwise healthy 54-year-old woman presented with an erythematous right lower eyelid lesion with a vermiform appearance, accompanied by pruritus and pain (Figure 1A).  
2. The lesion resolved after 1 month, but she developed redness and swelling of the inner part of her right conjunctiva the next day (Figure 1B).  
3. She denied any vision changes, eye pain, eye discharge, or systemic symptoms, such as fevers, chills, night sweats, weight loss, or diarrhea.  
4. The patient had recently immigrated from rural Moldova 1 month prior to presentation, where she had exposure to farm animals, including dogs and cats.  
5. She had not traveled to any other countries.  
6. Painful and pruritic lower eyelid lesion with a vermiform appearance (arrow) (A).  
7. This was followed by an elevation in the bulbar conjunctiva with whitish linear opacities within the lesion (B).  
8. Ophthalmological examination showed a best-corrected visual acuity of 20/40 OU and intraocular pressures of 17 OD and 18 OS.  
9. Pupils were equal and reactive to light.  
10. On slit-lamp examination of the right eye, there was diffuse conjunctival vasodilation and hyperemia that was worse nasally.  
11. There was a cystic elevation of the bulbar conjunctiva nasally with whitish linear opacities within the lesion (Figure 1B).  
12. The cornea was clear.  
13. There was no anterior chamber or vitreous inflammation.  
14. Dilated fundus examination showed slightly anomalous appearing optic nerves; the macula and periphery were flat and attached without any lesions.  
15. Cryotherapy of the conjunctival lesion and adjuvant therapy with interferon alfa-2b Injection of subconjunctival lidocaine followed by surgical removal of the lesion Biopsy of the conjunctival lesion including a fresh specimen for flow cytometry
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Cryotherapy of the conjunctival lesion and adjuvant therapy with interferon alfa-2b  
B: Injection of subconjunctival lidocaine followed by surgical removal of the lesion  
C: Biopsy of the conjunctival lesion including a fresh specimen for flow cytometry  
D: Oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and topical corticosteroids

step1_excerpts:
1. A 20-year-old male presents to the clinic six weeks after undergoing abdominal surgery for a gunshot wound, reporting diffuse, achy abdominal pain rated as 4/10.
2. He has been compliant with wound care and denies additional symptoms.
3. He has no significant past medical history and is not taking any medications.
4. Vital signs are normal.
5. Physical examination reveals a nearly healed surgical incision in the left upper quadrant without surrounding erythema or edema.
6. Structural examination identifies a hypertonic rectus abdominis muscle that is tender to palpation.
7. An anterior-superior iliac spine (ASIS) compression test is asymmetric, with the right ASIS inferior when supine and the left posterior-superior iliac spine (PSIS) inferior when prone.
8. The pubic symphysis is tender, with asymmetry of the pubic tubercles and a taut, tender left inguinal ligament.
question_options:
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Left posterior innominate rotation  
B. Left superior pubic shear  
C. Bilateral pubic compression  
D. Right anterior innominate rotation  
E. Right posterior innominate rotation  
F. Left inferior pubic shear  
G. Sacral torsion on a left oblique axis  
H. Right superior pubic shear  
I. Right inferior innominate shear  
J. Pubic symphysis compression

step1_excerpts:
1. An 81-year-old Mexican man was evaluated in the retina clinic for scattered subretinal lesions in the right eye.
2. He complained of a gradual decline in his vision bilaterally over the past 2 years.
3. He denied flashes, floaters, or eye pain but endorsed a chronic cough.
4. He had no known ocular or medical history and took no systemic medications.
5. He was born and raised in Mexico prior to his immigration to the United States 5 years before presentation.
6. He worked as a farmer and denied recent illnesses, contacts with illnesses, alcohol or tobacco use, and having pets.
7. His visual acuity was 20/60 OD and 20/40 OS with normal intraocular pressures.
8. His slitlamp examination results were notable for mild nuclear sclerosis in both eyes and were negative for conjunctival or corneal lesions.
9. He had round, reactive pupils and no anterior chamber inflammation in either eye.
10. Dilated fundus examination results revealed a few pigmented anterior vitreous cells, a normal optic disc, and flat and large yellowish chorioretinal lesions with overlying pigment scattered throughout the macula and periphery in the right eye (Figure).
11. The left eye had several similar chorioretinal lesions in the superotemporal periphery.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) haplotyping (eg, for HLA-A29)  
B: Empirical steroids  
C: Interferon-γ release assay  
D: Observation

step1_excerpts:
1. A 39-year-old woman presented to the emergency department after she noticed that her left pupil was dilated when looking in the mirror earlier in the day.  
2. She had a medical history of hypertension and palmar and axillary hyperhidrosis.  
3. She denied double vision, ptosis, headache, and weakness.  
4. On examination, she appeared well and her blood pressure was 128/78 mm Hg; heart rate, 76/min; and respiratory rate, 13/min.  
5. Visual acuity was 20/20 in both eyes, there was no ptosis, and extraocular movements were full.  
6. Pupillary examination revealed anisocoria that was more pronounced in bright lighting conditions (Figure).  
7. The right pupil measured 6 mm in the dark and 3 mm in the light, whereas the left pupil measured 9 mm in the dark and 8 mm in the light.  
8. The left pupil was poorly reactive to light and to a near target.  
9. Slitlamp examination revealed normal-appearing anterior chambers without any signs of intraocular inflammation.  
10. Cranial nerve function was otherwise normal.  
11. The remainder of the neurologic examination revealed normal muscle tone, strength, reflexes, and gait.Patient’s pupil sizes shown in dim and bright lighting conditions.  
12. Order computed tomography angiography of the head to rule out aneurysmal compression of the left third cranial nerve.  
13. Order magnetic resonance imaging of the brain to rule out a brainstem stroke.  
14. Perform detailed review of systemic and topical medications.  
15. Perform pharmacologic testing with apraclonidine to confirm Horner syndrome
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Order computed tomography angiography of the head to rule out aneurysmal compression of the left third cranial nerve  
B: Order magnetic resonance imaging of the brain to rule out a brainstem stroke  
C: Perform detailed review of systemic and topical medications  
D: Perform pharmacologic testing with apraclonidine to confirm Horner syndrome

step1_excerpts:
1. A 32-year-old man presents to his primary care provider for a headache.
2. He reports that he has headaches at night several times a week.
3. He first developed these headaches over 1 year ago, but they started up again 3 weeks ago.
4. The episodes start suddenly and feel like a stabbing, electrical pain over his left eye.
5. He also reports tearing of the left eye during these episodes.
6. The headaches self-resolve over the course of 2-3 hours, but the patient complains that he is avoiding going to sleep for fear of waking up in pain.
7. His medical history includes type 1 diabetes mellitus and an episode of herpes zoster on his right flank 1 year ago.
8. His only home medication is insulin.
9. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 112/69 mmHg, pulse is 61/min, and respirations are 14/min.
10. On physical exam, his extraocular muscles are intact and his eyes are not injected.
11. A CT of the head and sinuses shows no acute abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is most likely to prevent future episodes of headache in this patient?

A. Verapamil  
B. Sumatriptan  
C. Carbamazepine  
D. High-flow oxygen

step1_excerpts:
1. A 16-year-old male patient developed acute-onset right-sided periorbital swelling several days after being hit in that area by a snowball.
2. The swelling worsened over the following 3 weeks despite use of warm compresses and a course of doxycycline prescribed by his outside eye care professionals.
3. He had progressive binocular diplopia and right periorbital pain, swelling, and redness.
4. Blurriness of the right eye that started the week before presentation eventually caused enough concern that the patient presented to his local emergency department where magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and orbits revealed an intraconal mass (Figure, A).
5. He then came to our institution’s emergency department for urgent ophthalmology consultation.A, Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) axial T1 orbit fat-suppressed postcontrast image shows a right retro-orbital intraconal lesion (asterisk) with intrinsic T1 hyperintensity but without fat saturation or enhancement.
6. The lesion causes proptosis (difference between the dotted lines) and posterior globe flattening (white arrowheads).
7. B, B-scan ultrasonography of the right eye shows a well-circumscribed and homogenous lesion with low internal reflectivity (asterisk) sitting directly behind the globe (left).
8. There is a possible thin septation (white arrowheads).His examination revealed a visual acuity of 20/60 OD and 20/20 OS, intraocular pressures of 24 mm Hg and 17 mm Hg in the right and left eyes, respectively, and a normal pupil examination without a relative afferent pupillary defect.
9. His right eye had 5-mm relative proptosis, hyperglobus, supraduction deficit, conjunctival injection, grade IV optic disc edema, and choroidal folds.
10. An ultrasonography examination revealed a 2.0 × 2.5-cm echolucent avascular lesion (Figure, B).
11. MRI of the orbits was reviewed by the on-call pediatric radiologist whose leading diagnosis was dermoid/epidermoid cyst.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Admit to the hospital for a course of intravenous antibiotics  
B: Order a homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid test  
C: Start high-dose steroids  
D: Perform an emergency orbital exploration with lesion biopsy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 64-year-old man was referred to our clinic for suspected central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) in his right eye.
2. He had experienced blurred vision of the right eye for 2 months; medical history included hypercholesterolemia.
3. Best-corrected visual acuity was 20/80 OD and 20/20 OS.
4. The anterior segment was normal and intraocular pressure was 16 mm Hg in both eyes.
5. Dilated fundus examination of the right eye revealed a normal optic disc, mild venous engorgement, and widespread peripheral dot-blot retinal hemorrhages mainly located in the temporal midperiphery (Figure 1A).
6. No spontaneous retinal arterial pulsation was noted.
7. Examination findings of the left eye were unremarkable.
8. Fluorescein angiography in the right eye showed delayed venous filling, mild perifoveal leakage, and scattered microaneurysms in the temporal sector (Figure 1B).
9. A, Montage color fundus photograph of the right eye at presentation shows mild venous dilation and midperipheral dot and blot hemorrhages mostly located in the temporal sectors.
10. B, Fluorescein angiography frame (2 minutes, 3 seconds) shows multiple microaneurysms in correspondence of the dot-blot retinal hemorrhages and a barely visible perifoveal vascular leakage.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Observe  
B: Perform panretinal photocoagulation  
C: Obtain carotid Doppler  
D: Refer to cardiology

step1_excerpts:
1. A 21-year-old female student presents to her university's health clinic with symptoms including vaginal itching, painful urination, pelvic discomfort, and malodorous vaginal discharge.
2. These symptoms have recurred four times in the past year, despite both she and her partner receiving multiple treatment courses of ceftriaxone combined with either doxycycline or azithromycin.
3. Physical examination reveals cervical friability and mucopurulent discharge from the cervix.
4. Microscopic examination of a wet mount preparation shows numerous polymorphonuclear leukocytes.
question_options:
Which pathogen is the most probable cause of her cervicitis?

A. *Neisseria gonorrhoeae*  
B. *Mycoplasma genitalium*  
C. *Streptococcus agalactiae*  
D. *Mycoplasma hominis*  
E. *Chlamydia trachomatis*  
F. *Gardnerella vaginalis*  
G. *Ureaplasma urealyticum*  
H. *Candida albicans*  
I. Drug-resistant *Neisseria gonorrhoeae*  
J. *Trichomonas vaginalis*

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her mid-20s presented with subacute bilateral vision loss that was worse in the left eye.  
2. Her medical history was remarkable for type 1 diabetes diagnosed at 16 years of age and proliferative diabetic retinopathy in both eyes that had been treated with panretinal photocoagulation 7 years earlier.  
3. She had undergone pars plana vitrectomy with endolaser to treat a tractional retinal detachment in her right eye 2 years before this presentation.  
4. She also had a history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease, and she was 15 weeks into pregnancy.  
5. Visual acuity was 20/50 OD and 20/100 OS.  
6. Intraocular pressure was normal bilaterally, and no relative afferent pupillary defect was detected.  
7. Findings of an anterior segment examination were normal.  
8. The patient was in no apparent distress and denied any headache, chest pain, or focal weakness.  
9. Ophthalmoscopic examination (Figure) revealed mild optic nerve head edema that was greater in the left eye than the right eye with associated nerve fiber layer hemorrhage in the left eye.  
10. Nerve fiber layer infarctions, dot and blot hemorrhages, and lesions caused by panretinal photocoagulation also were seen bilaterally.  
11. Optical coherence tomography showed macular edema that involved the center of the macula in both eyes (Figure, inset).  
12. Fundus photographs obtained at presentation that show bilateral peripapillary hemorrhages and mild optic nerve head edema.  
13. Insets show the corresponding optical coherence tomographic image.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Obtain a fluorescein angiogram  
B: Determine blood glucose level and perform glycated hemoglobin test  
C: Measure heart rate, respiratory rate, and blood pressure  
D: Perform immediate computed tomography of the head

step1_excerpts:
1. An 82-year-old female nursing home resident presents with a two-week history of constipation, abdominal pain, and bloating.
2. Previously, she had soft bowel movements every other day, but now moves her bowels every 3-4 days with hard stools and straining.
3. There is no blood in the stool.
4. Her current medications include daily docusate, prune juice as needed, daily aspirin 81 mg, and amitriptyline 50 mg daily, which was started one month ago for depression.
5. Physical examination reveals normal temperature, blood pressure 125/85 mm Hg, and heart rate 80 beats per minute.
6. The abdomen shows mild diffuse tenderness.
7. Rectal examination reveals a small anal fissure and hard stool, with normal sphincter tone.
8. Complete blood count and routine laboratory tests are within normal limits.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Increase dietary fiber intake, and add polyethylene glycol daily  
B. Add a stimulant laxative and continue docusate daily  
C. Stop amitriptyline, and monitor the patient’s depressive symptoms  
D. Initiate bisacodyl suppositories and increase fluid intake  
E. Refer for surgical evaluation of chronic constipation  
F. Perform a colonoscopy to rule out malignancy  
G. Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous and oral contrast  
I. Start methylnaltrexone for opioid-induced constipation  
J. Start lubiprostone, and consider senna if no bowel movement in one week

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 50s presented to our emergency department with a 3-hour history of sudden epigastric and right upper quadrant pain.
2. She did not report any previous abdominal surgery.
3. The colicky pain did not migrate during that period and occurred in paroxysms at 9- to 10-minute intervals.
4. The patient was afebrile and had no nausea or vomiting.
5. Physical examination revealed mild tachycardia (96/min) and moderate abdominal distension without signs of peritonism; the bowel sounds were hyperactive.
6. Careful examination ruled out incarcerated hernias in the groin, femoral triangle, and obturator foramen.
7. Blood analysis results showed mild leukocytosis (total white blood cell count, 10.5 × 103/μL [to convert to ×109 per liter, multiply by 0.001]) without elevation of the C-reactive protein level (<3 mg/L [to convert to nanomoles per liter, multiply by 9.524]).
8. Serum electrolyte levels were within the normal range.
9. Computed tomography of the abdomen was conducted (Figure).Computed tomographic images of the abdomen.
10. A, Axial imaging.
11. B, Coronal imaging.
12. Arrowheads indicate the border of the epiploic foramen; asterisk, the air-filled cecum in the lesser sac.Lesser sac (omental bursa) internal hernia through the epiploic foramen
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Abscess of the lesser sac (omental bursa)  
B: Perforated ulcer of the posterior stomach wall  
C: Lesser sac (omental bursa) internal hernia through the epiploic foramen  
D: Large diverticle of the transverse colon

step1_excerpts:
1. A 64-year-old man presented to the emergency department with 2 months of progressively worsening vision in both eyes.  
2. The worsening vision was preceded by binocular diplopia, which was intermittent at first and then became constant.  
3. He had no relevant ocular or other medical history.  
4. A review of systems was notable for a 2-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath.  
5. He denied any fevers, night sweats, or unintentional weight loss.  
6. Visual acuity was found to be 20/200 OD and 20/25 OS.  
7. His pupils were round and equally reactive, and there was no relative afferent pupillary defect.  
8. The intraocular pressure was normal in both eyes.  
9. On external examination, bilateral proptosis and increased resistance to retropulsion was observed.  
10. There was very limited extraocular motility in all directions of gaze on the right side and moderately limited extraocular motility on the left side.  
11. In addition, the patient had an esotropia and right hypertropia.  
12. Anterior segment examination revealed bilateral chemosis.  
13. The fundus examination (Figure 1) showed chorioretinal folds in both eyes and intraretinal hemorrhages in the right eye.  
14. The optic discs had normal color and sharp margins bilaterally.A, Fundus photograph of the right eye showing prominent chorioretinal folds throughout the macula and 2 intraretinal hemorrhages near the vascular arcades.  
15. B, Fundus photograph of the left eye, also demonstrating chorioretinal folds.  
16. Both photographs were taken in the emergency department using a smartphone-based camera system.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  

A: Perform an orbital biopsy  
B: Order a computed tomographic scan of the orbits  
C: Obtain a consultation from the retina service  
D: Perform emergency canthotomy and cantholysis to decompress the orbits

step1_excerpts:
1. A 39-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the community-based health center because of a 6-month history of a copious, foul-smelling vaginal discharge.
2. She also reports spotting that began 6 months ago and has progressed to heavy bleeding during the past 3 weeks.
3. Medical history is significant for an abnormal Pap smear in her 20s; her most recent Pap smear was done 12 years ago during her second pregnancy, and she recalls the results as being normal.
4. She takes no medications.
5. The patient was married for 18 years; her husband died 4 years ago and had undergone vasectomy after the birth of their last child.
6. The patient has not had any new sexual partners since her husband's death.
7. BMI is 32 kg/m2 .
8. Vital signs are temperature 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse 90/min, respirations 14/min, and blood pressure 155/96 mm Hg.
9. Speculum examination discloses normal vaginal mucosa.
10. The cervix is friable with a 1-cm exophytic mass lateral to the cervical os at the nine o'clock position.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most critical factor in formulating a management plan for this patient?

A. Hypertension

B. Obesity

C. Patient age

D. Stage of disease

step1_excerpts:
1. A 28-year-old woman visited the emergency department for a sudden, diffuse, and painful enlargement of the upper quadrants of the left breast with edema and palpable axillary lymph nodes without clinical signs of inflammation or infection (Figure 1A).
2. She had neither fever nor skin redness but was experiencing fatigue.
3. Initial presentation of the patient.
4. A, Asymmetric mass in the upper quadrant of the left breast.
5. B, Breast ultrasonogram revealing hypoechogenicity of the breast tissue with periductal small cysts.
6. The patient had stopped breastfeeding 10 months before the emergency department admission, and she had a recent history of pneumonia self-medicated with antibiotics.
7. She had no family history of breast or ovarian cancer and no history of drug addiction or hyaluronic acid or free silicone injections in the breast.
8. She denied any trauma to the breast.
9. On physical examination, the patient had a 6-cm hard mass without nipple discharge or retraction and left axillary palpable lymph nodes.
10. Breast ultrasonography revealed diffuse nonspecific hypoechogenicity of the breast tissue with periductal small cysts (Figure 1B).
11. Mammography revealed asymmetric density and distortion in the left upper quadrants.
12. Multiple 14-gauge ultrasound-guided biopsies in the upper quadrants of the left breast and fine-needle aspiration cytologic testing of an enlarged lymph node revealed granulomatous inflammation with epithelioid histiocytes, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils.
13. Lymph nodes were normal.
14. Blood test results were as follows: hepatitis B surface antigen, hepatitis C antibody, human immunodeficiency virus enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and whole-blood interferon γ release assay (QuantiFERON), negative; IgG cytomegalovirus, positive; fibrinogen level, 234 mg/dL (to convert to micromoles per liter, multiply by 0.0294); erythrocyte sedimentation rate, 4 mm/h; leukocyte count, 7660/µL (to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001); no acquired immunosuppression; and no hematologic disorders.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Inflammatory breast cancer  
B: Tuberculous mastitis  
C: Idiopathic granulomatous mastitis  
D: Mastitis caused by immunosuppression

step1_excerpts:
1. A 30-year-old man had involuntary orofaciolingual movements for 7 years and unsteady gait for 2 months.
2. At age 23 years, he began experiencing involuntary orofaciolingual movements and vocalizations.
3. At age 27 years, he developed dysphagia, dysarthria, and involuntary tongue- and lip-biting.
4. This oral dyskinesias worsened while eating.
5. However, a handkerchief in the mouth markedly reduced involuntary tongue-biting and mouth movements.
6. No neuropsychiatric symptoms or seizures were exhibited.Neurological examination results revealed mild cognitive decline, with a Montreal Cognitive Assessment score of 18/30.
7. Orofacial dyskinesia (Video 1), involuntary vocalizations, and mild dysarthria were exhibited.
8. His muscle strength and tone were normal, but his deep reflexes were diminished or absent.
9. The patient’s sensory and coordination examination results were unremarkable, and bilateral Babinski signs were negative.
10. The patient’s gait was mildly wide based (Video 2).
11. Fundus examination results were normal.
12. Laboratory examination results, including blood electrolytes and lactate, liver, kidney, and thyroid function, antinuclear antibodies, ceruloplasmin levels, and vitamin A and E levels were normal.
13. Routine and biochemical examination results, oligonucleotide band, antibodies against antiaquaporin 4, and autoimmune encephalitis-related antibodies (ie, N-methyl-d-aspartate, α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazoleproprionic, γ-aminobutyric acid-B, leucine-rick glioma inactivated 1, contactin-associated protein 2, and IgLON5) of cerebrospinal fluid were normal.
14. Creatine kinase (CK) levels were significantly elevated at 2304 U/L (to convert to microkatals per liter, multiply by 0.0167; normal range, 25-200 U/L).
15. Low-density lipoprotein and apolipoprotein B levels were slightly decreased at 61 mg/dL (to convert to micromoles per liter, multiply by 0.0357; normal range, 80-119 mg/dL) and 58 mg/dL (to convert to grams per liter, multiply by 0.01; normal range, 66-133 mg/dL), respectively.
16. Acanthocytes were found in the blood smear via Wright staining (Figure, A).
17. Electrophysiological examination results revealed reduced compound muscle action potential and sensory nerve action potential of bilateral median and ulnar nerves.
18. Electromyogram results showed neurogenic damage in lower limb muscles.
19. Cerebral magnetic resonance imaging results revealed a marked bilateral caudate head atrophy (Figure, B).Beginning of dialog window.
20. Escape will cancel and close the window.This is a modal window.
21. This modal can be closed by pressing the Escape key or activating the close button.Beginning of dialog window.
22. Escape will cancel and close the window.This is a modal window.
23. This modal can be closed by pressing the Escape key or activating the close button.A, Acanthocytes in the peripheral blood smear shown via Wright staining (original magnification, ×1000).
24. B, Axial T2-weighted magnetic resonance image of the patient’s brain.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Pantothenate kinase–associated neurodegeneration  
B: Hypobetalipoproteinemia  
C: Chorea-acanthocytosis  
D: Huntington disease–like 2

step1_excerpts:
1. A previously healthy 40-year-old man presented with a 3-month history of a right breast mass slowly enlarging with associated pain.
2. The patient denied history of local trauma, and his family history was negative regarding breast or ovarian cancers.
3. The patient had no history of liver disease, hormonal therapy, or radiation to the chest wall.
4. The physical examination disclosed an obese man with no signs of hypogonadism or liver failure.
5. There was a 3 × 4-cm hard, irregular, mobile nodule in the retroareolar area of the right breast, tethered to the overlying skin but not fixed to the underlying muscle.
6. There were no other masses on the chest wall.
7. The ipsilateral lymph nodes were palpable.
8. The left breast and axilla were normal.
9. Right mediolateral oblique mammography (Figure, A) and computed tomography scan of the chest (Figure, B) are shown.A, Right mediolateral oblique view of male breast showing a breast mass and axillary lymph nodes.
10. B, Computed tomography of the chest showing the right breast mass involving the skin but not the pectoralis muscle.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Gynecomastia  
B: Lipoma  
C: Carcinoma  
D: Epidermal inclusion cyst

step1_excerpts:
1. A 57-year-old woman with non–insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus and no other medical history had worsening left-sided back pain over 4 months and no other symptoms.
2. Physical examination findings were significant for mild left flank pain, but there was no costovertebral angle tenderness.
3. Laboratory results were within normal limits.
4. Axial imaging demonstrated an exophytic, retroperitoneal mass with solid and cystic components involving the left kidney, posterior abdominal wall, and mesocolon (Figure 1).
5. The mass measured 20 cm in its greatest dimension.
6. Findings on colonoscopy and mammography were negative.
7. Positron emission tomography–computed tomography did not reveal any other abnormality.Coronal computed tomographic image showing a retroperitoneal mass with a cystic component and involvement of adjacent kidney and mesocolon.
8. Red arrowhead indicates descending colon; blue arrowhead, left kidney invaded by mass; and yellow arrowhead, retroperitoneal mass with cystic component.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Lymphoma  
B: Malignant transformation of an enterogenous cyst  
C: Retroperitoneal sarcoma  
D: Primary neoplasm arising from the kidney

step1_excerpts:
1. A 62-year-old woman presents with a one-month history of worsening dyspnea, a nonproductive cough, and weight loss.
2. She now experiences dyspnea at rest and severe shortness of breath when climbing one flight of stairs.
3. She denies chest pain, orthopnea, or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.
4. Her medical history includes nonischemic cardiomyopathy and sustained ventricular tachycardia, for which she has an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator.
5. She was started on oral amiodarone several months ago for recurrent ventricular tachycardia.
6. Her current medications include lisinopril, carvedilol, and torsemide.
7. On examination, the patient is afebrile, with a heart rate of 64 beats per minute and blood pressure of 120/80 mm Hg.
8. Jugular venous pressure is normal, and there is no lower-extremity edema.
9. Cardiovascular examination is unremarkable, but pulmonary examination reveals bilateral inspiratory crackles.
10. An electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm, and a chest radiograph demonstrates bilateral, diffuse interstitial opacities.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

A. Switch amiodarone to dofetilide without additional treatment  
B. Continue amiodarone and add oral prednisone  
C. Perform a bronchoscopy and continue amiodarone until confirmed diagnosis  
D. Stop amiodarone and start oral prednisone plus another antiarrhythmic agent  
E. Stop amiodarone and give no additional treatment  
F. Initiate diuretic therapy to manage suspected pulmonary edema  
G. Start high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone without stopping amiodarone  
H. Discontinue all medications and initiate mechanical ventilation  
I. Stop amiodarone and initiate bronchodilator therapy with albuterol  
J. Stop amiodarone and start high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone plus another antiarrhythmic agent

step1_excerpts:
1. Six years ago, a white woman in her 60s was incidentally found to have chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) after being noticed to have lymphocytosis during treatment for diverticulitis.  
2. Immunophenotyping was typical for CLL, showing expression of CD 5, CD 19, CD 23, CD 38, and dim κ light chain restriction.  
3. Fluorescence in situ hybridization was positive for del (13)(q14) in 63% of her cells.  
4. Lymphadenopathy was noticed during the initial physical examination and imaging studies.  
5. Owing to progressive disease, she was started on therapy with fludarabine and rituximab (FR) 6 months later for 4 cycles, and clinical complete remission was achieved (bone marrow assessment was not done).  
6. However, 2.5 years later she experienced disease relapse.  
7. Repeated cytogenetic tests showed complex karyotype with del(17)(p13.1) in 35% of her cells as a new abnormality.  
8. The immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgHV) gene mutational status was studied at this time and found to be unmutated, with somatic mutation rate of 0%.  
9. Owing to developed worsening fatigue and lymphadenopathy, she wanted to discuss treatment options.  
10. The patient is much less likely to respond and have a durable remission with chemoimmunotherapy.  
11. The patient is at lower risk of Richter transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.  
12. IgHV-mutated status is defined by more than a 2% sequence difference compared with the germline sequence and can change over the evolution of the disease.  
13. The patient is likely to have unfavorable cytogenetic features, positive ZAP-70 protein expression/promoter unmethylated status, and clonal evolution.
question_options:
How Do You Interpret These Test Results?

A: The patient is much less likely to respond and have a durable remission with chemoimmunotherapy.  
B: The patient is at lower risk of Richter transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.  
C: IgHV-mutated status is defined by more than a 2% sequence difference compared with the germline sequence and can change over the evolution of the disease.  
D: The patient is likely to have unfavorable cytogenetic features, positive ZAP-70 protein expression/promoter unmethylated status, and clonal evolution.

step1_excerpts:
1. A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of persistent nonproductive cough for 6 weeks.
2. She has not had fever or weight loss.
3. She has hypertension treated with enalapril for the past 3 months.
4. She does not smoke.
5. There is no history of lung disease.
6. She weighs 54 kg (120 lb) and is 163 cm (64 in) tall.
7. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 12/min.
8. Examination and an x-ray of the chest show no abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's cough?

A. Decreased plasma renin activity

B. Decreased serum angiotensin II concentrations

C. Increased serum angiotensin I concentrations

D. Increased serum bradykinin concentrations

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 40s training for weight-lifting presented with new-onset progressive dizziness, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath.  
2. His medical and family history as well as review of other systems were unremarkable.  
3. Physical examination revealed a positive Kussmaul sign and pulsus paradoxus but no cardiac murmurs.  
4. There was no pedal edema, clubbing, or cyanosis.  
5. An electrocardiogram demonstrated sinus tachycardia.  
6. Results of a complete blood cell count and biochemical panel were within reference ranges.  
7. A chest radiograph revealed convexity on the right heart border suggestive of cardiomegaly (Figure 1A).  
8. Echocardiography demonstrated normal cardiac chambers and valves.  
9. However, an echogenicity was noted compressing the superior vena cava and right ventricle.  
10. The patient subsequently underwent computed tomographic imaging of the chest that revealed a large, 16.2 × 6.8 × 5.6-cm anterior mediastinal mass compressing the right cardiac structures, particularly the superior vena cava.  
11. The mass consisted mostly of fat attenuation, but was interspersed with nodular densities (Figure 1B).  
12. Tumor marker levels, including α-fetoprotein, lactate dehydrogenase, and β-human chorionic gonadotropin, were within reference ranges.  
13. Chest imaging.  
14. A, Radiograph showed a convexity on the right heart border and cardiomegaly.  
15. B, Tomographic examination revealed a large, anterior mediastinal mass with fat attenuation interspersed with nodular soft tissue elements (asterisk).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Thymoma  
B: Thymolipoma  
C: Mediastinal lipomatosis  
D: Myelolipoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 60s who was a former smoker with a medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, anemia, and cervical myelopathy experienced low-grade fevers, unintentional 80-pound weight loss, productive cough, and development of cutaneous ulcers over a 6-month period after cervical spine fusion.
2. Two ulcers developed at the surgical site, and 2 similar ulcers developed on his back shortly after cyst excision.
3. He had been recently diagnosed with lung cancer based on computed tomographic (CT) and positron emission tomographic imaging showing an enhancing, hypermetabolic, 7-cm cavitary right upper lobe mass with mediastinal adenopathy.
4. A chest x-ray 6 months prior revealed negative results.
5. A few days after establishing care, he presented to the emergency department with extreme weakness and intolerable pain related to his ulcers.
6. Physical examination revealed an ill-appearing man.
7. In the right upper lobe, there were decreased breath sounds with clear auscultation in the remaining chest.
8. On the right anterior neck were two, 3- to 4-cm tender ulcers extending to the deep subcutaneous fat with erythematous, friable borders (Figure).
9. On his back were 2 similar 2- to 2.5-cm ulcers.
10. Inflammatory markers were notably elevated.
11. A complete autoimmune panel, indirect immunofluorescence assays, enzyme immunoassays for antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA)/proteinase 3, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody/myeloperoxidase, a quantiferon gold test, cultures of blood, broncheoalveolar washings, and tissue analysis were performed.
12. Only c-ANCA testing revealed positive results.
13. A CT scan of the sinus showed multiple bony defects and acute and chronic sinusitis.
14. A transbronchial biopsy of the lung and excisional biopsy of the skin bridge between back ulcers were performed.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Disseminated tuberculosis  
B: Paraneoplastic pyoderma gangrenosum  
C: Disseminated nocardiosis  
D: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

step1_excerpts:
1. A healthy adolescent Latino man with juvenile open-angle glaucoma underwent Ahmed valve placement in the left eye via uncomplicated surgery.
2. Preoperative Snellen visual acuity was 20/40 and intraocular pressure (IOP) was 36 mm Hg; on postoperative day 1, IOP was 10 mm Hg and visual acuity fell to count fingers.
3. Slitlamp examination of the left eye revealed an elevated bleb over the Ahmed plate with no leakage.
4. The cornea was clear and compact, and there was a well-positioned tube overlying the iris superotemporally.
5. The anterior chamber was deep with trace inflammation.
6. Dilated fundus examination revealed disc edema, peripapillary hemorrhages, and diffuse intraretinal hemorrhages throughout the posterior pole and periphery (Figure 1).
7. Spontaneous venous pulsations were not appreciated.
8. Slitlamp examination of the right eye revealed a normal anterior and posterior segment, with no retinal vascular abnormality or hemorrhage.
9. The fundus of the left eye showed peripapillary hemorrhages, nasal disc edema, and diffuse retinal and preretinal hemorrhages throughout the posterior pole and periphery; a white-centered hemorrhage is found within the superior macula.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Order a complete blood cell count and coagulation testing  
B: Oral and topical corticosteroids  
C: Plasmapheresis for hyperviscosity syndrome  
D: Fluorescein angiography

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 30s was referred for evaluation of a large splenic cyst identified on a computed tomographic (CT) scan.  
2. She had previously lived in Beijing, China.  
3. In 2011, she was evaluated in a Chinese clinic for abdominal bloating and moderate left upper quadrant pain; she was offered a splenectomy, but she declined and pursued a second opinion at a hospital in the United States in 2012.  
4. During that evaluation, the patient reported that she had run in areas with dog feces on the ground and had eaten sheep meat (notably, not organ meat); she denied consuming canine meat.  
5. Results of serologic tests for Echinococcus antibody IgG were negative.  
6. Results of a CT scan were remarkable for a 9.7 × 9.0 × 10.5-cm anterior cyst and a smaller posterior cyst measuring 4.6 × 4.7 × 3.8 cm, both with rim calcifications (Figure 1).  
7. A large splenic cyst with calcified capsule is present in the anterior aspect of the spleen, with a smaller cyst in the posterior aspect of the spleen, also with calcified capsule.  
8. Arrowheads indicate the location of the cysts.  
9. Under higher resolution, debris is noted within the larger cyst.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Congenital cyst  
B: Splenic abscess  
C: Cystic metastasis to the spleen  
D: Echinococcal disease

step1_excerpts:
1. A 54-year-old White woman with a history of lobular breast carcinoma in situ treated with lumpectomy as well as chromophobe kidney cell carcinoma treated with partial nephrectomy was referred for evaluation of an asymptomatic, amelanotic choroidal mass in her left eye, suspicious for metastatic disease.
2. On examination, best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OU and intraocular pressures were normal in both eyes at 10 mm Hg.
3. Slitlamp biomicroscopy of the anterior chamber was within normal limits in both eyes.
4. Dilated fundus examination revealed normal findings in the right eye and clear vitreous with a subretinal mass in the left eye inferior to the optic disc and measuring 3 × 2 mm in base.
5. Color fundus photography of the left eye (Figure, A) showed an amelanotic lesion under the retina inferior to the optic disc and 3 mm from the foveola surrounded by a subtle orange halo.
6. Fundus autofluorescence (Figure, B) showed the lesion to be hyperautofluorescent.
7. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) imaging of the lesion showed the mass was primarily in the sclera and pushed and thinned the overlying choroid (Figure, C).
8. A, Color fundus photography of the left eye showing a 3 × 2-mm yellow lesion with orange halo 0.5 mm inferior to the optic disc.
9. B, Fundus hyperautofluorescence of the lesion.
10. C, Optical coherence tomography showing a horizontal cross-section of the mass, originating in the sclera (white arrowheads) and not the choroid and measuring 1.5 mm in thickness with overlying choroidal thinning (yellow arrowhead).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform fine-needle aspiration biopsy with cytology and cytogenetics  
B: Perform iodine 125 plaque radiotherapy  
C: Initiate intravitreal methotrexate  
D: Observe with no additional testing or intervention

step1_excerpts:
1. A 70-year-old woman with an ocular history of primary open-angle glaucoma on latanoprost, bilateral trabeculectomies, and argon laser trabeculoplasties presented with several months of worsening vision in the left eye.  
2. On examination, her best-corrected distance visual acuity was 20/40 OD and 20/60 OS (baseline 20/40 OU).  
3. Pupils were equally round and reactive, without afferent pupillary defect.  
4. Findings of Amsler grid testing were notable for a small area of distortion inferiorly in the left eye.  
5. Intraocular pressures (IOPs) were 13 mm Hg in both eyes.  
6. Findings of anterior segment examination were unremarkable.  
7. Findings of dilated fundus examination were notable for cup-disc ratio of 0.9 in the right eye and 0.85 in the left eye with temporal thinning, stable from prior, and new intraretinal thickening in the left eye.  
8. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) imaging of the left eye revealed schiticlike separation of the outer plexiform and outer nuclear layers extending from the temporal edge of the optic nerve head to the fovea (Figure 1A), continuous with the peripapillary nerve sheath.  
9. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) of macula demonstrating schisislike separation involving fovea (A) and OCT of optic nerve head, with optic pit marked with an arrowhead (B).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Pars plana vitrectomy  
B: Laser barricade  
C: Observation  
D: Genetic testing for the RS1 gene

step1_excerpts:
1. A 56-year-old woman with a history of multiple myeloma complicated by therapy-related acute myeloid leukemia was admitted for myeloablative conditioning in preparation for allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplant.
2. Her course was complicated by severe mucositis, acute kidney injury, and neutropenic fever.
3. During her admission, the patient also developed painful necrotic skin lesions, a nonproductive cough, and altered mental status.
4. Physical examination findings demonstrated dusky, purpuric, and pink papulonodules, some with overlying eschar, scattered on the scalp, neck, trunk, and extremities (Figure, A).
5. Laboratory study results revealed a white blood cell count of 150/μL (reference range, 3500/μL to 10 500/μL), an absolute neutrophil count of 130/μL (reference range, 1500/μL to 7400/μL), and a platelet count of 19 ×103/μL (reference range, 150 ×103/μL to 400 ×103/μL). (To convert the white blood cell and neutrophil counts to cells ×109/L, multiply by 0.001; conversion of the platelet count to cells ×109/L is 1:1.) Blood culture results were negative.
6. The results of a computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain showed no acute intracranial hemorrhage, territorial infarction, or mass effect.
7. The results of a CT scan of the chest demonstrated multifocal bilateral ground-glass patchy opacities, scattered solid bilateral pulmonary nodules, and a moderately sized pericardial effusion.
8. A biopsy specimen from a skin nodule on the left lateral thigh was obtained for histopathologic examination and tissue culture, and wet mount preparation of a tissue culture colony was performed (Figure, B).
9. A, Physical examination findings demonstrate dusky and pink papulonodules, some with overlying eschar, scattered on the scalp, neck, and extremities.
10. B, Lactophenol cotton blue staining of a tissue culture colony reveals septated hyphae and oval microconidia.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Disseminated fusariosis  
B: Invasive aspergillosis  
C: Pseudomonal ecthyma gangrenosum  
D: Sweet syndrome

step1_excerpts:
1. An 86-year-old man presented with left forehead numbness and intermittent left eyelid edema for the past several months.
2. His medical history was significant for hypertension, gastroesophageal reflux, and prostate cancer.
3. On examination, uncorrected visual acuity was 20/25 OU, pupils were equal and reactive to light without afferent defect, confrontational fields were normal, and ocular motility was full.
4. External examination was significant for decreased sensation in the distribution of the ophthalmic branch of the left trigeminal nerve.
5. A palpable mass was appreciated at the left supratrochlear notch.
6. There was 4 mm of proptosis and 2 mm of inferior globe dystopia, with increased resistance to retropulsion in the left eye.
7. Magnetic resonance imaging of the orbits demonstrated an infiltrating superomedial mass involving the extraconal and intraconal space on the left side (Figure 1).
8. Magnetic resonance imaging of the orbits.
9. An 86-year-old man presents with an infiltrating mass of the left superomedial orbit demonstrated on T1-weighted axial (A) and coronal (B) images.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Observe  
B: Administer empirical corticosteroid treatment  
C: Perform external beam radiotherapy  
D: Perform orbitotomy with biopsy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 15-month-old boy presents with his mother for his well-child exam.
2. His mother is concerned about his vision, as she noticed him squinting while watching television.
3. The patient was born at 39 weeks of gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery.
4. He is up to date with routine vaccinations.
5. He is able to walk alone, speak 3 words, and scribble with a crayon.
6. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure is 80/55 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 25/min.
7. On exam, his pupils are round and reactive to light.
8. A photograph of his eyes is shown in Figure A.
9. When focusing on the pediatrician's penlight, the patient's left eye wanders.
10. However, when the right eye is covered, the left eye refocuses on the light.
11. The rest of his neurological exam, including extraocular movements, is within normal limits.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

A. Perform a Bielschowsky head tilt test  
B. Brain MRI  
C. Patch the left eye  
D. Patch the right eye

step1_excerpts:
1. A 32-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 41 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor.  
2. Pregnancy has been complicated by mild asthma treated with inhaled bronchodilators.  
3. At the beginning of the second stage of labor, the cervix is 100% effaced and 10 cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station.  
4. The fetal heart rate is reactive with no decelerations.  
5. After 10 minutes of pushing, there is a prolonged deceleration to 60/min.  
6. The patient has the acute onset of shortness of breath, rapidly develops cyanosis, and becomes unresponsive.  
7. Her pulse and blood pressure cannot be detected.  
8. Immediate resuscitation is started.  
9. Five minutes later, there is bleeding from the nose, mouth, and intravenous sites.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Amniotic fluid embolism

B. Intracerebral hemorrhage

C. Myocardial infarction

D. Status asmaticus

step1_excerpts:
1. A 40-year-old woman visits her primary care physician for evaluation of recurring kidney stones.
2. She is currently asymptomatic and reports feeling well.
3. She has had four episodes of urolithiasis over several years without any known predisposing factors.
4. Analysis has shown the stones to be calcium-based.
5. Her only medication is a daily prenatal vitamin.
6. Being adopted at birth, she has no available family history.
7. Her vital signs show: temperature 98.6º F, blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, pulse 70/min, and respiratory rate 12/min.
8. Physical examination reveals no abdominal or costovertebral angle tenderness.
9. Her serum creatinine is stable at 0.7 mg/dL.
10. An intravenous pyelogram reveals striations in the papillary ducts of the renal medulla and multiple collecting duct cysts throughout both kidneys' medulla, with no cortical cysts.
11. Small calculi are scattered throughout the urinary system.
question_options:
What inheritance pattern is most likely associated with this condition?

A. Variable expressivity  
B. No inheritance pattern  
C. Incomplete penetrance  
D. Autosomal dominant  
E. X-linked dominant  
F. Autosomal recessive  
G. Codominant inheritance  
H. X-linked recessive  
I. Mitochondrial inheritance  
J. Multifactorial inheritance

step1_excerpts:
1. A 4-week-old boy presents to the pediatrician for vomiting.
2. The patient is breastfed and typically feeds for 20-30 minutes every 2 hours.
3. One week ago, he began vomiting and regurgitating breastmilk through his nose after most feedings.
4. His stools over the past week have also become blood-streaked.
5. The patient does not seem to be in any distress when he passes these bloody stools.
6. The patient surpassed his birth weight by 2 weeks of age but has fallen 1 standard deviation on the growth curve since then.
7. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 78/47 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 28/min.
8. On physical exam, the patient is well-appearing.
9. His face and back have the physical exam finding seen in Figure A.
10. The patient’s abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended.
11. A digital rectal exam reveals a small amount of blood in the rectal vault.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Obtain abdominal ultrasound  
B. Initiate a proton pump inhibitor  
C. Switch to hydrolyzed formula  
D. Modify mother's diet

step1_excerpts:
1. A 30-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks' gestation presents to the emergency department with worsening upper abdominal pain over the past hour.
2. She reports initial dull stomach pain approximately 6 hours ago that has progressed and localized to the upper abdomen.
3. She experienced one episode of emesis en route to the hospital.
4. Her medical and family histories are unremarkable.
5. She is in a monogamous relationship with her husband.
6. She denies tobacco or alcohol use.
7. Her only medications are folic acid and prenatal vitamins.
8. Her vital signs show a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate of 100/min, and blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg.
9. Physical examination reveals right upper quadrant tenderness but is otherwise normal.
10. Laboratory findings are as follows:

| Hemoglobin | 13.1 g/dL |
| --- | --- |
| Leukocyte count | 17,000/mm3 |
| Serum |  |
| Urea nitrogen | 20 mg/dL |
| Creatinine | 0.8 mg/dL |
| Alkaline phosphatase | 79 U/L |
| Bilirubin |  |
| Total | 1 mg/dL |
| Direct | 0.3 mg/dL |

Urinalysis demonstrates mild pyuria.
question_options:
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pancreatitis  
B. Ovarian torsion  
C. Acute cholecystitis  
D. Acute cholangitis  
E. Diverticulitis  
F. HELLP syndrome  
G. Appendicitis  
H. Hepatic abscess  
I. Pyelonephritis  
J. Gastritis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 37-year-old G1P0 woman at 37 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with complaints of headache and abdominal pain.  
2. She has a history of morbid obesity, diabetes, chronic kidney disease, hypertension, bipolar disorder, and malingering.  
3. She has been non-compliant with prenatal care, including medications for her hypertension and diabetes.  
4. The patient is demanding morphine and becomes aggressive when it is denied.  
5. Her vital signs are: temperature 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure 157/105 mm Hg, pulse 82/min, respirations 12/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air.  
6. Initial laboratory findings are as follows:  
   - Hemoglobin: 12 g/dL  
   - Hematocrit: 36%  
   - Leukocyte count: 5,500/mm³ with normal differential  
   - Platelet count: 117,000/mm³  
   - Serum:  
     - Na⁺: 141 mEq/L  
     - Cl⁻: 101 mEq/L  
     - K⁺: 5.0 mEq/L  
     - HCO₃⁻: 23 mEq/L  
     - BUN: 29 mg/dL  
     - Glucose: 156 mg/dL  
     - Creatinine: 2.2 mg/dL (baseline 1.9 mg/dL)  
     - Ca²⁺: 9.8 mg/dL  
   - Urine:  
     - Color: Amber  
     - Protein: Positive  
     - Blood: Negative  
   The patient is admitted and treated appropriately, leading to resolution of her symptoms.  
7. While hospitalized, she becomes somnolent but can respond to questions when stimulated with a sternal rub.  
8. Neurological examination reveals intact cranial nerves II–XII, 1+ reflexes throughout, and preserved strength and sensation in all extremities.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Urgent neuroimaging  
B. Psychiatric consultation  
C. Emergency caesarean section  
D. Dialysis initiation  
E. Continuous fetal monitoring  
F. Immediate intubation  
G. Calcium  
H. Naloxone administration  
I. Labetalol infusion  
J. Magnesium

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 50s with a history of ‎poorly controlled type 2 diabetes reported decreased vision in both eyes.
2. On examination, visual acuity was counting fingers OD and 20/200 OS.
3. Anterior segment examination was unremarkable.
4. Dense vitreous hemorrhage precluded fundus examination of the right eye, and B-scan ultrasonography did not reveal any additional pathology.
5. The left fundus examination exhibited diabetic macular edema with central subfield thickness of 425 μm on optical coherence tomography and severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy, for which he had laser surgery for diabetic macular edema and panretinal photocoagulation.
6. He subsequently underwent vitrectomy in the right eye for nonclearing vitreous hemorrhage with an uneventful postoperative course and improvement of his visual acuity to 20/100.
7. The patient was lost to follow-up and returned 4 months later with visual acuity 20/125 OD and counting fingers OS, with a vitreous hemorrhage in the left eye for which he underwent vitrectomy with thorough panretinal photocoagulation (1200 spots).
8. On postoperative day 1, visual acuity was 20/200 and intraocular pressure was elevated to 35 mm Hg.
9. The conjunctiva had mild hyperemia with foci of subconjunctival hemorrhage, the anterior chamber was deep and quiet, the anterior vitreous contained no cells, and a few cobweblike, tan strands were present throughout the vitreous cavity.
10. Topical timolol/acetazolamide and brimonidine were started twice daily, together with prednisolone acetate and moxifloxacin every 6 hours.
11. On postoperative day 3, the patient noted decreased visual acuity OS but he denied pain or discharge.
12. Visual acuity was hand motion, and intraocular pressure was 17 mm Hg.
13. The anterior chamber had minimal inflammation.
14. Extensive strands and veils were noted throughout the vitreous cavity (Figure 1).
15. Anterior vitreous cavity (A) and wide-field fundus photograph (B) of the left eye demonstrating extensive transvitreal strands and sheets.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Increase topical steroids  
B: Inject intravitreal antibiotics  
C: Perform vitrectomy  
D: Inject antifungal drug

step1_excerpts:
1. An 82-year-old man presented with intractable pruritus of several months’ duration and a skin eruption.
2. He reported being diagnosed with dermatitis herpetiformis more than 20 years ago and receiving sulfapyridine and dapsone for treatment.
3. He stopped taking these medications because of limited benefit and concern about nephrotoxicity.
4. Since then, he was treated with periodic courses of oral antibiotics and oral corticosteroids.
5. Recently, extensive skin disease and pruritus developed.
6. He noted 20 years of chronic diarrhea, which improved with a gluten-free diet, in addition to chronic renal insufficiency, hypothyroidism, and aortic stenosis.
7. Physical examination revealed diffuse erosions with grouped papules and vesicles on his bilateral extremities, elbow and knee extensors, chest, back, buttocks, face, and scalp (Figure 1).
8. Examination also revealed extensive excoriations, as well as superficial honey-colored crusts.
9. A few possible burrows were noted on his wrists.Grouped papules, vesicles, and erosions of chest and elbow extensors (left) and back (right; inset is a close-up view).
10. Obtain complete blood cell count and creatinine level
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Examine for infestation with scabies  
B: Obtain complete blood cell count and creatinine level  
C: Perform skin biopsy and direct immunofluorescence  
D: Obtain a chest radiograph

step1_excerpts:
1. An otherwise healthy man in his 20s presented to the dermatology department with thickening and swelling of hands after immersion in water, accompanied by burning pruritus for 3 years.
2. The lesions occurred as symmetrical white and transparent papules, white keratosis, excessive wrinkling on the dorsum of hands after water immersion and worsened in summer, and remitted in winter.
3. He was treated with topical tretinoin ointment intermittently per a diagnosis of chronic eczema at the local clinic with little improvement.
4. The lesions gradually aggravated, and the affected area dispersed to wrists and elbows during past the 1.5 years.
5. He attributed these changes to the need for washing hands frequently in the period of the COVID-19 epidemic.
6. He had no family history of similar skin problems and did not have a history of hyperhidrosis, cystic fibrosis, atopy, or trauma to the hands.
7. Physical examination showed some changes emerged on both hands after water immersion contrasting with any other condition (Figure, A and B).
8. We took a skin biopsy specimen from white papules on the right hand, and representative histopathologic features are shown in the Figure, C and D.
9. A and B, After immersing both hands in water for 10 mins, there were symmetrical white papules, white hyperkeratosis spots, and excessive wrinkling on the thenar eminence, wrist flexure of both hands, and dorsum of fingers and hands.
10. C and D, A skin biopsy taken from white papules after water immersion for 10 mins showed hyperkeratosis, dilated eccrine ducts in the epidermis and dermis, and hyperplasia of the eccrine sweat glanda (hematoxylin-eosin).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Eczema  
B: Aquagenic syringeal acrokeratoderma  
C: Hereditary papulotranslucent acrokeratoderma  
D: Progressive symmetric erythrokeratoderma

step1_excerpts:
1. A teenage girl presented with recurrent episodes of palpitations for 6 consecutive years.  
2. The resting 12-lead electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm with no preexcitation or repolarization abnormalities.  
3. There were incessant multiple runs of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia with right bundle branch block morphologic features.  
4. QRS complexes were negative in the rest of the precordial leads (V2-V6) and in leads I and avL, but positive in III, avR, and avF, suggesting a left (lateral) ventricular apical origin (Figure 1).  
5. The echocardiogram showed no structural abnormalities.  
6. The patient was prescribed sotalol but her symptoms did not improve.  
7. Invasive electrophysiological mapping of the left ventricle endocardium demonstrated that the ventricular tachycardia probably originated from the epicardial surface of left ventricular apex.Twelve-lead surface electrocardiogram during tachycardia.  
8. QRS complexes are positive in V1, negative in the rest of the precordial leads (V2-V6), and negative in leads I and avL but positive in III, avR, and avF.Add a second antiarrhythmic drug and reassess the need for epicardial intervention after 3 to 6 monthsPerform cardiac magnetic resonance imaging to define pathologic substrate
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Map and ablate the epicardium  
B: Add a second antiarrhythmic drug and reassess the need for epicardial intervention after 3 to 6 months  
C: Implant a cardioverter defibrillator  
D: Perform cardiac magnetic resonance imaging to define pathologic substrate

step1_excerpts:
1. A 74-year-old man with a history of multiple squamous cell carcinomas that were treated with Mohs micrographic surgery presented with a tender, enlarging scalp lesion of 6 months’ duration.  
2. Skin examination revealed a 5-mm bright pink, dome-shaped papule with overlying vessels located at the crown of the scalp (Figure, A).  
3. There was no purulent discharge or overlying skin changes.  
4. A shave skin biopsy was performed and submitted for histopathologic analysis (Figure, B-D).  
5. A, Bright pink, dome-shaped papule of the scalp crown with overlying vessels measuring 5 mm.  
6. B, Hematoxylin-eosin staining of the lesion from biopsy.  
7. Scanning magnification demonstrates dermal-based tumor cells arranged in a vague nodular configuration.  
8. C, Proliferation of tumor cells is present around small vessels with scattered mitoses (black arrowhead) and necrosis (yellow arrowheads) (hematoxylin-eosin).  
9. D, Smooth muscle actin stain.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Symplastic glomus tumor  
B: Angioleiomyoma  
C: Solitary fibrous tumor  
D: Malignant myopericytoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 75-year-old female presents to the office for a health maintenance examination.
2. She says that she is more fatigued than she was at 65, but she still gardens and drives to the grocery store.
3. Routine laboratory studies reveal a leukocyte count of 25.0 × 103/mcL (reference range 4.5-11.0 × 103/mcL) and 97% mature-appearing lymphocytes on a peripheral blood smear.
4. Immunohistochemical stains demonstrate the lymphocytes to be of B-cell origin.
question_options:
The most likely diagnosis is

A. acute lymphocytic leukemia

B. acute myelogenous leukemia

C. chronic lymphocytic leukemia

D. chronic myelogenous leukemia

step1_excerpts:
1. A boy in his late teens with short stature presented with gradual loss of vision in both eyes since 8 years of age.  
2. He received a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes at 10 years of age and has been taking insulin since the diagnosis.  
3. He had consulted several physicians for hearing loss during the past 2 years.  
4. He had received multiple courses of antibiotics for frequent urinary tract infections.  
5. The results of a systemic examination revealed hypochondroplasia, alopecia (Figure 1), and generalized hypotonia.  
6. His best-corrected visual acuity was 6/60 OU.  
7. Bjerrum tangent screen visual field analysis showed preservation of central 10 degrees of fields.  
8. His color vision was defective, and his pupils were slow reactive to light.  
9. The results of an optic nerve examination revealed bilateral pale optic discs with no evidence of edema and normal retinal vasculature.  
10. The results of the examination of the macula were normal in both eyes, with no diabetic retinopathy.  
11. A urine specific gravity test was performed, and the urine specific gravity was found to be low (sp g 1.001-1.003), consistent with diabetes insipidus.  
12. Physical presentation of the patient, an adolescent boy presenting with hypochondroplasia, alopecia, and short stature.  
13. Order a hormone profile (thyrotropin, adrenocorticotrophic hormone, growth hormone, and testosterone) and consult endocrinology
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  
A: Order magnetic resonance imaging of the brain  
B: Order a hormone profile (thyrotropin, adrenocorticotrophic hormone, growth hormone, and testosterone) and consult endocrinology  
C: Perform a peripheral blood smear examination  
D: Order targeted genetic testing

step1_excerpts:
1. A 71-year-old otherwise healthy woman presented with an enlarging, immobile, painless mass in her right gluteal area.
2. She had no other associated symptoms.
3. On examination, she had a large, palpable, nontender right gluteal mass.
4. She had no neurovascular deficits.
5. Results of laboratory studies were within normal limits.
6. Computed tomography (CT) revealed an 11-cm heterogeneous lipomatous tumor involving the right gluteal musculature (Figure).
7. Axial (left) and coronal (right) computed tomography images of patient’s right gluteal mass.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Incisional biopsy of the lesion  
B: Core needle biopsy of the lesion  
C: Simple excision of the lesion  
D: Repeat imaging in 6 months

step1_excerpts:
1. A 10-year-old girl developed an annular skin lesion on her anterior neck.  
2. The lesion, initially attributed to a bug bite by her mother, enlarged and developed central clearing.  
3. The patient lived in North Carolina with no recent travel or known tick bite.  
4. She had no symptoms other than mild local itching.  
5. After several weeks, the patient’s mother applied over-the-counter topical antifungal cream and the lesion faded.  
6. After 10 days of antifungal therapy, the patient was evaluated by her pediatrician.  
7. Examination results were normal except for a 2.0-cm annular lesion with central clearing and peripheral flaking (Figure).  
8. The pediatrician ordered serologic testing for Lyme disease, prescribed 14 days of doxycycline based on the results (Table), and referred the patient to an infectious disease specialist for evaluation.  
9. Complete 14 days of antibiotic treatment for Lyme disease.  
10. No further testing is indicated.  
11. Complete 14 days of antibiotic treatment for Lyme disease.  
12. Repeat Lyme disease serology in 1 month to evaluate response.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next

A: Complete 14 days of antibiotic treatment for Lyme disease. No further testing is indicated.  
B: Complete 14 days of antibiotic treatment for Lyme disease. Repeat Lyme disease serology in 1 month to evaluate response.  
C: Obtain skin biopsy for Borrelia burgdorferi PCR.  
D: Discontinue doxycycline and restart topical antifungal cream.

step1_excerpts:
1. A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency room with difficulty speaking for the past 1 hour.
2. He was having dinner at home with his wife when he suddenly noticed he had difficulty eating and speaking.
3. He also noticed a new-onset weakness on his left side.
4. His medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia.
5. His current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril.
6. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 15/min.
7. On examination, strength is 5/5 in the right upper and lower extremities and 3/5 in the left upper and lower extremities.
8. On cranial nerve examination, his tongue deviates to the right side.
9. There is also decreased sensation to light touch and vibration on the left side of his body.
question_options:
Which of the following arteries is most likely involved in this patient’s presentation?

A. Anterior spinal artery  
B. Lenticulostriate branches of the middle cerebral artery  
C. Pontine perforators of the basilar artery  
D. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

step1_excerpts:
1. A 35-year-old man seeks medical consultation regarding his colon cancer risk after learning that his 45-year-old sister was recently diagnosed with colon cancer.
2. His vital signs show: temperature 98.8°F, heart rate 72/min, blood pressure 122/80 mmHg, and respiratory rate 12/min.
3. He is currently asymptomatic but concerned about cancer prevention.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate screening recommendation for this patient?

A. CT colonography every 5 years starting at age 40  
B. Repeat screening in 10 years if initial colonoscopy is negative  
C. Colonoscopy at the age of 40 years  
D. Fecal occult blood testing annually  
E. Immediate screening for colon cancer  
F. Genetic testing for Lynch syndrome before screening  
G. Routine screening starting at age 45 per general guidelines  
H. Stool DNA testing every 3 years  
I. Flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years starting at age 40  
J. Colonoscopy at the age of 50 years

step1_excerpts:
1. A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with progressive right arm swelling and discomfort over the past 6 months, which worsens when his arm is dependent.
2. His medical history includes successfully treated infective endocarditis and a history of intravenous heroin use, though he reports 3 years of sobriety.
3. He takes no medications and denies current substance use.
4. Physical examination reveals normal vital signs but shows significant nonpitting edema of the right hand and arm, skin thickening, and visible track marks in the antecubital fossa.
question_options:
Which osteopathic lymphatic technique should be used as the initial treatment for this condition?

A. Sacral rocking technique  
B. Thoracic lymphatic pump  
C. Lymphatic drainage of the lower extremities  
D. Thoracic inlet myofascial release  
E. Rib raising technique  
F. Hepatic pump technique  
G. Pedal pump technique  
H. Upper extremity lymphatic pump  
I. Abdominal diaphragm release  
J. Splenic pump technique

step1_excerpts:
1. A 78-year-old male presents to the office with the complaint of severe neck pain.  
2. He rates the pain as a 7 on a scale of 0 to 10 scale.  
3. He denies any trauma but reports that he had been doing a lot of painting over the past week.  
4. He denies any radicular pain or numbness.  
5. Cervical range of motion is moderately limited in all fields.  
6. He is treated with articulatory springing technique.  
7. Four hours later the physician receives a call from the local emergency department, where the patient presented confused, nauseated, and vertiginous.
question_options:
The physician may be found liable if

A. the motion barrier was articulated more than 3 times

B. the motion barrier was met with a vectored force from the direction of ease

C. the neck was treated in simultaneous hyperrotation and extension

D. the patient was previously treated for osteoarthritis of the cervical spine

step1_excerpts:
1. A 2-year-old white boy was referred for evaluation of a choroidal mass.
2. He had mild periorbital edema and low-grade eye pain in the left eye over 2 weeks prior to presentation.
3. He had completed antibiotic treatment for presumed sinusitis with no improvement.
4. A recent flulike illness over the past 1.5 weeks responded minimally to ibuprofen.
5. Medical and family history were otherwise unremarkable.
6. Magnetic resonance imaging of the orbits revealed an intraocular mass, suspicious for retinoblastoma.
7. The patient was advised consultation by an ocular oncology service.
8. On examination, visual acuity was fix and follow OU.
9. The right eye showed normal findings anteriorly and posteriorly.
10. The left eye revealed mild conjunctival chemosis with periorbital edema.
11. There was trace eyelid edema and mild leukocoria.
12. Dilated ophthalmoscopic examination of the left eye displayed a solid gray mass in the macular region, deep to the retina and with surrounding subretinal fluid (Figure 1A).
13. A, Dilated ophthalmoscopic examination found a gray mass in the macular region of the left eye measuring 12 mm in diameter and 5.1 mm in thickness, with additional subretinal fluid inferiorly.
14. B, B-scan ultrasonography confirmed the fundus mass, dependent subretinal fluid, and echolucency outside the posterior wall of the eye.
15. Examination under anesthesia confirmed the solid mass, measuring 12 mm in diameter and 5.1 mm in thickness and demonstrating echodensity on ultrasonography (Figure 1B).
16. There were no tumor-feeding vessels, and tumor margins were ill defined.
17. Fluorescein angiography demonstrated slight hyperfluorescence of the disc and faint hyperfluorescence of the mass with overlying scattered pinpoint hyperfluorescent leakage.
18. Optical coherence tomography revealed shallow subretinal fluid extending within 3.2 mm of the foveola.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Treat with intra-arterial chemotherapy  
B: Treat with plaque radiotherapy  
C: Treat with oral corticosteroids  
D: Perform fine-needle aspiration biopsy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 56-year-old male presents with severe anal pain that started 2 hours ago.
2. He has a history of chronic constipation but no other significant medical conditions and takes no medications.
3. His vital signs are normal.
4. Rectal examination under local anesthesia reveals a palpable perianal mass without evidence of a skin tag or mucosal prolapse through the anal canal.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?

A. Lateral internal sphincterotomy  
B. Application of topical hydrocortisone  
C. Sclerotherapy injection  
D. Hemorrhoidectomy  
E. Elliptical excision  
F. Fistulotomy  
G. Conservative management with sitz baths  
H. Topical nitroglycerin application  
I. Rubber band ligation  
J. Incision and drainage

step1_excerpts:
1. A 57-year-old man receives radiation therapy for a squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.
2. Despite therapy, the tumor progressively increases in size, and he dies 6 months later.
3. His tumor cells contain a point mutation in the p53 gene (TP53), leading to an inactive gene product.
question_options:
Based on this finding, the progressive tumor growth despite irradiation therapy is most likely to be related to a defect in cell cycle arrest in which of the following phases of the cell cycle?

A. G0

B. G1

C. G2

D. M

step1_excerpts:
1. A 4-year-old boy is brought for a follow-up examination.
2. He has a history of chronic recurrent otitis media and recently completed a 10-day course of antibiotics.
3. His vital signs are within normal limits.
4. Examination shows clear ear canals and intact tympanic membranes; a brown, irregular mass is visualized behind the tympanic membrane.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

A. Epithelial tissue proliferation

B. Lingual papillae loss

C. Middle ear effusion
