12. B, Spectral-domain optical coherence tomographic (SD-OCT) image of the right eye shows outer retinal foveoschisis and outer retinal thinning with interruptions of the ellipsoid in the peripheral macula (seen in both eyes).
13. C, Fluorescein angiogram at 1 minute 15 seconds in the right eye shows no disc leakage or angiographic macular edema; there is faint staining of the annular area of hypopigmentation seen on the fundus photograph.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform an intravitreous injection of an anti–vascular endothelial growth factor  
B: Refer for genetic counseling and potential testing for an NR2E3 mutation  
C: Order testing for antirecoverin antibodies  
D: Perform a vitreous biopsy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 41-year-old woman comes to the doctor because of gradually progressive weakness in her right hand over the past few weeks.
2. She goes to the gym to lift weights 5 times a week.
3. With the dorsum of the right hand on a flat surface, the patient is unable to move her thumb to touch a pen held 2 cm above the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.
4. An MRI of the right arm shows compression of a nerve that passes through the pronator teres muscle.
question_options:
Based on the examination findings, loss of innervation of which of the following muscles is most likely in this patient?

A. Abductor pollicis longus  
B. Palmaris brevis  
C. Adductor pollicis  
D. Extensor pollicis longus  
E. Flexor pollicis brevis  
F. Extensor pollicis brevis  
G. Abductor pollicis brevis  
H. Opponens pollicis  
I. First dorsal interosseous  
J. Flexor pollicis longus

step1_excerpts:
1. A 52-year-old man comes to the physician with his wife because of a 1-year history of excessive daytime sleepiness.
2. He does not think the symptoms are problematic, but his wife is concerned because he sometimes falls asleep on the sofa early in the evening when guests are present.
3. He also once fell asleep while driving at night and drove off the road, narrowly avoiding injury.
4. His wife says that he has always snored loudly, and over the past year, he has had episodes of choking or gasping for breath while sleeping.
5. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 105 kg (231 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2 .
6. His pulse is 76/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 150/76 mm Hg.
7. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

A. 24-Hour ambulatory ECG monitoring

B. Multiple sleep latency test

C. Polysomnography

D. CT scan of the head

step1_excerpts:
1. A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her family.
2. They found her somnolent next to her computer with an empty pill bottle around 3 hours ago.
3. The family cannot recall the types of pill bottles that they found and did not bring them to the ED.
4. The patient's medical history is notable for anxiety, obesity, hypertension, and polycystic ovarian syndrome.
5. She is currently not on any medications.
6. She was given an exercise program but she has not been compliant with these exercises.
7. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), pulse is 82/min, blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg, respirations are 11/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air.
8. Physical exam is within normal limits.
9. The patient begins communicating with the physician and states that she did take acetaminophen but it was only a few pills.
10. Her parents are certain the bottle was new.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Lactated ringer bolus  
B. N-acetylcysteine  
C. Charcoal  
D. Syrup of ipecac

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her early 30s presented with acute onset of painful proptosis of the right eye and mild epistaxis with no inciting trauma.
2. Her medical history was notable for hypertension, treated with clonidine hydrochloride, and opiate abuse, treated with methadone hydrochloride.
3. Her blood pressure was 138/87 mm Hg.
4. The patient was afebrile with no leukocytosis.
5. Her visual acuity was 20/20 OU with no afferent pupillary defect and normal intraocular pressures.
6. Examination revealed periorbital edema, proptosis, and limitation in supraduction, abduction, and adduction in the right eye.
7. There was no periorbital soft-tissue erythema, warmth, or tenderness to palpation.
8. Computed tomography showed hyperattenuating soft tissue in the superior, medial, and inferior right orbit (Figure 1A, arrowheads).
9. Magnetic resonance imaging showed no internal flow voids to suggest vascular malformation.
10. Results of a laboratory workup revealed mildly elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (49 mm/h; reference range, 0-20 mm/h) and antinuclear antibody titer (1:80; reference range, <1:40) as well as positive results for anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies.
11. Results of further autoimmune and infectious workup were negative.
12. Two weeks later, new proptosis and periocular edema of the left eye developed, with no inciting trauma.
13. Her examination results were significant for proptosis, periorbital edema, and limitation in supraduction in the left eye.
14. Computed tomography showed new hyperattenuating soft tissue in the left superior and lateral orbit (Figure 1B, arrowhead).
15. A, Coronal contrast-enhanced computed tomographic scan shows hyperattenuating soft tissue in the superior, medial, and inferior subperiosteal space of the right orbit (arrowheads).
16. B, Computed tomographic scan, not contrast enhanced, shows hyperattenuating orbital soft tissue in the left orbit (arrowhead).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Empirical corticosteroid treatment  
B: Orbitotomy with biopsy  
C: External beam radiotherapy  
D: Intravenous antibiotic therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her mid-70s with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, end-stage renal disease, and coronary artery disease was admitted to the hospital for fever, lethargy, and altered mental status.
2. On day 7 of her hospital stay, she developed severe, unremitting left ankle pain with purpuric lesions on the skin.
3. She had previously undergone coronary artery bypass grafting with simultaneous aortic valve replacement and ileal conduit urinary diversion as a result of to recurrent upper urinary tract infections.
4. Laboratory findings were significant for neutrophil-predominant leukocytosis (leukocyte count, 19 400/μL [to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001]).
5. Physical examination revealed multiple stellate, purpuric plaques with central flaccid bullae on the medial and lateral aspects of the left ankle (Figure, A).
6. The remainder of her skin examination findings were unremarkable.
7. Punch biopsy specimens were obtained along the border of normal and lesional skin (Figure, B and C), and she underwent transesophageal echocardiography.
8. A, Stellate purpura with overlying flaccid bulla on the medial aspect of the ankle.
9. B, Partially necrotic epidermis with intraepidermal bulla formation with marked perivascular infiltrates in the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×25).
10. C, A small blood vessel occluded with fibrinoid material with a perivascular lymphoneutrophilic infiltrate (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×400).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Calciphylaxis  
B: Septic emboli  
C: Vasculitis  
D: Necrotizing fasciitis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 6-week-old girl presents with her parents to the pediatrician for blood-streaked diapers.
2. The patient is breastfed every 2-3 hours and voids 10-12 times daily.
3. The patient previously had several soft stools per day that ranged in color from mustard yellow to dark green.
4. Over the past 2 days, the patient’s stools have become looser and streaked with blood.
5. The patient has also regurgitated several of her feedings in the last few days.
6. Neither the vomit nor bloody stools have seemed to bother the patient.
7. The patient’s weight continues to trend along the 50th percentile.
8. The patient’s temperature is 98.4°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 66/51 mmHg, pulse is 127/min, and respirations are 26/min.
9. On physical exam, the patient appears well nourished and is cooing.
10. Her abdomen is soft and non-tender.
11. Physical exam reveals the finding seen in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s presentation?

A. Congenital enzyme deficiency  
B. Passage of gastric contents into esophagus  
C. Non-IgE-mediated immunologic reaction  
D. Hypertrophy of sphincter muscle

step1_excerpts:
1. A 59-year-old man presented to the vitreoretinal service with a 2-week history of acute-onset, progressively worsening decreased vision and central scotomas in both eyes.  
2. He had no systemic symptoms and denied having eye redness, pain, and photophobia.  
3. His medical and surgical history included prostate cancer, status postcryotherapy, osteoarthritis, and migraines.  
4. His social history was significant for active cigarette smoking and immigration from a Middle Eastern country.  
5. His medications included naproxen at 500 mg as needed, tamsulosin at 0.4 mg daily, and aspirin at 81 mg daily.  
6. On examination, his best-corrected visual acuities were 20/40 OD and 20/25 OS.  
7. His pupils were reactive, his extraocular motility was full, and the intraocular pressures were 16 mm Hg in both eyes.  
8. The results of the external examination and anterior slitlamp examinations were unremarkable, and there was no anterior chamber or anterior vitreous cell or flare.  
9. The dilated fundus photography examination revealed yellow-gray, curvilinear, and puzzle piece–shaped subretinal macular lesions in both eyes (Figure).  
10. The lesions were hyperfluorescent with hypofluorescent borders on fundus autofluorescence testing results (Figure).  
11. Optical coherence tomography revealed that the involved areas exhibited a disruption of the outer retinal layers (including and deep to the outer nuclear layer) along with hyperreflectivity of the outer retina, retinal pigment epithelium, and choroid.  
12. There was no involvement of the inner retina.  
13. The patient underwent laboratory testing for syphilis and tuberculosis, which yielded negative results.  
14. Fundus photographs showing yellowish, puzzle piece–shaped, curvilinear lesions in the maculae of the right eye (A) and left eye (B).  
15. Fundus autofluorescence (insets) exhibits hyperfluorescent lesions with hypofluorescent borders.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Recommend multivitamin supplementation  
B: Give an intravitreal anti-VEGF injection  
C: Discuss the potential risks and benefits of initiating oral corticosteroid therapy  
D: Insist on observation for spontaneous resolution

step1_excerpts:
1. A 70-year-old man presented to the dermatology clinic for evaluation of a pruritic exanthem that began on his scalp and face and spread across most of his body over a 2-month period.
2. The patient had no fever, night sweats, fatigue, recent unintentional weight loss, shortness of breath, chest pain, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
3. He reported no new prescription medications, over-the-counter drugs, or herbal supplements prior to the onset of the exanthem.
4. He had no history of psoriasis, atopic dermatitis, or other skin disorder, and no recent viral or bacterial infection.
5. On presentation, his temperature was 37.1 °C (98.7 °F); blood pressure, 128/86 mm Hg; heart rate, 110/min; and respiratory rate, 30/min.
6. Physical examination revealed confluent salmon-colored plaques composed of folliculocentric scaly papules across his body with several patches of unaffected skin on his trunk.
7. The patient had waxy, exfoliative scale on the volar aspect of his hands and feet and thickened, onycholytic nails.
8. Severe ectropion prevented complete eyelid closure (Figure).
9. He was referred to the emergency department, where laboratory testing revealed a normal complete blood cell count and normal lactate dehydrogenase level.
10. The patient was admitted to the hospital and was treated with intravenous fluids and daily wet-wrap therapy with topical triamcinolone ointment (0.1%) applied to his trunk, arms, and legs, followed by a layer of warm, damp gauze and dry, cotton pajamas.
11. Clinical examination at the time of presentation revealed generalized and coalescing salmon-colored plaques with “islands of sparing” on the abdomen (far left); waxy, exfoliative scale on the palms (center left) and soles (center right); and ectropion (far right).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Order a myositis-specific autoantibody panel  
B: Obtain skin biopsy with T-cell clonality studies  
C: Order testing for anti–double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibody  
D: Order testing for HLA-B27

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 30s presented for evaluation of asymptomatic erythematous scaly plaques over the face and proximal extremities.
2. The lesions started as an erythematous papule on the face, which had progressed to larger plaques within 10 years.
3. There was involvement of the upper respiratory tract, causing palatal perforation and stridor, necessitating a tracheostomy a year ago.
4. In addition, there was history of wheezing and breathlessness.
5. There was no history of preceding trauma, fever, malaise, joint pain, cough, epistaxis, hemoptysis, or hematuria.
6. Examination revealed multiple well-defined brown erythematous scaly plaques with central scarring measuring 2 × 1 to 8 × 7 cm on the face, arm, and thighs.
7. The patient also had saddle nose deformity, perforation of the hard palate, and necrotic plaques on the ear, causing destruction of ear cartilage (Figure, A and B).
8. There was cervical lymphadenopathy: multiple, nontender, discrete nodes, ranging from 1.5 to 2 cm without any surface changes.
9. The results of sensory examination and peripheral nerve examination were within normal limits.
10. Respiratory examination and chest radiography results were normal.
11. Hemogram showed anemia (hemoglobin, 10.1 g/dL [to convert to g/L, multiply by 10.0]); the results of a kidney function test, a liver function test, a fasting blood glucose test, and routine urinalysis were within normal limits.
12. Serologic analysis results for HIV-1/2, antinuclear antibody, and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies were negative.
13. Punch skin biopsy was obtained for histopathologic analysis and culture (Figure, C).
14. A, Multiple well-defined brown erythematous scaly plaques with central scarring, saddle nose deformity, and necrotic lesions on the ear with loss of ear cartilage.
15. B, Perforation of the hard palate.
16. C, Infiltrate of foamy histiocytes and pigmented yeasts without multiaxial septation (Fontana-Masson).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Chromoblastomycosis  
B: Hyalohyphomycosis  
C: Blastomycosis  
D: Phaeohyphomycosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 52-year-old woman has had dyspnea and hemoptysis for 1 month.
2. She has a history of rheumatic fever as a child and has had a cardiac murmur since early adulthood.
3. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 130/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg.
4. Jugular venous pressure is not increased.
5. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases.
6. There is an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur at the third left intercostal space.
7. An x-ray of the chest shows left atrial enlargement, a straight left cardiac border, and pulmonary venous engorgement.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

A. Aortic valve insufficiency

B. Aortic valve stenosis

C. Mitral valve insufficiency

D. Mitral valve stenosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of mild nausea, increased urinary urgency and frequency, and constipation.
2. She also has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss during the past 2 weeks and a 3-week history of vaginal bleeding.
3. Pelvic examination shows a nodular cervix with an irregular, friable posterior lip, and a rock-hard, irregular, immobile pelvic mass that extends across the pelvis.
4. Examination of biopsy specimens from the cervix and anterior wall of the vagina show well-differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma.
question_options:
Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of this patient's disease?

A. Inactivation of cellular p53

B. Insertion of viral promotors adjacent to cellular growth factor genes

C. Specialized transduction

D. Transactivation of cellular growth factor genes by TAX

step1_excerpts:
1. A 53-year-old man received a diagnosis of stage IV melanoma with metastatic disease to the spine and brain 3 months before presentation.
2. Four weeks following receipt of immunotherapy with ipilimumab and nivolumab, he developed acute abdominal pain in the setting of a rapidly rising lactic acid dehydrogenase levels, prompting hospital admission.
3. Imaging results showed mild disease progression (new ascites and periportal metabolic lymph node).
4. Splenic infarct and portal/splenic vein thrombi were identified as etiologies of his acute pain and were presumed to be secondary to hypercoagulable state of malignancy.
5. Over the next 3 days, he had rising serum creatinine (sCr) levels (baseline, approximately 1 mg/dL [to convert to μmol/L, multiply by 88.4]).
6. The initial workup included ultrasonography and urinalysis.
7. Ultrasonography results showed abnormal intraparenchymal flow to both kidneys without evidence of kidney artery stenosis.
8. Urine studies were consistent with prerenal etiology, while the presence of casts suggested acute tubular necrosis.
9. Nephrotoxic medications (omeprazole/pantoprazole) were discontinued.
10. The top differential diagnoses at this juncture included contrast-induced nephropathy or immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI)–induced acute interstitial nephritis, and empirical high dose steroids were prescribed.
11. Despite observation and steroid treatment, his sCr levels continued to increase over the next 5 days, peaking at 5.8 mg/dL, and the patient progressed into anuric kidney failure, requiring hemodialysis.
12. This prompted a kidney biopsy for definitive diagnosis (Figure).
13. One week later, he received encorafenib, a BRAF inhibitor.
14. Two weeks later, the patient’s kidney function began to improve, and hemodialysis was discontinued.
15. He continued to show gradual improvement, with a return to near baseline kidney function (sCr level, 1.3 mg/dL) approximately 6 weeks after treatment initiation.
16. Histopathology (original magnification x40) of kidney capillaries with hematoxylin and eosin stain showing atypical cells (arrowheads) (A), tubules with hematoxylin and eosin stain (B), and capillaries with melanin-A (C).
17. Acute tubular necrosis secondary to kidney melanoma metastasis
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Immune checkpoint inhibitor–induced acute interstitial nephritis  
B: Postinfectious glomerulonephritis  
C: Acute tubular necrosis secondary to kidney melanoma metastasis  
D: Drug-induced acute tubular necrosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 80s presented with 3 months of painless progressive vision loss, followed by gait changes, memory loss, and 10-lb unintentional weight loss.
2. Medical history was notable for coronary artery disease, hypothyroidism, and prostate cancer in remission.
3. On ophthalmic examination, visual acuity was hand motion OU (baseline from 9 months prior was 20/50 OD and 20/30 OS), with briskly reactive left pupil and trace right relative afferent pupillary defect.
4. He could detect 2/4 gross colors in the right eye and 1/4 gross colors in the left eye.
5. Confrontation visual fields revealed dense right homonymous hemianopia with additional asymmetric deficits on Goldmann perimetry (Figure 1).
6. Extraocular movements were full with gaze-evoked nystagmus.
7. Horizontal vestibulo-ocular reflex, assessed by head impulse testing, was normal.
8. Slitlamp and dilated fundus examination revealed pseudophakia and mild epiretinal membrane in the right eye and mild nuclear sclerosis in the left eye.
9. Goldmann perimetry (V4e stimulus) of left (A) and right (B) eyes shows right homonymous hemianopia, left inferotemporal visual field loss, and right nasal paracentral visual field loss.
10. Neurologic examination showed full motor strength, decreased vibration sense and proprioception in the feet, positive Romberg sign, and inability to tandem walk.
11. Mini-Mental State Examination score was 6 of 30.
12. Magnetic resonance imaging brain and orbits with and without contrast and magnetic resonance angiography head and neck were unremarkable.
13. An electroencephalogram showed no localizing signs.
14. Syphilis screen was negative.
15. Serum thiamine, vitamin B12, and thyrotropin levels were normal.
16. Cerebrospinal fluid composition, infectious studies, cytology, flow cytometry, and paraneoplastic panel showed only mildly elevated protein.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Pars plana vitrectomy with vitreous biopsy  
B: Prescribe aspirin for secondary stroke prevention  
C: Order cerebrospinal fluid prion disease panel  
D: Refer to psychiatry for functional vision loss

step1_excerpts:
1. A 52-year-old man presents to the clinic with a left foot ulcer that he noticed 6 days ago.
2. He has a history of obesity, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and depression.
3. His current medications include metformin, aspirin, rosuvastatin, lisinopril, and fluoxetine.
4. He has a 25-pack-year smoking history and drinks 1 glass of wine a day.
5. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 12/min.
6. On physical exam, he has a 1.2 x 1.7 cm ulcer on the plantar surface of his left metatarsal head.
question_options:
Which of the following tests will most appropriately assess this patient’s future risk of foot ulcers?

A. Knee reflex testing  
B. Monofilament testing  
C. Contrast-enhanced foot magnetic resonance imaging  
D. Ankle-brachial index

step1_excerpts:
1. A 15-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician for a follow-up visit.
2. His parents report that he is doing well in school and has many friends.
3. Their only concern is that he has a “difficult stomach.” Every few months, he complains of intermittent abdominal pain that takes several days to pass.
4. He occasionally misses school due to the pain.
5. There is blood in his stool during these episodes.
6. These symptoms have persisted for many years.
7. The parents have so far managed the condition using herbal teas and essential oils but have not sought formal medical care.
8. His temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 106/61 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 12/min.
9. He has lost 10 pounds since his annual visit the year before and is the same height.
10. On physical exam, the patient is thin with conjunctival pallor.
11. His sclerae are anicteric and his abdomen is soft and non-tender without hepatosplenomegaly.
12. He also has the findings seen in Figure A.
13. He undergoes an abdominal CT that shows disease affecting the terminal ileum.
question_options:
Which of the following is most likely to be present in this patient?

A. Increased serum methylmalonic acid level  
B. Microcytes  
C. Decreased serum homocysteine level  
D. Prolonged partial thromboplastin time

step1_excerpts:
1. A 65-year-old white man was referred to the clinic with a pigmented conjunctival lesion in the left eye.  
2. The referring physician suspected primary acquired melanosis (PAM).  
3. His ocular history was notable for occupational exposure to sunlight and occasional smoking.  
4. There was no personal or family history of cancer, and he denied ocular surgery or trauma.  
5. On examination, his best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OD/OS, and intraocular pressures were 15 mm Hg OD and 18 mm Hg OS.  
6. A slitlamp examination of the right eye showed no conjunctival pigmentation.  
7. Examination of the left eye revealed a pigmented lesion at the temporal limbus from 3 to 4 o’clock with a 2-mm extension into the cornea (Figure 1A).  
8. Some opalescence underlied the pigment on the cornea.  
9. In addition, there was an adjacent small area of flat, superficial, mobile bulbar conjunctival pigmentation.  
10. The anterior segment high-resolution optical coherence tomography (HR-OCT) of the 4-o’clock corneolimbal lesion of the left eye demonstrated thickened hyperreflective corneal epithelium with an abrupt transition from normal to abnormal (Figure 1B).  
11. A, Slitlamp photography of the left eye shows a pigmented limbal lesion at 3 to 4 o’clock; another small area of bulbar conjunctival pigmentation is noted (arrowhead).  
12. B, High-resolution optical coherence tomography of the left eye through the area of the pigmented conjunctival lesion (inset with red line in area of scan), showing epithelial hyperreflectivity and thickening with an abrupt change from normal to mildly thickened epithelium (arrowhead).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  
A: Refer to an oncologist for metastatic workup  
B: Biopsy the conjunctival and corneal lesion  
C: Perform cryotherapy over the lesion  
D: Start oral doxycycline

step1_excerpts:
1. A randomized controlled trial is conducted to assess the effectiveness of a new combination-drug antihypertensive therapy (Drug X) compared with a standard antihypertensive single-drug therapy.
2. Study participants include 140 women (70%) and 60 men (30%) ages 30 to 60 years, with baseline blood pressure measurements of 150/95 mm Hg or higher.
3. The investigators defined antihypertensive therapy as effective if the treatment resulted in a blood pressure measurement below 140/90 mm Hg.
4. When designing the study, the investigators set the probability of wrongly finding that Drug X is more effective than the standard therapy as 1%; they set the probability of wrongly finding that the effectiveness of the two drugs is the same as 10%.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most accurate estimate of the statistical power in this study?

A. 1%

B. 10%

C. 40%

D. 90%

step1_excerpts:
1. A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a bar fight.
2. He was punched in the eye and is having pain and blurry vision.
3. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications.
4. His temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg, pulse is 103/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
5. Physical exam is notable for conjunctival injection of the patient’s left eye as shown in Figure A.
6. Visual acuity reveals 20/20 vision in his right eye and 20/40 vision in his left.
7. His left pupil is sluggish to constrict when compared to the right.
8. A fluorescein stain is unremarkable and tonometry reveals a pressure of 45 mmHg in the left eye.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Lateral canthotomy  
B. Cyclopentolate  
C. Topical timolol and pilocarpine  
D. Orbital ultrasound

step1_excerpts:
1. A 40-year-old male presents with a 10 kg (22 lb) unintentional weight gain over the past 3 months, along with decreased libido, oily skin, and trouble sleeping.  
2. He denies any significant personal or family medical history but has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years.  
3. On examination, he appears lethargic, with a temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse of 80/min, and blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg.  
4. Findings include central obesity, acne, thin and easily bruisable skin with abdominal stretch marks, hyperpigmentation of mucous membranes and skin creases, and proximal muscle weakness and atrophy.  
5. His serum glucose level is 240 mg/dL.
question_options:
Which imaging finding is most likely in this patient?

A. Adrenal adenoma  
B. Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia  
C. Pituitary adenoma  
D. Pulmonary tumor  
E. Ectopic ACTH-producing tumor  
F. Paraneoplastic syndrome-induced adrenal hypertrophy  
G. Retroperitoneal mass  
H. Hypothalamic tumor  
I. Adrenal cortical carcinoma  
J. Adrenal hemorrhage

step1_excerpts:
1. Twelve hours after birth, a 2700-g (5-lb 15-oz) male newborn presents with three episodes of bilious vomiting.
2. He was delivered at 36 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old mother whose pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios.
3. The mother has a history of smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily and intravenous cocaine use.
4. The newborn's vital signs are stable.
5. On examination, his upper abdomen is distended, and bowel sounds are hypoactive.
6. An abdominal x-ray reveals three gas shadows in the upper abdomen and a gasless distal abdomen.
question_options:
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pyloric stenosis  
B. Malrotation with volvulus  
C. Ileal atresia  
D. Necrotizing enterocolitis  
E. Duodenal atresia  
F. Meconium ileus  
G. Jejunal atresia  
H. Intestinal malrotation  
I. Annular pancreas  
J. Midgut volvulus

step1_excerpts:
1. A 28-year-old female patient comes in for her yearly physical examination, stating she has no health concerns to report.  
2. Her medical history includes major depressive disorder treated with sertraline.  
3. Her vital signs show: temperature 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure 115/71 mmHg, pulse 62/min, and respirations 15/min.  
4. Physical examination reveals multiple bruises at various healing stages on her upper arms, upper legs, and back, along with small circular lesions on her hips and stomach.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate initial response in this situation?  
A. "Is someone hurting you?"  
B. "I'm concerned about your safety at home."  
C. "I need to report this to the authorities immediately."  
D. "Would you like to speak with a counselor today?"  
E. "Tell me more about what has been happening."  
F. "Are you experiencing any bleeding disorders?"  
G. "Would you like me to examine these bruises more closely?"  
H. "Do you have a safe place to go if things get out of hand?"  
I. "These bruises don't look like they're from falling."  
J. "I can call the police so that they can protect you."

step1_excerpts:
1. A 25-year-old woman is brought to a psychiatrist by her husband, who is concerned about her recent episodes of violent behavior.
2. He reports that during a family dinner last night, she threatened his parents with a knife, prompting him to call the police.
3. He states that over the past 9 months, she has been exhibiting increasingly alarming behavior, starting with claims that her deceased sister was communicating with her through a vase in their living room.
4. Initially, he thought she was joking, but her reports of "hearing ghosts" throughout the house have persisted and worsened.
5. She has also experienced depression for the past year, along with insomnia and an unintentional weight loss of 12 pounds over the last 6 months.
6. The patient does not take any medications or use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.
7. During the interview, she avoids eye contact and refuses to speak, allowing her husband to provide all the information.
8. He expresses concern that she may harm herself or others.
question_options:
What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A. Bipolar I disorder with psychotic features  
B. Major depressive disorder with psychotic features  
C. Substance/medication-induced psychotic disorder  
D. Delusional disorder  
E. Schizophreniform disorder  
F. Borderline personality disorder  
G. Psychotic disorder due to another medical condition  
H. Schizophrenia  
I. Schizoaffective disorder

step1_excerpts:
1. A 35-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of worsening fatigue and difficulty concentrating at work, despite adequate sleep.
2. She was diagnosed with Crohn disease 3 years ago and currently experiences approximately 7 nonbloody, mildly painful bowel movements daily.
3. Her only medication is topical budesonide.
4. She does not smoke or consume alcohol.
5. On examination, she appears pale.
6. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg.
7. Abdominal examination reveals diffuse tenderness without guarding.

Laboratory findings include:

| Hemoglobin | 10.5 g/dL |
| --- | --- |
| Mean corpuscular volume | 83 μm3 |
| Reticulocytes | 0.2 % |
| Platelets | 189,000/mm3 |
| Serum |  |
| Iron | 41 μg/dL |
| Total iron-binding capacity | 176 μg/dL |
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s management?

A. Initiation of adalimumab  
B. Initiation of methotrexate  
C. Initiation of vitamin B12 injections  
D. Oral prednisone therapy  
E. Subcutaneous erythropoietin injection  
F. Oral iron supplementation  
G. Addition of azathioprine  
H. Switch to systemic budesonide  
I. Intravenous iron supplementation  
J. Switch to oral mesalamine

step1_excerpts:
1. A physician is conducting a retrospective review of a trial involving the use of Drug X in patients with a specific disease.
2. It is known that Drug X is associated with an increased probability of cancer in patients who use the drug.
3. A total of 600 individuals with a specific disease were included in the trial.
4. Of the participants, 200 individuals received Drug X and 400 individuals did not receive it.
5. One hundred individuals who received Drug X died of a particular type of cancer and 100 individuals who did not receive the drug died of the same type of cancer.
question_options:
Based on these data, which of the following is the relative risk of death from this type of cancer in individuals who take Drug X as compared with individuals who do not take Drug X?

A. Individuals who take Drug X have an equal risk of dying from this type of cancer

B. Individuals who take Drug X have four times the risk of dying from this type of cancer

C. Individuals who take Drug X have three times the risk of dying from this type of cancer

D. Individuals who take Drug X have two times the risk of dying from this type of cancer

step1_excerpts:
1. A 40-year-old previously healthy man was seen with acute-onset bilateral decreased vision and metamorphopsia of 1-day duration.
2. The patient denied any recent illness, travel, viral prodromal symptoms, headache, or skin lesions.
3. He reported no exposure to pets or animals.
4. A complete review of systems was otherwise negative.
5. At presentation, his visual acuity was counting fingers OD at 1 ft and 20/100 OS, without an afferent papillary defect.
6. Slitlamp examination revealed fine inferior keratic precipitates bilaterally, with 3+ anterior chamber cells in the right eye and 2+ anterior chamber cells in the left eye.
7. Dilated ophthalmoscopic examination demonstrated numerous confluent creamy yellow lesions in the peripheral retina, with more discrete nummular lesions in the posterior pole in both eyes (Figure 1A).
8. No pigmented lesions were noted in the peripheral retina.
9. In addition, fine macular striae were present in both eyes, along with subtle optic nerve edema (Figure 1B).
10. Case presentation.
11. A, Montage photograph of right eye shows lesions extending from the posterior pole to the retinal periphery.
12. B, Enlarged fundus photograph shows nummular macular lesions with mild retina striae and optic disc edema.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform B-scan ultrasonography  
B: Perform electroretinography  
C: Perform fluorescein angiography  
D: Perform magnetic resonance angiography

step1_excerpts:
1. A 40-year-old man comes to the office for a preemployment physical examination.
2. The patient has been generally healthy.
3. Medical history is unremarkable and he takes no routine medications.
4. Vital signs are normal.
5. Physical examination shows a palpable nodule in the right lobe of the thyroid gland.
6. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration is within the reference range.
7. Ultrasonography of the thyroid gland confirms a solid, 1-cm nodule.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?

A. CT scan of the neck

B. Fine-needle aspiration of the nodule

C. Radionuclide thyroid scan

D. Thyroidectomy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 28-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider with a headache.
2. Every few weeks she has an episode of a right-sided, throbbing headache.
3. The episodes began several years ago and are accompanied by nausea and bright spots in her vision.
4. The headache usually subsides if she lies still in a dark, quiet room for several hours.
5. The patient denies any weakness, numbness, or tingling during these episodes.
6. Her medical history is significant for acne, hypothyroidism, obesity, and endometriosis.
7. Her home medications include levothyroxine, oral contraceptive pills, and topical trans-retinoin.
8. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 125/81 mmHg, pulse is 64/min, and respirations are 11/min.
9. She has 2 glasses of wine with dinner several nights a week and has never smoked.
10. She works as a receptionist at a marketing company.
11. On physical exam, the patient has no focal neurologic deficits.
12. A CT of the head is performed and shows no acute abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient during these episodes?

A. Topiramate  
B. Sumatriptan  
C. Acetazolamide  
D. High-flow oxygen

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 50s presented with a 3-month history of rapidly spreading intensively pruritic papules on her extremities.
2. The lesions consisted of scattered, erythematous, annular papules measuring up to 5 mm wide (Figure 1).
3. Further examination revealed a few asymptomatic brown flat papules scattered on her face; the palms, soles, and oral mucosa were not involved.
4. The patient had no remarkable medical or family history and was not concurrently being treated with any medications.
5. She had been previously diagnosed with eczema and treated with topical steroid ointments and oral compound glycyrrhizin tablets, which had no obvious effect.
6. Clinical images of keratotic papules diffusely distributed on an extremity, original (A) and magnified (B).
7. Laboratory investigations, including routine blood, liver and kidney function, antistreptolysin O, C-reactive protein, antinuclear antibody, and rheumatoid factor tests, disclosed no abnormal findings.
8. A biopsy specimen was obtained for histopathologic examination.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Annular lichen planus  
B: Perforating granuloma annulare  
C: Eruptive pruritic papular porokeratosis  
D: Atypical pityriasis rosea

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old white woman presented with 1 week of decreased visual acuity and ache on abduction in the right eye.
2. She had decreased right-sided hearing and tinnitus, a moderate right-sided frontal headache, and an unsteady gait.
3. She did not have diplopia, facial numbness, or paresthesias.
4. She had a history of stage IV breast cancer treated with letrozole after a mastectomy 5 years prior.
5. On an initial examination, her best-corrected visual acuity was 20/50 OD and 20/25 OS, with dyschromatopsia, relative afferent pupillary defect, and visual-field defects on the right side.
6. Her extraocular movements were full.
7. A dilated fundus examination demonstrated a pale right optic nerve.
8. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain was reported to have normal results, but on review, we noted thickening and enhancement of both optic nerves (with the right eye larger than the left eye), cranial nerve III in the right eye, cranial nerve V bilaterally, the pituitary infundibulum, and the hypothalamus, as well as adjacent cavernous sinuses.
9. Leptomeningeal thickening over the convexities of the anterior frontal lobes was also evident.
10. The patient’s cerebrospinal fluid contained a small population of polyclonal CD19+ B cells and CD4+ and CD8+ T cells.
11. An extensive laboratory workup, including tests for HIV, antinuclear antibodies, anti–double-stranded DNA, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, serum protein electrophoresis, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, complete blood cell count, antiganglioside antibodies, anti–myelin-associated glycoprotein antibodies, and angiotensin-converting enzyme, gave normal results.
12. A computed tomographic (CT) scan of the thorax and a whole-body positron emission tomography (PET)/CT scan revealed no abnormalities.
13. Clinically, she initially responded to corticosteroids.
14. Over the ensuing 5 years, she had multiple similar presentations that also included facial pain and paresthesias.
15. She also developed a chronic small-fiber peripheral neuropathy and was treated with mycophenolate mofetil, cyclophosphamide, and intravenous immunoglobulin at various points.
16. She remained clinically stable for 4 years and returned with similar symptoms.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Administer high-dose corticosteroids  
B: Repeat the magnetic resonance imaging of the brain  
C: Repeat the whole-body positron emission tomography scan  
D: Repeat the testing for angiotensin-converting enzyme in serum and cerebrospinal fluid

step1_excerpts:
1. A 4-year-old girl with newly diagnosed acute lymphocytic leukemia, receiving her initial course of chemotherapy with vincristine, daunorubicin, and methotrexate, developed a painful lesion on her left triceps.
2. The tender area was beneath an adhesive bandage placed where she had received DTaP (diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis) and polio vaccinations 3 weeks earlier.
3. Otherwise, she appeared remarkably well, and her vital signs were normal.
4. Removing the bandage revealed a tender indurated gray-violet plaque (Figure, A).
5. White blood cell and neutrophil counts were low at 0.4 K/μL (normal range, 4.86-13.18 K/μL) and 0.18 K/μL (normal range, 1.60-8.29 K/μL), respectively.
6. Blood culture findings were negative.
7. Punch biopsy specimens were obtained for histopathologic analysis (Figure, B) and fungal culture (Figure, C).
8. A, Gray-violet plaque on posterior upper arm at site of adhesive portion of bandage.
9. B, Broad nonseptate hyphae surrounding and infiltrating dermal blood vessels (hematoxylin-eosin; original magnification ×400).
10. Of note, occasional septae are seen in this specimen, consistent with the characteristic finding that mucormycetes are pauciseptate, rather than aseptate, molds.
11. C, Nonseptate hyphae with round terminal sporangia and free spores (lactophenol cotton blue mount; original magnification ×400).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Mucormycosis  
B: Cutaneous diphtheria  
C: Pseudomonal ecthyma gangrenosum  
D: Aspergillosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 29-year-old woman is prescribed carbamazepine for trigeminal neuralgia.
2. She has a strong family history of osteoporosis.
3. As a result, the physician also advises her to increase her intake of vitamin D.
question_options:
The most likely reason for this recommendation is that carbamazepine may affect which of the following pharmacokinetic processes?

A. Absorption

B. Distribution

C. Excretion

D. Metabolism

step1_excerpts:
1. A 25-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for trouble with focus and concentration.
2. He states that he lives at home with his parents his entire life and recently was able to get a job at a local factory.
3. Ever since the patient started working, he has had trouble focusing on his job.
4. He is unable to stay focused on any task.
5. His boss often observes him "daydreaming" with a blank stare off into space.
6. His boss will have to yell at him to startle him back to work.
7. The patient states that he feels fatigued all the time and sometimes will suddenly fall asleep while operating equipment.
8. He has tried going to bed early for the past month but is unable to fall asleep until 2 hours prior to his alarm.
9. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 112/68 mmHg, pulse is 81/min, and respirations are 12/min.
10. A physical exam is within normal limits.
11. The patient fears that if this continues he will lose his job.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

A. Ethosuximide  
B. Zolpidem  
C. Bright light therapy and decreased light at night  
D. Modafinil

step1_excerpts:
1. A 27-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for bilateral, painful loss of vision.
2. Her symptoms started last night and have persisted until this morning.
3. She has experienced an episode of urinary incontinence as well.
4. The patient has a medical history of anxiety as well as peripheral neuropathy which is currently treated with duloxetine.
5. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
6. On physical exam, the patient demonstrates 4/5 strength in her upper and lower extremities with decreased sensation in her fingers bilaterally.
7. An MRI is obtained and is within normal limits.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management and corresponding finding?

A. Temporal artery biopsy demonstrating giant cell arteritis  
B. Acetylcholine receptor antibody testing revealing myasthenia gravis  
C. High resolution CT demonstrating hyperdense lesions  
D. Anti-MOG antibody testing showing positive results  
E. Nerve conduction study showing demyelinating neuropathy  
F. Serum B12 level showing severe deficiency  
G. CT angiogram revealing vertebral artery dissection  
H. Visual evoked potentials revealing delayed P100 latency  
I. Psychiatric evaluation revealing multiple acute life stressors  
J. Lumbar puncture demonstrating oligoclonal bands

step1_excerpts:
1. A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department with right ear pain that he developed 4 days prior, and it has progressively worsened.
2. The pain is worse at night.
3. He has associated fever and chills.
4. This morning, he awoke with purulent, foul-smelling discharge on his pillow.
5. He has a history of type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension.
6. He takes metformin, insulin, and lisinopril.
7. His temperature is 102.2°F (39.0°C), blood pressure is 130/87 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 16/min.
8. The patient is toxic in appearance and in mild distress due to pain.
9. Examination of the external ear reveals findings shown in Figure A.
10. Granulation tissue and purulent drainage are noted in the external auditory canal.
11. Physical exam is otherwise unremarkable.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient?

A. Ceftriaxone  
B. Ofloxacin ear drops  
C. Amoxicillin  
D. Vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam

step1_excerpts:
1. A 70-year-old woman comes to the office because of worsening tremor of her hands.
2. The tremor has been present for most of her life and initially was mild and would occur only when she was tired or stressed.
3. During the past month the shaking has become more noticeable and frequent.
4. She is now embarrassed to eat with other people because of how obvious the tremor has become.
5. The patient has been taking fluoxetine for the past 3 weeks to help her to cope with the death of her husband 2 months ago.
6. Medical history is also remarkable for essential hypertension controlled with lisinopril and hyperlipidemia controlled with atorvastatin.
7. Her only other medication is occasional ibuprofen for joint pain.
8. She used to drink one to two alcoholic beverages monthly but now drinks one glass of wine daily because, she says, it reduces her tremor.
9. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (155 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2 .
10. Vital signs are temperature 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 130/85 mm Hg.
11. Physical examination shows a moderate tremor of both hands that is not present at rest.
12. Complete blood count, serum chemistry profile, and serum thyroid function tests are ordered and results are pending.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's worsening tremor?

A. Adverse effect of fluoxetine therapy

B. Bereavement reaction

C. Early Parkinson disease

D. Increase in alcohol consumption

step1_excerpts:
1. A 61-year-old man with a history of hypertension, psychosis, and recurrent venous thromboembolism was admitted to the emergency department with fatigue, weakness, and arthralgias after an unexplained fall.
2. At presentation, he was experiencing psychosis and being treated in an inpatient psychiatric ward.
3. He was nonadherent with medications and denied drug and alcohol abuse.
4. On examination, he appeared comfortable.
5. His blood pressure was 150/67 mm Hg; heart rate, 77/min; temperature, 36.7°C (98.1°F); respiratory rate, 16/min; and oxygen saturation, 99% on room air.
6. On both lower extremities, there was peripheral edema with widespread hematomas, scattered ecchymosis, petechiae, and diffuse perifollicular purpura (Figure).
7. The remainder of the examination was unremarkable.
8. Laboratory test results showed a normocytic anemia (hemoglobin level, 5.2 g/dL [reference, 13.5-17.5 g/dL]; mean corpuscular volume, 85 fL [reference, 80-100 fL]); normal platelet count (thrombocytes, 285 ×109/L [reference, 150-400 ×109/L]); and a mild leukopenia (leukocytes, 3.9 ×109 [reference, 4.3-10 ×109/L]).
9. Folic acid level was low (3 nmol/L [reference, ≥5 nmol/L]) and vitamin B12 level was normal (478 pg/mL [reference, 193-982 pg/mL]).
10. Results for iron panel, reticulocyte count, prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), international normalized ratio, liver function tests, and levels of indirect bilirubin, haptoglobin, fibrinogen, and creatine kinase were all within reference range.
11. Chest radiographs and computed tomography of the head were negative for any acute pathology.
12. A 12-lead electrocardiogram revealed no abnormalities.
13. Ultrasound of both lower legs showed no thromboembolism.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Order a bone marrow biopsy  
B: Administer prothrombin complex concentrate  
C: Initiate vitamin C supplementation  
D: Order additional coagulation tests (thrombin time, platelet function assay)

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his late 30s with a history of proliferative diabetic retinopathy presented for evaluation of sudden-onset painless blurry vision of the right eye.
2. His ocular history included nonclearing vitreous hemorrhage in the right eye requiring pars plana vitrectomy, panretinal photocoagulation, multiple treatments with intravitreous bevacizumab, and cataract extraction with placement of an intraocular lens (IOL) into the capsular bag approximately 4 years ago.
3. At his routine follow-up visit 2 weeks prior, the proliferative diabetic retinopathy was quiescent, and his Snellen visual acuity was 20/20 OD with manifest refraction of −1.50 + 0.25 × 180.
4. Examination of the anterior segment at that time was unremarkable.
5. At his current visit, visual acuity with the previous correction had been reduced to 20/150.
6. Repeated manifest refraction of the right eye was −4.00 + 1.50 × 166, resulting in a visual acuity of 20/25.
7. Intraocular pressure of the right eye was 10 mm Hg by Goldmann applanation tonometry.
8. Evaluation of the posterior segment, including dilated fundus examination and optical coherence tomography (OCT) of the macula, showed stability compared with previous results.
9. Imaging of the anterior segment with OCT is shown in Figure 1.
10. The anterior chamber did not appear shallow, and there was no cell or flare.
11. Slitlamp photograph of the anterior segment (A) and optical coherence tomographic imaging of the lens–capsular bag complex (B) obtained at initial presentation (arrowheads show hyperdistention of the capsular bag with turbid fluid).
12. Perform posterior capsulotomy as part of pars plana vitrectomy
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform posterior capsulotomy as part of pars plana vitrectomy  
B: Perform posterior capsulotomy with Nd:YAG laser  
C: Exchange the IOL  
D: Observe the patient

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 60s was evaluated in the epilepsy monitoring unit for various spells he had been having up to 5 times a day over the previous 8 months.
2. He described transient episodes of expressive speech difficulties, paroxysmal dizziness, and involuntary nonsuppressible jerks of the right arm, which occurred without warning and were associated with mild disorientation.
3. Video electroencephalography (EEG) captured the movements (Figure, A).
4. They consisted of involuntary, synchronous contractions of the right face, arm, and leg that were sustained for a few seconds before muscle relaxation occurred (Figure, B and C; Video).
5. The movements were not elicited by action or exertion.
6. There was no epileptic abnormality that correlated with the movements on EEG, and head magnetic resonance imaging was unremarkable.A, Electroencephalogram (EEG) during the event (bipolar montage, 60-Hz filter, 7-uV/mm sensitivity).
7. B, Patient position prior to the event.
8. C, Patient position while experiencing an involuntary, sustained contraction of the right lower face, arm, and leg lasting almost 2 seconds before spontaneous resolution.
9. The event took place during the time span marked with red vertical lines on the EEG and did not show a clear change from baseline rhythm.
10. Muscle artifacts are seen prior to and during the event.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Myoclonus  
B: Paroxysmal dyskinesia  
C: Faciobrachial dystonic seizures  
D: Tic disorder

step1_excerpts:
1. A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever and painful swelling of the left ankle.
2. He has had recurrent cervical lymphadenitis and pneumonia since infancy.
3. Two years ago, a culture from an abscess in the cervical region grew Staphylococcus aureus.
4. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F).
5. Examination shows a tender, erythematous, edematous left ankle; there is point tenderness over the medial malleolus.
6. A bone scan shows increased uptake in the left lower tibial metaphysis.
7. Culture of bone aspirate grows Serratia marcescens.
8. Nitroblue tetrazolium test shows no color change.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely mechanism for these findings?

A. Developmental arrest of maturation of B lymphocytes

B. Dysmorphogenesis of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches

C. Impaired chemotaxis

D. Impaired phagocytic oxidative metabolism

step1_excerpts:
1. A 3-year-old girl is brought to the office for a routine well-child appointment.
2. She was delivered preterm at 35 weeks, and her medical history is significant for several ear infections over the last year.
3. Her older brother has been diagnosed with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), but the rest of her family history is otherwise unremarkable.
4. The patient has become more withdrawn lately and has sometimes been ignoring her parents when asked to perform tasks at home.
5. This seems to have worsened over the last 8 weeks.
6. Otherwise, the patient is energetic and started preschool 3 months ago.
7. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 98/62 mmHg, pulse is 97/min, and respirations are 26/min.
8. The patient successfully draws a square and can stand on 1 foot.
9. Her language skills are unchanged from her appointment 6 months ago.
10. Her neurological examination is normal, and she is at the 50th percentile for height and weight.
11. She seems distracted during the interview and responds only intermittently to the physician’s directions.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Refer to genetic testing  
B. Speech and language assessment  
C. Audiometry testing  
D. Parent and teacher ADHD rating scales

step1_excerpts:
1. An 84-year-old man presents to the physician with numbness and tingling in the right hand for the last 6 months.
2. He reports these symptoms started intermittently in the middle finger after returning from a golfing trip but has progressed to being nearly constant.
3. The thenar eminence, thumb, and other digits are spared.
4. He reports no other symptoms.
5. His medical problems include hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, and chronic neck pain for which he takes amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, atorvastatin, levothyroxine, and duloxetine.
6. Surgical history consists of posterior lumbar fusion and elective left total hip arthroplasty.
7. He has a 90-pack-year smoking history and quit 10 years ago.
8. The patient’s temperature is 99.6°F (37.6°C), blood pressure is 134/80 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 16/min.
9. Physical exam reveals 4/5 strength in elbow extension and wrist flexion on the right.
10. He has 5/5 strength in the remainder of the motor exam on the right upper extremity and on the left upper extremity.
11. The triceps reflex is 1+ on the right compared to 2+ on the left.
12. There is no spasticity.
13. His neck pain, which radiates down his right arm, is reproduced with axial loading during neck extension with simultaneous rightward rotation and lateral bending.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis  
B. Carpal tunnel syndrome  
C. Cervical spondylosis  
D. Syringomyelia

step1_excerpts:
1. A 22-year-old woman (G2P2) experiences ongoing vaginal bleeding immediately following vaginal delivery.
2. Her labor was induced over 30 hours using continuous oxytocin infusion.
3. The pregnancy had been uncomplicated, and her only medication is albuterol for asthma.
4. Following delivery of an intact placenta, cumulative blood loss surpasses 1050 mL.
5. Despite aggressive management including uterine massage, intramuscular oxytocin, and continued oxytocin infusion, the uterus remains boggy.
6. Examination reveals no cervical lacerations or clots in the lower uterine segment.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next intervention for this patient?

A. Perform manual exploration of uterus  
B. Administer methylergonovine intramuscularly  
C. Initiate crystalloid fluid resuscitation  
D. Initiate tranexamic acid infusion  
E. Provide an additional dose of oxytocin intravenously  
F. Begin misoprostol administration  
G. Administer carboprost intramuscularly  
H. Perform immediate hysterectomy  
I. Insert Bakri balloon  
J. Begin fresh frozen plasma transfusion

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year old woman presented with a 6-week history of an enlarging, tender, pruritic, 4-cm erythematous patch with central inflammatory papules distributed on the medial forehead (Figure, A).
2. No inciting events, such as arthropod bite or trauma, were noted.
3. She was initially treated for presumed shingles with valacyclovir, cephalexin, gabapentin, and hydrocortisone 2.5% topical ointment with no improvement in appearance or symptoms.
4. No other cutaneous abnormalities were noted.
5. A punch biopsy specimen of the left medial forehead was obtained, and histological and immunohistochemical analyses were performed (Figure, B and C).
6. A, Erythematous patch with central inflammatory papules on the forehead.
7. B, Histopathological results revealed dissecting vascular channels (black arrowheads) and spindle cells (white arrowheads) (hematoxylin-eosin).
8. C, Immunohistochemical staining revealed CD31 and diffuse expression of FLI-1 and ERG in the vascular and spindle cell components.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Cutaneous B-cell lymphoma  
B: Angiosarcoma  
C: Metastatic carcinoma  
D: Merkel cell carcinoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 19-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity.  
2. A lumbar puncture reveals elevated opening pressure, significantly increased white blood cell count, reduced glucose levels, and elevated protein levels.  
3. She is admitted, stabilized, and started on antibiotics.  
4. Two days later, she reports constipation and signs of urinary retention, though she is now afebrile and has a cranial rhythmic impulse (CRI) of 6.
question_options:
Which component of the primary respiratory mechanism is most likely responsible for these new symptoms?

A. Lumbar spine dysfunction  
B. Coccygeal segment dysfunction  
C. Cranial base compression  
D. Thoracic diaphragm restriction  
E. Sphenobasilar synchondrosis restriction  
F. Pelvic diaphragm dysfunction  
G. Peripheral nerves  
H. Sacrum  
I. Reciprocal tension membrane  
J. Autonomic imbalance due to vagus nerve involvement

step1_excerpts:
1. A 41-year-old woman with an 8–pack-year history of tobacco use presented for progressive cough and dyspnea of 4 years’ duration.
2. Her cough was productive of yellow-green sputum and treated with antibiotics on multiple occasions, which provided some alleviation of her symptoms.
3. She had no history of neonatal respiratory distress, nasal congestion, persistent urticaria, joint laxity, or illicit drug use.
4. She denied a family history of liver cirrhosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), or cystic fibrosis.
5. Examination revealed scattered wheezes and rhonchi on auscultation.
6. Pulmonary function testing demonstrated a severe obstruction with a forced expiratory volume at 1 second (FEV1) of 0.79 L (28% of predicted), forced vital capacity (FVC) of 1.64 L (47% of predicted), FEV1:FVC ratio of 48%, and a reduced diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide of 8.74 mL/min per mm Hg (23.75% of predicted), which was consistent with emphysema.
7. Chest radiography followed by computed tomography (CT) of the chest showed lower lobe predominant emphysema and bronchiectasis (Figure).Computed tomography of the chest.
8. Left, Transverse view.
9. Right, Coronal view.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Order bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage and transbronchial biopsy  
B: Assess serum α1-antitrypsin level and genotype  
C: Order inhaled nasal nitric oxide and ciliary dyskinesia genetic testing  
D: Assess sweat chloride and cystic fibrosis genetic screening

step1_excerpts:
1. An 8-year-old boy presented to the pediatric emergency department with 2 weeks of fatigue and 3 days of double vision, ptosis, and painless periorbital swelling of the left eye.  
2. Medical history was unremarkable with no recent weight loss, travel, or trauma.  
3. Visual acuity without correction was 20/20 OU.  
4. The right pupil was 3.5 mm and briskly reactive, while the left pupil was 8.5 mm and unreactive to light or near effort; there was no relative afferent pupillary defect.  
5. Results of testing with the use of an Amsler grid and Ishihara color plates were within normal limits.  
6. Visual fields were full to confrontation.  
7. The optic nerves and retina were normal in both eyes.  
8. External examination was notable for left periorbital swelling, proptosis, and moderate ptosis of the upper eyelid (Figure 1A).  
9. Extraocular motility examination results were normal in the right eye but demonstrated severe ophthalmoparesis of the left eye: 0% supraduction (Figure 1B), 20% of normal abduction/adduction, and 10% of normal infraduction (not pictured).  
10. Corneal reflex was normal in the right eye but diminished in the left eye, and facial strength was normal bilaterally.  
11. The remainder of the neurologic examination results were normal.An 8-year-old boy presented with 2 weeks of painless proptosis of the left eye (A) accompanied by upper eyelid ptosis and ophthalmoplegia of the left eye (B).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?  
A: Thyroid eye disease  
B: Cavernous sinus syndrome  
C: Orbital apex syndrome  
D: Orbital cellulitis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 34-year-old white woman comes to the emergency department because of a persistent dull headache for the past 3 days.
2. She has been taking acetaminophen without relief.
3. She says, "I haven't slept in 3 days and I am having trouble focusing at work." There is no history of trauma and she takes no medications.
4. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 14 years but does not drink alcoholic beverages.
5. Vital signs are temperature 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse 86/min, respirations 19/min, and blood pressure 182/100 mm Hg.
6. Examination of the head shows no abnormalities.
7. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light; there is mild photophobia.
8. Funduscopic examination is normal.
9. A serous effusion is noted on examination of the left tympanic membrane.
10. Neck is stiff with painful flexion; when the patient's neck is flexed forward, she reports and electric shock sensation.
11. Mild expiratory wheezes are heard on auscultation of the chest.
12. A midsystolic click is heard best at the left sternal border; there are no murmurs or gallops.
13. Abdominal examination shows striae, but is otherwise noncontributory.
14. Examination of the lower extremities shows varicosities bilaterally and 1+ edema; muscle strength is 4/5.
15. Neurologic examination shows no other abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following physical findings is most indicative of the need for immediate further evaluation?

A. Abdominal striae

B. Expiratory wheezes

C. Midsystolic click

D. Neck stiffness

step1_excerpts:
1. A 48-year-old man with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and obstructive sleep apnea presented with a rash over his right foot accompanied by 1 week of episodic fever, diaphoresis, and headaches.  
2. Six weeks prior, he fell from a ladder and had right nondisplaced medial malleolar and comminuted talar fractures.  
3. The fractures were managed nonsurgically in a controlled ankle movement boot, with resolution of swelling and bruising.  
4. On current presentation, his temperature was 38.2 °C (100.8 °F); heart rate, 88/min; respiratory rate, 18/min; and blood pressure, 102/65 mm Hg.  
5. He was well appearing with normal cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations.  
6. There was trace right lower extremity edema localized to the ankle and normal pedal pulses.  
7. Erythema without warmth was present over the right ankle and dorsomedial foot, along with nontender, nonpalpable purpura over the dorsum of the foot and scattered petechiae over the right lower leg (Figure).  
8. When the leg was elevated above the level of the heart, the surrounding erythema faded.Right lower extremity rash 2 days before admission (left) and at presentation (right).Results of laboratory testing were as follows: white blood cell count, 6000/μL; hemoglobin level, 13.7 mg/dL; platelet count, 118 000/μL; creatinine level, 1.3 mg/dL (114.95 μmol/L); prothrombin time, 15.2 seconds (reference range, 12.2-14.9 seconds); activated partial thromboplastin time, 41 seconds (reference range, 23.1-34.2 seconds); C-reactive protein level, 7 mg/dL (reference range, 0-1 mg/dL); and normal urinalysis results.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Order skin biopsy  
B: Order antinuclear antibody, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, and complement levels  
C: Order lower extremity duplex ultrasound  
D: Order antibiotic therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 68-year-old man presented with progressive right-sided facial numbness and weakness, vision changes, and headaches.
2. His symptoms began 5 years earlier with right temple numbness, which expanded to include the entire right face and mouth.
3. He then developed progressive right facial weakness with a droop, slurred speech, and eyelid ptosis.
4. Finally, binocular vertical and horizontal diplopia and periorbital headaches began.
5. Trials of gabapentin and steroids provided no relief.
6. His history was significant for a left cheek melanoma completely excised years prior, numerous cutaneous squamous and basal cell carcinomas of the bilateral head and neck removed without issue, type 2 diabetes, and hyperlipidemia.
7. His medications included metformin and simvastatin; he had no history of smoking or drinking.
8. On examination, he had right-sided ptosis and severe right facial weakness in a lower motor neuron pattern with temporal wasting.
9. The right pupil was fixed and dilated.
10. There was no afferent pupillary defect.
11. The left pupil was appropriately sized and reactive.
12. His right-sided vision was impaired (20/250) with blurriness.
13. Vertical and horizontal binocular diplopia was present.
14. Right extraocular movements were significantly limited in all directions and painful, and right-sided facial sensation was diminished to pinprick in all cranial nerve (CN) V distributions.
15. His speech was slightly slurred.
16. Left-sided extraocular movements were intact.
17. His left facial sensation was intact to pinprick, and his strength was without deficit.
18. There were no other neurological abnormalities.
19. Initial magnetic resonance images (MRIs) were unremarkable.
20. A biopsy of CN VII was nondiagnostic.
21. Hemoglobin A1c was 6.8%.
22. Tests for infection and autoimmune disease had negative results.
23. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) studies showed mildly elevated protein values.
24. Figure 1 shows the MRI at presentation.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Primary leptomeningeal lymphoma  
B: Tolosa-Hunt syndrome  
C: Perineural spread of cutaneous malignancy  
D: Sphenoid wing meningioma

step1_excerpts:
1. A female patient with a history of premature birth (24 weeks’ gestational age, 538 g) and zone I, stage 3 retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) with plus disease treated with a single injection of 0.625 mg of intravitreal bevacizumab in each eye presented for routine examination at 2 years of age.  
2. Examination with the patient under anesthesia with fluorescein angiography (Figure 1) revealed significant peripheral retinal avascularity, circumferential vascular loops at the border of vascular and avascular retina, and arteriovenous anastomoses in both eyes.  
3. There was no evidence of retinal neovascularization or recurrence of ROP.  
4. Fluorescein angiography 2 years after intravitreal bevacizumab treatment for retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) shows sparse retinal vasculature with peripheral retinal avascularity (white arrowheads) and arteriovenous anastomoses (yellow arrowhead) without evidence of neovascularization or recurrent ROP.  
5. Observe or perform laser photocoagulation to areas of peripheral retinal nonperfusion Administer intravitreal anti–vascular endothelial growth factor therapy again Administer combined intravitreal anti–vascular endothelial growth factor therapy and laser photocoagulation to areas of nonperfusion
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Observe or perform laser photocoagulation to areas of peripheral retinal nonperfusion  
B: Administer intravitreal anti–vascular endothelial growth factor therapy again  
C: Administer combined intravitreal anti–vascular endothelial growth factor therapy and laser photocoagulation to areas of nonperfusion  
D: Perform pars plana vitrectomy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 27-year-old man presents with dull, right-sided chest pain that began after being struck by a softball during a pick-up game one week ago.  
2. The pain worsens with deep breathing.  
3. He has no significant medical history and is not on any medications.  
4. Vital signs are as follows:

| Temperature | 37.4°C (99.4°F) |
| --- | --- |
| Blood pressure | 110/76 mm Hg |
| Heart rate | 62/min |
| Respiratory rate | 12/min |

The patient appears moderately uncomfortable.  
5. Cardiac auscultation is normal, and lung examination reveals clear breath sounds bilaterally.  
6. Tenderness is localized to the right sternocostal region of the upper anterior thoracic cage.  
7. Osteopathic assessment of the ribs shows that the upper ribs on the right side move symmetrically with the left ribs during inhalation but fail to descend properly during exhalation.
question_options:
Which diagnosis best characterizes the primary somatic dysfunction in this patient?

A. Intercostal neuralgia of the right 5th intercostal space  
B. Bucket handle dysfunction of the right ribs  
C. Pump handle dysfunction of the sternum  
D. Exhalation dysfunction of the right 1st rib  
E. Inhalation dysfunction of the right 1st rib  
F. Somatic dysfunction of T5 vertebra  
G. Thoracic outlet syndrome of the right side  
H. Inhalation dysfunction of the right 5th rib  
I. Costochondritis of the right 5th rib  
J. Exhalation dysfunction of the right 5th rib

step1_excerpts:
1. A 24-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine Pap smear.
2. She previously had a normal Pap test at age 21 and reports having had seven lifetime male partners.
3. For the past six months, she has been in a monogamous relationship with one male partner.
4. She denies any irregular vaginal bleeding and uses oral contraceptive pills for contraception.
5. The Pap test results reveal atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance, and reflex human papillomavirus (HPV) testing is positive.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

A. Perform cervical biopsy immediately  
B. Repeat cervical cytology alone in 12 months  
C. Recommend HPV vaccination and repeat cytology in 3 months  
D. Recommend abstinence and repeat testing in 6 months  
E. Refer for colposcopy  
F. Repeat cervical cytology and human papillomavirus testing in 12 months  
G. Schedule follow-up in 6 months with repeat HPV testing  
H. Perform endocervical curettage  
I. Schedule immediate LEEP procedure  
J. Start antiviral therapy and repeat cytology in 3 months

step1_excerpts:
1. A 19-year-old Asian female college student comes to the university health center because of a 1-week history of nasal stuffiness, occasional clear rhinorrhea, and a mild sore throat.
2. Two days ago, she began to feel hot, but she has not taken her temperature.
3. Medical history is unremarkable and her only medication is an oral contraceptive.
4. She has no history of allergies.
5. She does not smoke cigarettes.
6. BMI is 22 kg/m2 .
7. Vital signs are temperature 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse 88/min, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 116/74 mm Hg.
8. Physical examination discloses tenderness over the left maxillary sinus without purulent drainage.
9. There is clear fluid behind the left tympanic membrane, enlarged tonsils bilaterally, and pain with tapping of the left upper incisors.
10. Left frontal sinus does not transilluminate.
11. Cardiopulmonary examination discloses no abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's sinusitis?

A. Eustachian tube dysfunction

B. Mucosal edema

C. Nasal polyps

D. Oral contraceptive use

step1_excerpts:
1. A 42-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination.
2. Four months ago, he underwent repair of a Dupuytren contracture.
3. Physical examination shows decreased range of motion in the affected hand.
4. The patient is upset that his hand has not fully healed, and he files a malpractice suit against the physician.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely precipitating factor in this patient's decision to file a malpractice suit?

A. The patient's perception that the physician is incompetent

B. The patient's perception that the physician is uncaring

C. The patient's socioeconomic status

D. The physician's amount of experience in the medical field

step1_excerpts:
1. A 67-year-old male patient is evaluated on the surgical floor following a renal transplant performed the previous day using a matched donor.
2. His recovery is progressing well.
3. His medical history includes intravenous drug use, diabetes mellitus, oral cold sores, hypertension, renal failure, and dyslipidemia.
4. Before the transplant, he was on dialysis and taking lisinopril, atorvastatin, insulin, and aspirin.
5. Cyclosporine has been initiated postoperatively.
6. Over the next few days, the patient remains stable with a temperature of 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure of 121/76 mmHg, pulse of 70/min, and respirations of 13/min.
question_options:
Which of the following medications should be initiated for this patient?

A. Ganciclovir  
B. Azithromycin  
C. Penicillin  
D. Voriconazole  
E. Atovaquone  
F. Caspofungin  
G. Dapsone  
H. TMP-SMX  
I. Fluconazole  
J. Valacyclovir

step1_excerpts:
1. A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found minimally responsive at a homeless shelter.
2. He has a history of intravenous drug use and malingering but is unable to provide a history due to obtundation.
3. His temperature is 96.6°F (35.9°C), blood pressure is 84/44 mmHg, pulse is 150/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
4. After receiving 3 liters of fluids, his vitals remain unchanged.
5. Physical examination reveals multiple abscesses in the antecubital fossae and a cardiac murmur.
6. The patient’s Glasgow Coma Scale score is 6, prompting intubation following the administration of an induction agent and a paralytic.
7. Over the next 15 minutes, his blood pressure drops further but improves rapidly after stress dose steroids are administered.
question_options:
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s post-intubation hypotension?

A. Fentanyl  
B. Cisatracurium  
C. Propofol  
D. Atracurium  
E. Etomidate  
F. Ketamine  
G. Rocuronium  
H. Vecuronium  
I. Midazolam  
J. Succinylcholine

step1_excerpts:
1. A 12-year-old girl with a history of myopia presented to the emergency department complaining of floaters in her right eye for the past 2 weeks.
2. She had a medical history of patchy hair loss and a violaceous maculopapular rash on the face and upper extremities for 5 years, which was well controlled with topical corticosteroids.
3. She reported new, sharp headaches in a headband distribution, exacerbated by lights, sounds, and neck flexion.
4. One week prior to presentation, she experienced a subjective fever and recurrence of the facial rash.
5. She denied experiencing eye pain, blurry vision, or light sensitivity.
6. Results of a comprehensive review of systems were otherwise negative.
7. Family history was notable for antiphospholipid syndrome in her mother.
8. Best-corrected visual acuity was 20/25 OU.
9. Results of an anterior segment examination, pupil examination, and tonometry were unremarkable.
10. During dilated ophthalmoscopy, both eyes revealed diffuse intraretinal hemorrhages in the posterior pole and temporal retinal neovascularization, worse in the right eye with associated macular traction and striae.
11. Both eyes demonstrated extensive peripheral vascular sheathing and retinal capillary nonperfusion (Figure 1).
12. Fundus photograph composite images of the right eye (A) and left eye (B) demonstrating intraretinal hemorrhages (white arrowheads), superficial retinal hemorrhage (asterisk), and neovascularization (yellow arrowheads) with associated traction and macular striae (black arrowhead) as well as vascular nonperfusion (blue arrowheads) and sheathing (magenta arrowheads).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Observe the patient  
B: Perform magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) of the brain  
C: Perform a vitreous tap for viral polymerase chain reaction  
D: Administer an intravitreal injection of foscarnet

step1_excerpts:
1. A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of easy bruising for 4 months.
2. She has a history of lung cancer treated with radiation therapy 6 months ago.
3. She has a 2-year history of hypertension treated with a thiazide diuretic and an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.
