4. Examination, including neurologic examination, shows no abnormalities except for multiple ecchymoses.
5. Her hemoglobin concentration is 13 g/dL, leukocyte count is 5000/mm3 , and platelet count is 35,000/mm3 .
6. A serum antiplatelet antibody assay is negative.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

A. CT scan of the abdomen

B. CT scan of the chest

C. Bronchoscopy

D. Bone marrow aspiration

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 60s presented with a 2-month history of painful, occasionally pruritic, fixed erythema on the abdomen.
2. In addition, the patient suffered from a splenic marginal zone lymphoma with bone marrow infiltration, had a history of splenectomy, and an IgM-κ paraproteinemia.
3. His hematologic condition was considered stable by his physician, who had also been treating the patient for hepatitis C with ledipasvir-sofosbuvir for 3 months.
4. On examination, there was a warm erythema on most of the abdomen, which appeared distended owing to hepatitis-induced ascites (Figure, A).
5. Laboratory results showed an elevated but stable white blood cell count of 19.04 × 103µL (reference range, 3.6-10.5 × 103µL), a recent rise of C-reactive protein levels to 179 mg/L (reference range, 0-5 mg/L), as well as a rise of IgM levels from 1060 mg/dL to 2220 mg/dL (reference range, 34-248 mg/dL) within the past year.
6. A biopsy procedure was performed on the abdomen (Figure, B-D).A, Light red erythema on most of the abdomen.
7. B, Interstitial infiltrate of deeply eosinophilic cells in the entire dermis and adjacent subcutis.
8. Hematoxylin-eosin staining (original magnification ×2).
9. C, Hematoxylin-eosin staining (original magnification ×40).
10. D, Original magnification ×10.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Wells syndrome  
B: Cutaneous amyloidosis  
C: Crystal-storing histiocytosis  
D: Erysipelas

step1_excerpts:
1. A 19-year-old man presents to his primary care physician.
2. He is asymptomatic and has no acute complaints, has no medical problems, and takes no medications.
3. He was born in the United States but moved to El Salvador at age 11 and has only recently moved back to the United States in the past year.
4. He was up to date on his vaccinations prior to his move to El Salvador.
5. He last received a diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine 14 years ago at age 5, the second dose of a meningococcal vaccine 3 years ago, and an influenza vaccine 2 months ago.
6. The patient’s temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 120/76 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, and respirations are 16/min.
7. There are no rashes noted on physical exam.
question_options:
Which of the following vaccine regimens is indicated in this patient?

A. Tetanus, diphtheria, acellular pertussis, and influenza  
B. Tetanus and diphtheria  
C. Influenza  
D. Tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 60s was diagnosed with high-grade leiomyosarcoma of the uterus in 2017 for which she underwent total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.
2. In 2020, she relapsed in the liver and spine.
3. In November 2020, she underwent posterior lateral stabilization of C7-T4 for a T2 vertebral body metastasis causing cord compression, followed by postoperative stereotactic body radiation therapy to T2 to T3 (35 Gy/5 fractions) in January 2021.
4. In February 2021, she received palliative radiation therapy (20 Gy/5 fractions) to T9 to T12 for a T11 vertebral body metastasis with epidural extension.
5. From January to August 2021, she was treated with gemcitabine, and in September 2021, she received her first dose of liposomal doxorubicin.
6. Two weeks later, she developed progressive bilateral lower extremity numbness, pain, weakness, and imbalance, prompting emergent evaluation.
7. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) findings demonstrated extensive spinal cord edema extending from T2 to the conus and a posterior ring-enhancing intramedullary lesion at T9 to T10 without any mass effect (Figure 1).
8. Because the intramedullary lesion appeared atypical for malignant disease given the lack of mass effect, she was prescribed high-dose steroids while further workup was pursued.
9. Lumbar puncture showed no malignant cells.
10. Positron emission tomographic-computed tomographic (PET/CT) scan demonstrated multifocal intensely F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG)-avid disease, but only mild uptake from T9 to T12 and no definitive FDG-avidity at the intramedullary lesion.
11. Her symptoms remained stable with steroid treatment and a plan was made to repeat an MRI of the spine in 6 to 8 weeks.A, T1-weighted postgadolinium sagittal image demonstrating an enhancing spinal intramedullary lesion (blue arrowhead).
12. Of note, there was enhancement of the previously irradiated T11 vertebral body metastasis, and adjacent vertebrae demonstrated marrow hyperintensity on T1-weighed noncontrast imaging.
13. B, T2-weighted short τ inversion recovery imaging demonstrating extensive spinal cord edema (blue bracket).Spinal cord infarct: underlying cause workup, supportive care
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Metastatic progression: proceed with irradiation  
B: Radiation recall myelopathy: continue steroids, discontinue doxorubicin  
C: Radiation necrosis: continue steroids, add bevacizumab  
D: Spinal cord infarct: underlying cause workup, supportive care

step1_excerpts:
1. A 66-year-old woman with a history of osteoporosis and hypertension presents to the clinic complaining of upper back pain, which worsens after prolonged sitting.
2. She notes mild pain relief with acetaminophen.
3. During an osteopathic structural examination, the physician identifies a right posterior transverse process lateral to the T2 spinous process, which becomes more prominent when the spine is extended.
question_options:
What is the most accurate diagnosis?

A. T3 FRRSR  
B. T2 FRLSL  
C. T2 ERRSL  
D. T2 FRRSR  
E. T2 ERRSR  
F. T2 ERLSL  
G. T2 FRLSR  
H. T2 NRLSR  
I. T3 ERRSR  
J. T1 FRRSR

step1_excerpts:
1. A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination.
2. He was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy.
3. His birth weight was 3500 g (7 lb 11 oz), and Apgar scores were 8 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively.
4. At the age of 15 months, physical examination showed no abnormalities, but he was not yet talking.
5. Both of his parents had learning difficulties in school, and his mother stopped attending after the 10th grade.
6. He has a maternal uncle with cognitive disabilities.
7. He is at the 25th percentile for height, 15th percentile for weight, and 90th percentile for head circumference.
8. He appears irritable, he resists making eye contact, and he is flapping his hands.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

A. Frameshift mutation

B. Missense mutation

C. Nonsense mutation

D. Trinucleotide repeat expansion

step1_excerpts:
1. A 31-year-old pregnant woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 27 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever and productive cough producing yellow-green sputum.
2. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated so far.
3. She has a medical history of asthma, controlled with inhaled fluticasone and as-needed albuterol.
4. On examination, she appears uncomfortable.
5. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 93/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, and blood pressure is 122/71 mm Hg.
6. Oxygen saturation on room air is 97%.
7. Chest auscultation reveals rhonchi in the right middle lung field.
8. Fundal height measures 26 cm, and fetal heart rate is 155/min.
9. Laboratory findings are as follows:

| Hemoglobin | 12.8 g/dL |
| --- | --- |
| Leukocyte count | 13,100/mm3 |
| Platelet count | 250,000/mm3 |
| Serum |  |
| Na+ | 142 mEq/L |
| K+ | 4.1 mEq/L |
| Urea nitrogen | 10 mg/dL |
| Creatinine | 0.8 mg/dL |

Urinalysis reveals no abnormalities.
10. A chest x-ray shows an infiltrate in the right middle lobe.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Outpatient treatment with levofloxacin  
B. Inpatient treatment with ampicillin-sulbactam and azithromycin  
C. Inpatient treatment with cefuroxime and azithromycin  
D. Outpatient treatment with doxycycline  
E. Inpatient treatment with amoxicillin-clavulanate  
F. Outpatient treatment with amoxicillin and azithromycin  
G. Outpatient treatment with clarithromycin  
H. Outpatient treatment with cefuroxime and erythromycin  
I. Inpatient treatment with ceftriaxone and azithromycin  
J. Inpatient treatment with piperacillin-tazobactam and vancomycin

step1_excerpts:
1. A 53-year-old woman, married for 30 years, visits the clinic for a routine breast examination.  
2. She expresses concern about having a somewhat reduced desire for sexual activity with her husband, despite having a "wonderful" relationship.  
3. She has two children, underwent menopause at age 50, and states that sexual desire was never an issue previously.  
4. She is not on hormone replacement therapy, and her physical examination is normal.  
5. She wonders if her hormone levels, particularly after menopause, might be affecting her libido.
question_options:
What would be the most appropriate response from the physician?

A. “Testosterone levels are more closely associated with libido than estrogen levels and should be evaluated.”  
B. “Your symptoms suggest hypoactive sexual desire disorder, which can be treated with medication.”  
C. "You should visit your gynecologist for help with this issue."  
D. “A referral to a sex therapist may help address the emotional and relational aspects of your concern.”  
E. “Menopause is known to reduce estrogen levels and might need to be supplemented to bring sexual desire back to pre-menopausal levels.”  
F. “There is no evidence that estrogen levels modulate libido.”  
G. “Low libido after menopause is typically caused by psychological factors rather than hormonal changes.”  
H. “It is common for women to experience reduced libido after menopause due to vaginal dryness, which can be treated with lubricants or local estrogen therapy.”  
I. “Low estrogen levels after menopause are the primary cause of reduced sexual desire in most women.”  
J. “Hormone replacement therapy is the standard treatment for restoring libido in postmenopausal women.”

step1_excerpts:
1. A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department with difficulty breathing.
2. He has experienced similar symptoms before.
3. Today, he was hit in the face with a football, followed by significant swelling of his lips and tongue.
4. The patient speaks with a muffled voice.
5. His temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 120/83 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
6. Physical exam reveals swollen lips and a protruding, enlarged tongue.
7. His breath sounds are clear.
8. He demonstrates no rash and his abdomen is soft and nontender.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most effective therapy for this patient?

A. Diphenhydramine  
B. Dexamethasone  
C. Fresh frozen plasma  
D. Epinephrine

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 50s presented to the emergency department with acute, severe, left flank pain.
2. There was no medical history of trauma, fever, or hematuria.
3. She was receiving therapy for mantle cell lymphoma and had previously undergone 1 cycle of the Nordic protocol (comprising cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, prednisolone, cytarabine, and rituximab).1  However, this resulted in tumor lysis syndrome and neutropenic sepsis.
4. The patient was reluctant to undergo further infusional therapy and was switched to ibrutinib, 560 mg, once daily.
5. During the 2-month period that she was receiving ibrutinib therapy, there were no concurrent administrations of anticoagulants.
6. At presentation, she was hypotensive (blood pressure, 79/45 mm Hg) with conjunctival pallor and left renal angle tenderness.
7. The patient’s hemoglobin count was low (7.6 g/dL; reference range, 12-16 g/dL; to convert to g/L, multiply by 10.0), which represented a significant decrease from the baseline (10.6 g/dL) measured 1 month before presentation.
8. She was also found to have acute-onset thrombocytopenia (40×109/L; reference range, 140-400×109/L) and leukocytosis (12.75×109/L, reference range, 4-10×109/L).
9. Her coagulation profile (prothrombin time) was normal.
10. A computed tomographic (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis was performed (Figure 1A) and compared with a similar scan performed 4 months prior (Figure 1B).
11. A, Findings from computed tomographic scan at presentation.
12. B, Previous findings from computed tomographic scan.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture  
B: Spontaneous perinephric hematoma  
C: Splenic rupture  
D: Pyelonephritis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 4-day-old girl presents with her parents to the pediatrician for a routine visit.
2. She was feeding well until this morning when she had several episodes of vomiting.
3. The parents describe the vomitus as “bright green” and the patient has shown little interest in feeding since then.
4. She was born at 36 weeks gestation to a 37-year-old G2P2 mother.
5. The pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes, and all prenatal testing was unremarkable.
6. The patient has not yet regained her birth weight and is in the 46th percentile for height and the 36th percentile for weight.
7. The patient’s temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 68/46 mmHg, pulse is 132/min, and respirations are 32/min.
8. On physical exam, the patient is in mild distress.
9. She has no dysmorphic features.
10. Her abdomen is distended and firm without guarding.
11. Bowel sounds are hypoactive.
12. The patient’s abdominal radiograph can be seen in Figure A and the patient’s upper gastrointestinal series can be seen in Figure B.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?

A. Hirschsprung disease  
B. Duodenal atresia  
C. Meconium ileus  
D. Intestinal malrotation

step1_excerpts:
1. A 19-year-old male presents to the office for evaluation after he was hit from behind below the right knee while playing football.
2. Gait analysis reveals a lack of fluid motion.
3. Standing flexion test results are negative.
4. Cruciate and collateral knee ligaments appear intact.
5. Foot drop on the right is noted.
question_options:
The most likely diagnosis is

A. anteriorly deviated distal femur

B. plantar flexed cuboid

C. posteriorly deviated fibular head

D. unilateral sacral shear

step1_excerpts:
1. An 80-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with sudden-onset bilateral horizontal diplopia accompanied by left-sided upper eyelid ptosis.  
2. On further questioning, she reported a 1-week history of drooling when eating.  
3. She had no other associated neurological or constitutional symptoms.  
4. No anhidrosis was noted.  
5. Her medical history was significant for a 2-year history of constant, dull, left-sided facial pain diagnosed as trigeminal neuralgia by her treating neurologist and moderately improved with gabapentin and nortriptyline.  
6. Recent computed tomography (CT) of the brain, conducted as part of her headache workup, had been reported as normal.  
7. On examination, visual acuity was 20/25 OU.  
8. Extraocular motility testing demonstrated no abduction of the left eye with corresponding large-angle incomitant esotropia increasing when looking to the left (Figure 1).  
9. There was 2 mm of left upper eyelid ptosis with preserved levator function.  
10. The left pupil was 1 mm smaller than the right in the light, with the difference increasing to 2 mm in the dark.  
11. There was no relative afferent pupillary defect.  
12. Cranial nerve examination demonstrated reduced sensation in the left V1-V3 distribution and mild flattening of the nasolabial fold.  
13. Corneal sensation was slightly decreased on the left.  
14. Intraocular examination, including dilated fundus examination, was normal in both eyes.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Obtain CT angiography of head and neck  
B: Perform lumbar puncture to analyze cellular composition of cerebrospinal fluid  
C: Obtain magnetic resonance imaging of the brain with contrast  
D: Order tests of inflammatory markers: erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, and complete blood cell count

step1_excerpts:
1. A 28-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with a 5-day history of bilateral blurry vision, eye redness, discharge, photophobia, and pain.
2. She also reported rhinorrhea and lethargy.
3. Her medical history included Leber congenital amaurosis treated with voretigene neparvovec (Luxturna; Spark Therapeutics) 8 years ago, and acute myeloid leukemia (AML) diagnosed 6 months prior to presentation treated with cytarabine and idarubicin.
4. Her latest chemotherapy was 3 weeks before presentation, and a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) was removed 2 weeks ago.
5. A complete blood cell count was ordered, revealing anemia, neutropenia, lymphocytopenia, and monocytopenia in the setting of recent chemotherapy.
6. Blood cultures were drawn, and results were pending at the time of presentation.Her ophthalmic examination showed visual acuity of 20/800 OD and 20/400 OS, decreased from her baseline of 20/200 OU.
7. Intraocular pressures were 37 mm Hg OD and 31 mm Hg OS.
8. Slitlamp examination revealed chemosis, conjunctival hyperemia, and microcystic corneal edema bilaterally.
9. There were more than 20 cells per high-power field of 1 mm × 1 mm beam, with fibrin bilaterally and 2.5-mm hypopyon in the right eye and 2.7-mm hypopyon in the left eye (Figure 1).
10. Posterior segment examination was limited because of corneal edema and anterior inflammation, but there were no vitreous opacities on B-scan ultrasonography.A 2.5-mm pseudohypopyon in the right eye due to leukemic infiltrate.Observe, as this is expected inflammation after voretigene neparvovec gene therapyObtain a sample of the hypopyon through anterior chamber paracentesis and inject intravitreal antibioticsAwait results from systemic laboratory tests and blood culture
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Observe, as this is expected inflammation after voretigene neparvovec gene therapy  
B: Perform pars plana vitrectomy  
C: Obtain a sample of the hypopyon through anterior chamber paracentesis and inject intravitreal antibiotics  
D: Await results from systemic laboratory tests and blood culture

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old man presented to the emergency department following an unwitnessed assault, sustaining multiple facial contusions and lacerations.
2. He was initially agitated and admitted to the intensive care unit with hemodynamic instability.
3. The oral-maxillofacial surgery service was consulted for assessment of the facial lacerations, and the oculoplastic service was consulted for possible damage to the nasolacrimal system.
4. The patient’s medical history at this point was unknown.
5. From an ophthalmic standpoint, a single, deep laceration extended inferomedially from the right upper zygoma across the nasal dorsum and involving the eyelid-cheek junction (Figure 1).
6. A significant amount of clear fluid was noted to be continually draining from the wound site.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Perform nasolacrimal duct irrigation  
B: Explore, irrigate, and close the wound  
C: Order computed tomography of the head/facial bones  
D: Order magnetic resonance imaging of the head

step1_excerpts:
1. A 20-year-old student shadowing in surgery loses consciousness, becoming pale and falling to the ground.
2. He experiences lightheadedness and blurred vision immediately before fainting, regains consciousness within 5 seconds, and recovers completely after brief rest.
3. During the episode, his heart exhibited decreased rate and contractility.
question_options:
Which of the following medications operates through the same cellular signaling pathway that was activated in this student's cardiac tissue?

A. Norepinephrine  
B. Epinephrine  
C. Digoxin  
D. Propranolol  
E. Atropine  
F. Clonidine  
G. Adenosine  
H. Verapamil  
I. Dobutamine  
J. Methacholine

step1_excerpts:
1. During a recent hiking trip, a 17-year-old girl with up-to-date immunizations stepped on a wire, which went through her sneaker and punctured her right heel.
2. She was prescribed a 5-day course of amoxicillin-clavulanate.
3. Seven days after completing the antibiotics, she is unable to bear weight on her right foot and reports purulent drainage from her right heel.
4. On examination, the patient has a temperature of 38.7°C.
5. Her right heel is erythematous, and she has point tenderness over the puncture site.
6. In addition, pus is draining from the site of the wound.
7. Laboratory testing reveals a leukocyte count of 13,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–13,000) and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 30 mm/hr (1–25).
8. Radiographic findings reveal soft-tissue swelling and destructive changes of the calcaneus.
question_options:
In addition to surgical debridement, which one of the following regimens, if any, should be initiated in this patient?

A. Vancomycin and ceftriaxone  
B. Vancomycin and metronidazole  
C. Doxycycline and rifampin  
D. Ampicillin-sulbactam and azithromycin  
E. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and ceftazidime  
F. Clindamycin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole  
G. Clindamycin and ciprofloxacin  
H. Vancomycin and cefepime  
I. Cefazolin and gentamicin  
J. Daptomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam

step1_excerpts:
1. A 68-year-old man presents for evaluation by a neurologist for an involuntary hand tremor that started approximately 3 months ago.
2. The shaking improves when he reaches for objects but returns when he is not using his hand.
3. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 12/min.
4. His left hand exhibits a 4-6 Hz tremor when resting on his lap.
5. The tremor extinguishes with voluntary movement.
6. In addition, his left upper extremity has increased tone with passive range of motion.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cerebellar stroke  
B. Essential tremor  
C. Lacunar stroke  
D. Parkinson disease

step1_excerpts:
1. A 25-year-old woman who is 19 weeks pregnant comes to the office for a prenatal examination.  
2. Her father had classic hemophilia.  
3. A karyotype obtained from an amniotic fluid sample of the patient shows that the fetus is XY.
question_options:
Which of the following should you tell the patient regarding her infant?

A. The infant will neither have hemophilia nor be a carrier

B. The infant has a 50% risk for hemophilia

C. The infant has a 50% risk for being a carrier

D. The infant has a 75% risk for hemophilia

step1_excerpts:
1. You are visiting an 86-year-old woman in her home at the request of the patient's daughter because of worsening shortness of breath at rest for the past 2 days.
2. The patient is confined to her home because of severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with cor pulmonale.
3. She was discharged 1 week ago from the hospital following 3 weeks of treatment for pneumonia that required intubation; her hospital stay was complicated by sepsis.
4. She had a prolonged weaning program from intubation.
5. Prior to discharge, the patient and her daughter met with you to review the patient's advance directive.
6. During the discussion, the patient said, "I'd rather die than be intubated again." At that time, both the patient and her daughter signed an addendum to that effect on the patient's advance directive.
7. Today, the patient is dyspneic and is unable to complete a sentence.
8. Vital signs are temperature 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse 88/min, respirations 35/min, and blood pressure 100/70 mm Hg.
9. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 84% while the patient is breathing 4 L of oxygen.
10. You ask the patient if she wishes to return to the hospital.
11. She says, "No, I want to die at home." Her daughter takes you aside and says, "My mother doesn't know what she's saying.
question_options:
After further discussion with the daughter regarding support available at home, which of the following is the most appropriate step?

A. Admit the patient to the hospital

B. Arrange for consultation with a home hospice team

C. Consult with the hospital ethics committee

D. Order a home continuous positive airway pressure machine and instruct the daughter in its use

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her early 50s was admitted to the hospital with several days of headaches, bilateral photophobia, and blurry vision.
2. Her medical history was notable for cystic fibrosis, receipt of bilateral lung transplant, cytomegalovirus (CMV) viremia, and chronic kidney disease.
3. Earlier treatment for CMV viremia included valganciclovir hydrochloride therapy that was discontinued because of the development of drug resistance and foscarnet sodium therapy with resultant renal dysfunction.
4. The patient was subsequently treated with intravenous renally dosed cidofovir therapy; however, she again developed a nephrotoxic reaction and required dosage reduction in the weeks before presentation.
5. At admission, cidofovir therapy was discontinued because of acute kidney injury (creatinine level, 5.75 mg/dL) (to convert to micromoles per liter, multiply by 88.4).
6. The findings of a workup for meningitis were unremarkable.
7. Ophthalmic consultation occurred 1 week after admission.
8. The patient’s visual acuity was 20/30 OD and 20/25 OS.
9. Pupils were minimally reactive and without an afferent pupillary defect.
10. Intraocular pressures were 15 mm Hg OD and 12 mm Hg OS.
11. Portable slitlamp examination findings included bilateral posterior synechiae and a shallow anterior chamber in the left eye.
12. No anterior segment cell was appreciable by portable examination.
13. The patient had early nuclear sclerosis and posterior subcapsular cataracts in both eyes.
14. Results of a fundus examination demonstrated bilateral temporal choroidal elevations without vitritis, vascular sheathing, retinitis, or optic nerve abnormalities.
15. B-scan ultrasonography findings demonstrated bilateral choroidal effusions (Figure 1).
16. B-scan ultrasonographic images obtained at initial presentation demonstrating choroidal effusions in a patient with recent exposure to cidofovir.
17. Discontinue cidofovir therapy, and start therapy with topical corticosteroids and cycloplegia
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Restart cidofovir therapy to treat CMV retinitis  
B: Discontinue cidofovir therapy, and start therapy with topical corticosteroids and cycloplegia  
C: Administer bilateral subtenon corticosteroid injections  
D: Begin treatment with oral prednisone

step1_excerpts:
1. A 62-year-old man is brought to his primary care physician by his daughter after avoiding medical care for the past 10 years.
2. He reports worsening abdominal pain that started mildly but has intensified over the past week.
3. The patient has been consuming more vegetables in an attempt to alleviate his symptoms.
4. His medical history includes chronic constipation and a 50-pack-year smoking history.
5. He is not taking any medications.
6. On review of systems, he reports difficulty defecating and blood coating his stool.
7. Vital signs include a temperature of 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure of 197/128 mmHg, pulse of 100/min, respirations of 17/min, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air.
8. Physical examination reveals right upper quadrant tenderness, a palpable liver edge extending 4 cm below the costal margin, and pain upon pressure release in the same area.
9. His skin appears jaundiced.
10. HEENT examination shows poor dentition but normal sclera and extraocular movements.
11. No lymphadenopathy is noted.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Ischemic colitis  
B. Liver metastases from an unknown primary tumor  
C. Colon cancer  
D. Acute appendicitis  
E. Crohn's disease  
F. Diverticulitis  
G. Hepatocellular carcinoma  
I. Pancreatic cancer  
J. Gallbladder carcinoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 25-year-old man with a history of rheumatoid arthritis currently taking oral methotrexate, 25 mg per week, presented with a lesion of the left bulbar conjunctiva of about 1 month’s duration.
2. He had no other symptoms other than occasionally noticing a sensation of a foreign body in that eye and denied any changes in his vision.
3. He had no history of contact lens use, ocular trauma, or ocular surgery.
4. His only other medications were oral vitamin D and folic acid.
5. He was initially treated with topical antibiotics followed by a course of oral sulindac, 200 mg twice daily, without any improvement.
6. On examination, his visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/25 OS.
7. Intraocular pressure was 16 mm Hg OD and 23 mm Hg OS.
8. The lesion measured 6.5 × 2.5 mm and was firm, nonvascular, slightly mobile, and located on the superotemporal portion of the bulbar conjunctiva (Figure 1).
9. It was purulent in appearance, but no material was expressed with attempted incision and drainage at the slitlamp.
10. A culture was positive only for Propionibacterium acnes.
11. Tests for herpes simplex, cytomegalovirus, and Epstein-Barr virus polymerase chain reactions were negative.External slitlamp photograph showing conjunctival lesion at presentation.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Initiate oral colchicine therapy  
B: Observe with serial examinations  
C: Perform excisional biopsy  
D: Perform intralesional dexamethasone injection

step1_excerpts:
1. A 47-year-old man is admitted to the hospital through the emergency department because of the sudden onset of palpitations, left-sided chest pain, light-headedness, and shortness of breath that began while he was watching television 2 hours ago.
2. Medical history is remarkable for paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
3. The patient is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2 .
4. ECG obtained in the emergency department showed atrial fibrillation with narrow QRS complex.
5. Pulse was 146/min.
6. Physical examination was remarkable for rapid heart rate.
7. The patient was given oxygen via nasal cannula and intravenous metoprolol 5 mg every 5 minutes for a total of 15 mg.
8. His pulse slowed to 90/min.
9. Two hours after admission, he is pain free but his pulse is now 160/min.
10. Blood pressure is 122/78 mm Hg.
question_options:
In order to decrease the patient's pulse, which of the following should be administered intravenously?

A. Digoxin

B. Enalapril

C. Lidocaine

D. Metoprolol

step1_excerpts:
1. A 9-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for a well-child examination.
2. The patient and his family immigrated to the United States 2 months ago and he has not been evaluated by a physician in 4 years.
3. He has been generally healthy.
4. Medical history is significant for pneumonia at age 3 years.
5. He takes no medications.
6. He is at the 25th percentile for height, weight, and BMI.
7. Vital signs are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 82/min, respirations 20/min, and blood pressure 112/74 mm Hg.
8. Cardiac examination discloses a grade 3/6 systolic murmur audible along the left sternal border at the third and fourth intercostal spaces.
9. Femoral pulses are weak and brachial pulses are strong; there is a radiofemoral delay.
10. Chest xray discloses mild cardiomegaly with left ventricular prominence.
11. ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy.
question_options:
This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?

A. Atrial fibrillation

B. Cor pulmonale

C. Systemic hypertension

D. Tricuspid valve regurgitation

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath.  
2. He has a medical history of hypertension, diabetes, and obesity.  
3. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure is 177/118 mmHg, pulse is 127/min, respirations are 11/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.  
4. An ECG is performed and notable for ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF.  
5. The patient is treated appropriately and transferred to the medical floor.  
6. On the 2nd day of his hospitalization, the patient has abdominal pain.  
7. His serum lipase is 272 U/L and his creatinine is 1.6 mg/dL.  
8. A physical exam is notable for the finding in Figure A.  
9. He is requesting pain medication for his abdominal pain.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis?

A. Cholesterol embolism  
B. Heart failure and reinfarction  
C. Pancreatitis  
D. Renal failure

step1_excerpts:
1. A 69-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for trouble sleeping.
2. He recently retired from working the day shift at a cemetery.
3. When the patient retired, his goal was to finally be able to go out with his wife; however, he finds that he is unable to stay awake past 6 pm in the evening.
4. His wife is disappointed that they cannot do any activities in the evening together.
5. The patient has tried drinking caffeine but finds that it does not help.
6. The patient’s wife claims that the patient seems to sleep peacefully, and the patient states he feels rested when he awakes.
7. The patient has a medical history of irritable bowel syndrome which is managed with fiber supplements.
8. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 125/83 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and respirations are 11/min.
9. The patient’s neurological exam is within normal limits.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Normal aging  
B. Delayed sleep phase disorder  
C. Chronic insomnia  
D. Advanced sleep phase disorder

step1_excerpts:
1. A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his babysitter because of a 30-minute history of respiratory distress.  
2. The babysitter reports that she is 15 years old and has cared for the patient on numerous occasions during the past year.  
3. The child's mother, who is a single parent, is currently out of town for business but will return later tonight.  
4. The babysitter says, "He has had a runny nose since I started babysitting yesterday, but this afternoon he awoke from a nap with a barking sound and he was breathing real heavy." She does not know the child's prior health history, nor does she know if the boy takes any medications on a regular basis.  
5. The child looks tired and sits upright on the babysitter's lap.  
6. He is obviously comfortable with his caregiver.  
7. Vital signs are temperature 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse 110/min, respirations 28/min and labored, and blood pressure 85/50 mm Hg.  
8. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%.  
9. Physical examination discloses inspiratory stridor.  
10. Neck is supple, tympanic membranes are normal, and there is a profuse nasal discharge.  
11. Examination of the pharynx discloses no abnormalities.  
12. Auscultation of the chest discloses equal air entry on both sides and no crackles.  
13. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.  
14. Treatment with 40% oxygen via venturi mask and intravenous fluids is initiated.  
15. Despite continued supplemental oxygen and hydration, the child remains tachypneic and stridorous at rest.  
16. Oxygen saturation is now 93%.
question_options:
In addition to administering racemic epinephrine by nebulizer, which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

A. Intravenous aminophylline therapy

B. Intravenous antibiotic therapy

C. Intubation

D. Oral dexamethasone therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 92-year-old woman presents for management of type 2 diabetes.
2. She has been controlling her diabetes with dietary measures since diagnosis, and her glycated hemoglobin value has routinely been below 7.0% until last week, when it was 7.4%.
3. The patient has no other symptoms and feels well.
4. She has hypertension, which is well controlled with hydrochlorothiazide and amlodipine.
5. She also has osteoporosis, which is treated with denosumab as well as calcium and vitamin D supplements.
6. She takes fluvastatin for hypercholesterolemia.
7. Her blood pressure is 134/82 mm Hg, her weight is 58 kg, and her BMI is 21.7.
question_options:
Which one of the following next steps is best in managing this patient’s type 2 diabetes?

A. Begin a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist  
B. Initiate sitagliptin  
C. Continue dietary control alone  
E. Start thiazolidinedione therapy  
F. Initiate basal insulin combined with prandial insulin  
G. Initiate metformin  
H. Adjust dietary control and add low-dose insulin  
I. Initiate insulin therapy  
J. Recommend short-acting sulfonylurea therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 26-year-old medical student presents to occupational health after sustaining a needlestick injury.
2. She was drawing blood from an HIV-positive patient when she stuck herself percutaneously while capping the needle.
3. She immediately washed the puncture wound with saline.
4. The medical student has had a negative HIV serology from the beginning of medical school 2 years ago.
5. She is monogamous with one male partner and denies any intravenous drug use.
6. The source patient was recently diagnosed with HIV and has a CD4 count of 550 cells/µL.
7. His most recent viral load is 1,800,000 copies/mL, and he was started on HAART 3 days ago.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Repeat HIV serology and initiate triple antiretroviral therapy if negative  
B. Immediately initiate triple antiretroviral therapy  
C. Repeat HIV serology and initiate triple antiretroviral therapy if positive  
D. Repeat HIV serology and initiate triple antiretroviral therapy immediately

step1_excerpts:
1. A 14-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for behavioral issues.
2. At school, he interrupts class by making barking noises.
3. His mother notes that he has been making throat-clearing noises daily for the past 2 years.
4. He has no medical problems and takes no medications.
5. He gets along with his 2 brothers, plays turn-taking games with his friends, and completes his chores.
6. His temperature is 98.4°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 16/min.
7. On exam, he grimaces several times and blinks his eyes rapidly.
8. He does not appear to be reacting to internal stimuli.
9. His mood and affect are normal.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A. Methylphenidate  
B. Fluoxetine  
C. Haloperidol  
D. Dextroamphetamine

step1_excerpts:
1. A 64-year-old man presented with concern about an abnormal genetic test result for apolipoprotein E (APOE) obtained through his primary care physician.
2. He reported forgetfulness and word-finding difficulties for 3 years but performed all activities of daily living independently and was generally healthy.
3. His father and maternal great aunt developed dementia in their 70s.
4. Physical (including neurologic) examination, basic laboratory studies, and brain magnetic resonance imaging results were normal.
5. The Short Test of Mental Status (STMS) score was 33 (maximal attainable score of 38 indicates best performance).
6. Neuropsychological assessment showed average to above-average performance in all cognitive domains, accounting for age and education.
7. Results of his genetic testing for APOE were reported as follows: “This individual possesses an apolipoprotein E genotype (3 and 4) that indicates, with high specificity, that Alzheimer’s disease is the cause of or a contributor to the observed dementia.”
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Obtain a brain fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) scan.  
B: Order cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) testing for Alzheimer disease biomarkers.  
C: Reassure and address patient’s concerns and follow up in 1 year.  
D: Refer for genetic counseling.

step1_excerpts:
1. A 74-year-old woman was referred for bilateral blurry vision occurring 2 hours after a car crash.
2. At the moment of impact, she was wearing her seat belt, the airbag deployed, and an intense flexion-extension head movement occurred.
3. Best-corrected visual acuity was 20/125 OD and 20/63 OS.
4. Intraocular pressure was 19 mm Hg OD and 20 mm Hg OS.
5. Slitlamp examination revealed no palpebral hematoma, and the anterior segment was found to be normal.
6. On the fundus bilaterally, we only noted an alteration of the foveal reflection, with neither retinae commotio nor hemorrhages.
7. Macular optical coherence tomography (OCT) showed bilateral macular edema with cystoid abnormalities (Figure 1).
8. An epiretinal membrane also was noted in the left eye (Figure 1B).
9. Optical coherence tomography showed bilateral macular edema with cystoid abnormalities.
10. Central subfield thickness was 696 μm in the right eye and 392 μm in the left eye.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Observe  
B: Systemic or bilateral intraocular corticosteroid therapy  
C: Epiretinal membrane peeling in the left eye  
D: Bilateral antivascular endothelial growth factor therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A girl younger than 2 years presented with a 7-month history of an inflammatory plaque on her left index finger (Figure, A).
2. This lesion had started as a light erythema a few months before, initially oriented as a bacterial paronychia or herpetic whitlow and treated with an oral antibiotic (amoxicillin) and antiviral (acyclovir) without improvement.
3. There was no relevant medical history.
4. The family reported living in a rural area on the Mediterranean coast.A, Erythematous nodule on the proximal nail fold.
5. B, Inflammatory erythematous plaque with a central shiny orange crust on the left index.
6. C, Diffuse dermatitis with epithelioid granulomas (hematoxylin-eosin stain).
7. D, Intracellular amastigotes in the dermal macrophages (hematoxylin-eosin stain).Physical examination findings revealed an inflammatory erythematous plaque with a central shiny orange crust on the left index finger (Figure, B).
8. No other fingers were affected.
9. There were no systemic symptoms or family history of similar lesions.
10. Given the chronic course, with no improvement with empiric therapy, a biopsy specimen was obtained for further evaluation (Figure, C and D).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Herpetic whitlow  
B: Bacterial paronychia  
C: Cutaneous leishmaniasis  
D: Pyogenic granuloma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 50-year-old woman presented to the emergency department for 3 months of right orbital pain.
2. Her medical history was noncontributory.
3. Examination revealed a right afferent pupillary defect, visual acuity of hand motion OD and 20/30 OS, full extraocular movements, and bilateral retinal dot blot hemorrhages.
4. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed enhancement along the right intracanalicular optic nerve and adjacent sinuses (Figure).
5. Glycosylated hemoglobin level was elevated at 10.3% (to convert to proportion of total hemoglobin, multiply by 0.01).
6. Workup results for sarcoidosis, IgG4-related disease, seropositive and seronegative arthropathies, human immunodeficiency virus, tuberculosis, syphilis, Epstein-Barr virus, and herpes simplex virus types 1 and 2 were negative.T1 fat-suppressed postgadolinium magnetic resonance imaging.
7. A, Contrast enhancement centered on the right intracanalicular optic nerve (blue arrowhead), involving right orbital apex and posterior ethmoidal sinus (white arrowhead).
8. B, Enhancement encircling right optic nerve (arrowhead).Orbital apex and sinus biopsy revealed acute and chronic inflammation without neoplasm or microorganisms.
9. Specimen cultures grew methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA).
10. The patient was diagnosed as having type 2 diabetes and MSSA sino-orbital infection.
11. She was discharged 10 days later with intravenous (IV) antibacterials, sitagliptin, insulin, and oral opiates.The patient returned to the emergency department 2 weeks later with recurrent orbital pain.
12. Although examination was stable, MRI showed increased apical enhancement.
13. The diagnosis was revised to nonspecific orbital inflammation and the neurology department initiated a 3-day course of IV methylprednisolone.
14. Pain rapidly resolved, repeated MRI showed reduced enhancement, and she was discharged with a prednisone taper.Ten days later, the patient returned once again to the emergency department with pain.
15. Although imaging was stable, examination revealed visual acuity of no light perception OD and new-onset right-sided third, fourth, and sixth cranial neuropathies.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Repeat IV methyprednisolone with slower taper  
B: Initiate steroid-sparing immunomodulator  
C: Initiate broad-spectrum IV antibacterials  
D: Repeat biopsy of orbital apex and sinuses

step1_excerpts:
1. A 67-year-old man with dyslipidemia, obesity (body mass index, 34), past tobacco use, anxiety, and borderline hypertension presented to the emergency department (ED) after 3 days of shortness of breath on exertion.  
2. He described increased anxiety and a pleuritic chest pain that began a few hours prior to his ED visit, but no hemoptysis.  
3. He had no personal history of cancer, venous thrombosis, recent surgery, trauma, or admission to hospital.  
4. His medications included fluoxetine, atorvastatin, vitamin D, magnesium, and niacin.  
5. On examination, his blood pressure was 164/82 mm Hg; pulse rate, 104/min; and respiratory rate, 18/min.  
6. Oxygen saturation level was 96% in room air.  
7. His lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally.  
8. No extra heart sounds or murmurs were noted.  
9. Examination of his extremities were unremarkable with no leg symptoms or swelling or pain at calf palpation.  
10. Laboratory test results showed a hemoglobin level of 160 g/dL (reference range, 14.0-17.5 g/dL), a platelet count of 129 × 103/μL (reference range, 150-350 × 103/μL), and a serum creatinine level of 1.26 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6-1.2 mg.dL) (111 μmol/L; reference range, 13-106 μmol/L).  
11. His chest film was normal.  
12. The attending physician’s presumptive diagnosis was pulmonary embolism (PE).  
13. His pretest clinical probability of PE according to the 2-level Wells score was likely (1.5 points for heart rate >100, and 3.0 for other diagnoses less likely than PE).  
14. Therefore, D-dimer measurement was not performed.  
15. His computed tomographic pulmonary angiography (CTPA) result is reported in the Table.  
16. Rule out PE and perform a work up for alternative diagnoses.  
17. Obtain a bilateral lower limb veins compression ultrasonography.  
18. Obtain a lung ventilation-perfusion (V̇/Q̇) scan or pulmonary angiogram.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Rule out PE and perform a work up for alternative diagnoses.  
B: Obtain a bilateral lower limb veins compression ultrasonography.  
C: Obtain a lung ventilation-perfusion (V̇/Q̇) scan or pulmonary angiogram.  
D: Test for D-dimer.

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 30s was referred for evaluation of severe bilateral optic disc edema, retinal hemorrhages, and a gradual decrease in vision during a 3-week period.
2. She had a history of chronic migraines and reported worsening headaches during the past 3 months.
3. The patient experienced intermittent episodes of numbness of her tongue, teeth, and upper extremities.
4. She reported intermittent tinnitus but denied transient visual obscurations or hearing changes.
5. Results of a review of systems were otherwise unremarkable.
6. The patient was not taking any medications and denied a history of illicit drug use.
7. Her best-corrected visual acuity was 20/100 OD and 20/70 OS.
8. Extraocular movements were intact, and pupils were round and reactive with no afferent pupillary defect.
9. Her intraocular pressure was 14 mm Hg OD and 10 mm Hg OS.
10. Results of the patient’s anterior segment examination were within normal limits.
11. Results of examination of her fundus are shown in the Figure, A.
12. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain revealed diffuse abnormalities on T2-weighted fluid-attenuated inversion recovery sequences (Figure, B).A, Color fundus photograph of the right eye demonstrates severe optic disc edema, retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, and macular exudates.
13. B, Magnetic resonance imaging scan of the brain in axial T2-weighted fluid-attenuated inversion recovery sequences reveals diffuse T2-weighted signal abnormality involving the cerebral hemispheres, brain stem, and cerebellum.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Order a lumbar puncture  
B: Prescribe corticosteroids and consult rheumatology  
C: Prescribe azithromycin  
D: Measure the patient’s blood pressure

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 50s presented with an edematous, massively enlarged right auricle.
2. The patient had immigrated to Israel 9 years before admission.
3. She was adamant that the lesion had been present since early childhood but had gradually increased with a recent appearance of foul-smelling otorrhea.
4. On examination, the auricle was markedly enlarged, edematous, and encircled by an erythematous, indurated plaque partially covered with a fine scale (Figure 1A).
5. Diascopy revealed an “apple jelly” appearance.
6. There was no local or distant lymphadenopathy; general physical examination findings were unremarkable.A, Clinical findings at presentation in 2008 showed an enlarged and edematous auricle encircled by an indurated erythematous plaque.
7. Bloody otorrhea from the external auditory canal was seen.
8. Image resolution was digitally enhanced.
9. B, Biopsy specimen showed superficial and deep diffuse granulomatous dermatitis (hematoxylin-eosin).
10. C, Higher magnification demonstrated classic tuberculoid granuloma with histiocytes and Langhans giant cells surrounded by lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate (hematoxylin-eosin).Results of routine laboratory investigations, including complete blood cell count, biochemical profile, liver function tests, and chest radiography, were normal.
11. An intradermal Mantoux test induced a 20-mm induration.
12. Histopathologic evaluation of the cutaneous lesion revealed noncaseating granulomatous dermatitis involving the dermis (Figure 1B).
13. High magnification demonstrated tuberculoid dermal granulomas composed of histiocytes and Langhans giant cells surrounded by lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate (Figure 1C).
14. Results of polarized light examination and periodic acid–Schiff, Ziehl-Neelsen, Giemsa, Gram, and Grocott methenamine silver stains were negative for microorganisms.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Lupus pernio  
B: Granulomatous mycosis fungoides  
C: Lupus vulgaris  
D: Leishmania recidivans

step1_excerpts:
1. A pregnant woman in her late 30s had normal findings on anatomic ultrasonography at 19 weeks’ gestation.  
2. Follow-up ultrasonography at 32 weeks’ gestation identified fetal hydrops.  
3. The fetal ultrasonogram showed a large left-sided hydrothorax, mediastinal shift, and ascites.  
4. After ruling out infectious causes, an ultrasonography-guided thoracoamniotic shunt was placed successfully at 32 weeks’ gestation.  
5. Results of follow-up ultrasonography on postoperative day 3 showed improvement in the fetal hydrothorax and resolution of hydrops and identified a feeding vessel originating from the descending aorta supplying a lung mass (Figure 1A).  
6. A, Feeding vessel (arrowhead) from descending aorta identified on ultrasonography at 32 weeks’ gestation.  
7. B, Feeding vessel (arrowhead) to lung mass (outlined) over left hemidiaphragm on computed tomography at age 9 months.  
8. Owing to premature rupture of membranes, the mother delivered at 33 weeks.  
9. The neonate showed no respiratory distress after birth, and the shunt was removed.  
10. On the day of birth, radiographic findings showed a left-sided pleural effusion.  
11. Ongoing pleural effusion caused respiratory distress, and on day 3 of life, a temporary thoracostomy tube was placed.  
12. During the following weeks, the thoracostomy tube output decreased, the tube was removed, and the patient was discharged home.  
13. At 9 months of age, follow-up computed tomography confirmed a lung mass with a feeding vessel (Figure 1B), and the patient returned for elective thoracoscopic resection.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?  
A: Teratoma  
B: Bronchopulmonary sequestration  
C: Congenital pulmonary airway malformation  
D: Carcinoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of right shoulder pain that began after he chopped wood 2 days ago.  
2. Examination of the right upper extremity shows no obvious bone deformities or point tenderness.  
3. The pain is reproduced when the patient is asked to externally rotate the shoulder against resistance; there is no weakness.
question_options:
In addition to the teres minor, inflammation of which of the following tendons is most likely in this patient?  

A. Infraspinatus  

B. Pectoralis  

C. Subscapularis  

D. Supraspinatus

step1_excerpts:
1. A 44-year-old man presents to the clinic with acute back pain that began two days ago after lifting a heavy box.  
2. He was initially evaluated in the emergency department, where imaging studies were negative.  
3. He has no prior history of back pain or significant medical history.  
4. The pain does not radiate, and a review of systems is unremarkable.  
5. Physical examination reveals tenderness and warmth over the lumbar region, with exquisite tenderness of the soft tissue around L3.  
6. Applying anterior pressure to the right transverse process reveals a woody end-feel that resolves with flexion at that level.  
7. The patient is positioned for direct, passive treatment by lying lateral recumbent on the opposite side of the posterior transverse process, but the motion barrier is challenging to localize.
question_options:
Which adjustment during the setup would best isolate the dysfunction?

A. Rotate the torso away from the posterior transverse process  
B. Pull the left upper extremity toward the table while side-bending the torso  
C. Rotate the torso toward the posterior transverse process  
D. Flex the hips and knees to 90 degrees  
E. Extend the lower extremities to increase lumbar lordosis  
F. Pull the left upper extremity inferiorly  
G. Pull the right upper extremity anteriorly while rotating the torso  
H. Pull the left upper extremity out, twisting torso toward ceiling  
I. Pull the right upper extremity superiorly  
J. Pull the right upper extremity out, twisting torso toward table

step1_excerpts:
1. A 9-year-old female presents for evaluation with a 2-day history of fever, nausea, and left-sided back pain.
2. She denies vomiting or diarrhea and maintains oral intake.
3. Her medical history is unremarkable with no medications or allergies.
4. Physical examination reveals a moderately ill-appearing but communicative patient.
5. Vital signs show temperature 38.5°C, heart rate 110/min, respiratory rate 20/min, and blood pressure 100/70 mm Hg.
6. Left costovertebral angle tenderness is present with mild diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation.
7. Urinalysis demonstrates:
- pH: 5
- White blood cells: 2+
- Nitrites: 1+
- Blood: trace
question_options:
While awaiting culture results, which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?

A. Oral fosfomycin  
B. Oral cefixime  
C. Intramuscular gentamicin  
D. Oral ciprofloxacin  
E. Admission to the hospital and administration of intravenous ceftriaxone  
F. Oral nitrofurantoin  
G. Observation without antibiotics until culture results return  
H. Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate  
I. Oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole  
J. Oral ampicillin

step1_excerpts:
1. A 17-year-old previously healthy girl presented with 3 months of decreased vision in the right eye associated with throbbing pain with eye movement.  
2. The patient had no history of weakness, incontinence, or severe headaches.  
3. Initial presentation was notable for hand motion visual acuity with a 2+ relative afferent pupillary defect on the right; fundus examination revealed grade IV disc edema with obscuration of all major vessels on the disc (Figure, A).  
4. A magnetic resonance image (MRI) of the brain with and without gadolinium contrast was degraded by motion and orthodontic artifact but was suggestive of optic nerve enhancement consistent with optic neuritis.  
5. Results of serology tests and cerebral spinal fluid analysis were negative for infectious and inflammatory etiologies, including syphilis, sarcoidosis, Lyme disease, viral etiologies, multiple sclerosis, and lupus.  
6. The patient started treatment with intravenous methylprednisone and plasmapheresis for a presumptive diagnosis of optic neuritis; however, after 3 days there was minimal improvement and a second MRI of the brain and orbits was performed (Figure, B).  
7. The second MRI revealed a fusiform expansion of the right optic nerve and enhancement of the orbital, canalicular, and prechiasmatic segments of the right optic nerve, suggestive of an optic nerve glioma.  
8. Two weeks after initial presentation, the visual acuity in the right eye progressed to no light perception.  
9. Repeated MRI showed progression of the lesion with masslike expansion at the chiasm measuring 1.3 cm (anterior-posterior) × 1.5 cm (craniocaudal) × 1.1 cm (transverse).  
10. The left visual field remained full.  
11. Transorbital biopsy of the right optic nerve for grading and immunohistochemistry Transcranial resection of the orbital, canalicular, and prechiasmal optic nerve Chemotherapy and/or radiation for presumptive optic nerve glioma Observation given progression to no light perception vision
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Transorbital biopsy of the right optic nerve for grading and immunohistochemistry  
B: Transcranial resection of the orbital, canalicular, and prechiasmal optic nerve  
C: Chemotherapy and/or radiation for presumptive optic nerve glioma  
D: Observation given progression to no light perception vision

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 40s was referred to our service owing to unusual findings detected on routine abdominal ultrasonography ordered by her gynecologist.
2. The ultrasonographic scan showed a hepatic mass in the right lobe composing approximately 50% of the liver parenchyma.
3. The patient was asymptomatic, and there were no significant findings on abdominal physical examination— the liver was not palpable.
4. Results of whole blood analyses, including α-fetoprotein, were within the reference ranges.
5. She had not received any medication, including contraceptive pills or hormones, for more than 10 years.
6. Nine years before this examination, the patient underwent elective splenectomy and hepatic biopsy at another institution.
7. However, she did not know the reason for removal of the spleen, and results of the histopathologic examination were not available.
8. She had undergone a cesarean section at age 25 years.
9. The patient had no history of trauma or other previous medical events.
10. An abdominal computed tomographic scan revealed a well-defined, solid, heterogeneous mass, completely intrahepatic, with no enhancement and no liquid component, causing slight displacement of the right hepatic vein (Figure 1).
11. Cross-sectional computed tomographic image of the abdomen shows a large, intrahepatic, 20-cm solid mass.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Hepatocellular carcinoma  
B: Fibrolamellar carcinoma  
C: Hepatic metastasis  
D: Gossypiboma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 53-year-old man presents to the clinic with a non-tender mass in his right anterior neck.
2. The mass has been slowly enlarging over the past 1 year.
3. He reports no dysphagia, difficulty breathing, or changes to his voice.
4. He also denies heat intolerance, palpitations, tremors, or diarrhea.
5. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia, for which he takes lisinopril and atorvastatin.
6. He has never smoked cigarettes.
7. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 130/84 mmHg, pulse is 86/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air.
8. Bedside ultrasound reveals a 1x2 cm hypoechogenic nodule with microcalcifications in the right thyroid lobe, which is biopsied.
9. Pathology results are shown in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Repeat ultrasound in 6 months  
B. Thyroidectomy followed by radioactive iodine  
C. Methimazole  
D. Radioactive iodine

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 30s presented with abdominal pain associated with unintentional weight loss for 6 months.
2. The patient had a history of hyperlipidemia.
3. Results of examination revealed a palpable mass of about 15 cm in the left paraumbilical region.
4. The patient had a normal right testis but a missing left testis.
5. Results of a computed tomography scan of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis revealed large intraperitoneal and retroperitoneal masses.
6. The intraperitoneal heterogenous mass was 20 × 15 × 11 cm, with linear calcifications (Figure 1).
7. There was a right moderate hydronephrosis.
8. The retroperitoneal mass was homogeneous, with associated lymphadenopathy encircling the aorta, inferior mesenteric artery, and both renal arteries.
9. A large left supraclavicular lymph node and left inguinal lymph node were also detected.
10. There was no metastasis identified elsewhere.
11. Serum lactate dehydrogenase was elevated at 1358 U/L (to convert to microkatals per liter, multiply by 0.0167), β human chorionic gonadotrophin was elevated at 1485 mIU/mL (to convert to international units per liter, multiply by 1.0), and α fetoprotein levels were normal.A computed tomography scan of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis showing large intraperitoneal and retroperitoneal masses.
12. The intraperitoneal heterogenous mass was 20 × 15 × 11 cm, with linear calcifications.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Colorectal cancer  
B: Testicular cancer  
C: Bladder cancer  
D: Lymphoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A previously healthy woman in her 50s presented with complaints of increasing forgetfulness, fatigue, and depressed mood after dealing with the deaths of several close relatives.
2. She was diagnosed with depression and began treatment with antidepressant medication.
3. After 8 months, she had worsening complaints.
4. At that time, a family member reported that her memory problems had progressed.
5. She was no longer able to find misplaced objects, remember appointments, or handle financial affairs.
6. She was often subdued, her mood depressed, and her sleeping time increased.
7. Clinical examination at that time revealed a flattened affect and a 22 of 30 Mini-Mental State Examination score.
8. Findings were otherwise normal, and there were no focal neurologic deficits.
9. Basic laboratory workup results were unremarkable.
10. She was referred to a neurologist, who ordered contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain.
11. The MRI (Figure) revealed extensive ill-defined areas of FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery) and T2 signal abnormalities with additional enhancing nodular foci located within deep white matter structures, the basal ganglia, the caudate, the pons, and the midbrain.
12. Also identified was enhancement of the interpeduncular cistern and cerebral peduncles, suggestive of leptomeningeal involvement.
13. Magnetic resonance images (MRIs) of the head obtained 8 months after patient’s first clinical visit.
14. A, Axial T2-weighted MRI of the head at the level of the lateral ventricles demonstrates extensive ill-defined areas of increasing signal with only minimal associated mass effect involving the frontal lobe white matter, greater on the left than on the right.
15. B, Contrast-enhanced T1-weighted MRI at the same level demonstrates abnormal patchy enhancement of the head of the left caudate nucleus and the deep anterior left frontal lobe white matter.
16. Neoplasms such as multicentric glioma, glioblastoma multiforme, and metastases
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Inflammatory demyelinating processes such as multiple sclerosis  
B: Neoplasms such as multicentric glioma, glioblastoma multiforme, and metastases  
C: Infectious causes including tuberculosis, neurosyphilis, and toxoplasmosis  
D: Primary central nervous system lymphoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 42-year-old woman visits the primary care clinic to discuss treatment options for obesity.
2. Over the past six months, she has achieved a 3% reduction in body weight through dietary counseling, participation in a commercial weight loss program, and regular exercise.
3. Her medical history includes diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome, seizure disorder, and insomnia.
4. Current medications include loperamide, levetiracetam, and melatonin.
5. She has a family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2) in her mother but has previously declined genetic testing for MEN2.
6. Her vital signs are normal, and her BMI is 38 kg/m².
7. Physical examination findings are unremarkable.
question_options:
Which of the following medications is the most suitable for managing weight loss in this patient?

A. Orlistat  
B. Lorcaserin  
C. Phentermine-topiramate, extended release  
D. Bupropion alone  
E. Naltrexone-bupropion  
F. Liraglutide  
G. Topiramate monotherapy  
H. Semaglutide  
I. Metformin  
J. Levothyroxine

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with fatigue, malaise, and a painful rash.
2. The patient states that his symptoms have been worsening over the past week.
3. He also has experienced abdominal pain and diarrhea.
4. He has a medical history of obesity and smokes regularly.
5. His temperature is 97.5°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 142/82 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
6. Physical exam is notable for an erythematous rash with papules and plaques on the patient's face, torso, and extremities.
7. He states that the rash is painful.
8. A fingerstick blood glucose is unable to accurately read his blood glucose and gives a reading of > 500 mg/dL.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

A. Alpha cell tumor  
B. Hypercortisolism  
C. Beta cell destruction  
D. Insulin resistance

step1_excerpts:
1. A white man in his 50s initially presented in the fall of 2015 with “macular changes” noticed by his referring optometrist.
2. The patient was asymptomatic at the time.
3. He had a history of hypertension and non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which was last treated in 2012 without evidence of recurrence.
4. His visual acuity was 20/25 OU, and neither fundus was seen to be abnormal.
5. The vitreous was clear in both eyes.
6. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) revealed vitreomacular adhesion in the right eye and a macular posterior vitreous detachment in the left.
7. The patient was told to follow-up as needed.
8. About 2 months later, the patient called on the telephone to say that he had a new onset of blurry vision and photopsias in the right eye that started about 2 days prior.
9. He denied any recent viral-type illness.
10. An examination revealed that his visual acuity was still 20/25 OU.
11. The anterior segment and the anterior vitreous of his right eye were still clear.
12. However, an examination of the posterior pole of the right eye revealed a light white, deep subretinal/choroidal ring surrounding the optic nerve, with smaller rings around the edge of the larger ring (Figure, A).
13. The left eye still appeared normal.
14. Optical coherence tomography of the right eye revealed loss of the outer retina (more nasal than temporal to the fovea), whereas OCT of the left eye revealed that it was normal (Figure, B).
15. The results of fluorescein angiography and fundus autofluorescence were both unremarkable (data not shown).
16. A, Fundus photograph of the right eye at the time of presentation shows a white-gray ring centered on the optic nerve.
17. B, Optical coherence tomography (OCT) of the right eye reveals significant loss of the outer retina, especially nasal to the fovea.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Treatment with oral prednisone  
B: Full laboratory workup for uveitis  
C: Electrophysiology  
D: Orbital imaging (B-scan or computed tomography)

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 50s was referred to the dermatology clinic with a diagnosis of granuloma annulare made on the basis of prior skin biopsy results.  
2. He had been treated by a rheumatologist for polyarticular inflammatory arthritis involving the wrists, metacarpophalangeal joints, and proximal interphalangeal joints, as well as fatigue and dyspnea on exertion.  
3. Examination revealed numerous, pink-purple dermal papules on the trunk and extremities, with preference for the extensor surfaces of the arms (Figure, A) and legs.  
4. No lymphadenopathy was noted.  
5. The patient reported a 5- to 7-kg weight loss without fever or sweats.  
6. His pulmonary and joint symptoms were relieved by daily oral prednisone and flared with taper below 10 mg.  
7. Other medications prescribed included hydroxychloroquine, 400 mg, daily for 18 months and weekly adalimumab injections for 7 months, without improvement.A, Pink-purple papules on the extensor surface of the arms.  
8. B, Biopsy results show a nodular to diffuse lymphohistiocytic infiltrate (hematoxylin-eosin).  
9. C, Admixed atypical, irregularly contoured lymphocytes with numerous histiocytes are present.  
10. D, Biopsy results show low CD4 signal and robust CD8 signal (magnification ×20).Pulmonary function testing revealed mild restrictive disease with decreased forced vital capacity and total lung capacity.  
11. Results of a complete blood cell count and metabolic panel; hemoglobin A1c; viral and rheumatologic panels, including HIV blood tests; chest radiograph; high-resolution chest computed tomographic scan; echocardiography; endoscopic studies; hand radiographs; and serum and urine protein electrophoresis were normal or otherwise unremarkable.  
12. The results of lesional skin biopsies obtained from multiple involved sites initially revealed nonspecific granulomatous dermatitis before a diagnostic biopsy was performed (Figure, B, C, and D).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?  
A: Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma  
B: Granuloma annulare  
C: Small-vessel vasculitis  
D: Sarcoidosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 43-year-old man with generally good health presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of cramps and abdominal pain.
2. For the past year, the patient had been investigated for hypochromic microcytic anemia.
3. As part of the investigation, he underwent an esophagogastroduodenoscopy and a colonoscopy, which revealed a normal-looking bowel with no obvious source of bleeding visualized.
4. Further investigation involved capsule endoscopy, which was ingested 3 days prior to his emergency department admission.
5. The patient claimed not to have passed a bowel movement containing the capsule.
6. Physical examination results were normal except for a nontender distended and tympanic abdomen.
7. Results of routine laboratory testing were essentially normal except for a low level of hemoglobin (8.1 g/dL [to convert to grams per liter, multiply by 10]), with no leukocytosis noted.
8. Contrast-enhanced abdominopelvic computed tomography demonstrated a small-bowel obstruction, with a transition zone located at the mid-jejunum.
9. An intraluminal hypodense mass was demonstrated in this area and appeared to be the cause of the obstruction.
10. Adjacent to this area, the capsule was clearly demonstrated in a dilated proximal loop of the small bowel (Figure 1).Computed tomographic scan showing an intraluminal hypodense mass (pink arrowhead) causing a small-bowel obstruction.
11. Adjacent to this area, the endoscopic capsule (asterisk) is demonstrated in a proximal dilated loop of the small bowel.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Small-bowel adenocarcinoma  
B: Lymphoma of the small bowel  
C: Carcinoid tumor  
D: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor of the small bowel

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 20s presented with a 2-month history of itchy skin lesions on his trunk, arms, and groin.  
2. He was otherwise healthy, with no other underlying conditions, and he was taking no medications.  
3. He had no history of atopic dermatitis or other eczematous dermatoses.  
4. There were no associated extracutaneous symptoms.  
5. His family medical history was relevant only in that his mother had systemic lupus erythematosus.  
6. On physical examination, there were several erythematous annular patches on the abdomen (flanks and periumbilical region), lower back, groin, wrists, and legs (Figure, A).  
7. The lesions showed slightly raised red-brown borders and a clear center in some patches with no visible scaling, hypopigmentation, induration, or atrophy.  
8. Results of laboratory studies including complete blood cell count, biochemical analysis, complement levels, antinuclear antibodies, anti-Ro, anti-La, anti-ribonucleoprotein, anti-Smith, and anti-dsDNA antibodies, as well as serologic testing for syphilis and hepatitis B and C virus, were all normal or negative.  
9. A punch biopsy specimen was obtained for histopathologic evaluation (Figure, B and C).  
10. A, Clinical image shows several erythematous annular patches on the flanks and periumbilical region.  
11. B, Histopathologic analysis of a punch biopsy sample from the abdomen showing superficial lymphocytic infiltrates in the papillary and superficial reticular dermis.  
12. C, There are also prominent vacuolar changes at the dermoepidermal junction, and in some areas mild lymphocytic exocytosis.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Pigmented purpuric dermatosis  
B: Mycosis fungoides  
C: Annular lichenoid dermatitis of youth  
D: Secondary syphilis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 71-year-old man arrives to the emergency room appearing cyanotic and having weak, shallow respirations.
2. He is brought in by his home care nurse, who reports that the patient has a history of myasthenia gravis and frequent urinary tract infections.
3. The patient was in his normal state of health until 5 days ago when he developed a urinary tract infection.
4. He was receiving gentamicin infusions for his infections.
5. This morning, he experienced poor grip strength and progressive difficulty breathing.
6. The patient’s medications include pyridostigmine and aspirin, both of which he takes as prescribed.
7. His temperature is 99.0°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 128/78 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 28/min with an oxygen saturation of 86% O2 on room air.
8. The patient has gray-blue skin, hypophonia, weak upper extremities, and normal leg strength.
9. An arterial blood gas is drawn with results as shown below:

PO2: 55 mmHg
PCO2: 60 mmHg
pH: 7.30

The patient is intubated.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Edrophonium  
B. Plasmapheresis  
C. Thymectomy  
D. Atropine

step1_excerpts:
1. A 26-year-old medical student reports to occupational health after experiencing a needlestick injury while drawing blood from an HIV-positive patient.  
2. The injury occurred when she accidentally stuck herself while capping the needle.  
3. She promptly rinsed the puncture site with saline.  
4. Her last HIV serology test, performed at the start of medical school two years ago, was negative.  
5. She is in a monogamous relationship with one male partner and denies intravenous drug use.  
6. The source patient was recently diagnosed with HIV, has a CD4 count of 550 cells/µL, and a viral load of 1,800,000 copies/mL.  
7. The patient began HAART therapy three days ago.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Repeat HIV serology and initiate triple antiretroviral therapy immediately  
B. Begin post-exposure prophylaxis with two antiretroviral drugs  
C. Immediately initiate triple antiretroviral therapy  
D. Perform rapid HIV test and wait for results before initiating therapy  
E. Administer hepatitis B immune globulin and initiate HIV prophylaxis  
F. Defer treatment until baseline HIV serology results are available  
G. Start dual antiretroviral therapy and monitor viral load  
H. Monitor CD4 count and viral load weekly for 4 weeks  
I. Repeat HIV serology and initiate triple antiretroviral therapy if positive  
J. Initiate single-drug prophylaxis with zidovudine

step1_excerpts:
1. An 18-month-old girl with an unremarkable medical history was referred to ocular oncology from pediatric ophthalmology for an intraocular mass near the optic nerve.
2. Her parents noticed the left eye turning out for the past year.
3. On examination, she fixed and followed with her right eye but not with the left, with 5.0-diopter exophoria at near in the left eye.
4. Penlight examination results showed left leukocoria.
5. Intraocular pressure and motility were normal bilaterally.
6. On subsequent examination under anesthesia, the left optic nerve was obscured by a whitish mass.
7. While the optic nerve itself was obscured, a pigmented crescent could be seen surrounding it (Figure, A).
8. Ultrasonography results demonstrated an elevated retinal mass overlying an excavated optic nerve head.
9. A small focus of hyperechogenicity was noted at the optic nerve head, consistent with calcium (Figure, B).
10. Fluorescein angiography results demonstrated staining of the central whitish mass, which was obscuring the underlying retinal vessels.
11. On fluorescein angiography results, no vessels were seen within the central whitish mass itself.A, Retinal fundus photograph of the left eye demonstrating a whitish mass obscuring the optic nerve with a surrounding pigmented crescent.
12. B, Ultrasonography B-scan of the left eye demonstrating an excavated optic nerve underlying the intraocular mass (arrowheads).Orbital magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to evaluate for optic nerve invasion and brain MRI to assess for a pineal gland tumor, followed by chemotherapy for the eyeObservation for the eye and MRI and magnetic resonance angiography of the headCareful examination of the skin and genetic testing of genes on chromosomes 9 and 16
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Orbital magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to evaluate for optic nerve invasion and brain MRI to assess for a pineal gland tumor, followed by chemotherapy for the eye  
B: Observation for the eye and MRI and magnetic resonance angiography of the head  
C: Careful examination of the skin and genetic testing of genes on chromosomes 9 and 16  
D: Enucleation

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 70s with history of pancreatic adenocarcinoma who had undergone a Whipple procedure 2 years prior to presentation came to the emergency department with a 1-day history of waxing and waning sharp abdominal pain radiating to his back.
2. He admitted to nausea but no vomiting, fevers, or chills.
3. He reported having normal bowel movements and passing flatus without difficulty.
4. On examination, he was afebrile and not tachycardic.
5. He had a well-healed abdominal midline wound.
6. His abdomen was soft, not distended, and mildly tender diffusely, worse in the epigastrium, without rebound, guarding, or any palpable masses.
