2. Her medical history was unremarkable, and she had no allergies.
3. She had been well until 2 hours before the flight home, when at the Havana airport, she developed generalized weakness, increased sweating, severe nausea, and vomiting.
4. In flight, she had lethargy, vomiting, and urinary incontinence.
5. On arrival to the emergency department, she was stuporous and required intubation.
6. Initial laboratory tests showed a hemoglobin level of 10.9 g/dL (reference range, 12.0-15.2 g/dL [to convert to grams per liter, multiply by 10.0]), a creatinine level of 1.31 mg/dL (reference range, 0.51-1.08 [to convert to micromoles per liter, multiply by 88.4]), and a pH of 7.22 with a normal anion gap.
7. Serum electrolyte levels; a white blood cell count; levels of glucose, creatine kinase, lactic acid, and thyrotropin; coagulation studies; and liver function tests had normal results.
8. An electrocardiogram showed sinus bradycardia at 53 bpm and borderline QT interval prolongation (QTc; 465 milliseconds).
9. A urine toxicology screen had negative results for acetaminophen, salicylates, opiates, barbiturates, benzodiazepines, cocaine, and ethanol.
10. Cerebrospinal fluid was clear, with normal levels of glucose, total protein, and white blood cells and negative microbiology and cytology testing results.
11. A malaria smear and antigen test, respiratory viral assay, and cultures of cerebrospinal fluid, blood, and urine had negative results.
12. Computed tomography of the head showed bilateral hyperdensity of the globus pallidi (Figure 1).
13. Within several hours, her level of consciousness improved spontaneously, and she was extubated.
14. Her blood pressure was 99/61 mm Hg; pulse, 80 bpm; temperature, 37.6 °C; and oxygen saturation, 99% on room air.
15. The patient was alert but disoriented.
16. The pupils were 2 mm and reactive.
17. Involuntary facial muscle twitching was noted.
18. Her muscle tone was normal, and she had mild proximal muscle weakness with occasional bilateral upper extremity and lower extremity fasciculations and jerky movements.
19. Deep tendon reflexes were normal, with flexor plantar responses.
20. Her sensations to pain and vibration were normal.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Carbon monoxide poisoning  
B: Methanol poisoning  
C: Organophosphate poisoning  
D: Fahr disease

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 60s with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma was admitted for fevers, sepsis, and Enterococcus faecalis urinary tract infection in the context of bilateral malignant ureteral obstruction.
2. Physical examination was notable for a genital vesicular rash; a culture of the skin lesion yielded herpes simplex virus (HSV).
3. Blood cultures were positive for Candida glabrata, triggering an ophthalmology consultation to rule out ocular candidiasis.
4. The patient reported blurry vision in both eyes for 1 week.
5. Visual acuity was 20/100 OD and 20/50 OS.
6. Intraocular pressures, pupillary responses, and results of a portable slitlamp examination were normal.
7. Dilated fundus examination revealed bilateral optic nerve edema with disc hemorrhages in the right eye (Figure, A).
8. On extended ophthalmoscopy, subtle areas of granular retinal whitening were noted in the peripheral retina.
9. No vitritis was appreciable.
10. Fluorescein angiography exhibited disc hyperfluorescence (Figure, A [inset]) and late peripheral staining in both eyes.
11. Optical coherence tomography demonstrated thickening of the papillary nerve fiber layer (Figure, B).
12. Automated perimetry demonstrated bilateral enlargement of the physiological blind spot and bilateral arcuate scotomas, greater in the right eye.
13. A, Right fundus image shows optic nerve edema with disc hemorrhages and peripheral retinal whitening (arrowhead).
14. Corresponding fluorescein angiography shows disc hyperfluorescence (inset).
15. B, Horizontal line scan through the right optic nerve illustrates thickening of the papillary nerve fiber layer.
16. Diagnostic anterior chamber paracentesis with intravitreal injection of foscarnet sodium
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Intravitreal injection of amphotericin B  
B: Diagnostic anterior chamber paracentesis with intravitreal injection of foscarnet sodium  
C: Diagnostic vitrectomy  
D: Stereotactic radiation therapy to the optic nerve

step1_excerpts:
1. A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of abdominal pain.
2. She has a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, sinusitis, and pancreatitis.
3. She has thick nasal secretions.
4. She says that her sweat is salty and crystallizes on her skin.
5. Her vital signs are within normal limits.
6. Physical examination shows epigastric tenderness.
7. Genetic testing for the 36 most common mutations shows a detectable mutation (G551D) in one allele of the CFTR gene.
question_options:
Which of the following best explains this patient's clinical phenotype?

A. Only one G551D allele is needed in CFTR

B. The patient is a CFTR obligate carrier

C. The patient's CFTR mutation is unrelated to her clinical phenotype

D. The second CFTR mutation was not detected by the testing obtained

step1_excerpts:
1. A 36-year-old man presents to the office for follow up after initiating antidepressant therapy.  
2. Two months ago, he was started on citalopram after several weeks of depressed mood, loss of interest in activities, depressed appetite, and inability to sleep.  
3. Today, he reports minimal improvement in his symptoms.  
4. He had some nausea after starting the medication, but this has resolved.  
5. He denies thoughts of suicide or self-harm.  
6. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, respirations are 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air.  
7. Exam reveals a depressed, tired appearing man.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Switch to paroxetine  
B. Switch to phenelzine  
C. Electroconvulsive therapy  
D. Add mirtazapine

step1_excerpts:
1. A middle-aged man sought treatment for a painful nonhealing foot ulcer of 1-year duration.
2. The lesion had started on the left foot as a painful blister that eventually ruptured to form an ulcer, which subsequently progressed.
3. During this time, multiple hypopigmented asymptomatic lesions appeared on his face and scalp.
4. A diagnosis of multibacillary leprosy was considered previously in another health care facility for which multidrug therapy with rifampicin, 600 mg/mo, dapsone, 100 mg/d, and clofazimine, 50 mg/d, was administered for 6 months.
5. There was no appreciable clinical improvement.
6. On physical examination, an 8 × 6-cm ulcer was noted on the lateral aspect of the dorsum of the left foot (Figure, A).
7. The ulcer was well defined with regular margins, and the floor was covered by a yellowish slough.
8. Perilesional tenderness and pitting edema were observed.
9. Multiple ill-defined, hypopigmented patches of various sizes were present on the scalp and face (Figure, B).
10. Lesional appendages and sensations were preserved.
11. Inguinal lymph nodes on both sides were enlarged, nontender, and movable.
12. Peripheral nerve trunks were not thickened, and peripheral arteries could be easily palpated.
13. Skin punch biopsy specimens were obtained from the ulcer (Figure, C and D) and a hypopigmented facial lesion.A, Nonhealing ulcer.
14. B, Ill-defined hypopigmented macules on the left side of the face.
15. Lesional skin appendages are preserved.
16. C, Histologic analysis showing acute ulceration of the epidermis with granulation tissue and infiltrating neutrophils and macrophages (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×100).
17. D, Histologic analysis showing intracellular and extracellular inclusion bodies (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×1000).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Borderline lepromatous leprosy with trophic ulcer  
B: Tropical phagedenic ulcer  
C: Post–kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis  
D: Cutaneous diphtheria

step1_excerpts:
1. A 48-year-old male patient reports experiencing recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and diarrhea over the past year.
2. He describes his stools as watery, frothy, and bulky, with some episodes occurring without associated abdominal pain.
3. Additionally, he mentions three episodes of intense flushing over his head and neck without an identifiable cause.
4. Physical examination reveals no significant abnormalities.
5. Further diagnostic evaluation confirms the presence of metastasized carcinoid tumors.
6. The physician discusses the condition with the patient and recommends long-term treatment with octreotide.
question_options:
Which of the following conditions is most likely to occur as a side effect of this medication?

A. Hypocortisolism  
B. Hypomagnesemia  
C. Hypocalcemia  
D. Hypophosphatemia  
E. Hypokalemia  
F. Hypothyroidism  
G. Hypogonadism  
H. Hyperglycemia  
I. Hyponatremia  
J. Hypoparathyroidism

step1_excerpts:
1. A young girl with an unremarkable medical history presented with 1 week of drowsiness, double vision, and left cranial nerve VI and VII palsies.
2. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed T2-weighted and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery changes with associated patchy enhancement in the brainstem, left frontal lobe, left cingulate gyrus, and left parietal lobe without restricted diffusion (Figure, A and B).
3. Cervical spine imaging results were negative.
4. Cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) study results were unremarkable (red blood cell count, 0 × 106/µL [to convert to ×1012/L, multiply by 12]; white blood cell count, 0/µL [to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001]; glucose, 61 mg/dL [to convert to millimoles per liter, multiply by 0.0555]; and total protein, 19 g/dL [to convert to grams per liter, multiply by 10]), and CSF cytologic test results were negative for malignancy.
5. Oligoclonal bands and IgG index were not measured.
6. The results of serum cell-based aquaporin 4 antibody tests were negative.
7. She was diagnosed with acute demyelinating encephalomyelitis (ADEM) and received 5 days of high-dose intravenous corticosteroids followed by a 1-month course of oral prednisone with improvement back to baseline in 3 weeks.Brain magnetic resonance imaging during initial presentation: T2-weighted and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) hyperintensity in the left frontal lobe (A) and associated enhancement on T1-weighted postcontrast imaging (B).
8. Brain magnetic resonance imaging during second attack: resolution of the initial left frontal lobe lesion now with T2-weighted and FLAIR recovery hyperintensity in the left parietotemporal region (C) with associated patchy enhancement (D).She presented again, 15 months later, with 2 weeks of dysarthria and progressive ataxia without change in mental status.
9. Subsequent brain MRI revealed resolution of the prior supratentorial involvement and new T2/fluid-attenuated inversion recovery changes with patchy enhancement in the brainstem and a large new lesion in the left parietotemporal area (Figure, C and D).
10. Head magnetic resonance angiography findings were unremarkable.
11. The CSF studies revealed a mild lymphocytic pleocytosis (white blood cell count of 11/µL with 3 neutrophils, 6 lymphocytes, and 2 monocytes) with 1 red blood cell, glucose level of 57 mg/dL, and total protein level of 39 g/dL.
12. The results of the CSF viral polymerase chain reaction studies, including cytomegalovirus, varicella-zoster virus, herpes simplex virus, enterovirus, and Epstein-Barr virus, were negative.
13. The CSF bacterial culture returned without growth.
14. The results of tests for the CSF oligoclonal bands and IgG index were negative.
15. The patient received pulse dose corticosteroids (intravenous solumedrol, 30 mg/kg per dose every 24 hours) for 5 days with resolution of her truncal ataxia during hospitalization.
16. She was discharged with a month-long oral prednisone taper starting at 20 mg/d.
17. When tapered down to prednisone, 5 mg every other day, she developed a right facial droop with recurrent ataxia.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Multiple sclerosis  
B: Central nervous system lymphoma  
C: Autoimmune encephalitis  
D: Neurosarcoidosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 60s presented with a painless rapidly enlarging ulcer on his left leg 1 week after the onset of diverticulitis, a neutropenic fever, and severe sepsis due to multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection that necessitated admission to the intensive care unit.
2. His medical history included a heart transplant for ischemic cardiomyopathy in his early 50s, and he was receiving long-term immunosuppressive therapy with cyclosporine, mycophenolate mofetil, and deflazacort.
3. He had received a diagnosis of plasmablastic lymphoma 6 months earlier and was being treated with polychemotherapy (cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin hydrochloride, vincristine sulfate, and prednisone [CHOP] regimen).
4. Physical examination revealed a well-demarcated 5 × 5-cm round ulcer with raised border, surrounding erythema, and a base with purulent debris (Figure 1A).
5. A superficial swab culture sample grew P aeruginosa.
6. A punch biopsy specimen from the edge of the ulcer was obtained and sent for histopathologic evaluation (Figure 1B).
7. A, Cutaneous ulcer on the patient’s left leg with a raised erythematous border and a base with purulent debris.
8. B, Diagnostic biopsy shows enlarged endothelial cells with intranuclear inclusions surrounded by a clear halo, and some cytoplasmic inclusions.
9. Similar findings are detected in some macrophages (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×400).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Ecthyma gangrenosum  
B: Cytomegalovirus ulcer  
C: Mucormycosis ulcer  
D: Pyoderma gangrenosum

step1_excerpts:
1. A 51-year-old man presents for his annual wellness visit with his primary care physician.
2. His wife has noticed a tremor while he is working on his car and knows that his father died of Parkinson disease.
3. He says that the tremor is nothing to worry about and only occurs during a few activities such as pouring drinks, pointing the remote at the television, or fixing his car.
4. The patient states his wife is just overreacting.
5. His medical problems include hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia for which he takes lisinopril, metformin, and atorvastatin.
6. He has 3-5 drinks of scotch per night before working on his car.
7. On physical exam, the tremor is replicated during finger to nose testing.
8. Romberg sign is negative.
9. Cranial nerves II-XII are intact.
10. The rest of the exam is benign.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's tremor?

A. Alcoholics anonymous  
B. Aripiprazole  
C. Phenobarbital  
D. Propranolol

step1_excerpts:
1. A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department for a persistent fever.
2. The patient has felt unwell for the past week and has felt subjectively febrile.
3. The patient has a medical history of a suicide attempt and alcohol abuse.
4. He is not currently taking any medications.
5. The patient admits to using heroin and cocaine and drinking 5-8 alcoholic drinks per day.
6. His temperature is 103°F (39.4°C), blood pressure is 92/59 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air.
7. Cardiopulmonary exam is notable for a systolic murmur heard best along the left sternal border.
8. Dermatologic exam reveals scarring in the antecubital fossa.
9. IV fluids are administered and the blood pressure is subsequently 120/70 mmHg.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for the most likely underlying diagnosis?

A. Blood cultures  
B. CT scan  
C. Ultrasound  
D. Vancomycin and gentamicin

step1_excerpts:
1. A 45-year-old morbidly obese woman with a history of asthma and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to her primary care physician for advice on weight loss.
2. She thinks that her husband is having sex with other women because they have not had sex over the past year.
3. She feels that her co-workers also disrespect her for her weight and constant sweat stains around her armpits and chest.
4. She has noticed that the sweat stains get itchy and induce a burning sensation unless she showers or changes her shirt.
5. She has been compliant with her medications, which include albuterol, metformin, glyburide, and atorvastatin.
6. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 128/85 mmHg, pulse is 91/min, and respirations are 11/min.
7. On physical exam, the patient has a flat affect, with moist oral mucosa and nasal polyps.
8. She denies sinus tenderness.
9. Her neck is thick with a posterior cervical fat pad.
10. During cardiac auscultation, the finding in Figure A is noted below her breasts.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in management for this finding?

A. Topical nystatin  
B. Topical clobetasol  
C. Prednisone  
D. Fluconazole

step1_excerpts:
1. An otherwise healthy white man in his 40s was referred to the cornea service for decreased vision in the setting of a white cataract in his left eye.  
2. The patient reported the acute onset of foreign body sensation in his left eye while splitting wood 1 year prior.  
3. He attended a hospital emergency department at that time and was diagnosed with a corneal abrasion and treated with topical antibiotics.  
4. He stated that his vision initially returned to normal after treatment, but had subsequently worsened.  
5. He complained of tearing, photophobia, and burning in the left eye.  
6. The visual acuity was hand motions OS with a grossly constricted visual field by confrontation.  
7. The intraocular pressure was normal.  
8. The anterior segment examination revealed mild edema of the cornea, a shallow anterior chamber, iris heterochromia (Figure 1A), and an intumescent white cataract with pigment deposition on the anterior lens capsule.  
9. The cataract precluded visualization of the fundus.  
10. B-scan ultrasonography did not reveal masses, retinal detachment, or foreign body (Figure 1B).  
11. Heterochromia iridis.  
12. A, External photograph displaying significant heterochromia.  
13. B, B-scan ultrasonography image of the left eye.  
14. Computed tomography scan of the orbits without contrast Magnetic resonance imaging of the orbits without contrast Phacoemulsification with intraocular lens placement in the left eye
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  
A: Observation  
B: Computed tomography scan of the orbits without contrast  
C: Magnetic resonance imaging of the orbits without contrast  
D: Phacoemulsification with intraocular lens placement in the left eye

step1_excerpts:
1. A 42-year-old female presents to the ED with symptoms of recurring chest pressure accompanied by jaw pain radiation.
2. Her ECG demonstrates ST-segment elevation, while cardiac enzyme levels remain normal on both initial and follow-up testing hours later.
3. Her vital signs show a heart rate of 82/min and blood pressure of 128/76 mm Hg.
4. Upon cardiac examination, heart sounds are regular without any friction rub detected.
question_options:
Given this patient's suspected diagnosis, which therapeutic combination would be most appropriate?

A. Aspirin, clopidogrel, beta blockers, and nitrates  
B. Aspirin and beta blockers  
C. Aspirin and clopidogrel  
D. Beta blockers, nitrates, and aspirin  
E. Statins and beta blockers  
F. Calcium channel blockers and nitrates  
G. Low molecular weight heparin and nitrates  
H. ACE inhibitors and aspirin  
I. Nitrates only  
J. Coronary stenting with dual antiplatelet therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a rash.
2. He first noticed the rash 2 weeks prior and he endorses intermittent itchiness from the rash.
3. His medical history is significant for chronic hepatitis C infection, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and heart failure.
4. The patient works as a butcher at a local meat processing shop and is sexually active with several partners.
5. He does not use barrier protection.
6. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), pulse is 90/min, blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg, and respirations are 12/min.
7. On physical exam, his skin has the finding shown in Figure A.
8. Fine, lace-like white lines are also noted on the patient’s buccal mucosa.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Atopic dermatitis  
B. Lichen planus  
C. Scabies  
D. Psoriasis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 72-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia presents to his primary care provider for concerns about his cognitive decline.
2. His wife has noticed that he has a worsening ability to organize, plan, and exhibit impulse control over the last month.
3. The patient states that he is able to complete his activities of daily living without assistance, but has some weakness of his left upper and lower extremities that began 3 months prior.
4. He needs reminders from his wife about daily tasks to complete.
5. He enjoys spending time with his spouse, playing cards with his friends, and taking daily walks around his neighborhood.
6. His temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 149/87 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and respirations are 12/min.
7. Physical exam reveals an elderly man who is oriented to person, place, and time.
8. He has 4/5 left-sided weakness of the upper and lower extremities and associated pronator drift of the left upper extremity.
9. A mini-mental status exam reveals he is able to remember 2 out of 3 words after 4 minutes.
10. He is able to appropriately draw a clock.
11. A magnetic resonance imaging study of the brain is shown in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Normal aging  
B. Vascular dementia  
C. Pseudodementia  
D. Mild cognitive impairment

step1_excerpts:
1. A 35-year-old man is brought into the emergency department by ambulance for a stab wound to the left leg near the inguinal ligament.  
2. The patient has no significant medical history, and takes no other medication.  
3. He was not stabbed or otherwise injured elsewhere.  
4. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), pulse is 130, blood pressure is 85/50, and respirations are 22.  
5. Primary and secondary survey and FAST exam are unremarkable for other associated injuries.  
6. Pressure is removed from the wound, and pulsatile bleeding from the wound is noted.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Emergent surgical intervention  
B. Wound closure  
C. Observation  
D. CT scan of the left lower extremity

step1_excerpts:
1. A 33-year-old female presents to the office with the complaint of chronic pelvic pain that began after she underwent a hysterectomy 6 months ago.  
2. Following a physical examination, a CT scan of the pelvis is ordered.  
3. After the scan is complete, the radiologist calls to report that the patient has a surgical sponge in her pelvis.  
4. In a subsequent malpractice suit, the plaintiff establishes that the sponge could not have been left unless there was negligence.
question_options:
The most appropriate term to represent the legal concept invoked by the patient is

A. collateral estoppel

B. proximate cause

C. res ipsa loquitur

D. respondeat superior

step1_excerpts:
1. A 40-year-old male with a history of four episodes of calcium-containing kidney stones over the past 4 years presents for follow-up one week after passing an unrecovered stone.
2. His vital signs show blood pressure 124/76 mm Hg, heart rate 72/min, and weight 92 kg.
3. Laboratory studies reveal normal serum electrolytes, calcium, uric acid, and parathyroid hormone.
4. His 24-hour urine collection shows elevated sodium (190 mEq/24 hr), calcium (378 mg/24 hr), and oxalate (44 mg/24 hr), with low citrate (204 mg/24 hr) and alkaline pH (7.1).
5. Imaging reveals two 3-4 mm radiopaque stones in the left kidney.
question_options:
Beyond lifestyle modifications including sodium restriction and increased fluid intake, which of the following is the most appropriate therapeutic intervention?

A. Start a low-calcium diet  
B. Initiate allopurinol  
C. Initiate bisphosphonate therapy  
D. Initiate furosemide  
E. Initiate potassium citrate  
F. Restrict dietary calcium  
G. Initiate acetazolamide  
H. Initiate sodium bicarbonate  
I. Recommend vitamin D supplementation  
J. Initiate chlorthalidone

step1_excerpts:
1. A 35-year-old individual with trisomy 21 and a history of repaired partial atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) is admitted due to the recent onset of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular conduction.
2. Following medical therapy, the ventricular rate appropriately decreases, and perfusion remains normal.
3. Physical examination reveals a prominent apical impulse and a grade III/VI harsh systolic ejection murmur at the upper sternal border.
4. Echocardiography demonstrates a mean left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) gradient of 55 mm Hg at rest.
question_options:
Which therapeutic intervention is most appropriate for this patient?

A. Watchful waiting with serial echocardiography  
B. Administration of digoxin therapy  
C. Aortic balloon valvuloplasty  
D. Surgical outflow tract repair  
E. Chronic β-blockade therapy  
F. Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty  
G. Alcohol septal ablation  
H. Dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel  
I. Transcatheter mitral valve replacement  
J. Catheter-based ablation of atrial fibrillation

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 30s was referred for evaluation of corneal opacities.
2. Her medical history was notable for keratoconjunctivitis sicca, Hashimoto thyroiditis, and anti–interferon-γ autoantibody syndrome treated with 6 monthly rituximab infusions (375 mg/m2 with 100 mg of methylprednisolone acetate).
3. Infusions were given weekly for the first 3 weeks and then every 6 to 8 months based on a CD20 count.
4. She had previously been diagnosed with disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection requiring 2 years of treatment with rifabutin, 300 mg/d; ethambutol hydrochloride, 1000 mg/d; and clarithromycin in a divided dose, 500 mg twice a day.
5. This treatment concluded 2½ years before presentation.
6. In addition, she had a long-standing history of arthralgias with intermittent arthritis treated with hydroxychloroquine, 300 mg/d, that was discontinued 2 years before presentation.
7. On examination, she had no visual concerns.
8. Her visual acuity was 20/20 OU.
9. Conjunctivas were normal, lenses were clear, and anterior chambers were deep and quiet.
10. The results from the slitlamp examination showed numerous bilateral, peripheral light brown corneal opacities.
11. The opacities were located in the far posterior corneae and were present circumferentially (Figure, A).
12. There was no associated keratitis or corneal neovascularization.
13. Anterior segment optical coherence tomographic findings showed focal areas of hyperreflectivity anterior to the Descemet membrane.
14. Confocal microscopy revealed variably shaped, hyperreflective clusters of opacities just anterior to the endothelium (Figure, B).
15. Imaging of the right eye of a patient with rifabutin-related posterior corneal deposits.
16. A, Slitlamp photograph with arrowhead highlighting one of numerous bilateral peripheral, small corneal light brown opacities.
17. B, Confocal microscopic image captured at a slightly oblique angle illustrates normal endothelial cells (yellow arrowhead).
18. Just anterior to the endothelium, the drug deposit appears as variably shaped, hyperreflective clusters of opacities (white arrowhead).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Start treatment with topical corticosteroids  
B: Start treatment with topical antibiotics  
C: Plan a descemetorhexis and posterior cornea biopsy  
D: Reassure the patient and observe

step1_excerpts:
1. A 75-year-old woman comes to the office because she has band-like, burning pain in her right upper abdomen extending from the epigastrium around to the midline of the back.  
2. Physical examination discloses no abdominal tenderness to palpation.  
3. Findings on ultrasonography of the gallbladder are normal.  
4. Serum amylase concentration is within the reference range.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acalculous cholecystitis

B. Chronic relapsing pancreatitis

C. Diverticulitis of the cecum

D. Herpes zoster

step1_excerpts:
1. A 52-year-old female presents to the office with the complaint of greenish discharge from her left nipple.
2. There is no history of trauma or fever, and the patient is not currently using oral contraceptives nor is she on hormone replacement therapy.
3. Her last pregnancy was approximately 20 years ago.
4. Physical examination findings are normal except for the green discharge.
question_options:
The most likely cause of this patient's presenting complaint is

A. breast cancer

B. fibrocystic disease

C. mammary duct ectasia

D. pituitary adenoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 2-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician with her mother for a routine well-child visit.
2. Her mother is concerned that the patient is a picky eater and refuses to eat vegetables.
3. She drinks milk with meals and has juice sparingly.
4. She goes to sleep easily at night and usually sleeps for 11-12 hours.
5. The patient has trouble falling asleep for naps but does nap for 1-2 hours a few times per week.
6. She is doing well in daycare and enjoys parallel play with the other children.
7. Her mother reports that she can walk downstairs with both feet on each step.
8. She has a vocabulary of 10-25 words that she uses in the form of 1 word commands.
9. She is in the 42nd percentile for height and 48th percentile for weight, which is consistent with her growth curves.
10. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 92/56 mmHg, pulse is 106/min, and respirations are 23/min.
11. On physical exam, she appears well nourished.
12. She can copy a line and throw a ball.
question_options:
She can follow the command to “give me the ball and then close the door.” Which of the following is abnormal in this patient?

A. Fine motor skills  
B. Social and receptive language skills  
C. This child is developmentally normal  
D. Expressive language skills

step1_excerpts:
1. A 56-year-old woman with no medical comorbidities presented to her primary care clinician with postprandial retrosternal burning that occurred multiple times daily for several years.
2. She had no dysphagia, gastrointestinal bleeding, weight loss, anemia, or exertional chest pain.
3. Over-the-counter antacids provided incomplete benefit.
4. She was prescribed proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy with esomeprazole 40 mg, which she took daily, 30 minutes before breakfast.
5. Her heartburn did not improve and continued to bother her daily despite adding famotidine at bedtime.
6. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) results, with esophageal mucosal biopsies, were normal.
7. She was referred for esophageal physiologic testing for possible gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
8. Twenty-four-hour ambulatory reflux monitoring was performed after acid suppressive medications were discontinued for 1 week (Table).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Increase esomeprazole to 40 mg twice daily.  
B: Perform a barium esophagogram.  
C: Refer to a surgeon for antireflux surgery.  
D: Replace esomeprazole with nortriptyline.

step1_excerpts:
1. A 39-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with a 3-week history of worsening spasms in her axial and lower limb muscles and new-onset urinary retention.
2. Sudden episodes of painful involuntary spasms first appeared in her abdominal muscles 2 weeks after a cold.
3. Soon after, spasms spread to all of her axial muscles and both lower limbs.
4. These paroxysmal episodes lasted a few seconds, occurred up to 20 times a day, and were exacerbated by external stimuli.
5. There was no impairment of consciousness during the attacks.
6. A review of her previous records revealed a diagnosis of Hashimoto thyroiditis 1 month earlier.
7. She had no history of tobacco, alcohol, or drug use.
8. She had hyperhidrosis and tachypnea on admission.
9. Neurological examination results disclosed an abnormal mental status.
10. Cranial nerve examination results demonstrated slow saccades.
11. Motor system examination results revealed a symmetric and severe hypertonia and rigidity throughout her trunk and all 4 extremities.
12. Further notable occurrences were severe spasms (Figure, A; Video 1) and patella clonus associated with brisk deep tendon reflexes (Video 2).
13. She demonstrated marked myoclonus on tactile and acoustic stimulation.
14. Extensor plantar responses were present bilaterally.
15. A, Patient experiencing spasms.
16. B, Electromyography examination of the patient.
17. Laboratory results were significant for an elevated level of thyroperoxidase antibodies (50.85 IU/mL; normal, <5.16 IU/mL) and thyroglobulin antibodies (88.35 ng/mL; normal: <4.11 ng/mL; to convert to micrograms per liter, multiply by 1).
18. Cerebrospinal fluid testing results revealed normal protein level and cell counts, as well as absent oligoclonal bands or evidence of infection.
19. Her paraneoplastic panel results were negative.
20. Cranial and spinal magnetic resonance imaging yielded no abnormalities.
21. Needle electromyography (EMG) results showed a continuous firing of normal motor unit potentials at rest within the axial and lower limb muscles (Figure, B; Video 3).
22. A routine electroencephalogram (EEG) showed mild background slowing without periodic discharges.
23. Computed tomography scan results of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis were negative.
24. An electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Progressive myoclonic epilepsies (PMEs)  
B: Faciobrachial dystonic seizures  
C: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)  
D: Progressive encephalomyelitis with rigidity and myoclonus (PERM)

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 50s with diagnoses of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, hepatitis B, and latent tuberculosis presented with a slow-growing nodule on the left foot.
2. The lesion started 1 year prior as a tender red nodule on the medial aspect of his first metatarsophalangeal joint, which would enlarge and become painful approximately once a month (Figure, A).
3. The patient reported that with manipulation, a clear-to-yellow material drained from the lesion.
4. The patient denied any purulent drainage, additional skin lesions, fever, chills, or other systemic symptoms.
5. His medications included efavirenz–emtricitabine–tenofovir disoproxil fumarate for his HIV, with the most recent absolute CD4-positive cell count of 341 cells/mm3 (reference range, 263-2045 cells/mm3), and recent completion of an 8-month course of isoniazid treatment after being exposed to tuberculosis.
6. Physical examination demonstrated an erythematous papulonodule without warmth or drainage on the dorsal left great toe.
7. No lymphadenopathy was appreciated.
8. A punch biopsy was performed (Figure, B, C, and D) to help establish the diagnosis.A, Clinical photograph of slow-growing red papulonodule on the left toe dorsal foot.
9. B, Biopsy with hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) staining demonstrating acral skin with acute and chronic inflammation within the deep dermis.
10. C, Higher magnification highlights eosinophilic material surrounding small cocci.
11. D, Gram staining of the biopsy supported the diagnosis.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Botryomycosis  
B: Cutaneous tuberculosis  
C: Digital mucous cyst  
D: Foreign-body reaction

step1_excerpts:
1. A 54-year-old woman comes to the office because she has had intermittent shooting pain over her right cheek and jaw during the past 3 weeks.
2. Each episode of pain lasts for 1 second or less.
3. The pain is often triggered by cold air, chewing, tactile stimulation, and brushing her teeth.
4. She has had no trauma to the face or head.
5. Medical history is remarkable for tension headaches, obesity, and gastric bypass surgery.
6. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2 .
7. Vital signs are normal.
8. The patient cannot tolerate touch over the right side of the face.
9. There is no facial weakness or loss of sensation.
10. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities.
11. CT scan of the head with and without contrast shows no abnormalities.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy at this time?

A. Carbamazepine

B. Lamotrigine

C. Levetiracetam

D. Topiramate

step1_excerpts:
1. A 58-year-old overweight African American man presented with a 5-year history of a slightly pruritic and painful rash of the right lateral area of the neck and right axilla.
2. It was worse during the summers, and blisters sometimes developed.
3. Emollients were unhelpful.
4. The patient was otherwise healthy.
5. His sister had diabetes mellitus and a similar rash in her axillae.
6. The patient performed indoor manual labor as a maintenance engineer and had no significant sun exposure.
7. Physical examination revealed irregularly thickened skin of the right axilla (Figure 1, left) and right lateral area of the neck (Figure 1, right) containing hyperpigmentation, hypopigmentation, multiple acrochordons (skin tags), malodorous crust, and areas of maceration and erosion.
8. Further examination of the skin revealed pseudofolliculitis barbae in the submental and mandibular regions bilaterally.
9. The nails, oral cavity, and mucosal membranes appeared normal.
10. A biopsy of right axillary skin was performed (Figure 2).Left, Rash of right axilla.
11. Right, Rash of right lateral area of the neck with global view and close-up view (inset).Epidermal acantholysis causing separation of keratinocytes into dilapidated brick wall appearance (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×10).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Prescribe topical ketoconazole  
B: Obtain glycated hemoglobin (HbA1C) level  
C: Prescribe a topical corticosteroid and a topical antimicrobial  
D: Consult for surgical excision

step1_excerpts:
1. A healthy woman in her 20s presented with a 5-month history of a painful erythematous eruption over her bilateral thighs.
2. She reported that the eruption was worsening during the winter months.
3. She had not experienced any fevers, chills, joint pains, recent weight loss, or any other constitutional symptoms.
4. She was a nonsmoker and took no medications.
5. A review of her social history revealed that she was working at a horse stable and rode for many hours a day.
6. On physical examination, distributed over the bilateral posterior lateral thighs, there were several arcuate to circinate erythematous to violaceous plaques.
7. There were also several focal areas of ulceration with overlying scale-crust (Figure, A and B).
8. A biopsy was performed during this initial visit (Figure, C and D).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Erythema annulare centrifugum  
B: Subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus  
C: Palisaded neutrophilic and granulomatous dermatitis  
D: Equestrian perniosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 19-month-old boy presented for evaluation of widespread edema and acute dermatitis.
2. Following an upper respiratory tract infection 1 month prior, he developed disseminated red, scaly patches and a progressive eruption of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented patches of skin.
3. He had occasional nonbloody loose stools but no fevers or vomiting.
4. Although he was otherwise well, his growth had fallen from the 75th to the 25th percentile for height and weight over the preceding 9 months, and he could speak only 2 words.
5. His medical history was notable for atopic dermatitis and diarrhea in infancy that prompted allergy testing at age 6 months; he was subsequently diagnosed with milk, egg, and peanut allergies.
6. His parents avoided feeding him these foods, providing him only soy-based milk and formula, with improvement of dermatitis, until age 1 year.
7. Since then his diet had consisted of multiple rice milk feeds daily, supplemented only with pureed fruits and vegetables, pasta, snack puffs, and sunflower butter.
8. The patient had no history of meconium ileus or family history of cystic fibrosis.
9. There was no recent travel and no changes to the home environment.
10. On presentation, the patient was irritable, with normal vital signs.
11. He displayed prominent scrotal swelling and pitting edema of the legs bilaterally.
12. Skin examination was notable for erythematous, denuded patches with peeling scale and reticulate hyperpigmentation, accentuated on the abdomen, back, diaper area, and extensor extremities (Figure; left panel).
13. Notably, his skin also demonstrated widespread patches of hypopigmentation, with an accompanying band of hypopigmentation proximally at the site of newest hair growth (Figure; right panel).
14. Physical examination findings at presentation.
15. Left, Right abdomen, back, buttock, and thigh.
16. Right, Site of newest scalp hair growth.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Check levels of serum protein, albumin, prealbumin, and other nutritional laboratory measures  
B: Check urinalysis and urine microscopy to evaluate for protein in urine  
C: Perform a skin biopsy  
D: Treat with topical steroids

step1_excerpts:
1. A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the office by his mother because of a 2-day history of white lesions in the mouth.
2. The infant was born at term via uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery; he has been breast-feeding well and is urinating and having bowel movements normally.
3. At birth, he weighed 3289 g (7 lb 4 oz; 30th percentile).
4. Today, he weighs 3629 kg (8 lb; 25th percentile).
5. He appears adequately hydrated.
6. Vital signs are normal.
7. Physical examination discloses white patches on the tongue and buccal mucosa that do not come off when gently scraped with a tongue blade.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

A. Acyclovir

B. Fluconazole

C. Nystatin

D. Valacyclovir

step1_excerpts:
1. An 8-year-old girl was referred to the vitreoretinal service for evaluation of bilateral macular lesions noted by her pediatric ophthalmologist.  
2. Bilateral lateral rectus muscle recession for exotropia was performed 4 years before this presentation.  
3. Medical history was otherwise unremarkable.  
4. The patient was born full term after a normal pregnancy and delivery, with normal growth assessments.  
5. The patient was performing well in school.  
6. On examination, her best-corrected visual acuity was 20/40 OD and 20/40 OS, which was stable from previous visits.  
7. Her pupils were round and reactive.  
8. There was a residual intermittent exotropia of 4 prism diopters bilaterally.  
9. Findings on slitlamp examination of the anterior segment were unremarkable.  
10. A single, 1-cm, oval, lightly pigmented macule with irregular borders was noted on her right upper arm.  
11. Dilated fundus examination revealed eccentric, yellow-clear, preretinal lesions in the maculas of both eyes.  
12. Optical coherence tomography revealed hyperreflective areas on the surface of the macula with a spiculated appearance, projecting anteriorly into the vitreous.  
13. There was an increase in retinal thickness and loss of the foveal contour in both eyes (Figure).  
14. Optical coherence tomography of the right eye (A) showing an atypical epiretinal membrane with anterior projection into the vitreous and hazy borders and the left eye (B) showing a similar epiretinal membrane with mild anterior projection and hazy borders.  
15. Obtain a family medical history and genetic testing Recommend pars plana vitrectomy with epiretinal membrane peel
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  
A: Obtain a family medical history and genetic testing  
B: Recommend pars plana vitrectomy with epiretinal membrane peel  
C: Observe the lesions  
D: Give an intravitreal ocriplasmin injection

step1_excerpts:
1. A 48-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 3, presents to the clinic with a 5-month history of intermittent loss of urine.
2. Her urinary leaking occurs throughout the day and night, and she often has to get up to use the bathroom while asleep.
3. Exercising does not affect the loss of urine.
4. She states that she often cannot make it to the bathroom in time once she senses a need to void.
5. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago.
6. Her urinalysis is unremarkable, and her postvoid residual volume is 40 mL.
7. On pelvic examination, there is no dribbling of urine when the patient coughs.
8. Physical exam is otherwise unremarkable.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Overflow incontinence  
B. Urge incontinence  
C. Stress incontinence  
D. Mixed urinary incontinence

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her early 50s with a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome, diabetes, stroke, and coronary artery disease that required coronary artery bypass graft 6 years earlier presented to the emergency department with 12 hours of sudden-onset, constant, right lower quadrant abdominal pain associated with vomiting and melena.
2. She denied any hematochezia or history of peptic ulcer disease.
3. She had no other surgical history and denied alcohol use or smoking.
4. On examination, she was hypertensive (blood pressure, 185/85 mm Hg) although not tachycardic and was afebrile.
5. She was locally tender to palpation in the right lower quadrant with rebound and voluntary guarding.
6. Her abdomen was not tympanitic.
7. The patient had no abdominal scars, hernias, or palpable masses.
8. Laboratory results were significant for the following: leukocyte count, 23 600/µL (to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001) with neutrophilia (94%); blood urea nitrogen level, 28 mg/dL (to convert to millimoles per liter, multiply by 0.357); creatinine concentration, 0.01 mg/dL (to convert to micromoles per liter, multiply by 88.4); lipase concentration, 195 U/L (to convert to microkatals per liter, multiply by 0.0167); and lactate concentration, 2.02 mg/dL (to convert to millimoles per liter, multiply by 0.111).
9. Electrolyte levels and liver function test results were within normal limits.
10. An electrocardiogram showed normal sinus rhythm.
11. Computed tomography of the abdomen and pelvis with oral and intravenous contrast enhancement was performed (Figure).
12. Axial cross-sectional computed tomograms of the patient’s abdomen and pelvis with oral and intravenous contrast enhancement show segmental mural thickening of the anterior cecum with wall hypoenhancement and pneumatosis, adjacent fat stranding, and a lucency medial to the cecum (A) and bilateral renal hypodensities (B).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Acute appendicitis  
B: Colonic ischemia  
C: Diverticulitis with perforation  
D: Infectious colitis

step1_excerpts:
1. A previously healthy African American man in his 20s presented to the emergency department after referral by an optometrist for “bleeding in the back of the eye.” The patient noted that 2 months prior he began experiencing throbbing headaches in the back of his head that were more painful and associated with lightheadedness when laying down.  
2. Two weeks prior to presentation, he started noticing black spots in his peripheral vision and progressive blurring of vision in both eyes.  
3. The patient denied recent travel, cough, gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract symptoms, ulcers, aching joints, tinnitus, or transient visual obscurations.  
4. He reported owning cats.  
5. On presentation, the patient’s blood pressure was 210/150 mm Hg, and he had a history of acute kidney failure and non–ST-elevation myocardial infarction.  
6. On ophthalmic examination, his uncorrected near visual acuity was 20/25 OD and 20/30 OS.  
7. Extraocular motility, Ishihara color plates, intraocular pressure, pupils, and results of slitlamp examination were within normal limits.  
8. Ophthalmoscopy showed Frisen grade 5 optic nerve head swelling in both eyes with extensive flame hemorrhages and nerve fiber layer infarcts surrounding both nerves and retinal exudates extending from the nerves temporally into both fovea’s (Figure 1).  
9. The vessels were of normal course and caliber.  
10. There were scattered peripheral dot-and-blot hemorrhages.  
11. Results of Humphrey visual field testing were reliable and showed bilateral concentric constriction and enlarged blind spots.  
12. Grade 5 optic nerve head edema.  
13. A, Fundus photograph of the right eye shows Frisen grade 5 optic disc edema, flame hemorrhages, and peripapillary exudation into the macula.  
14. B, Fluorescein angiogram of the right eye in the early venous phase shows blockage from flame hemorrhages, peripapillary microaneurysms, leakage from optic disc capillaries, and absence of vascular leakage at arcades.  
15. Control the systemic blood pressure and workup underlying possible cause of the hypertension Perform magnetic resonance imaging and magnetic resonance venogram of the brain and orbits, then perform lumbar puncture
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Control the systemic blood pressure and workup underlying possible cause of the hypertension  
B: Perform blood tests for neuroretinitis  
C: Perform magnetic resonance imaging and magnetic resonance venogram of the brain and orbits, then perform lumbar puncture  
D: All of the above

step1_excerpts:
1. A 25-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the emergency department for evaluation of a hyperpigmented lesion on the shin.
2. The lesion appeared as a small reddish-brown macule 3 years ago and has gradually increased in size.
3. During the past several months, the lesion has become indented and increasingly tender.
4. Cutaneous examination reveals a 3-cm sclerotic reddish brown patch with central yellow deposits (Figure 1).
5. Laboratory evaluation includes a random blood glucose level of 217 mg/dL (12 mmol/L).
6. The patient denies systemic symptoms, including fevers and chills, and is primarily concerned about the changing appearance of the lesion and the new-onset tenderness.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Obtain a radiograph of the lower leg  
B: Obtain antinuclear antibody levels  
C: Perform a punch biopsy of the lesion  
D: Obtain blood cultures and prescribe empirical antibiotics

step1_excerpts:
1. A 48-year-old man presented to the emergency department with a 1-week history of worsening right lower quadrant tenderness and fullness.
2. This was associated with diarrhea, vomiting, fevers, and chills.
3. He reported some relief of symptoms with loperamide.
4. He denied any history of weight loss, melena, or hematochezia.
5. Other than a previous open hemorrhoidectomy, the patient had no significant medical history.
6. Of note, he had no family history of intestinal disease.
7. On examination, he had a fever with a temperature of 39°C and tachycardia with a heart rate of 102 beats per minute.
8. On abdominal examination, there was localized tenderness with guarding and fullness in the right lower quadrant.
9. Results from his blood laboratory investigations demonstrated leukocytosis, with white blood cell count of 17 000/µL (to convert to ×109/L, multiple by 0.001) and a C-reactive protein level of 205 mg/L (to convert to nmol/L, multiple by 9.524).
10. However, given the clinical history, the patient underwent a computed tomographic (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast (Figure 1).
11. He then underwent an exploratory laparotomy.
12. Transverse computed tomographic scan indicated a large right-sided inflammatory phlegmon measuring 7.5 cm in transverse diameter in a 48-year-old man.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Desmoid tumor  
B: Acute appendicitis  
C: Lymphoma  
D: Carcinoid tumor

step1_excerpts:
1. A 51-year-old woman presented with a 1-month history of intense and worsening polyarthralgia and swelling of bilateral fingers and toes.
2. There was no history of alopecia, oral ulcers, rashes, or Raynaud phenomenon.
3. She did not report preceding fever, diarrhea, or dysuria.
4. There was no history of weight loss or anorexia.
5. Medical history included tertiary hyperparathyroidism related to end-stage kidney disease from chronic glomerulonephritis.
6. The patient had successfully received an ABO-incompatible kidney transplant 1 year ago, but this was complicated by invasive fungal (Volvariella volvacea) infection of the central nervous system.
7. Medications included tacrolimus (0.5 mg twice daily), prednisolone (10 mg daily), cinacalcet (12.5 mg daily), and voriconazole (500 mg daily).
8. On examination, her fingers and toes were symmetrically and diffusely swollen and tender.
9. There was no rash, enthesitis, psoriatic nail changes, clubbing, or lower limb edema.
10. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.
11. Alkaline phosphatase level was elevated at 640 U/L (10.69 μkat/L) (reference range, 40-130 U/L [0.67-2.17 μkat/L]).
12. Corrected calcium and parathyroid hormone levels were 10.88 mg/dL (2.71 mmol/L) (reference range, 8.6-10.2 mg/dL [2.15-2.55 mmol/L]) and 23.7 pmol/L (reference range, 1.3-9.3), respectively.
13. Serum bilirubin, aspartate transferase, alanine transferase, creatinine, and phosphate levels were within reference ranges.
14. Free thyroxine and thyrotropin levels were normal.
15. Results of testing for rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated protein antibody were negative.
16. Her chest radiograph was unremarkable.
17. Radiography of her hands was performed
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Obtain a positron emission computed tomography scan  
B: Perform a bone biopsy  
C: Schedule parathyroidectomy  
D: Stop voriconazole

step1_excerpts:
1. A 59-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to a 3-month history of “always feeling the urge to urinate” as well as vaginal pruritis.
2. She states that she has had involuntary loss of urine about 4 times each day over the past 3 months.
3. It is not associated with coughing or sneezing.
4. Menopause occurred at age 52.
5. She has a history of chlamydial infection in her 20's and has had 3 urinary tract infections over the past year.
6. The patient has not been sexually active with her husband due to pain with intercourse.
7. She has no other significant medical history and does not take any medications.
8. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 12/min.
9. On physical examination, the vulvar skin is pale and atrophic with reduced elasticity and multiple areas of petechiae.
10. The vaginal mucosa also has a loss of rugae and several areas of friable irritation.
11. There is minimal clear vaginal discharge.
12. Urinalysis is normal and fecal occult blood test is negative.
13. Pelvic ultrasound reveals a small, retroverted uterus.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Metronidazole  
B. Nitrofurantoin  
C. Vaginal moisturizers  
D. Topical clobetasol

step1_excerpts:
1. A 37-year-old machinist presents to his primary care physician with eye problems.
2. He has felt a mass in his eye that has persisted for the past month.
3. The patient has a medical history of blepharitis treated with eye cleansing and squamous cell carcinoma of the skin treated with Mohs surgery.
4. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 157/102 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
5. Physical exam is notable for a firm and rubbery nodule palpable inside the patient's left eyelid.
6. Physical exam does not elicit any pain.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Chalazion  
B. Foreign body  
C. Hordeolum  
D. Meibomian cell carcinoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A previously healthy 6-year-old boy taking no regular medications presented to the emergency department with persistent fever and cough for 15 days.  
2. Six days prior to presentation, multiple vesiculobullous lesions appeared on his palms and soles.  
3. Three days later, he developed erythema; vesicles and erosions on his face, trunk, and limbs; erosions on his lips and oral mucosa; eyelid swelling; and blisters on his anal mucosa.  
4. On presentation, his temperature was 38.7 °C (101.7 °F); heart rate, 125/min; blood pressure, 98/50 mm Hg; and oxygen saturation, 98% on room air.  
5. Physical examination revealed bilateral exudative conjunctivitis and white exudates on his tongue, posterior pharynx, and buccal mucosa.  
6. Erosions with overlying dried blood were noted around his eyes, lips, and anal mucosa.  
7. He had targetoid erythematous papules on his face and vesiculobullous lesions on his torso and extremities (Figure).  
8. Auscultation of his lungs revealed bilateral crackles.  
9. Laboratory testing showed a white blood cell count of 15 000/μL (82% neutrophils); erythrocyte sedimentation rate, 39 mm/h; and C-reactive protein level, 57.1 mg/L.  
10. A computed tomography scan of the chest revealed bilateral lower lobe infiltrates.  
11. Azithromycin (10 mg/kg daily, intravenously) was started.  
12. Patient presentation.  
13. A, Erosions with overlying dried blood around the lips and targetoid erythematous papules on the face.  
14. B, Vesiculobullous lesions on the trunk and arms.  
15. C, Vesiculobullous lesions on the palms.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  
A: Carry out pathergy test for Behçet disease  
B: Obtain Mycoplasma pneumoniae IgM and IgG levels  
C: Perform an echocardiogram  
D: Test for monkeypox virus

step1_excerpts:
1. A 16-year-old boy presents to an ophthalmologist with blurry vision.
2. Over the past several months, he has had increasing difficulty seeing the board from the back of the classroom at school.
3. The patient is otherwise doing well in school and enjoys playing basketball.
4. His medical history is otherwise significant for scoliosis which is managed by an orthopedic surgeon.
5. His family history is significant for a mother with type 2 diabetes mellitus and a father who underwent aortic valve replacement last year.
6. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 115/71 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 12/min.
7. On physical exam, the patient is tall for his age and has long arms.
8. He has 20 degrees of thoracic scoliosis, which is stable from previous exams.
9. On slit-lamp examination, the patient is found to have bilateral upward lens subluxation and is prescribed corrective lenses.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

A. Extra copy of sex chromosome  
B. Mutation of RET proto-oncogene  
C. Defective metabolism of methionine  
D. Mutation of chromosome 15

step1_excerpts:
1. A previously healthy 25-year-old woman presented with headache, dysarthria, double vision, and dizziness for 1 week.
2. She denied any history of fever, head trauma, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, or cough.
3. She had traveled to northeastern Brazil 2 months before the onset of the neurological symptoms.
4. On examination, she had a mild right-side hemiparesis with hyperreflexia and hemiataxia.
5. She could walk unassisted but presented with a broad base.
6. There were no meningeal signs.
7. She did not present with hepatosplenomegaly of lymphadenopathy.
8. Her cranial magnetic resonance imaging showed a T2-weighted fluid-attenuated inversion recovery hyperintense lesion with heterogeneous gadolinium enhancement in the pons (Figure).
9. There were no signs of diffusion restriction on diffusion-weighted imaging or hemorrhages on susceptibility-weighted imaging.
10. Sagittal gadolinium-enhanced T1-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) (A) and sagittal T2-weighted fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) (B) showing the extent of the lesion.
11. The laboratory test results showed a hemoglobin level of 15.3 g/dL (to convert to grams per liter, multiply by 10.0), total leukocyte count of 10 390/uL (to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001), of which 1703 (16.4%) were eosinophils, and a platelet count of 284 000/μL (to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001).
12. The patient’s liver and kidney function test results were normal.
13. Computed tomography of the chest revealed bilateral patchy pulmonary infiltrates.
14. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis showed 640 cells, of which 57% were lymphocytes, 26% were eosinophils, and 13% were monocytes; protein levels were 70 mg/dL, and glucose levels were 46 mg/dL.
15. Her blood cultures were found to be sterile.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Listeriosis  
B: Neuroschistosomiasis  
C: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis  
D: Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder

step1_excerpts:
1. A 75-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fatigue.
2. He has had severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for the past 3 days.
3. Today, his wife noticed that he was confused.
4. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease with a drug-eluting stent placed 1 year ago, obesity, hypertension, and dyslipidemia.
5. He denies chest pain or dyspnea, but complains of diffuse abdominal pain.
6. His temperature is 99.0°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 22/min.
7. Physical exam reveals a confused man with dry mucous membranes.
8. His abdomen is diffusely tender to palpation.
9. Laboratory studies are ordered and notable for the following:

Serum:
Na+: 147 mEq/L
Cl-: 112 mEq/L
K+: 3.5 mEq/L
HCO3-: 14 mEq/L
BUN: 80 mg/dL
Glucose: 100 mg/dL
Creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL
Troponin: 0.10 mcg/L (normal < 0.01 mcg/L)

An ECG is ordered and is pending.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient's elevated troponin?

A. Aspirin, heparin, clopidogrel, and cardiac catheterization  
B. Ringer lactate bolus  
C. Metoprolol and aspirin  
D. Obtain a urinalysis and creatine phosphokinase level

step1_excerpts:
1. An 18-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 10 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to his chest.  
2. On arrival, he is unresponsive to painful stimuli.  
3. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 8/min and shallow, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg.  
4. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and infusion of 0.9% saline is begun.  
5. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg.  
6. Examination shows a 2-cm wound at the left sixth intercostal space at the midclavicular line.  
7. There is jugular venous distention.  
8. Breath sounds are normal.  
9. The trachea is at the midline.  
10. Heart sounds are not audible.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Chest x-ray

B. Echocardiography

C. Bronchoscopy

D. Pericardiocentesis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.  
2. He also has been confused and agitated during this period.  
3. He has a history of mild hypertension.  
4. His current medication is a diuretic.  
5. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 70/47 mm Hg.  
6. Physical examination shows delayed capillary refill of the lips and nail beds and cool extremities.  
7. His oxyhemoglobin saturation in a central vein is 60% (N=70–75).
question_options:
These findings are most consistent with which of the following types of shock?

A. Cardiogenic

B. Distributive

C. Hypovolemic

D. Obstructive

step1_excerpts:
1. A white teenage boy was referred for 3 months of bilateral reduced central visual acuity characterized as atraumatic, painless, constant, symmetric, and nonprogressive.  
2. His parents reported that he had recently been hospitalized for a suspected overdose with the medications atomoxetine, quetiapine, melatonin, fluoxetine, bupropion, and clonazepam, and shortly after, he reported central visual acuity loss.  
3. A dilated fundus examination with normal results had been documented 6 months prior to our examination.  
4. His ocular history was unremarkable.  
5. His medical history included attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, depression, generalized anxiety disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, and learning disabilities.  
6. His medications included atomoxetine, quetiapine, melatonin, and fluoxetine.  
7. The patient was adopted, and a detailed family history was unknown.  
8. A social history was limited.  
9. The patient was born full term.  
10. His biological sister has learning and attention difficulties but had a normal fundus examination result.  
11. The patient’s best-corrected visual acuity was 20/50 OD and 20/60 OS.  
12. His intraocular pressure, pupils, extraocular movements, visual fields, and color testing results were normal.  
13. The anterior segments were unremarkable.  
14. The vitreous, optic nerve, and retinal vasculature were normal.  
15. A bilateral maculopathy was present, with focal areas of gray-brown discoloration (Figure 1A).  
16. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) exhibited an intact foveal depression with subfoveal disruption of the ellipsoid layer and hyperreflective material extending into the Henle layer (Figure 1B).  
17. No subretinal or intraretinal fluid was present.  
18. A, Fundus photograph of the left eye demonstrates a central maculopathy with focal gray discolored lesions and yellow-orange pigmentation.  
19. B, Scanning laser ophthalmoscopy and spectral-domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT) of the same eye reveal ellipsoid zone disruption and vertical hyperreflective bands.  
20. Similar findings were present in the fellow eye.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Stop all psychiatric medications  
B: Obtain an electroretinogram  
C: Inquire about bright light exposures  
D: Prescribe oral steroids

step1_excerpts:
1. A 23-year-old woman presented with 6 months of intermittent bilateral retro-orbital pain associated with blurred vision and wavy lines in the vision of both eyes, followed by worsening numbness and tingling of her hands and legs.
2. Medical history was notable for mild obesity (body mass index of 30 [calculated as weight in kilograms divided by height in meters squared]).
3. Visual acuity was 20/20 OU, with briskly reactive pupils OU and no relative afferent pupillary defect.
4. Intraocular pressure was 17 mm Hg OU.
5. Ishihara color plates were 13/13 OU.
6. Extraocular movements were full.
7. Ophthalmoscopic examination revealed blurring and elevation of the nasal margins of the optic disc consistent with grade 1 optic disc edema in both eyes (Figure).
8. Optical coherence tomography showed an elevated mean peripapillary retinal nerve fiber layer thickness of 170 μm OD and 150 μm OS.
9. Automated visual fields demonstrated subtle enlargement of the blind spots.
10. Fundus photography demonstrating bilateral grade 1 optic disc edema.
11. On neurologic examination, she had moderate weakness of dorsiflexors at the ankles bilaterally as well as toe extensors and everters.
12. There was large and small fiber sensory loss distally in the legs.
13. Findings of magnetic resonance (MR) imaging and MR venography of the head were unremarkable.
14. Electromyography suggested a brachial plexopathy.
15. Lumbar puncture showed a normal opening pressure of 170 mm Hg with a cerebrospinal fluid protein of 113 mg/dL and 2 nucleated white blood cells.
16. Serum studies were notable for a thrombocytosis of 479 × 103/μL (to convert to × 109/L, multiply by 1) and an elevated quantitative monoclonal IgA λ-protein level of 492 mg/dL (to convert to grams per liter, multiply by 0.01).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Fluorescein angiography  
B: Serum vascular endothelial growth factor  
C: Repeated lumbar puncture  
D: Start acetazolamide

step1_excerpts:
1. An 82-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with 2 months of diarrhea and 2 weeks of rash.
2. She had sustained a left radius fracture 6 months prior, which resulted in deconditioning and poor appetite.
3. Her diet consisted of mostly vegetables, and she lost 4 kg (8.8 lb) during this time.
4. Two months prior, she developed postprandial nonbloody diarrhea that occurred 5 times daily.
5. Two weeks prior, a pruritic rash in her extremities emerged.
6. She had no fever, night sweats, or abdominal pain.
7. Past medical history included chronic nondeforming rheumatoid arthritis, hypothyroidism, and colon adenocarcinoma resected 10 years prior.
8. Her medications were prednisolone (1 mg/d) and levothyroxine.
9. On examination, she was afebrile, with blood pressure 90/46 mm Hg; pulse, 90/min and regular; and respirations, 18/min.
10. Body mass index was 16.8 (calculated as weight in kilograms divided by height in meters squared).
11. She was alert, cognitively intact, and appeared emaciated.
12. Glossitis and a scaly pruritic rash with an erythematous brawny peeling base on her neck and extremities were noted (Figure).
13. Findings on cardiovascular, pulmonary, abdominal, and neurologic examinations were unremarkable.
14. Left, Dorsum of the hands, exhibiting symmetric scaly eruption.
15. Right, Bilateral lower extremities showing ruptured bullae on an erythematous brawny peeling base.
16. Laboratory studies showed mild hyponatremia (132 mmol/L) and an otherwise normal basic metabolic panel.
17. Other laboratory values were as follows: C-reactive protein, 0.58 mg/dL; erythrocyte sedimentation rate, 23 mm/h; total protein, 4.8 g/dL; and albumin, 1.8 g/dL.
18. Her white blood cell count was 7200/μL (66.5% neutrophils, 30.4% lymphocytes); hemoglobin level, 9.9 g/dL; mean corpuscular volume, 96 fL; and platelet count, 332 000/μL.
19. Results of liver function tests, coagulation tests, urinalysis, thyroid function tests, measurement of serum vitamin B12 and folic acid levels, and cosyntropin stimulation tests were normal.
20. Serum copper level was 46 μg (reference range, 66-130 μg) and zinc level was 23 μg (reference, ≥80 μg).
21. Abdominal computed tomography revealed no abnormalities.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Measure fecal calprotectin level  
B: Check for fecal ova and parasites  
C: Measure serum niacin level  
D: Test for serum antitissue transglutaminase antibody

step1_excerpts:
1. A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with diarrhea.
2. He states he has had profuse, watery diarrhea for the past 24 hours.
3. He notes that eating and drinking make him defecate more, thus he has been refraining from drinking.
4. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications.
5. His temperature is 97.7°F (36.5°C), blood pressure is 84/64 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air.
6. Physical exam reveals dry mucous membranes with an otherwise benign exam.
7. The patient is given 1L of normal saline and drinks 1L of oral fluids.
8. His blood pressure is subsequently 120/70 mmHg and pulse 95/min.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Stool PCR
B. Ciprofloxacin
C. Stool ova and parasite study
D. Rest and oral rehydration

step1_excerpts:
1. An 8-week-old boy presents with his mother to the pediatrician for a well visit.
2. The patient has been breastfed since birth, and usually feeds for 30 minutes every 2-3 hours.
3. The patient’s mother is concerned that her milk production is not keeping up with the patient’s nutritional requirements.
4. She reports that about 2 weeks ago the patient began regurgitating breastmilk through his nose and mouth after some feeds.
5. He seems mildly upset during the episodes of regurgitation but usually settles down quickly and is hungry again soon afterwards.
6. His mother has already tried limiting the volume of each feed, which seems to have reduced the frequency of regurgitation.
7. She denies any diarrhea, hematochezia, or family history of food allergies.
8. Her older son had a similar problem with vomiting that resolved around 12 months of age.
9. Four weeks ago, the patient’s height and weight were in the 40th and 34th percentiles, respectively.
10. His height and weight are now respectively in the 37th and 36th percentiles.
11. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 72/49 mmHg, pulse is 121/min, and respirations are 32/min.
12. On physical exam, the patient is cooing in his mother’s lap and smiles reciprocally with her.
13. He lifts his head and shoulders off the examination table when placed in the supine position.
14. His abdomen is soft, non-tender and non-distended.
15. Bowel sounds are normoactive.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Reassurance and counseling on positioning  
B. Switch to hydrolyzed formula  
C. Recommend modification of mother’s diet  
D. Initiate proton pump inhibitor

step1_excerpts:
1. A child presented with multiple, asymptomatic, scattered white macules on the lower abdomen and pubic area, which were present at birth and had gradually increased in size and number.
2. Physical examination revealed multiple, well-demarcated, hypopigmented 1- to 5-mm macules on the lower abdomen and pubic area (Figure, A and B).
3. There was no history of any systemic disorder and no family history of similar lesions.
4. Direct microscopic examination of scales soaked in potassium hydroxide did not reveal hyphae.
5. Wood light examination revealed no accentuation.
6. A punch biopsy specimen was obtained for further evaluation (Figure, C and D).
7. A, Multiple discrete hypopigmented macules on the lower abdomen and pubic area.
8. B, Well-demarcated hypopigmented macules on the lower abdomen.
9. C, Histopathological examination revealed mild hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and scattered clear cells in the epidermis (hematoxylin-eosin).
10. D, The clear cells are larger than the neighboring keratinocytes and contain abundant pale cytoplasm (hematoxylin-eosin).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Tinea versicolor  
B: Vitiligo  
C: Clear cell papulosis  
D: Idiopathic guttate hypomelanosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 72-year-old man seeks medical attention for urinary difficulties lasting 6 months, characterized by slow and intermittent urinary stream with terminal dribbling.
2. He reports no blood in urine or painful urination.
3. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, managed with lisinopril and atorvastatin.
4. Vital signs show: pulse 72/min, respiratory rate 14/min, blood pressure 140/92 mm Hg, and temperature 36.8°C (98.3°F).
5. The patient is alert and oriented.
6. Cardiac examination reveals a 2/6 systolic murmur at the left sternal border and an S3 gallop.
7. Digital rectal examination finds a symmetrically enlarged, non-tender prostate without nodules.
8. Stool occult blood test is negative.
question_options:
Which posterior Chapman reflex point location would most likely correspond to this patient's condition?

A. Posterior iliac crest  
B. Inferior pubic ramus  
C. Coccyx  
D. Lateral femoral epicondyle  
E. Medial iliotibial band  
F. Sacroiliac joint  
G. Anterior superior iliac spine  
H. Ischial tuberosity  
I. Lateral sacral base  
J. Proximal left iliotibial band

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 60s with no significant medical history presented to the dermatology clinic for evaluation of a gray-white plaque on his soft palate.
2. These findings developed over the prior week and did not improve after treatment with 3 days of oral cefuroxime.
3. The patient reported no sore throat, dysphagia, hoarse voice, cough, dyspnea, nausea, vomiting, headache, fever, night sweats, weight loss, rash, or genital, rectal, or oral ulcers over the past 6 months.
4. He was taking no regular daily medications, did not smoke cigarettes, and had no history of oral trauma.
5. Over the prior 6 months, he reported sexual contact with 1 male partner.
6. Physical examination revealed irregular gray-white ulcers with a surrounding erythema on the soft palate, uvula, and tonsils (Figure 1) and nontender bilateral submandibular lymphadenopathy.
7. His tongue was of normal appearance, and he had no skin lesions or mucosal erosions in the anal or genital areas.Patient presentation showing irregular gray-white pseudomembranous ulcerated plaques on an erythematous base on the soft palate, uvula, tonsils, and posterior pharynx.
8. The white appearance on the tongue is a cotton swab.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Obtain serologic test results for Treponema pallidum  
B: Perform a biopsy of the gray-white plaque  
C: Prescribe oral amoxicillin  
D: Start topical nystatin

step1_excerpts:
1. A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain.  
2. He reports several months of meal-associated abdominal discomfort, for which he has been using over-the-counter antacids, but notes a significant worsening of epigastric pain radiating to the right shoulder in the past hour, accompanied by nausea and vomiting.  
3. He denies fever, chills, or cough.  
4. His medical history includes hypertension managed with amlodipine, and he has no history of surgeries.  
5. He works as a carpenter and denies smoking, alcohol use, or illicit drug use.  
6. On examination, his temperature is 101.0°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 22/min.  
7. Physical examination reveals diffuse abdominal rigidity, rebound tenderness, and hypoactive bowel sounds.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic step?

A. Blood cultures and broad-spectrum antibiotics  
B. Serum lipase and amylase testing  
D. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage  
G. Exploratory laparotomy  
H. Admission and serial abdominal exams  
I. Abdominal ultrasound  
J. Chest radiograph

step1_excerpts:
1. A 41-year-old woman with a history of ocular hypertension (and using brimonidine tartrate and timolol maleate) was referred by her ophthalmologist for a second opinion regarding yellowish subfoveal precipitates in her left eye.
2. Three months earlier, she had undergone pneumatic retinopexy for macula-on retinal detachment (RD) with a superotemporal tear, followed by vitrectomy with gas injection for macula-on inferonasal detachment 1 month later.
3. She had persistent postoperative subretinal fluid inferonasally, and she was concerned about a central scotoma.
4. An examination within 2 months of the vitrectomy revealed yellowish subfoveal precipitates.
5. Her best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/200 OS.
6. Extraocular motility was full, but she displayed left exotropia.
7. Confrontational visual fields were full for the right eye but showed a decreased field inferiorly for the left eye.
8. Intraocular pressures as determined using Tonopen tonometry were 13 mm Hg OD and 12 mm Hg OS.
9. A slitlamp examination revealed trace nuclear sclerosis and pigmented cells in the anterior vitreous of the left eye.
10. An ophthalmoscopic examination indicated laser and cryotherapy scars 360° around a horseshoe tear superotemporally in the left eye, whereas the right eye appeared normal.
11. In addition, pre-equatorial subretinal fluid in the left eye between the 6-o’clock and 8:30 position was associated with 2 tiny holes at the 7:30 position and with a small area of fibrotic tissue contraction consistent with early proliferative vitreoretinopathy.
