3. External ocular movements are normal but funduscopic examination shows pallor of the optic disk.
question_options:
This patient's condition is most likely a result of demyelination of which of the following?  

A. Medial longitudinal fasciculus  

B. Oculomotor nerve  

C. Optic nerve  

D. Trigeminal nerve

step1_excerpts:
1. A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 6-day history of fever, severe muscle pain, and diffuse, painful swelling of his neck, underarms, and groin area.
2. The symptoms began after returning from a camping trip in New Mexico.
3. He appears ill and lethargic and can barely answer questions.
4. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg.
5. Physical examination shows generalized scattered black maculae.
6. Examination of the right upper extremity shows an erythematous, solid, tender mass on the underside of the upper extremity just above the elbow; the mass is draining blood and necrotic material.
question_options:
The most effective antibiotic for this patient’s disorder will interfere with which of the following cellular processes or enzymes?

A. DNA helicase

B. Glucuronosyltransferase

C. Proteasomal degradation

D. Ribosomal assembly

step1_excerpts:
1. A 30-year-old woman presented with widespread, erythematous, purpuric macules and papules on the abdomen and extremities.
2. The eruption had been present for approximately 8 months and consisted of asymptomatic, self-resolving, and continuously appearing macules and papules.
3. Her medical history was significant for chronic hepatitis B infection, for which tenofovir was initiated 4 months ago.
4. Review of systems was positive only for occasional arthralgias in her knees and ankles.
5. She was not taking any other medications.
6. The patient was in no acute distress, and her vital signs were within normal limits.
7. On physical examination, there were purpuric, erythematous macules coalescing into patches on the upper extremities, abdomen, and lower extremities (Figure).
8. She had no oral or genital involvement and no joint effusions or deformities.
9. A skin punch biopsy showed extravasated erythrocytes, a neutrophilic infiltrate, fibrinoid necrosis, and broken-down neutrophils releasing nuclear debris, consistent with leukocytoclastic vasculitis (Figure).
10. A second skin punch biopsy was performed for direct immunofluorescence, which was negative.
11. Results of a complete blood cell count and comprehensive metabolic panel were unremarkable.
12. Physical examination of the lower extremities.
13. Dotted areas indicate areas of the skin that were biopsied.
14. Inset, Photomicrograph from first skin punch biopsy (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×200).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Prescribe prednisone  
B: Evaluate for systemic vasculitis  
C: Prescribe a topical glucocorticoid  
D: Provide reassurance and observe patient

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 60s presented with a 1-month history of painless, blurred vision in the left eye.
2. Her medical history was significant for Waldenström macroglobulinemia (WM), and recent laboratory test results showed active WM with bone marrow involvement.
3. Results of the eye examination showed best-corrected visual acuity of 20/20 OD and 20/40 OS.
4. Anterior segment examination results showed a relatively shallow anterior chamber in the left eye.
5. Results of a dilated fundus examination showed a choroidal detachment in the left eye extending circumferentially from the 2-o’clock to the 5-o’clock position and extending posteriorly up to 3 to 4 disc diameters temporal to the macula (Figure, A).
6. There was vitreous hemorrhage with a poor view of the posterior pole (Figure, A).
7. A, Ultra-widefield fundus photograph of the left eye showing posterior vitreous hemorrhage (white arrowhead) and a choroidal detachment temporally (yellow arrowheads).
8. B, Anterior segment spectral domain optical coherence tomography of the left eye showing the narrow angle from suprachoroidal effusion.
9. Results of fundus fluorescein angiography of the left eye showed hypofluorescence corresponding to vitreous hemorrhage.
10. Tortuosity of the temporal vessels was prominent, with diffuse peripheral vascular leakage temporally.
11. Choroidal folds were observed 3 disc diameters temporal to the macula, extending to the periphery.
12. Peripheral capillary nonperfusion, vascular reorganization, neovascularization, and choroidal detachment were noted.
13. Anterior segment spectral domain optical coherence tomographic results showed a shallow anterior chamber and 360° narrow angles in the left eye (Figure, B).
14. Results of B-scan ultrasonography confirmed choroidal detachment in the left eye and revealed a small area of suprachoroidal effusion in the right eye in the superotemporal periphery.
15. Treat with combined systemic chemotherapy and pars plana vitrectomy
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Observe the patient  
B: Perform pars plana vitrectomy  
C: Treat with systemic chemotherapy  
D: Treat with combined systemic chemotherapy and pars plana vitrectomy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 44-year-old man presents to the emergency department with palpitations.
2. He has a history of anxiety managed with fluoxetine and lorazepam.
3. He also has hypertension but does not take any medications.
4. Today, his symptoms have been persistent despite taking his medications.
5. He says that he feels lightheaded and can’t walk.
6. His temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 120/72 mmHg, pulse is 183/min, respirations are 25/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air.
7. Physical exam reveals a somnolent and uncomfortable man.
8. His pulse is rapid and regular.
9. An ECG is performed as seen in Figure A.
10. During the exam, the patient states that he feels lightheaded and appears occasionally somnolent.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A. Adenosine  
B. Amiodarone  
C. Procainamide  
D. Cardioversion

step1_excerpts:
1. A 47-year-old male visits his primary care physician reporting a seven-month history of fatigue.
2. His symptoms include morning headaches, poor concentration at work, and excessive daytime drowsiness.
3. He has experienced a 25-pound weight gain over the past year and recently began taking daily post-work walks for weight management.
4. He has no remarkable medical history.
5. His vital signs show: temperature 36.1°C (97°F), heart rate 84/min, respiratory rate 15/min, and blood pressure 138/82 mmHg.
6. His BMI is 36, and physical examination reveals a neck circumference of 42 cm with normal thyroid.
7. His skin is warm and slightly moist without edema.
8. Heart and lung examinations are normal.
9. His abdomen is non-tender, and he demonstrates full muscle strength in all extremities.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in diagnostic testing?

A. Complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and thyroid-stimulating hormone  
B. Thyroxine  
C. Creatine kinase level  
D. Serum iron studies and vitamin B12 level  
E. Brain MRI with contrast  
F. Polysomnography  
G. Hemoglobin A1C and fasting glucose  
H. Morning cortisol  
J. 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring

step1_excerpts:
1. A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath.
2. He typically has poor exercise tolerance and is only able to walk from his house to his mailbox before becoming dyspneic.
3. He now has shortness of breath even at rest.
4. He had a cold recently but has no new medical problems.
5. His past medical history is notable for a myocardial infarction 7 years ago, COPD, heart failure with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 22%, obesity, diabetes, and peripheral vascular disease.
6. His temperature is 97.7°F (36.5°C), blood pressure is 124/82 mmHg, pulse is 140/min, respirations are 32/min, and oxygen saturation is 78% on room air.
7. Physical exam reveals an uncomfortable man with increased work of breathing.
8. He demonstrates bilateral crackles and wheezing on pulmonary exam.
9. The patient is started on BiPAP, and his oxygen saturation improves to 94%.
10. An ECG is performed, as seen in Figure A, and a chest radiograph is performed, as seen in Figure B.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Digoxin  
B. Albuterol and prednisone  
C. Intubation  
D. Metoprolol

step1_excerpts:
1. A patient in their 50s presented with asymptomatic keratotic papules, first noticed on the left middle and ring fingers and left toe web spaces more than 10 years earlier.
2. The papules progressed proximally over the subsequent decade to involve the forearm, arm, scapular area, ankle, shin, and thigh, but only affected the left side of the body.
3. The patient’s face, palms, soles, and entire right side of the body were spared.
4. The patient has a history of rosacea being treated with topical metronidazole gel for flares but was otherwise asymptomatic.
5. The patient did not have any alopecia, night blindness, or dry eyes or skin.
6. There was no history of any exposure to radiation or arsenic, nutritional deficiency, inflammatory skin disease, or malignant neoplasm.
7. There was no family history of a similar condition.
8. Examination revealed multiple, submillimeter, skin-colored to yellowish keratotic spiny projections over the aforementioned areas, only on the left side of the body (Figure, A and B).
9. Punch biopsy from a lesion showed orthokeratosis with parakeratotic columns emerging from an epidermal invagination.
10. The epidermis was mildly acanthotic and with a normal granular layer.
11. There was a sparse superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate.
12. Adjacent hair follicles were unaffected (Figure, C).
13. A, Numerous, submillimeter, skin-colored spiny projections over left foot web spaces were present.
14. B, Close-up photograph over the left scapular area showed lesions of similar morphologic characteristics.
15. C, Histologic results showed a parakeratotic column overlying a mildly acanthotic epidermis with a normal granular layer and keratinocyte maturation.
16. A sparse superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate was present (hematoxylin-eosin).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Lichen spinulosus  
B: Multiple minute digitate hyperkeratosis  
C: Porokeratosis  
D: Viral warts

step1_excerpts:
1. A 72-year-old woman was treated with a total postoperative radiotherapy dose of 55.86 Gy (to convert to rad, divide by 0.01) in 21 fractions after lumpectomy of a cT1bN0M0 mammary carcinoma.
2. Two months after the last dose of radiation she developed pruritic pustules and papules on the skin of the ipsilateral right breast.
3. She mentioned that she had a cold sore once several years ago.
4. Levoceterizine gave some relief of the itch.
5. Physical examination findings showed pustules surrounding the areola on the right breast with an increasing number in the submammary fold (Figure 1).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Bacterial folliculitis  
B: Herpes infection  
C: Pityrosporum folliculitis  
D: Reaction to radiotherapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 16-year-old male collapses during a high school baseball game after being struck in the chest by a fastball while preparing to bat.
2. He immediately becomes unresponsive, and cardiopulmonary resuscitation is performed by the athletic trainer, but the patient does not regain consciousness.
3. An automated external defibrillator was not available, and the patient is pronounced deceased upon arrival at the emergency department.
4. His medical history is unremarkable, with no known conditions or family history of early-onset sudden cardiac death.
5. The only supplement he used daily was protein powder.
question_options:
Which electrocardiographic phase was most likely occurring at the moment the chest impact triggered this fatal event?

A. R-wave peak  
B. Upslope of T-wave  
C. ST-segment plateau  
D. P-wave peak  
E. T-wave nadir  
F. Downslope of T-wave  
G. QRS complex peak  
H. PR interval  
I. Downslope of P-wave  
J. QT interval midpoint

step1_excerpts:
1. A 43-year-old man presented as a referral for bilateral central vision loss.
2. His medical history was significant for Crohn disease controlled with monthly injections of ustekinumab (Stelara; Janssen Biotech Inc).
3. Symptoms of fever, headache, and myalgia began 1 week prior following a tick bite.
4. He was prescribed oral doxycycline hyclate for suspected Lyme disease.
5. Owing to persistent fever while receiving oral doxycycline hyclate, he was admitted for intravenous administration of doxycycline hyclate, and the fever resolved.
6. He was found to be anemic (hemoglobin concentration, 6.7 g/dL; normal concentration, 13.5-17.5 g/dL) (to convert hemoglobin concentration to g/L, multiply by 10), requiring transfusion.
7. While hospitalized, he developed acute bilateral central scotoma.
8. Magnetic resonance imaging of the orbit and brain with and without contrast was unremarkable.
9. Infectious serology test results for Lyme disease, syphilis, malaria, Anaplasma species, Cryptococcus species, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and rickettsia were negative.
10. Rheumatologic serology test results for antinuclear antibodies, including Sjögren anti-Ro and anti-La, anti-DNA, and anti-Smith, were also negative.
11. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody testing revealed elevated proteinase 3 antibody level.
12. In the setting of anemia, infectious-disease consultants raised concern for babesiosis.
13. Peripheral blood smear and polymerase chain reaction were performed; empirical therapy of azithromycin, 500 mg daily, plus atovaquone, 750 mg twice daily, was initiated.
14. Polymerase chain reaction results for babesiosis later returned as negative.Ocular examination revealed uncorrected distance acuity of 20/50 OD and 20/60 OS.
15. Intraocular pressure values were normal, and there was no afferent pupillary defect.
16. Slitlamp evaluation showed bilateral rare anterior vitreous cell.
17. Dilated fundus examination revealed bilateral reddened foveal lesions and irregular macular pigmentation.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Obtain indocyanine green angiography  
B: Discontinue immunosuppression therapy  
C: Order optical coherence tomography  
D: Repeat neuroimaging

step1_excerpts:
1. A 20-year-old female presents with headache and thick nasal discharge lasting four days.
2. Her symptoms began with a sore throat and nasal congestion the previous week that had shown initial improvement.
3. Current examination reveals a temperature of 38.1°C (100.6°F), purulent nasal drainage, maxillary sinus tenderness on percussion, and erythematous, mildly swollen nasal turbinates.
4. Lung examination is normal.
question_options:
In this clinical scenario, where would a Chapman reflex point most likely be identified?

A. Second intercostal space near the sternocostal junction  
B. Over the frontal sinuses at the supraorbital ridge  
C. Fourth rib at the costochondral junction  
D. T2 between the spinous and transverse processes  
E. Third intercostal space along the midclavicular line  
F. Between the spinous processes of C7 and T1  
G. First rib near the clavicle  
H. At the junction of the mastoid process and occipital bone  
I. Sixth rib at the midaxillary line  
J. Fifth intercostal space near the anterior axillary line

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his late 70s presented with a 1-month history of blurry vision in his left eye.  
2. He reported fatigue, muscle stiffness, joint pain, and a 10-lb unintentional weight loss.  
3. On ocular examination, his best-corrected visual acuity was 20/25 OD and 20/60 OS.  
4. Anterior segment examination findings were unremarkable.  
5. Fundus examination revealed bilateral microaneurysms and dot hemorrhages throughout the posterior pole, along with bilateral macular edema and serous neurosensory detachment in the left eye (Figure 1A).  
6. Optical coherence tomography of the right eye revealed severe cystoid macular edema, and fluorescein angiography showed normal filling with multiple microaneurysms.  
7. An optical coherence tomographic image of the left eye showed a large neurosensory detachment with overlying and surrounding cystoid macular edema.  
8. Fluorescein angiography of the left eye demonstrated hypofluorescence without pooling or leakage of fluorescein dye over the area of neurosensory detachment, which was persistent in later frames (Figure 1B).  
9. A, Fundus photograph of left eye showing neurosensory detachment.  
10. B, Photograph of left eye with fluorescein angiography showing hypofluorescence over area of neurosensory detachment and macular edema without associated capillary leakage or dye pooling.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Administer an intravitreous anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (anti-VEGF) agent in the left eye  
B: Obtain neuroimaging of the brain and orbits  
C: Obtain serum chemistry with radiographs of the extremities  
D: Obtain serum titers of viral antibodies

step1_excerpts:
1. A 4-year-old girl with no previous medical or ocular history presented with 10 days of right painless, periorbital swelling and erythema.
2. The patient was previously treated with an oral combination of amoxicillin and clavulanic acid and topical gentamicin therapy without any improvement.
3. The patient’s visual acuity, color vision, and pupillary examination results were within normal limits, and intraocular pressures were 28 mm Hg OD and 20 mm Hg OS.
4. The extraocular movements and confrontational visual fields were normal.
5. There was right upper and lower eyelid edema with mild erythema and 3 mm of proptosis.
6. The eyelids were nontender to palpation.
7. There was trace vasodilation and chemosis of the conjunctiva in the right eye.
8. The remainder of the slitlamp and dilated fundus examination results were within normal limits.
9. Computed tomography of the orbits and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and orbits showed a large lesion of the right greater wing of the sphenoid bone extending toward the orbital apex with edema and enhancement of the right temporal lobe of the brain (Figure 1).A, Axial computed tomography (CT) of the orbits with contrast shows a large destructive lesion in the right sphenoid bone and anterior aspect of the middle cranial fossa.
10. B, A T1-weighted magnetic resonance image (MRI) of the brain and orbits without contrast shows the involvement of the right temporal lobe.
11. The lesion can be seen also involving the right side of the sphenoid bone, orbital apex, and scalp anteriorly.
12. The scale across the bottom of each image is measured in centimeters.
13. A indicates anterior; R, right.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Order a positron emission tomographic scan  
B: Start treatment with intravenous antibiotics  
C: Start treatment with intravenous corticosteroids  
D: Perform biopsy of lesion

step1_excerpts:
1. A 71-year-old man presented to the dermatologist with a 6-week history of a rapidly progressing rash and swelling of the left side of the chest wall.
2. He had noticed the rash a few days after receiving the second dose of an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine (Moderna).
3. He denied itching, weeping, bleeding, or discharge from the rash or the nipple.
4. He had a history of metabolic syndrome treated with antihypertensives and oral hypoglycemics.
5. The physical examination showed a morbidly obese White man.
6. The skin examination showed a 19 × 10-cm pink, fallacious purple color deep-infiltrated papule in the left breast and a similar 15 × 7-cm papule under the left clavicle (Figure, A).
7. The breast examination was notable for bilateral gynecomastia and inverted left nipple without any palpable lumps.
8. No lymphadenopathy was noted either.
9. His laboratory results showed stage 2 chronic kidney disease.
10. Results of a viral panel including hepatitis A, B, and C and HIV were negative.
11. The punch biopsy of the skin showed a diffuse island of atypical cells in the dermis (Figure, B).
12. On immunohistochemical staining, the atypical cells stained positive for CK-7, GATA-3, and PAX-8 (weak focal staining) and negative for estrogen receptor (ER)/progesterone receptor (<1%), TTF-1, SATB-2, CDX-2, and NKX-3.1.
13. The positron emission tomography–computed tomography scan showed a diffuse, infiltrating fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG)-avid cutaneous lesion on the left chest wall (standardized uptake value, 6.5) and multiple FDG-avid nodes in the axilla (bilaterally), left internal mammary, and left cervical chain.
14. The core biopsy from the lymph node is shown in the Figure, C.A, Rash on the left chest wall.
15. B and C, Hematoxylin-eosin stains of the punch biopsy of the skin and core biopsy of the lymph node, respectively (both original magnification ×10).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Cutaneous angiosarcoma  
B: Leukocytoclastic vasculitis from COVID-19 vaccine  
C: Inflammatory breast cancer  
D: Primary adnexal gland carcinoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 23-year-old white man who has sex with men (MSM) presented with a 1-month history of skin lesions on the palms and soles as well as a 2-week history of lesions in his oropharynx.  
2. He reported that a fraction of the lesions had blistered earlier in the course of his illness.  
3. The patient also described myalgias and fatigue over the preceding month.  
4. He moved to Texas from the northeast a few months prior to his illness.  
5. He denied any exposure to sexually transmitted infections or a history of genital lesions.  
6. On examination, the patient had erythematous papules on bilateral palms and soles as well as eroded vesicles on the palate (Figure, A and B).  
7. Lymphadenopathy was not present.  
8. A biopsy specimen of a papule on the left sole was obtained for immunohistochemical staining (Figure, C and D).  
9. A serologic antibody test revealed an elevated coxsackievirus titer of 1:16 (reference range, <1:8; >1:32 indicative of infection).  
10. A, Patient’s soles at presentation.  
11. B, Patient’s palate at presentation.  
12. C, Hematoxylin-eosin–stained section of the biopsy specimen (original magnification, ×20).  
13. D, Immunohistochemistry stain of biopsy specimen (anti–Treponema pallidum polyclonal antibody immunostain; original magnification, ×20).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Rocky Mountain spotted fever  
B: Secondary syphilis  
C: Hand, foot, and mouth disease  
D: Primary human immunodeficiency virus infection

step1_excerpts:
1. A 24-year-old G1P0000 woman attends her first prenatal visit at approximately 8 weeks of gestation.
2. She reports no significant symptoms other than increased fatigue and occasional nausea.
3. The patient recently immigrated from Africa and works as a babysitter for neighborhood children, one of whom recently had the flu and another with chickenpox.
4. She has no immunization records and does not recall receiving any vaccines.
5. She is sexually active only with her husband, has no history of sexually transmitted infections or intravenous drug use, and her husband has no medical issues.
6. Her temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 122/76 mmHg, pulse is 66/min, and respirations are 12/min.
7. Physical examination is unremarkable.
question_options:
Which of the following vaccines should be administered to this patient at this time?

A. Tetanus/Diphtheria/Pertussis vaccine  
B. Rabies vaccine  
D. Live-attenuated influenza vaccine  
E. Varicella vaccine  
G. Intramuscular flu vaccine  
H. Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine  
I. Hepatitis A vaccine  
J. Hepatitis B vaccine

step1_excerpts:
1. A 5-year-old girl presents to the emergency room due to difficulty walking.
2. She has been complaining of pain in her right leg for the last few days.
3. Her neighbor’s cat bit her last week and her parents attributed the pain to her healing bite.
4. At the time of the bite, they cleaned the wound and irrigated it with sterile saline water from a first aid kit.
5. She has no medical history and has never been hospitalized.
6. Her temperature is 102.2°F (39°C), blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 21/min, and pulse oximetry is 99% on room air.
7. The open wound remains present on the thigh with surrounding erythema and edema.
8. MRI is consistent with osteomyelitis.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Doxycycline  
B. Ampicillin and sulbactam  
C. Amoxicillin and clavulanate  
D. Flucanozole

step1_excerpts:
1. A 16-year-old girl visits the primary care clinic with complaints of generalized fatigue, low-grade fever, and neck swellings.
2. After further evaluation, she is diagnosed with a rare type of lymphoma.
3. Public health officials observe a higher incidence of this lymphoma among young individuals in certain areas of a small community located near a power plant suspected of contaminating the drinking water supply.
4. To investigate whether exposure to the contaminated water is associated with an increased risk of developing this rare lymphoma, local physicians and epidemiologists plan a research study.
question_options:
Which subset of individuals from the population would be most appropriate to include in the control group for this study?

A. Individuals from an unaffected community with no exposure to the contaminated water  
B. Individuals with no history of cancer from a neighboring community  
C. Individuals without lymphoma that were not exposed to the contaminated water  
D. Individuals without lymphoma but with other chronic diseases  
E. Individuals without lymphoma from the local outpatient clinic  
F. Individuals with lymphoma from a region unaffected by the water contamination  
G. Individuals without lymphoma who have lived in the community for less than one year  
H. Individuals without lymphoma that were exposed to the contaminated water  
I. Individuals without lymphoma matched by age and gender to the cases  
J. Individuals with lymphoma without exposure to the contaminated water

step1_excerpts:
1. A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician in October for a follow-up examination.
2. She feels well.
3. She has a 2-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus controlled with insulin.
4. She had a normal Pap smear 3 months ago and saw her ophthalmologist 6 months ago.
5. Her 67-year-old grandmother has breast cancer.
6. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 57 kg (125 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2 .
7. Her hemoglobin A1c is 6.2%, and fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 118 mg/dL.
question_options:
Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?

A. Dietary modification for weight loss

B. Human papillomavirus testing

C. Mammography

D. Influenza virus vaccine

step1_excerpts:
1. A 58-year-old woman returned from the Ukraine with 3 months of constant blurry vision in the left eye.
2. Her history was significant for glaucoma and breast cancer with brain metastasis treated with CyberKnife and whole-brain radiation.
3. While abroad, she received 2 inferiorly placed periocular steroid injections and was treated with glaucoma drops for elevated pressures of 55 mm Hg.
4. At presentation, her visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/50 OS, and intraocular pressures were 18 and 20 mm Hg, respectively.
5. She had a left afferent pupillary defect and left superior visual field deficit.
6. Slitlamp examination of the right eye was unremarkable, while the left eye showed 1+ cell in the anterior chamber and 1+ nuclear sclerosis with pigment on the anterior lens capsule.
7. Posterior examination revealed 2+ whitish vitreous deposits, a cup-disc ratio of 0.8, and inferior retinal detachment with subretinal particulate material (Figure, A).
8. B-scan showed vitreous, subhyaloid, and subretinal opacities without choroidal involvement (Figure, B).
9. A magnetic resonance image of the brain and orbits did not reveal any new metastatic lesions.A, Whitish vitreous deposits, inferior retinal detachment, and subretinal material seen on fundus photography of the left eye.
10. B, B-scan ultrasonography of the left eye confirms retinal detachment and hyperechoic subretinal material without choroidal involvement.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Vitrectomy  
B: Biopsy  
C: Observe and manage glaucoma  
D: Enucleate

step1_excerpts:
1. A 14-year-old girl with no notable medical history reports having intermittent mild pain in her upper right abdomen for the past 2 months.  
2. Her father notes that her appetite has been diminished but that her abdominal discomfort does not seem to be associated with eating meals.  
3. She is an avid basketball player and has also been reporting pain in her right lower chest while playing.  
4. She passes one regular bowel movement every day and has had no vomiting.  
5. She reports no dysphagia, odynophagia, fever, cough, dyspnea, pleurisy, night sweats, sick contacts, or recent travel.  
6. She has not yet started menstruating and does not report fatigue or lethargy.  
7. She has taken no medications recently and denies any toxic ingestions.  
8. Her immunizations are up to date.  
9. Her BMI has been consistently at the 75th percentile.  
10. She is in the ninth grade and has always performed well in classes.  
11. Physical examination is unremarkable.  
12. The abdomen is soft and nontender with no organomegaly.  
13. Laboratory testing yields the following results:  

|  | Patient value | Reference range |  
| --- | --- | --- |  
| Leukocyte count (per mm3) | 9000 | 4500–13,500 |  
| Hemoglobin (g/dL) | 13 | 12–16 |  
| Hematocrit (%) | 38.5 | 36.0–46.0 |  
| Platelet count (per mm3) | 220,000 | 150,000–450,000 |  
| Mean corpuscular volume (μm3) | 85 | 78–102 |  
| Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hour) | 4 | 0–20 |  
| C-reactive protein (mg/liter) | 1 | 0–5 |  
| Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter) | 255 | 5–30 |  
| Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter) | 334 | 13–35 |  
| Total bilirubin (mg/dL) | 0.9 | <1.5 |  
| Direct bilirubin (mg/dL) | 0.1 | 0.2 |  
| Gamma-glutamyltransferase (U/liter) | 22 | 5–24 |  
| Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter) | 160 | 100–320 |  
| Total protein (g/dL) | 7.0 | 6–8 |  
| Albumin (g/dL) | 4.5 | 3.6–5.2 |  
| Prothrombin time | 13 | 11–14 |  
| International normalized ratio | 1.1 | — |  
| Total immunoglobulin G (mg/dL) | 1100 | 509–1580 |  
| Ferritin (ng/mL) | 110 | 7–140 |  
| Serum ceruloplasmin (mg/dL) | 19 | 20.8–43.2 |  

Testing is negative for anti-smooth muscle antibodies, anti-liver-kidney microsomal antibodies, hepatitis B antibodies, and hepatitis C antibodies.  
14. The alpha1-antitrypsin phenotype is MM (normal).  
15. Slit-lamp examination reveals copper deposition into the Descemet membrane.
question_options:
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

A. Initiation of zinc acetate therapy without further testing  
B. Testing for Kayser-Fleischer rings via slit-lamp examination  
C. Abdominal ultrasound to evaluate for hepatomegaly  
D. MRI of the brain to evaluate for basal ganglia changes  
E. Liver biopsy  
F. Measurement of 24-hour urinary copper excretion  
G. Serum free copper measurement  
H. Referral for liver transplantation evaluation  
I. Measurement of serum alpha-fetoprotein  
J. Genetic testing for common mutations in the ATP7B gene

step1_excerpts:
1. An otherwise healthy woman in her 30s presented to an outside health care professional with a 2-day history of floaters in her left eye.
2. She denied additional ocular symptoms and reported no relevant medical, ocular, or family history; medication use; or allergies.
3. The findings of a review of systems were unremarkable.
4. A workup for posterior uveitis was initiated, and the patient began therapy with oral antiviral and oral corticosteroid medications.
5. One week later, her symptoms had worsened, and she was referred for consultation.
6. Best-corrected visual acuity was 20/15 OD and 20/60 OS.
7. Intraocular pressures, extraocular movements, visual fields by confrontation, and pupil responses were normal.
8. Anterior segment examination and dilated fundus examination of the right eye had normal findings.
9. However, the left eye had 3+ anterior chamber cell and 1+ flare, nongranulomatous keratic precipitates, and a clear lens.
10. The dilated fundus examination revealed 2+ vitritis, a hyperemic disc with blurred margins, macular striae with a blunted foveal reflex, and vascular sheathing with segmental periarteriolar inflammatory plaques in multiple quadrants.
11. The peripheral retina had well-demarcated peripheral retinal whitening with scalloped margins and intraretinal hemorrhages in all quadrants (Figure 1A and B).
12. Four days later, repeat fundus photography showed that the peripheral lesions had coalesced into larger circumferential necrotic regions (Figure 1C).
13. A, Color fundus photography montage of the left eye shows hyperemic disc with blurred margins, vascular sheathing, and peripheral retinal whitening.
14. B, Magnified image of the temporal retina shows well-demarcated infiltrates with scalloped margins and adjacent intraretinal hemorrhages.
15. C, Montage from 4 days later shows convergence of necrotic lesions in a circumferential pattern around the equator with confluence in the anterior periphery.
16. Fresh laser barricade spots are seen at the posterior margin of the areas of necrosis.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Inject an antivascular endothelial growth factor agent  
B: Order a hypercoagulable workup and start a regimen of aspirin, 325 mg daily  
C: Obtain an aqueous fluid sample for polymerase chain reaction and treat with antiviral agents  
D: Obtain a vitreous sample for culture and inject vancomycin and ceftazidime

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with worsening dyspnea over the past 48 hours.
2. He recently had a cold that kept him home from work for the past week.
3. He has a past medical history of diabetes, obesity, and hypertension.
4. He had his Achilles tendon repaired 4 weeks ago and he has been less mobile.
5. His temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 150/85 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air.
6. Physical exam is notable for dyspnea provoked by walking short distances.
7. Jugular venous distension is noted on exam.
8. The patient’s blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg during inspiration.
9. A bedside echocardiogram demonstrates impaired diastolic filling with normal ventricular contractility.
10. An ECG is performed as seen in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Restrictive cardiomyopathy  
B. Myocardial infarction  
C. Constrictive pericarditis  
D. Pulmonary embolism

step1_excerpts:
1. A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of palpitations, sweating, and flushing.
2. Since he was promoted to a manager in a large software company 6 months ago, he has had several episodes of these symptoms when he has to give presentations in front of a large group of people.
3. During these episodes, his thoughts start racing and he fears that his face will “turn red” and everyone will laugh at him.
4. He has tried to avoid the presentations but fears that he might lose his job if he continues to do so.
5. He is healthy except for mild persistent asthma.
6. He frequently smokes marijuana to calm his nerves.
7. He does not drink alcohol.
8. His only medication is an albuterol inhaler.
9. His pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg.
10. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities.
11. On mental status examination, the patient appears calm.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Public speaking skills training  
B. Marijuana cessation counseling  
C. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor therapy  
D. Lorazepam therapy  
E. Biofeedback therapy  
F. Mindfulness-based stress reduction  
G. Group therapy  
H. Exposure therapy  
I. Propranolol therapy  
J. Cognitive behavioral therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A Chinese woman had painless, gradually declined vision for 2 years without redness.
2. She had a medical history of vomiting and emaciation in her early 40s.
3. Pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) had been done for her left eye owing to vitreous opacity half a year prior.
4. She claimed that her younger brother died of liver cancer and her mother had lost vision because of vitreous hemorrhage and glaucoma.
5. She denied any history of systemic disorders.
6. On initial examination, best-corrected visual acuity was measured at 0.1 (20/200) OU.
7. Intraocular pressure was 14 mm Hg OD and 16 mm Hg OS.
8. Her anterior segment examination results were within normal limits.
9. Dilated fundus examination demonstrated bilateral vitreous opacity without cells (Figure).
10. The peripheral residual vitreous cortex in the left eye was as cloudy as the cortex in the right eye.
11. Fundus was not visible in the right eye and was normal in the left eye.
12. A bilateral ocular ultrasonography showed normal results except for vitreous opacity.
13. The patient weighed 37.0 kg and was 155 cm tall.
14. Her blood pressure was 113/70 mm Hg.
15. Mild anemia (hemoglobin level 10.5 g/dL vs a normal range of 11.0-15.0 g/dL [to convert to grams per liter, multiply by 10]) was found in routine blood test results.
16. Liver and renal functions were normal according to serum test results.
17. The results of an electronic cardiogram were negative.
18. Mosaic 9-field 50° fundus photography showed a uniform, glassy, woollike appearance of the vitreous in the right eye (A) and peripheral vitreous opacity in the left after pars plana virectomy (B).
19. Aqueous humor biopsy for cytometry and biochemical test
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Aqueous humor biopsy for cytometry and biochemical test  
B: PPV plus pathological examination plus genetic test  
C: Abdominal ultrasonography  
D: Follow-up

step1_excerpts:
1. A 49-year-old woman presents with facial discomfort and nasal congestion lasting 10 days.
2. Her medical history is notable for chronic nasal congestion and anosmia, which have progressively worsened over the past few years.
3. She is otherwise healthy, without allergies, and is not on any medications.
4. On examination, her vital signs are normal, and she is afebrile.
5. There is no tenderness over the sinuses on palpation.
6. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals bilateral lobulated masses with pale mucosa in both nasal cavities.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

A. MRI with contrast of the sinuses  
B. CT of the sinuses  
C. Oral antibiotic therapy  
D. Allergy testing  
E. Nasal decongestant spray  
F. Referral to ENT specialist  
G. Saline nasal irrigation  
H. Oral antihistamine therapy  
I. Endoscopic biopsy of the masses  
J. Intranasal glucocorticoid spray

step1_excerpts:
1. An otherwise healthy 8-year-old girl presented with a relatively rapidly growing reddish mass on the caruncle of the left eye.
2. On external examination, a pink, fleshy, pedunculated lesion with telangiectatic vessels on the surface was seen over the left caruncle (Figure 1).
3. Her best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OU.
4. Her ocular motility was intact in both eyes.
5. The results of the examination of the anterior and posterior segments were within normal limits.
6. Treat with prednisolone acetate, 1%, ophthalmic solution 4 times per day
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Orbital imaging (magnetic resonance imaging)  
B: Treat with prednisolone acetate, 1%, ophthalmic solution 4 times per day  
C: Reassure and observe  
D: Cryotherapy (double–freeze-thaw method)

step1_excerpts:
1. A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found wandering the streets naked and armed with a sword.
2. He was restrained by police due to combative behavior.
3. Once calmed, he reports being pursued and expresses a need to "kill them all." The patient is treated with intramuscular haloperidol and diphenhydramine and is admitted to the psychiatric ward.
4. His medical history includes schizophrenia, obesity, anxiety, recurrent pneumonia, and depression.
5. After stabilization, he is discharged five days later on his home medications along with prescriptions for mood stabilizers and antidepressants.
6. One week after discharge, the patient is found by police outside in freezing temperatures and brought to the emergency department with a rectal temperature of 93.2°F (34°C).
7. Emergency resuscitation is initiated.
question_options:
Which of the following medications most likely contributed to this patient's hypothermia?

A. Clozapine  
B. Fluphenazine  
C. Fluoxetine  
D. Olanzapine  
E. Quetiapine  
F. Risperidone  
G. Haloperidol  
H. Aripiprazole  
I. Lithium  
J. Ziprasidone

step1_excerpts:
1. A 50-year-old woman was referred to the oculoplastic clinic for evaluation of bilateral vascular lesions of the eye visible beneath the palpebral conjunctivae on the upper and lower eyelids.  
2. She denied any vision changes or pain but did report a sensation of pressure in the location of the lesions, which was relieved when prone.  
3. She had a 25-year history of bulimia and was purging almost daily.  
4. She reported an inability to go more than 3 days at a time without purging and noted a reduction in the pressure and size of her lesions with respite from these daily episodes.  
5. She had no history of eye surgery, hypertension, atherosclerotic disease, or other risk factors for vascular disease.  
6. The patient first noticed these lesions 15 years ago in association with a subconjunctival hemorrhage on the left side.  
7. An orbital magnetic resonance image obtained at the time of that episode demonstrated a 2 × 0.6-cm focus of enhancement along the inferior and inferolateral palpebral tissues anterior to the left globe, suggestive of lymphangioma, hemangioma, or vascular malformation without other focal abnormalities.  
8. The anterior segment examination showed bilateral superior (Figure, A) and inferior (Figure, B) large dilated blood vessels underlying the palpebral conjunctivae.  
9. Complete ophthalmic and orbital examinations revealed no other abnormalities. Eyelids of the patient demonstrating vascular lesions visible within the palpebral tissue at the time of presentation.  
10. A, Atypical vascular dilation along the superior peripheral arcade of the right eye.  
11. The left eye had similar findings.  
12. B, Atypical vascular dilation along the inferior palpebral arcade of the left eye.  
13. The right eye had similar findings. Observe periocular lesions while psychiatric treatment is continued
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  
A: Sclerotherapy  
B: Surgical excision  
C: Initiate systemic administration of propranolol  
D: Observe periocular lesions while psychiatric treatment is continued

step1_excerpts:
1. A 52-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of severe dyspnea and cough productive of tenacious, brownishyellow sputum for the past 3 weeks.
2. He has a 15-year career history of sandblasting old buildings.
3. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years.
4. The patient is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 59 kg (130 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2 .
5. Vital signs are temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse 94/min, and blood pressure 150/92 mm Hg.
6. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 70%.
7. On physical examination he is in moderately severe distress with pursed lips and cyanotic nail beds.
8. Chest has an increased anteroposterior diameter.
9. Auscultation of the chest discloses scattered wheezes and rhonchi over all lung fields.
10. Cardiac examination discloses muffled heart sounds and an S4.
11. Fingers are clubbed.
12. Chest x-ray shows hyperinflated lungs, flattened diaphragm, large, irregular opacities in the upper lobes, and eggshell calcifications of the hilar lymph nodes.
question_options:
In addition to antibiotic therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?

A. Azathioprine therapy

B. Bronchoscopy

C. Continuous humidified oxygen

D. Nocturnal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)

step1_excerpts:
1. A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of dizziness for 6 weeks.
2. When she stands up suddenly, she becomes light-headed and has to steady herself for approximately 1 to 2 minutes before she is able to walk.
3. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus.
4. Current medications include glyburide, a diuretic, a β-adrenergic blocking agent, and an angiotensinconverting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.
5. Her pulse is 55/min.
6. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg in the right arm and 70/50 mm Hg in the left arm while supine; her blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg in the right arm and 50/30 mm Hg in the left arm immediately after standing.
7. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings.
8. An ECG shows sinus bradycardia with no evidence of ischemia.
9. Carotid duplex ultrasonography shows reverse flow in the left vertebral artery with no evidence of occlusion.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Cardiac stress scintigraphy

B. Adjusting her medication regimen

C. Warfarin therapy

D. Transesophageal echocardiography

step1_excerpts:
1. A 14-day-old girl presented with vesicular lesions over her trunk and lower extremities.  
2. According to her mother, lesions had started 2 days prior.  
3. Physical examination revealed vesicles filled with clear fluid disposed in a linear arrangement forming whorls and swirls (Figure, A).  
4. A, Linear vesicles on the calf of the newborn patient.  
5. The lesions appeared on the 13th day of life.  
6. B, After 15 months, the lesions had evolved into small hyperpigmented macules in a linear arrangement.  
7. C and D, A biopsy specimen of a vesicle was obtained.  
8. Herpes simplex and varicella zoster virus polymerase chain reactions were negative.  
9. Syphilis, cytomegalovirus, and toxoplasma serologies were negative.  
10. Bacterial and fungal cultures of the vesicles were negative.  
11. A biopsy sample of a vesicle was obtained.  
12. Over time, lesions healed leaving residual grayish hyperpigmentation (Figure, B).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Congenital herpes zoster  
B: Neonatal pustular melanosis  
C: Incontinentia pigmenti  
D: Linear and whorled nevoid hypermelanosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 25-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a chief complaint of "failing health." He states that he typically can converse with animals via telepathy but is having trouble right now due to the weather.
2. He has begun taking an assortment of Peruvian herbs to little avail.
3. Otherwise, he is not currently taking any medications.
4. The patient lives alone and works in a health food store.
5. He states that his symptoms have persisted for the past 8 months.
6. When obtaining the patient's medical history, there are several times he attempts to telepathically connect with the animals in the vicinity.
7. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 115/71 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 12/min.
8. On physical exam, you note a healthy young man who is dressed in an all-burlap ensemble.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Brief psychotic disorder  
B. Schizoid personality disorder  
C. Schizotypal personality disorder  
D. Schizophrenia

step1_excerpts:
1. A 32-year-old G1P0 presents to the antenatal testing unit at 32 weeks of gestation for a non-stress test (NST).
2. Yesterday she had several episodes of diarrhea and vomited once after attending a company picnic 2 days ago.
3. She took loperamide with symptomatic relief.
4. She is worried that she is dehydrated but otherwise feels well and has recovered from her gastrointestinal illness.
5. The patient was diagnosed with gestational diabetes after routine screening in the 2nd trimester and has been started on insulin after unsuccessful attempts at lifestyle management.
6. She also has migraines and gastroesophageal reflux disorder.
7. The patient has a 15-pack-year smoking history but quit smoking in her 1st month of pregnancy.
8. She denies alcohol or drug use.
9. Her temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 122/82 mmHg, pulse is 84/min, and respirations are 14/min.
10. A representative portion of the NST is shown in Figure A.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s non-stress test (NST) results?

A. Maternal medication use  
B. Normal results  
C. Fetal sleep cycle  
D. Maternal smoking

step1_excerpts:
1. A 4-year-old girl was referred for further evaluation of an asymptomatic, unilateral retinal mass identified by an optometrist on a routine vision screening examination.  
2. Her medical history was unremarkable.  
3. Her immunizations were up to date, and she had had an uncomplicated prenatal and delivery course.  
4. Her ocular history and family history were unremarkable.  
5. On examination, the patient’s visual acuity was 20/25 OU and pupillary responses and intraocular pressures were normal.  
6. The anterior segments were normal, the lenses were clear, and there was no inflammation in either eye.  
7. On a dilated fundus examination, the vitreous was clear bilaterally.  
8. A single, superonasal, white retinal mass with no visible calcification or subretinal fluid was present in the right eye (approximately 2.5 disc diameters away from the optic nerve), with associated retinal pigment epithelium changes at the edge of the lesion (Figure 1) and a normal optic disc and posterior pole.  
9. The left posterior segment was normal.Right eye fundus photograph at presentation: ultra-widefield image obtained in the clinic.  
10. Peripheral image artifacts include the nose and eyelashes (inverted).  
11. The retinal mass is denoted with arrowheads.Initiate a uveitis workup for infectious and inflammatory conditionsPlan an urgent examination under anesthesia, ultrasonography, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)Obtain chest and abdomen MRI to evaluate for cardiac rhabdomyoma and kidney cysts or tumors associated with neurocutaneous syndromes
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  

A: Initiate a uveitis workup for infectious and inflammatory conditions  
B: Plan an urgent examination under anesthesia, ultrasonography, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)  
C: Obtain chest and abdomen MRI to evaluate for cardiac rhabdomyoma and kidney cysts or tumors associated with neurocutaneous syndromes  
D: Continue to monitor clinically with serial examinations

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 70s presented with a new 4-cm left upper lobe lung mass with hilar lymphadenopathy.
2. Biopsy results demonstrated a squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung, and chemoradiotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel for stage 3A disease was initiated.
3. An allergic reaction prompted a change to cisplatin-etoposide, which continued as adjuvant chemotherapy after the radiation was complete.
4. At first restaging, a recurrence of disease in the lung was detected, which was treated with cisplatin and gemcitabine for 4 months before she enrolled in a clinical trial (NCT02009449) in which she received combination therapy with pembrolizumab, 2 mg/kg intravenously for 21 days, and an investigational agent, AM0010 (pegylated recombinant human interleukin-10), 10 μg/kg subcutaneously on days 1 through 14 of the 21-day cycle.
5. Three months into treatment, she developed multiple thick, mildly pruritic, yellow hyperkeratotic plaques on her lower extremities (Figure, A).
6. A referral to a dermatology expert was initiated.A, Clinical image showing representative plaque on left leg of patient on initial presentation.
7. B, Shave biopsy of skin (hematoxylin-eosin; original magnification ×10).
8. C, Deeper biopsy demonstrating bandlike lymphocytic infiltration (hematoxylin-eosin; original magnification ×20).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Squamous cell carcinoma  
B: Plaque psoriasis  
C: Hypertrophic lichen planus  
D: Keratoacanthoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 64-year-old female presents to the emergency department with progressive bilateral lower extremity edema that began one month ago and is now affecting her ability to walk.
2. Her medical history includes hypertension and morbid obesity, with losartan as her only medication.
3. Her vital signs show: temperature 37.4 ºC (99.3 ºF), heart rate 96/min, blood pressure 132/85, respiratory rate 18/min, and SpO2 90% on room air.
4. Physical examination reveals bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation and bilateral moderate pitting edema with erythematous, cool skin extending to the distal tibias.
5. Ultrasound demonstrates a non-compressible right small saphenous vein.
question_options:
While additional test results are pending, which of the following interventions would be most appropriate to initiate at this time?

A. Hydrochlorothiazide  
B. Enoxaparin  
C. Furosemide  
D. Spironolactone  
E. Cephalexin  
F. Warfarin initiation  
G. Torsemide  
H. Compression stockings  
I. Metolazone  
J. Elevation of lower extremities

step1_excerpts:
1. A 21-year-old college student presents for evaluation of an intensely pruritic eruption on the ankle and sole of his right foot.  
2. The patient recently returned from a trip to Puerto Rico.  
3. He noticed the lesions approximately 1 week after his return.  
4. He has no significant past medical history.  
5. On physical examination, the patient is in overall good health.  
6. Notable findings include 3 red, serpiginous lesions on the heel (Figure, A), lateral area of the midfoot (Figure, B), and ankle, some with vesicles.  
7. Vesicles were also noted over the Achilles tendon.Serpiginous lesions on the heel (A) and lateral area of the midfoot (B) of the patient.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  

A: Do nothing; it will resolve with time  
B: Prescribe topical steroids  
C: Prescribe oral anthelmintic therapy  
D: Prescribe oral antibiotics

step1_excerpts:
1. A 72-year-old man with a medical history of atrial fibrillation, type 2 diabetes mellitus, chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and congestive heart failure presented with a 2-month history of scaly erythematous papules on both forearms (Figure, A).
2. The lesions were pruritic at times and the patient reported no improvement with chlorhexidine wash or hydrocortisone, 1%, cream.
3. He was otherwise asymptomatic, and review of his systems revealed no abnormalities.
4. His medications included amiodarone, furosemide, nifedipine, insulin glargine, and allopurinol.
5. He denied preceding trauma, recent travel, or new medications.A, Red, scaly papules on the patient's forearm.
6. B, Punch biopsy specimen from the center of a papule on the forearm shows pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia, spongiosis with vesiculation, intraepidermal neutrophilic microabscesses, focal subepidermal bulla formation, and dermal infiltrate of neutrophils, lymphocytes, and histiocytes (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×4).Physical examination revealed numerous red to violaceous scaly papules symmetrically distributed on both forearms.
7. Laboratory tests revealed a serum creatinine level of 3.79 mg/dL (normal range, 0.70-1.40 mg/dL) and serum iodine level of 42 305 ng/mL (normal range, 40-92 ng/mL).
8. A punch biopsy was obtained from the center of a papule on the right forearm
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Sweet syndrome  
B: Iododerma  
C: Sporotrichosis  
D: Pemphigus vegetans

step1_excerpts:
1. A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 8 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit.
2. She delivered her first child spontaneously at 34 weeks' gestation; pregnancy was complicated by iron deficiency anemia.
3. She has no other history of serious illness.
4. Her blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg.
5. Examination shows no abnormalities.
6. Ultrasonography shows a dichorionic-diamniotic twin intrauterine pregnancy consistent in size with an 8-week gestation.
question_options:
This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?

A. Abruptio placentae

B. Fetal chromosome abnormality

C. Hyperthyroidism

D. Preterm labor and delivery

step1_excerpts:
1. A 12-year-old boy presented for evaluation of a 3-month history of ulcerated lesions on the dorsal aspect of his feet since returning from Pakistan, where his family was living.
2. The patient had no history of medical problems.
3. He was born in Spain and had received his childhood immunizations.
4. He remembered insect bites on his feet, but the lesions later became ulcerated and painful.
5. The patient denied experiencing fever, arthralgia, or a sore throat.
6. Findings from the physical examination revealed 6 painful ulcerated, exudative nodules with a grayish membrane over the ulcers on the dorsal aspect of his feet (Figure 1).
7. No signs of lymphangitis or lymphadenopathy were detected.
8. A 4-mm punch biopsy specimen from one lesion was obtained and stained with hematoxylin-eosin and Gram stain for histopathologic analysis.
9. Another skin specimen was cultured for microbiologic analysis.
10. Ulcerated and exudative nodules with grayish membrane on the dorsal aspect of the feet.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Cutaneous tuberculosis  
B: Ecthyma gangrenosum  
C: Leishmaniasis  
D: Cutaneous diphtheria

step1_excerpts:
1. A 62-year-old woman visits her physician for a routine health maintenance checkup.
2. She reports feeling well.
3. Six months ago, she received an influenza vaccine.
4. Her last mammogram, performed a year ago, was normal.
5. Two years ago, both her Pap smear and colonoscopy showed no abnormalities.
6. Her medical history includes hypertension.
7. She has a family history of myocardial infarction; her father passed away at age 50 due to the condition.
8. She emigrated from Japan 30 years ago.
9. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily and has done so for the past 18 years.
10. She consumes 4–5 glasses of wine per day and participates in ballroom dancing twice weekly.
11. Her medications include enalapril and low-dose aspirin.
12. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall, weighs 50 kg (110 lb), and has a BMI of 18 kg/m².
13. Vital signs are normal.
14. On examination, a soft S4 gallop is heard during cardiopulmonary evaluation, but the rest of the physical exam is unremarkable.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

A. Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry  
B. Transesophageal echocardiography  
C. Carotid doppler ultrasound  
D. Mammography screening  
E. 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring  
F. Spirometry testing  
G. Stress echocardiography  
H. Low-dose CT scan of the chest  
I. Comprehensive metabolic panel  
J. Serum alcohol level measurement

step1_excerpts:
1. A 3-week-old girl presents with her parents to her pediatrician for a routine visit.
2. The child is sleeping at regular 2-hour intervals and feeding and stooling well.
3. The parents have noticed a “swelling of the belly button.” Cord separation occurred at 7 days of age.
4. The swelling seems to come and go but is never larger than the size of a blueberry.
5. They deny any drainage from the swelling.
6. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 68/43 mmHg, pulse is 128/min, and respirations are 32/min.
7. On physical exam, the child is in no acute distress and appears developmentally appropriate for her age.
8. Her abdomen is soft and non-tender with a soft, 1 cm bulge at the umbilicus.
9. The bulge increases in size when the child cries and can be easily reduced inside the umbilical ring without apparent pain.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Elective surgical management  
B. Immediate surgical management  
C. Expectant management  
D. Histopathologic evaluation

step1_excerpts:
1. A pediatric patient with known cystic fibrosis presents to the emergency department with acute respiratory symptoms.
2. The 8-year-old male, who had meconium ileus at birth and was diagnosed through neonatal screening, has a history of multiple respiratory infections requiring hospitalization.
3. His current medications include albuterol, pancreatic enzymes, and vitamins A and D3.
4. He presents with a 2-day history of fever (39.6°C), tachypnea (44/min), tachycardia (122/min), and productive yellow sputum.
5. Physical examination reveals labored breathing with subcostal retractions, and decreased breath sounds with dullness to percussion over the right upper lung.
6. Chest x-ray demonstrates right upper lobe consolidation with increased translucency and tram-track opacities in the upper lung fields.
7. Oxygen saturation is 91% on room air.
question_options:
Which pathogen is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?

A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa  
B. Mycoplasma pneumoniae  
C. Haemophilus influenzae  
D. Escherichia coli  
E. Aspergillus fumigatus  
F. Klebsiella pneumoniae  
G. Moraxella catarrhalis  
H. Streptococcus pneumoniae  
I. Burkholderia cepacia  
J. Staphylococcus aureus

step1_excerpts:
1. A 43-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter because she has been intermittently crying for 6 hours and does not want to get out of bed.  
2. Her symptoms started after she was fired yesterday from her job of 20 years.  
3. She says she feels sad and does not understand what she will do with her life now.  
4. She uses an over-the-counter inhaler as needed for exercise-induced asthma, and recently started oral isotretinoin for acne.  
5. She used to smoke a pack of cigarettes per day, but for the last year, she has decreased to two cigarettes daily.  
6. She appears sad and upset.  
7. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg.  
8. Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  
9. On mental status examination, she is oriented to person, place, and time.  
10. She maintains eye contact and follows instructions.  
11. She denies suicidal ideation.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Normal stress reaction  
B. Acute stress disorder  
C. Bereavement  
D. Situational depression  
E. Substance-induced mood disorder  
F. Acute grief reaction  
G. Adjustment disorder  
H. Generalized anxiety disorder  
I. Major depressive disorder  
J. Dysthymic disorder

step1_excerpts:
1. A 31-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, who is at 32 weeks' gestation, is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-week history of progressive dyspnea and wheezing.
2. She says her heart is "racing" and she is coughing up a small amount of bloodstreaked sputum.
3. Medical history is significant for hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine.
4. An intravenous catheter is placed.
5. Vital signs are temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse 132/min, respirations 32/min, and blood pressure 135/78 mm Hg.
6. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen via nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 92%.
7. Auscultation of the lungs discloses decreased breath sounds at the bases with expiratory crackles bilaterally.
8. Cardiac examination discloses an irregularly irregular rhythm, an indistinct point of maximal impulse, and a loud S1.
9. A grade 3/6, low-pitched, diastolic, rumbling murmur is audible at the apex; a distinct snapping sound precedes the murmur.
10. Fetal heart rate is 144/min.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely cause of the findings in this patient?

A. Chronic mitral regurgitation secondary to rheumatic heart disease

B. Coarctation of the aorta

C. Congenital aortic stenosis

D. Mitral stenosis complicated by atrial fibrillation

step1_excerpts:
1. A 19-year-old female student-athlete with no prior medical conditions or medications presents for evaluation of elevated blood pressure.
2. Her current reading is 182/100 mm Hg, with consistent measurements between upper and lower extremities.
3. Previous readings include 178/85 mm Hg one week ago and 185/90 mm Hg six months prior.
4. A home measurement from last week showed 162/95 mm Hg in the right upper extremity.
5. Her dorsalis pedis pulses are strong and equal bilaterally, without radiofemoral delay.
6. The physical exam is normal except for elevated blood pressure, and no bruits are detected.
7. Pregnancy test is negative.
8. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, thyroid function tests, and inflammatory markers, are all within normal range.
question_options:
What is the most probable diagnosis?

A. White coat hypertension  
B. Thyroid storm  
C. Renal artery fibromuscular dysplasia  
D. Coarctation of the aorta  
E. Primary hyperaldosteronism  
F. Pheochromocytoma  
G. Essential hypertension  
H. Cushing's syndrome  
I. Renovascular atherosclerosis  
J. Performance-enhancing drug use

step1_excerpts:
1. A 48-year-old man was admitted to our emergency department 12 hours after a bicycle accident with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.
2. He described abdominal trauma caused by the bicycle handlebar.
3. The patient reported undergoing an appendectomy at age 23 years and having ulcerative colitis since he was aged 30 years.
4. He had received treatment (mesalazine and corticosteroids) for inflammatory bowel disease that had been discontinued.
5. Physical examination revealed paraumbilical ecchymosis (Figure 1A), general abdominal tenderness, and distension.
6. Body temperature, blood pressure, and heart and respiratory rates were normal.
7. Laboratory test findings did not show abnormalities except for the leukocyte count (12 300 cells/μL [to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001]); hemoglobin and hematocrit levels were within the reference ranges.
8. An abdominal computed tomographic (CT) scan, performed immediately, revealed a pneumoperitoneum and free fluid in the lower quadrants of the abdomen (Figure 1B).
9. Preoperative workup.
10. A, Paraumbilical bruising.
11. B, Abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan: coronal cut showing free fluid (white arrowhead) and pneumoperitoneum (red arrowheads).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Pancreas injury  
B: Flaring ulcerative colitis  
C: Rectosigmoid junction rupture  
D: Duodenal injury

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 70s with a history of sarcoidosis presented with progressive supraclavicular, facial, and mandibular swelling of 3 months’ duration.
2. She reported pain with chewing, which led to a 5-kg weight loss, but denied trismus.
3. On examination, there was craniofacial deformity with left facial preauricular swelling.
4. The left parotid was firm and a fixed mass was felt throughout the left preauricular space, expanding into the temporomandibular joint area and zygoma.
5. Soft-mobile lymphadenopathy was palpable in the left neck, and a firm, adherent, immobile right supraclavicular mass extended under the clavicle.
6. Cranial nerve examination findings were normal.
7. Magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomography of the neck showed a 3.2 × 4.4 × 2.8-cm lobulated enhancing paramandibular mass extending into the left masticator space and infratemporal fossa, with frank erosion of the left mandibular condyle (Figure).
8. Several enlarged lymph nodes were noted.
9. Computed tomography of the chest showed a 4.6 × 3.2 × 3.5-cm supraclavicular mass with infiltration of the surrounding fat and scalene muscle and extension into the chest wall and axilla.
10. Positron emission tomography showed a large metabolically active left masticator space mass (standardized uptake value for body weight at maximum counts per pixel [SUVmax], 18.2) and previously mentioned pathologic nodes.
11. The right supraclavicular mass was also metabolically active (SUVmax, 19.4), and metabolically active right axillary, left mediastinal, and intra-abdominal lymphadenopathy was also noted.
12. A, Axial computed tomography of the head and neck showing a lobulated paramandibular mass (arrowhead).
13. B, Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain showing a lobulated paramandibular mass (arrowhead).
14. C, Coronal computed tomography of the chest demonstrating a paramandibular mass (arrowhead).
15. D, Coronal computed tomography of the chest demonstrating a supraclavicular mass (arrowhead).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Squamous cell carcinoma  
B: Chondrosarcoma  
C: Adenoid cystic carcinoma  
D: Lymphoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A previously healthy, fair-skinned professional golfer aged 69 years with a history of frequent outdoor sun exposure presented to the surgery clinic with a mass on his left upper back, which he first noted 1 year ago as a small nodule on his back.
2. It grew rapidly throughout the past year, becoming increasingly painful and bleeding easily with light contact.
3. Clinical examination revealed an 8 × 6 × 4-cm multilobulated, purplish lesion that was fungating and friable (Figure 1).
4. He also had a palpable, hard mass in the left axilla.
5. He had no other lesions elsewhere on his body.
6. A punch biopsy of the back mass revealed immunohistochemistry strongly positive for S-100, MART-1, and HMB-45.
7. Computed tomographic and positron emission tomographic scans demonstrated a fludeoxyglucose-avid lesion on the back extending into the subcutaneous fat and fludeoxyglucose-avid uptake in the left axilla.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Cavernous lymphangioma  
B: Nodular basal cell carcinoma  
C: Squamous cell carcinoma  
D: Nodular melanoma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 21-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician due to a history of abdominal pain.
2. She states that she has had recurrent bouts of mood swings, bloating, and abdominal pain that occur together approximately every 4 weeks.
3. She states that when these symptoms occur, she gets into frequent arguments at work, is unable to concentrate, and sleeps longer than usual.
4. Furthermore, she has episodes of extreme anxiety during these periods, leading her to take off time from work.
5. She notes that these symptoms are causing distress in her interpersonal relationships as well.
6. She has no past medical history and takes no medications.
7. She experienced menarche at age 12 and has regular periods.
8. Her temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, pulse is 75/min, and respirations are 12/min.
9. Physical exam reveals a nontender abdomen.
10. Pelvic exam reveals a closed cervix with no cervical motion or adnexal tenderness.
11. Her cardiopulmonary and neurological exams are unremarkable.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Premenstrual dysophoric disorder  
B. Premenstrual syndrome  
C. Major depressive disorder  
D. Generalized anxiety disorder

step1_excerpts:
1. A patient with advanced melanoma (stage IV with liver, lung, and lymph node metastases) presents for evaluation of severe lower back pain that began one week ago.  
2. The pain is described as a significant midline lower back ache with sharp bilateral radiation to the lower extremities, accompanied by new difficulty standing from seated position.  
3. Current treatment includes oxycodone and combination immunotherapy with pembrolizumab and ipilimumab.  
4. On examination, vital signs show: temperature 98.4°F, pulse 94/min, blood pressure 132/86 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation 97% on room air.  
5. The lower back is tender to light touch.  
6. The patient moves all extremities spontaneously, with 3+/5 strength in both lower extremities.  
7. Lower extremity sensation and reflexes are intact.  
8. Spinal MRI reveals a new T12 lytic lesion with vertebral body collapse, bone fragment retropulsion into the spinal cord, epidural extension, and cord compression.
question_options:
After emergency administration of dexamethasone, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Discontinue immunotherapy  
B. Vancomycin plus piperacillin-tazobactam  
C. Increase oxycodone dosage  
D. MRI with contrast  
E. Urgent vertebroplasty  
F. Neurosurgical consultation  
G. Continue dexamethasone  
H. Physical therapy evaluation  
I. Palliative care consultation  
J. Radiation-oncology consultation

step1_excerpts:
1. A 27-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 41 weeks of gestation, is admitted to the hospital in active labor.
2. Her pregnancy has been uneventful, and her first two children were delivered vaginally.
3. She has a history of asthma and is currently taking iron and vitamin supplements.
4. Following a prolonged labor, she delivers vaginally but soon experiences heavy vaginal bleeding with clots.
5. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/72 mm Hg.
6. Examination reveals a soft, enlarged, and boggy uterus.
7. Laboratory results are as follows:

| Hemoglobin | 10.8 g/dL |
| --- | --- |
| Hematocrit | 32.3% |
| Leukocyte count | 9,000/mm³ |
| Platelet count | 140,000/mm³ |
| Prothrombin time | 14 seconds |
| Partial thromboplastin time | 38 seconds |

Despite bimanual uterine massage and administration of oxytocin, the bleeding persists.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Administer carboprost tromethamine  
B. Perform uterine artery embolization  
C. Administer tranexamic acid  
D. Begin methylergonovine administration  
E. Begin immediate blood transfusion  
F. Perform manual placental extraction  
G. Perform uterine tamponade  
H. Start misoprostol therapy  
I. Initiate fresh frozen plasma transfusion  
J. Initiate emergency hysterectomy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 20-year-old male presents to the emergency department 6 hours after sustaining a punch to the head during a fistfight.
2. He reports ongoing headache and dizziness since the incident, unrelieved by over-the-counter pain medication.
3. He denies losing consciousness or experiencing other trauma.
4. His vital signs are normal, and neurological examination shows intact cranial nerves I-XII with normal muscle strength, sensation, and deep tendon reflexes.
5. During vault hold examination, the examiner's index fingers demonstrate symmetric downward (caudad) movement, while the little fingers move upward (cephalad).
question_options:
Which sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) dysfunction is most likely present?

A. Superior vertical strain  
B. Compression  
C. Lateral strain dysfunction  
D. Flexion dysfunction  
E. Occipital-atlantal dysfunction  
F. Torsion dysfunction  
G. Extension dysfunction  
H. Bilateral temporal bone external rotation  
I. Compression dysfunction  
J. Inferior vertical strain

step1_excerpts:
1. A 44-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of neck pain following a motor vehicle collision the previous day.  
2. She was the restrained driver of a stationary vehicle that was rear-ended.  
3. She denies head trauma or loss of consciousness.  
4. Vital signs are normal, and physical examination reveals diffuse tenderness of the cervical spine without step-off deformities.  
5. The patient expresses interest in manipulative therapy, which she has found helpful for pain relief in the past.  
6. The physician plans to use a technique involving an impulse of force within the anatomic range of motion to address her restriction.
question_options:
Which of the following conditions would absolutely contraindicate this treatment?

A. Joint instability  
B. Acute whiplash  
C. Herniated disc  
D. Osteoporosis  
E. Degenerative disc disease  
F. Facet joint syndrome  
G. Muscle spasm  
H. Recent cervical strain  
I. Pregnancy  
J. Cervical spondylosis

step1_excerpts:
1. During a routine well-child visit, a 13-year-old boy is evaluated by his pediatrician.
2. His mother reports no significant concerns, and the patient is excelling in school and actively participates in soccer.
3. He has achieved all developmental milestones, and his vital signs and general examination are normal.
4. However, during the forward Adam's bend test, the physician observes a hump on the right side.
question_options:
Which of the following best characterizes this patient's condition?

A. Vertebrae compressed anteriorly  
B. Aggressive disease course  
C. Vertebrae anteriorly displaced  
D. Vertebrae wedged laterally left  
E. Vertebrae sidebent left  
F. Vertebrae posteriorly displaced  
G. Vertebrae compressed posteriorly  
H. Vertebrae rotated counterclockwise  
I. Vertebrae wedged laterally right  
J. Vertebrae sidebent right

step1_excerpts:
1. A 9-month-old girl presented to the emergency department with significant left periocular edema and erythema 3 days after receiving intra-arterial chemotherapy (IAC) with 0.4 mg/kg of melphalan, 50 mg of carboplatin, and 2 mg of topotecan (with routine intravenous dexamethasone therapy, 0.5 mg/kg) for treatment of unilateral International Classification of Retinoblastoma group C retinoblastoma in the left eye (Figure, A).
2. At the time of IAC, she had an upper respiratory tract infection (coughing, congestion, rhinorrhea, fever [temperature of 38.9 °C]).
3. On postoperative day 1, her temperature reached 39.4 °C, and she was diagnosed as having bilateral acute otitis media and discharged with amoxicillin therapy.
4. On postoperative day 3, she returned to the emergency department with left eye swelling, continued fever, and poor oral intake.
5. On physical examination, her temperature was 40.2 °C, and periorbital swelling and erythema were present without drainage.
6. Dilated fundus examination at the bedside showed the known large retinoblastoma tumor.
7. A large exudative retinal detachment was noted, which was not present prior to treatment.
8. Blood bacterial culture testing showed no growth, respiratory viral testing revealed rhinovirus, and results of comprehensive metabolic testing were unremarkable.
9. Complete blood cell count showed mild leukopenia (2700/μL [to convert to ×109 per liter, multiply by 0.001]) and anemia (hemoglobin, 9.2 g/dL [to convert to grams per liter, multiply by 10]) but were otherwise within reference ranges.
10. Computed tomography scan of the orbits, recommended by the on-call general ophthalmologist, demonstrated preseptal and periorbital soft tissue swelling and edema with subtle retrobulbar stranding, without substantial proptosis, along with retinal detachment (Figure, B).
11. She was admitted for intravenous fluids for her noted dehydration.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Begin intravenous vancomycin and cefepime  
B: Perform examination under anesthesia  
C: Start systemic corticosteroids  
D: Observe

step1_excerpts:
1. A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 2-hour history of confusion and agitation.  
2. He also has had fever, headache, stiff neck, and vomiting since he returned from summer camp 2 days ago.  
3. His parents say he does not use illicit drugs.  
4. On arrival, he is combative and there is evidence of hallucinations.  
5. His temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg.  
6. A lumbar puncture is performed.  
7. Results of cerebrospinal fluid analysis show cysts and trophozoites.
question_options:
The most likely portal of pathogen entry into this patient's central nervous system is which of the following?

A. Facial nerve

B. Frontal sinus

C. Mastoid sinus

D. Olfactory nerve

step1_excerpts:
