B. BUN/Creatinine ratio  
D. Urine output  
F. Serum chloride trend  
G. Urine osmolality  
J. Serum potassium trend

step1_excerpts:
1. A 67-year-old man with thoracolumbar scoliosis, poor mobility, and history of frequent falls presented to the emergency department with 2 months of left shoulder pain, stiffness and reduced range of motion, and numbness and paresthesias in his left upper extremity.
2. Ten years prior to presentation, he underwent surgical decompression for syringomyelia.
3. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of his cervical and thoracic spine performed 2 years prior to presentation revealed a recurrent syrinx extending from C1 to T11, which was not resected because it did not cause symptoms at that time.
4. On physical examination, he had mild tenderness to palpation and reduced range of motion of the left shoulder with abduction and flexion limited to 120° (normal range of motion, 180°).
5. The left scapular muscles were atrophic, and pain and temperature sensation were reduced in his proximal left arm, and dorsal aspect of his left shoulder.
6. His complete blood cell count, serum glucose levels, C-reactive protein levels, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate were normal.
7. Results of tests for rheumatoid factor and antinuclear antibody were negative.
8. Left shoulder radiograph showed complete absence of the left humeral head and a well-demarcated smooth osseous margin of the proximal humerus with associated soft tissue swelling and periarticular calcification (Figure 1).
9. A chest radiograph taken 2 years prior revealed a normal left shoulder joint.
10. The patient was hospitalized for further evaluation and treatment.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Obtain MRI of the left shoulder  
B: Order serum tumor marker testing  
C: Orthopedic surgery evaluation for shoulder replacement surgery  
D: Perform an urgent left shoulder joint aspiration

step1_excerpts:
1. A Hispanic man in his late 50s presented with gradual progression of bilateral blepharoptosis for 6 months (Figure), starting in the left eye and subsequently involving the right eye.
2. The ptosis did not worsen or fluctuate throughout the day.
3. He had a strong family history of bilateral ptosis, which included his father, grandfather, uncles, cousins, and 4 of his siblings (he had a total of 13 siblings [7 brothers and 6 sisters]).
4. None of his children or his siblings’ children were affected (the oldest being 31 years of age).
5. He had no history of trauma, crossing or drifting of the eyes, dysarthria, dyspnea, or diplopia.
6. He had noticed mild lightheadedness and trouble swallowing.
7. His medical history was unremarkable except for hypertension.
8. External photograph showing bilateral blepharoptosis with dermatochalasis.
9. Notice the chin-up head position that the patient has to maintain to look in the primary gaze.
10. His visual acuity was 20/25 OU with an intraocular pressure of 11 mm Hg OU.
11. He had a mild decrease in elevation and abduction in both eyes on extraocular motility testing.
12. Pupil reactivity and confrontational visual fields were normal.
13. The results of anterior and posterior segment examinations were normal.
14. The margin to reflex distance was −1 mm OD and −3 mm OS.
15. Levator function was 4 mm OD and 3 mm OS with normal orbicularis function.
16. No lagophthalmos was noted.
17. Goldmann perimetry showed a 30° improvement in the right eye and a 50° improvement in the left eye, with taping of the upper eyelids.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Ptosis repair by Müllerectomy or levator advancement  
B: Genetic testing for GCG triplet repeats  
C: Treatment with prednisone  
D: Observation

step1_excerpts:
1. A healthy 2-year-old girl is brought to the office for a routine well-child visit.
2. The child was weaned at 6 months of age and began to walk at 10 months of age.
3. On physical examination, she has mild bowlegs (10-degree genu varum).
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate management to recommend at this time?

A. Increased intake of vitamin D

B. A special exercise program

C. Surgical correction

D. No treatment is needed at this time

step1_excerpts:
1. A 55-year-old man presents to urgent care for weakness and weight loss.
2. For the past several months, he has felt progressively weaker and has lost 25 pounds with intermittent abdominal pain.
3. The patient has not seen a physician in 30 years and recalls being current on most of his vaccinations.
4. A few years ago, he went to the emergency department due to abdominal pain and was found to have increased liver enzymes due to excessive alcohol use and incidental gallstones.
5. The patient has a 50 pack-year smoking history.
6. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 161/108 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air.
7. Physical exam reveals an emaciated man.
8. The patient has a negative Murphy sign and his abdomen is non-tender.
9. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis  
B. CT scan of the chest  
C. HIDA scan  
D. Smoking cessation advice and primary care follow up

step1_excerpts:
1. A 17-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a headache.
2. The patient has had headaches in the past but this is the worst headache of her life.
3. Her symptoms started yesterday and have been getting progressively worse.
4. The patient states that the pain is mostly on the left side of her head.
5. There has been a recent outbreak of measles at the patient’s school and the patient’s mother has been trying to give her daughter medicine to prevent her from getting sick.
6. Her mother fears that her daughter may have caught measles.
7. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 123/74 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 13/min.
8. On exam, the patient is an obese girl who is clutching her head with the light in the room turned off.
9. Her neurological exam is within normal limits.
10. Fundoscopic exam reveals mild bilateral papilledema.
11. An MRI of the head is obtained and reveals cerebral edema.
12. A lumbar puncture reveals an increased opening pressure with a normal glucose level.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Subarachnoid hemorrhage  
B. Fat-soluble vitamin overuse  
C. Migraine headache  
D. Bacterial meningitis

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her early 20s presented with 1 year of discrete asymptomatic brown lesions distributed over her lower extremities.
2. She denied any history of trauma or prior lesions at these sites and could not pinpoint any exacerbating or alleviating factors.
3. She denied fever, arthralgias, myalgias, or constitutional symptoms.
4. She had no significant past medical history and took no medications or supplements.
5. A physical examination revealed several 2-mm to 4-mm round, hyperpigmented macules symmetrically distributed over the lower extremities and dorsal feet (Figure, A).
6. No prior treatments had been attempted.
7. A skin biopsy was performed (Figure, B-D).
question_options:
What is your diagnosis?

A: Case  
B: A woman in her early 20s presented with 1 year of discrete asymptomatic brown lesions distributed over her lower extremities. She denied any history of trauma or prior lesions at these sites and could not pinpoint any exacerbating or alleviating factors. She denied fever, arthralgias, myalgias, or constitutional symptoms. She had no significant past medical history and took no medications or supplements. A physical examination revealed several 2-mm to 4-mm round, hyperpigmented macules symmetrically distributed over the lower extremities and dorsal feet (Figure, A). No prior treatments had been attempted. A skin biopsy was performed (Figure, B-D). What is your diagnosis?  
C: Lichen planus pigmentosus  
D: Leukocytoclastic vasculitis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 66-year-old man with newly diagnosed multiple myeloma underwent autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).
2. On posttransplant day 10, he developed fever (38.4°C).
3. He was started on empirical treatment with cefepime; however, his fevers persisted despite antibiotic therapy.
4. On posttransplant day 14 he developed new-onset pruritic, confluent, erythematous, blanching morbilliform macules and papules on his trunk and extremities (Figure, left).
5. Review of systems was notable for diarrhea and a 6-pound weight gain since transplantation and negative for headache, cough, shortness of breath, or abdominal pain.Left, Macules and papules on the trunk of the patient.
6. Right, Axial chest computed tomography of the patient.On examination, there was no lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly.
7. The patient’s heart rate was 100/min, blood pressure was 106/68 mm Hg, and he occasionally experienced mild hypoxia to 94% on ambient air.
8. Results of a basic metabolic panel were normal, with a blood urea nitrogen level of 10 mg/dL (3.57 mmol/L) and creatinine level of 0.7 mg/dL (61.88 μmol/L).
9. White blood cell (WBC) count was 7300/μL, and absolute neutrophil count (ANC) was 5480/μL.
10. Neutrophil recovery occurred beginning on posttransplant day 10, with WBC count of 700/μL and ANC of 532/μL on posttransplant day 10, correlating with the onset of the patient’s fevers.
11. Platelet count was 48 × 103/μL, and hemoglobin was 8.2 g/dL.
12. Results of liver function tests were normal.
13. Blood, urine, sputum, and respiratory viral cultures were negative.
14. Tests for cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, human herpesvirus-6, adenovirus, parvovirus, cryptococcal antigen, aspergillus galactomannan antigen, β-glucan, and Clostridium difficile were negative.
15. Chest computed tomography demonstrated multifocal ground-glass and consolidative pulmonary opacities (Figure, right).
16. Computed tomography of the abdomen was unremarkable.
17. A skin punch biopsy demonstrated subtle vacuolar change; rare epidermal dyskeratosis, including within a hair follicle; and superficial perivascular mononuclear cell infiltrate with occasional eosinophils.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Initiate empirical antiviral and antifungal therapy  
B: Discontinue antibiotic therapy and consider systemic corticosteroids  
C: Obtain ferritin and soluble IL2Rα testing  
D: Perform bronchoscopy and biopsy of the pulmonary lesions

step1_excerpts:
1. An 18-year-old female presents to the office with a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain and a 2-day history of fever.
2. She reports frequent unprotected sexual intercourse with different partners since she started college 4 months ago.
3. Abdominal examination reveals suprapubic tenderness.
4. Bimanual examination of the uterus reveals more intense tenderness.
5. Swabs of cervical mucus are obtained.
question_options:
This patient should be given antimicrobial chemotherapy to provide treatment for

A. Candida albicans and Chlamydia trachomatis

B. Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae

C. Chlamydia trachomatis and Treponema pallidum

D. Gardnerella vaginalis and Mobiluncus species

step1_excerpts:
1. A 73-year-old man with a history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease presents with a left facial droop and left leg weakness.
2. The facial droop and leg weakness developed 3 weeks ago, while he was vacationing in upstate New York.
3. His symptoms have not progressed since initial onset.
4. He reports no rash, headache, joint pain, visual changes, fevers, night sweats, or weight loss.
5. His cancer screening is up to date and unremarkable.
6. He is a former smoker with a 12 pack-year history, having quit 40 years ago.
7. He is afebrile, and other vital signs are normal.
8. On physical examination he has a left lower facial droop with sparing of the forehead muscles.
9. Lower extremity strength is preserved and reflexes are normal; however, he has a subtle gait abnormality characterized by slight dragging of his left leg with ambulation.
10. His white blood cell count is normal.
11. Tests for toxoplasma, Lyme disease, cryptococcal antigen, and human immunodeficiency virus are negative.
12. T1-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of his brain demonstrates multiloculated ring-enhancing fluid collections involving the right basal ganglia, insula, and frontal lobe (Figure).
13. Computed tomography imaging of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis is unremarkable.
14. Begin therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone, vancomycin, and metronidazole
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Begin therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone, vancomycin, and metronidazole  
B: Perform a lumbar puncture  
C: Consult neurosurgery for biopsy  
D: Start systemic corticosteroids

step1_excerpts:
1. A new blood test to detect prostate cancer is evaluated in 300 male volunteers.
2. A needle biopsy of the prostate gland is done on all men with serum prostate-specific antigen concentrations greater than 5 ng/mL (N<4).
3. One hundred men undergo biopsy procedures; 90 are found to have prostate cancer, and five are found to have chronic prostatitis.
question_options:
Which of the following is necessary to calculate the sensitivity of this test?

A. Incidence of chronic prostatitis in the general population

B. Number of men with test results greater than 5 ng/mL and a normal biopsy specimen

C. Prevalence of chronic prostatitis in the general population

D. Prostate biopsies of men with test results equal to or below 5 ng/mL

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her late 40s presented with rapidly progressive redness and stiffness of both hands, accompanied by 2 months of multiple finger joint and right shoulder pain.
2. Results of autoimmune serology, including antinuclear antibody, C3 and C4, rheumatoid factor, and Scl-70 antibody tests, were negative.
3. Raynaud phenomenon was not seen.
4. There was an absence of nailfold capillary changes and distal digital pitting.
5. The patient was treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, systemic steroid therapy, and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (ie, hydroxychloroquine), but symptoms persisted.
6. Two weeks after treatment initiation, multiple tender nodules developed over the palms and interphalangeal joints, and flexion contractures continued (Figure, A).
7. Incisional skin biopsy of the palmar nodules (Figure, B and C) and computed tomography (CT) were performed.
8. Results of the CT demonstrated bilateral ovarian tumors with highly suspect peritoneal metastases.
9. A, Clinical image of erythematous and edematous changes of bilateral hands and multiple nodules on palms and interphalangeal joints.
10. B and C, Hematoxylin-eosin–stained specimen showing increased fibroblasts with fibrosis from dermis to subcutis.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Dupuytren contracture  
B: Fibroblastic rheumatism  
C: Palmar fasciitis and polyarthritis syndrome  
D: Scleroderma

step1_excerpts:
1. A 63-year-old man was seen with decreased vision in both eyes.
2. He had been diagnosed as having type 2 diabetes for 10 years.
3. His visual acuity was 20/40 OU.
4. Fundus examination showed venous dilatation, retinal hemorrhages, hard exudates, and serous macular detachment (arrowheads) (Figure 1).
5. Optical coherence tomography scans showed intraretinal fluid accumulation with serous macular detachment in both eyes.
6. He was diagnosed as having nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy with macular edema in both eyes.
7. He received 3 intravitreal bevacizumab injections at 4 weekly intervals and 2 intravitreal triamcinalone acetonide injections in both eyes, with minimal resolution of edema.
8. Blood analysis revealed a low hemoglobin level of 8 g/dL, red blood cell count of 3.3 × 106/μL, white blood cell count of 3460/μL (15% neutrophils, 84% lymphocytes, and 1% monocytes), fasting blood glucose level of 120 mg/dL, normal lipid profile, serum urea nitrogen level of 45 mg/dL, and an increased serum creatinine level of 1.4 mg/dL (to convert hemoglobin to grams per liter, multiply by 10.0; red blood cell count to ×1012 per liter, multiply by 1.0; white blood cell count to ×109 per liter, multiply by 0.001; blood glucose to millimoles per liter, multiply by 0.0555; serum urea nitrogen to millimoles per liter, multiply by 0.357; and serum creatinine to micromoles per liter, multiply by 88.4).
9. A and B, Fundus photographs showing retinal venous dilatation, hemorrhages, hard exudates, and serous macular detachment (arrowheads).
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Treat with intravitreal dexamethasone implant  
B: Treat with grid photocoagulation  
C: Do plasma electrophoresis and bone marrow analysis  
D: Treat with oral corticosteroids

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 30s presented with progressive, multiple itchy erythematous to violaceous papules and plaques localized to the left shin for more than 10 years (Figure, A and B).
2. On close inspection, milia and a few erosions with partially detached epidermis were identified.
3. There were no abnormalities of the mucous membranes, nails, hair, or teeth.
4. No extracutaneous involvement was observed.A, Multiple pruritic erythematous to violaceous lichenified papules and plaques on the left shin.
5. B, Close-up of the skin lesions showing an erosion with partially detached epidermis and multiple milia.
6. C, Histopathologic examination revealed dermoepidermal separation (hematoxylin-eosin stain).
7. D, Histopathologic examination revealed several milia (hematoxylin-eosin stain).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Pretibial pruritic papular dermatitis (PPPD)  
B: Hypertrophic lichen planus (HLP)  
C: Epidermolysis bullosa pruriginosa (EBP)  
D: Lichen amyloidosis (LA)

step1_excerpts:
1. A 53-year-old woman returns for follow-up two weeks after being hospitalized for decompensated heart failure.
2. During her hospitalization, an echocardiogram revealed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%.
3. She reports adherence to a low-sodium, low-potassium diet, improvement in dyspnea, and no lightheadedness.
4. Her medical history includes coronary artery disease, hypertension, stage 3 chronic kidney disease, and type 2 diabetes.
5. Her current medications are metoprolol 50 mg twice daily, atorvastatin 80 mg daily, torsemide 40 mg daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily, aspirin 81 mg daily, and insulin.
6. Her vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 138/72 mm Hg, heart rate 65 beats per minute, respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute, and weight 92 kg, which is 0.5 kg above her baseline from two months before her recent exacerbation.
7. Cardiac examination reveals a regular rate and rhythm, a 2/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex, and no rub or gallop.
8. Her lungs are clear, her abdominal examination is normal, and trace pretibial edema is noted in both lower extremities.
9. The following laboratory values were obtained at discharge and during today's visit:

|  | 2 weeks ago | Today | Reference range |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Sodium (mEq/liter) | 136 | 134 | 136–145 |
| Potassium (mEq/liter) | 5.7 | 5.4 | 3.5–5.0 |
| Chloride (mEq/liter) | 101 | 102 | 98–106 |
| Carbon dioxide (mEq/liter) | 23 | 24 | 21–30 |
| Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL) | 26 | 22 | 10–20 |
| Creatinine (mg/dL) | 1.4 | 1.5 | 0.6–1.1 |
| Glucose (mg/dL) | 125 | 115 | 70–100 |
| Magnesium (mg/dL) | 2.0 | 2.2 | 1.8–3.0 |

An electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm with no abnormalities.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient’s hyperkalemia?

A. Switch the lisinopril to hydralazine  
B. Reduce the dose of lisinopril to 10 mg daily  
C. Add patiromer to the medication regimen  
D. Initiate hemodialysis for potassium removal  
E. Switch the torsemide to chlorthalidone  
F. Increase the dose of torsemide  
G. Start sodium polystyrene sulfate  
H. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate  
I. Start a low-dose beta-agonist inhaler  
J. Prescribe a potassium-restricted diet with no other changes

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her mid-60s with a history of breast cancer (status post lumpectomy 7 years earlier [N0, M0]) and benign thyroid nodules presented for evaluation of right-sided proptosis.
2. Bulging of the right eye was first noted 6 months earlier elsewhere when she reported progressive proptosis, worsening vision, and tearing in the right eye.
3. She did not report any pain or diplopia.
4. Visual acuity was 20/150 OD (no improvement with pinhole) and 20/20 OS.
5. Pupillary reaction and confrontational visual fields were normal.
6. External examination was notable for proptosis of 7 mm, hypoglobus, and resistance to retropulsion.
7. A firm, nontender mass was palpable in the right superotemporal orbit.
8. The palpebral lobe of the right lacrimal gland was erythematous and prominent compared with the normal-appearing left lacrimal gland.
9. Ocular motility showed −2 abduction deficit, right eye.
10. Slitlamp examination revealed pseudophakia and posterior capsular opacification (right > left), but was otherwise normal.
11. Sensation was normal in the V1, V2 distribution, and there was no preauricular, submandibular, or anterior cervical lymphadenopathy.
12. Computed tomographic scan of the orbits without contrast from an outside facility revealed a spherical mass of unclear cause in the area of the right lacrimal gland.
13. No lytic bone changes or bone remodeling could be seen (Figure 1).
14. Computed tomographic imaging from outside facility revealed a 1.9 × 2.3 × 1.8-cm mass of an unclear cause within the anterolateral right orbit, exerting mass effect on the globe.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Arrange 6-month follow-up  
B: Obtain additional imaging  
C: Perform an incisional biopsy  
D: Perform an excisional biopsy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 38-year-old woman developed acute painless blurred vision in her right eye 3 weeks after receiving a single injection of corticosteroid in her deltoid for stenosing tenosynovitis.  
2. Her medical history was significant for stage II breast carcinoma with positive lymph nodes, which was diagnosed and treated 5 years prior.  
3. Subsequent annual metastatic surveillance test results had been negative for recurrence.  
4. Visual acuity was 20/60 OD and 20/20 OS.  
5. Ophthalmoscopy of the right eye revealed a 6 × 6-mm circumscribed serous macular detachment with turbid subretinal fluid.  
6. Similar lesions were present in the nasal and inferior midperiphery (Figure, A and B).  
7. The left eye was unremarkable.  
8. Fluorescein angiography (FA) showed hyperfluorescent pinpoint hot spots with interspersed hypofluorescent patches in the areas of the lesions (Figure, C-F).  
9. Notably absent on FA were retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) leakage, a smokestack pattern of subretinal leakage, or RPE gutter defects.  
10. B-scan ultrasonography demonstrated choroidal thickening nasal to the optic disc (Figure, G); vascularity could not be assessed.  
11. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) showed a localized serous macular detachment with a focal area of choriocapillaris infiltration and thickening near the nasal edge of the detachment (Figure, H).  
12. Fundus photograph (A-B) of the right eye demonstrates a serous macular detachment with yellowish choroidal discoloration.  
13. A, Similar yellowish choroidal lesions (arrowheads) were present in the nasal and inferior midperiphery.  
14. B, The enlarged image demonstrates the extent of serous macular detachment (arrowheads).  
15. C, Wide-angle fluorescein angiography in the late venous phase of the right eye shows an area between the disc and fovea with scattered hyperfluorescent hotspots.  
16. Magnified views of the macular lesion (D), nasal lesion (E), and inferior lesion (F).  
17. G, B-scan ultrasonography of the right eye shows a subtle nonspecific choroidal thickening with medium internal reflectivity.  
18. The arrowhead points to the choroidal infiltration by the metastatic tumor.  
19. H, Spectral-domain optical coherence tomography of the right eye demonstrates serous macular detachment with localized subtle choroidal vascular attenuation, infiltration, and thickening (arrowheads).  
20. Blood tests to consider diagnosis of syphilitic chorioretinitis
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Consider managing as multifocal central serous chorioretinopathy  
B: Consider a diagnosis of choroidal metastasis  
C: Obtain workup for Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome  
D: Blood tests to consider diagnosis of syphilitic chorioretinitis

step1_excerpts:
1. A previously healthy 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever and pain and swelling of the right knee.  
2. She remembers injuring the knee while playing soccer last week, but she was able to finish the game.  
3. She has no history of rash or joint pain.  
4. Her sister has inflammatory bowel disease.  
5. The patient's temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, pulse is 95/min, and respirations are 20/min.  
6. Examination of the right knee shows swelling, tenderness, warmth, and erythema; range of motion is limited.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Nuclear scan of the right knee

B. MRI of the right knee

C. Antibiotic therapy

D. Arthrocentesis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 72-year-old woman with advanced ovarian cancer metastatic to the liver is brought to the physician by her son because she cries all the time and will not get out of bed.
2. On a 10-point scale, she rates the pain as a 1 to 2.
3. She also has hypertension and major depressive disorder.
4. She has received chemotherapy for 2 years.
5. Current medications also include oxycodone (10 mg twice daily), hydrochlorothiazide (25 mg/d), and fluoxetine (20 mg/d).
6. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 66 kg (145 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2 .
7. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg.
8. Examination shows a firm, distended abdomen with moderate tenderness over the liver.
9. On mental status examination, she is oriented to person, place, and time.
10. She has good eye contact but appears sad and cries easily.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Reassurance

B. Assess for suicidal ideation

C. Begin dextroamphetamine therapy

D. Increase oxycodone dosage

step1_excerpts:
1. A boy aged 17 years presented after noticing that his right pupil was off-center.  
2. He had a high hyperopic refractive error, and the magnification of his spectacle lenses highlighted the eccentric pupil.  
3. He had no associated symptoms of decreased vision, ocular pain, diplopia, glare, or haloes and had no history of ocular infection, surgical procedure, or trauma.  
4. His mother, also hyperopic, previously underwent prophylactic laser iridotomy for anatomically narrow, occludable angles.  
5. Best corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OU, with a manifest refraction of +7.75 −1.00 × 170 OD and +7.75 −1.25 × 010 OS.  
6. Slitlamp examination confirmed mild corectopia in the right eye, along with 4 clock hours of iridocorneal touch nasally and a “hammered silver” appearance to the involved cornea (Figure 1).  
7. On examination via gonioscopy, there were high peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS) above the Schwalbe line in this area, while the remaining angle was deep without PAS.  
8. The left eye was normal.  
9. Intraocular pressures were 15 mm Hg OD and 14 mm Hg OS.  
10. Pachymetry testing revealed symmetric central corneal thicknesses of 577 μm OD and 582 μm OS.  
11. Both optic discs appeared healthy, with a cup-disc ratio of 0.2.  
12. There were no visual field defects.  
13. Slitlamp photography showed the right eye had mild corectopia and iridocorneal touch nasally.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Start pilocarpine eyedrops  
B: Test the aqueous fluid for Human herpesvirus 1  
C: Obtain specular microscopy  
D: Recommend genetic testing

step1_excerpts:
1. A 45-year-old woman with systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of progressive shortness of breath and nonproductive cough.  
2. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 136/85 mm Hg.  
3. Crackles are heard in both lower lung fields.  
4. Pulmonary function tests show total lung capacity is 80% of predicted, and diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide, corrected for alveolar volume, is 65% of predicted.
question_options:
Histologic examination of a lung biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?

A. Diffuse interstitial fibrosis

B. Intra-alveolar exudates

C. Multiple thromboemboli

D. Necrotizing vasculitis

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 50s presented with a 4- to 5-year medical history of mildly pruritic coalescent yellowish papules around the umbilicus (Figure 1A).
2. She was obese and multiparous.
3. Examination of the rest of the integument, systemic examination, and investigations including fundoscopy, electrocardiogram, and stool examination for occult blood revealed no significant abnormalities.
4. Dermoscopic examination was performed (polarized mode, Dinolite) as shown in Figure 1B.
5. We obtained a 4-mm punch biopsy from one of the papules for diagnostic clarification (Figure 1C).
6. A, Coalescent yellowish periumbilical papules.
7. B, Polarized dermoscopic image (Dinolite) showing curvilinear brown pigment lines (black arrowhead) with accentuation of normal pigmentary network (green box) without follicular plugging (red circle) or linear vessels (original magnification ×200).
8. C, Lesional specimen (original magnification ×100) showing clumped eosinophilic elastic fibers (asterisk) in the middermis (inset, original magnification ×40).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Periumbilical pseudoxanthoma elasticum  
B: Periumbilical pseudoxanthoma elasticum–like papillary dermal elastolysis  
C: Elastosis perforans serpiginosa  
D: Late-onset focal dermal elastosis

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 60s presented for evaluation of asymptomatic skin lesions on the chest that had been stable since onset 4 months prior.
2. His medical history was significant for hyperlipidemia, familial polyposis, and acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) for which he had undergone an allogenic hematopoietic stem cell transplant 13 months earlier.
3. Cutaneous examination revealed green-gray nodules and plaques on the left and right upper chest (Figure 1).
4. Bilateral cervical, axillary, and inguinal lymph node chains were negative for adenopathy.
5. The patient had not attempted measures to alleviate the nodules and denied experiencing exacerbating factors or pain.
6. Biopsies of the skin lesions were performed.A, Representative dusky, green-gray nodule located on the upper chest.
7. B, A prominent green hue is present at the base of a lesion following shave biopsy.
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Merkel cell carcinoma  
B: Chloroma  
C: Blastic plasmacytoid dendritic cell neoplasm  
D: Histiocytoid Sweet syndrome

step1_excerpts:
1. A 64-year-old male comes for a routine follow-up visit with his primary care physician.
2. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, chronic atrial fibrillation, and ischemic cardiomyopathy.
3. During his previous visit three months ago, he had hyperkalemia, leading to discontinuation of lisinopril and spironolactone.
4. His current medications are coumadin, aspirin, metformin, glyburide, metoprolol, furosemide, and amlodipine.
5. His vital signs show: temperature 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 154/92 mm Hg, heart rate 80/min, and respiratory rate 16/min.
6. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure, an S3 heart sound, and 1+ pitting pedal edema.

Current laboratory results show:

- Sodium: 138 mEq/L
- Potassium: 5.7 mEq/L
- Chloride: 112 mEq/L
- Bicarbonate: 18 mEq/L
- BUN: 29 mg/dL
- Creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL
question_options:
What is the most probable cause of this patient's acid-base and electrolyte disturbances?

A. Prerenal azotemia  
B. Chronic renal failure  
C. Furosemide  
D. Renal tubular acidosis  
E. Metabolic acidosis from heart failure  
F. Acute kidney injury  
G. Diabetic ketoacidosis  
H. Drug-induced hyperkalemia  
I. Cardiorenal syndrome  
J. Type 4 RTA from hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism

step1_excerpts:
1. A previously healthy 27-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of moderate-to-severe pain and swelling of the left labia.
2. She is sexually active and uses condoms inconsistently.
3. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg.
4. Pelvic examination shows a 4 x 3-cm, tender, fluctuant mass medial to the left labium majus compromising the introital opening.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Administration of intravenous metronidazole

B. Administration of intravenous penicillin G

C. Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration of the mass

D. Incision and drainage

step1_excerpts:
1. A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician for her first influenza virus vaccination.
2. She has a history of untreated hypertension.
3. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg, and pulse is 100/min.
4. Shortly after administration of the influenza virus vaccine, she develops shortness of breath, hives, and angioedema.
question_options:
Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this reaction?

A. Inquiry about an egg allergy

B. Heterophile agglutination test

C. Skin test with histamine reagent

D. β-Adrenergic blocking agent therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 29-year-old woman presented with a 6-month history of yellowing skin on her palms and soles.  
2. She was previously healthy, did not consume alcohol, and had no personal or family history of liver disease.  
3. She took no prescription medications; however, approximately 6 months prior to the onset of symptoms, she began taking a nutritional supplement (Nature Made Beta Carotene, Otsuka Pharmaceutical) manufactured in Japan and available online in China.  
4. This supplement contained 1.8 mg of beta carotene per tablet, and she had been taking 2 tablets daily for the past 6 months.  
5. She had no other dietary changes during this period, in particular, no increased intake of carrots or other yellow- or orange-colored fruits or vegetables.  
6. Physical examination revealed yellow-orange pigmentation of her palms and soles (Figure).  
7. There was no scleral icterus.  
8. Results of laboratory tests, including measurement of aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase, hemoglobin A1c, and total and direct bilirubin levels, ratio of blood urea nitrogen to creatinine, as well as fasting lipid profile and thyroid function tests, were normal.Yellowish orange pigmentation of the patient’s palms and soles, as compared with a nonpigmented palm in the center.  
9. Advise the patient to discontinue the nutritional supplement
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?  
A: Perform a biopsy  
B: Order repeat liver function tests  
C: Empirically treat with a topical steroid  
D: Advise the patient to discontinue the nutritional supplement

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 60s presented with a 6-month history of itchy eruptions that initially started on the arms and then spread to involve the lower legs.
2. The patient admitted to occasional burning sensation of new lesions.
3. On review of systems, the patient denied fevers, fatigue, myalgias, arthritis, shortness of breath, oral ulcers, and recent infections.
4. Clinical examination revealed several erythematous patches and plaques on the arms and lower legs, and nontender violaceous firm nodules on the elbows, wrist, ankle, interphalangeal, and metatarsophalangeal joints (Figure 1A and B).
5. There was no lymphadenopathy present.
6. A punch biopsy specimen from a plaque on the right forearm was obtained (Figure 1C and D).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Erythema elevatum diutinum  
B: Pyoderma gangrenosum  
C: Multicentric reticulohistiocytosis  
D: Sweet syndrome

step1_excerpts:
1. A 40-year-old healthy woman presented with an 8-year history of a slowly growing erythematous plaque on the left lower eyelid, with occasional discomfort.
2. Physical examination revealed a single erythematous scaling plaque involving the left lower eyelid, including its border.
3. Eyelashes were totally absent (Figure 1A).
4. No other lesions were found after complete physical examination.
5. Dermoscopy showed an erythematous background, telangiectatic vessels, whitish structureless areas, and whitish scales (Figure 1B).
6. A 4-mm punch biopsy specimen was obtained (Figure 1C).
7. A, Erythematous scaling plaque involving the left lower eyelid.
8. B, Dermoscopy shows erythematous background, telangiectatic vessels, structureless whitish areas, and white scales.
9. C, Histopathological analysis (hematoxylin-eosin).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Sarcoidosis  
B: Discoid lupus erythematosus  
C: Basal cell carcinoma  
D: Bowen disease

step1_excerpts:
1. A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a headache.
2. He suddenly developed a throbbing, bitemporal headache about 5 hours ago "out of nowhere." He has a history of migraine headaches, but he feels that this headache is significantly more painful than his typical migraines.
3. The patient took his prescribed sumatriptan with no relief of his symptoms.
4. He also endorses nausea and he reports that he vomited once before arrival in the emergency department.
5. The patient denies any recent trauma to the head.
6. His medical history is significant for migraines and hypertension.
7. He has a 20-pack-year smoking history and a history of cocaine use.
8. He drinks 5-6 beers per week.
9. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 147/91 mmHg, pulse is 62/min, and respirations are 12/min.
10. On physical exam, he appears to be in moderate distress and has pain with neck flexion.
11. He has no focal neurologic deficits.
12. A head CT is performed and can be seen in Figure A.
question_options:
This patient’s condition affects the space in between which of the following brain layers?

A. Periosteum and galea aponeurosis  
B. Arachnoid mater and pia mater  
C. Dura mater and arachnoid mater  
D. Skull and dura mater

step1_excerpts:
1. A sexually active 23-year-old man with multiple sex partners has dysuria and a yellow urethral exudate.
2. Gram stain of the exudate shows numerous neutrophils, many that contain intracellular gram-negative diplococci.
3. He has had three similar episodes of urethritis over the past 2 years.
question_options:
Which of the following properties of the infecting organism best explains the reinfection?

A. Antigenic variation

B. Catalase

C. Inhibition of B-lymphocyte function

D. Inhibition of T-lymphocyte function

step1_excerpts:
1. A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife with confusion.
2. He was seen in the emergency department 2 days ago for profuse epistaxis.
3. His primary care provider was concerned and had advised him to go to the hospital, as the patient is on warfarin for atrial fibrillation.
4. However, his bleeding resolved with pressure and nasal packing.
5. Upon presentation to the ED today, his temperature is 97.6°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 64/33 mmHg, pulse is 160/min, respirations are 32/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air.
6. Physical exam reveals an obtunded man who cannot answer questions.
7. A dark, purpuric rash is noted on his torso and extremities.
8. The patient’s nasal packing is removed with no further bleeding.
9. The patient is given IV fluids and blood cultures are drawn.
question_options:
Which of the following should be administered first?

A. Penicillin  
B. Piperacillin-tazobactam  
C. Meropenem  
D. Clindamycin

step1_excerpts:
1. A 25-year-old woman visits the clinic with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding and lower abdominal pain persisting for several years.
2. The pain typically begins one week prior to the onset of menstruation.
3. She mentions that her mother experienced similar symptoms at the same age.
4. On examination, she is hemodynamically stable, with noted pallor and mild tenderness on palpation of the lower abdomen, but no masses or organomegaly.
5. Laboratory tests, including a complete blood cell count, urinalysis, and urine microscopy, are normal.
6. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals a cystic ovarian lesion with low-level homogeneous echoes.
question_options:
Based on these clinical findings and investigations, which of the following statements is accurate?

A. Conservative management is preferred in most cases  
B. Laparoscopy is the not the definitive method of diagnosis  
C. Imaging findings alone are sufficient for diagnosis  
D. The lesions usually appear innocuous  
E. A chocolate cyst is unlikely in this case  
F. Surgical management is the mainstay of treatment  
G. The cystic lesion is most likely malignant  
H. The condition is unlikely to recur after treatment  
I. Hormonal therapy is the first-line treatment for all patients  
J. Pain is unrelated to the menstrual cycle in this condition

step1_excerpts:
1. An 11-month-old boy presented to the clinic with a papule on his right lower eyelid that had doubled in size since it first appeared 3 months earlier (Figure 1).  
2. He had been born at full term and was otherwise healthy.  
3. His medication regimen included a pediatric multivitamin.  
4. There was no history of trauma to the area.  
5. On examination, the patient’s pupils were equal in diameter and reactive to light, his ocular motility was full, and the lesion did not obstruct his vision.  
6. Findings from external examination were significant for a single 3 × 2 × 2–mm, red-brown, raised, solid, fixed papule at the center of the lower eyelid margin.  
7. There was no madarosis and no evidence of epiphora or conjunctivitis.  
8. The lesion was initially diagnosed as a hemangioma and the decision was made to monitor it.  
9. On examination 1 month later, the papule had grown slightly, with a 1 × 1–mm area of ulceration.  
10. It also appeared to encroach on the visual axis in the downgaze position.  
11. The parents reported that the patient had started to rub his eyelid intermittently, causing irritation and a minimal amount of associated bleeding.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Continue observation  
B: Prescribe propranolol hydrochloride  
C: Excise the lesion  
D: Perform curettage of the lesion

step1_excerpts:
1. A 57-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to the clinic with several weeks of vague abdominal discomfort.
2. She denies symptoms such as dysuria, flank pain, constipation, or vaginal bleeding.
3. Her medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension managed with lisinopril, and her surgical history includes two cesarean sections.
4. On examination, her temperature is 98.6 ºF, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, and respiratory rate is 12/min.
5. Auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds over the right lower lung fields without wheezes or rhonchi.
6. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness and a positive fluid wave.
7. Bimanual pelvic examination identifies right adnexal fullness.
question_options:
Which histopathologic finding in the ovary is most consistent with this clinical presentation?

A. Irregularly narrowed tubules with papillary branching  
B. Granulosa cells arranged in a Call-Exner body pattern  
C. Uniformly small, round cells with scant cytoplasm  
D. Mucin-filled glandular structures  
E. Spindle-shaped fibroblast bundle  
F. Sheets of large, pleomorphic cells with necrosis  
G. Signet-ring cells within glandular tissue  
H. Thecal cell hyperplasia  
I. Psammoma bodies surrounded by serous epithelium  
J. Lipid-laden stromal cells

step1_excerpts:
1. A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0, aborta 1, at 28 weeks' gestation comes to the office for a prenatal visit.
2. She has had one previous pregnancy resulting in a spontaneous abortion at 12 weeks' gestation.
3. Today, her vital signs are within normal limits.
4. Physical examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 28-week gestation.
5. Fetal ultrasonography shows a male fetus with no abnormalities.
6. Her blood group is O, Rh-negative.
7. The father's blood group is B, Rh-positive.
question_options:
The physician recommends administration of Rho immune globulin to the patient. This treatment is most likely to prevent which of the following in this mother?

A. Development of natural killer cells

B. Development of polycythemia

C. Formation of antibodies to RhD

step1_excerpts:
1. A 65-year-old male with a history of radical prostatectomy for prostate cancer presents to the emergency department following a ground-level fall.
2. He reports low back pain with posterior leg radiation starting the day before the fall.
3. His vital signs show temperature 99.4°F (37.4°C), blood pressure 132/78 mmHg, pulse 92/min, and respirations 18/min.
4. Neurological examination reveals decreased foot sensation, bilateral ankle dorsiflexion weakness (2/5), diminished lower extremity reflexes, and a post-void residual volume of 300 mL.
5. The patient has no history of smoking, intravenous drug use, or current medications.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate initial management step?

A. Intravenous antibiotics  
B. Physical therapy referral  
C. Observation and follow-up in 24 hours  
E. Computed tomography scan of the spine  
F. Lumbar puncture  
G. Epidural steroid injection  
H. Surgical consultation for decompression  
J. Dexamethasone

step1_excerpts:
1. A 6-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a one-week history of left eye swelling and pain.
2. According to the parent, the condition began as an insect bite on her lower eyelid that has progressively enlarged.
3. Today, the patient developed fever and pain with ocular movement, prompting the visit.
4. She is otherwise healthy with no significant past medical history.
5. Her vital signs show temperature 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure 108/65 mmHg, heart rate 117/min, respiratory rate 20/min, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air.
6. Physical examination reveals periorbital soft tissue swelling with erythema, tenderness, and pain on extraocular movement.
7. The patient reports blurred vision, though visual acuity testing is normal.
8. Neurological examination is unremarkable.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate initial management step?

A. Topical erythromycin ointment and discharge  
B. Surgical consultation  
C. Oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and close follow-up  
F. Oral amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and discharge home  
G. Immediate ophthalmology consultation and admission  
H. Intravenous vancomycin and ceftriaxone  
I. Intravenous clindamycin monotherapy  
J. Intravenous dexamethasone and antihistamines

step1_excerpts:
1. A 72-year-old woman presented with new-onset decreased vision in the right eye.
2. Her ocular history included pseudoexfoliation syndrome and glaucomatous optic neuropathy in the right eye.
3. Past ocular surgery included uncomplicated trabeculectomy in the right eye treated with mitomycin C (3 months prior) and no ocular surgery history in the left eye.
4. Her medical history included pulmonary Mycobacterium avium infection secondary to hypogammaglobulinemia.
5. Computed tomography scan 2 months prior exhibited reactivation and she started treatment with clarithromycin (1000 mg/d), ethambutol (15 mg/kg/d), and rifabutin (300 mg/d).
6. Best-corrected visual acuity was hand motions OD and 20/20 OS.
7. Intraocular pressures were 4 mm Hg OD and 13 mm Hg OS.
8. Anterior segment examination of the right eye showed substantial conjunctival hyperemia and substantial cellular response in the anterior chamber (2 to 3+) along with a 1-mm hypopyon.
9. There was no leak at the trabeculectomy bleb (negative Seidel test).
10. B-scan ultrasonography showed no retinal detachment or mass.
11. Presumed diagnosis of bleb-related infectious endophthalmitis was made and she was referred for treatment.
12. Pars plana vitrectomy was performed, including vitreous sampling, and showed very light growth of Staphylococcus aureus in 1 colony on 1 plate, which was highly suspicious for contaminant.
13. Intravitreal amikacin and vancomycin were administered after vitreous sampling was performed.
14. Postoperatively, the patient initiated treatment with topical antibiotics and corticosteroids.
15. Her visual acuity returned to 20/30.
16. Two months later, she presented again with a similar acute vision loss in the left eye (counting fingers).
17. Anterior segment examination showed conjunctival hyperemia, cellular reaction, and a small hypopyon (Figure).
18. Slitlamp photograph showing conjunctival hyperemia and hypopyon (arrowhead) of the left eye.
19. Pars plana vitrectomy with hyperemia of intravitreal antibiotics Review and adjust systemic medications and treat with topical corticosteroids
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Pars plana vitrectomy with hyperemia of intravitreal antibiotics  
B: Treatment with topical and oral antibiotics  
C: Review and adjust systemic medications and treat with topical corticosteroids  
D: Treat with systemic and topical corticosteroids

step1_excerpts:
1. A 54-year-old man presents to the clinic with 4 weeks of persistently worsening back pain.
2. The pain is localized to 1 spot in his lower back and is worse with physical activity.
3. His medical history is pertinent for intravenous drug use.
4. He has no past surgical history.
5. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 118/90 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air.
6. On physical exam, he has midline back tenderness to palpation at L2-L3.
7. Laboratory workup reveals an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 112 mm/h and C-reactive protein of 10 mg/dL.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Ankylosing spondylitis  
B. Osteomyelitis  
C. Degenerative spine disease  
D. Metastatic tumor

step1_excerpts:
1. A 32-year-old male seeks emergency care for arm pain following a recent open radius fracture that occurred during a fall from a ladder at home.
2. After undergoing open reduction and internal fixation and cast placement, he has experienced progressive arm pain.
3. His medical history includes hypertension and asthma, with current medications including albuterol, fluticasone, loratadine, and lisinopril.
4. Vital signs show temperature 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure 150/95 mmHg, pulse 90/min, respirations 19/min, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air.
5. Upon cast removal and examination, his left arm shows tenderness to palpation, severe pain with passive movement of wrist and fingers, palpable radial and ulnar pulses, and a firm, tender forearm without bruising.
question_options:
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Administration of IV antibiotics  
B. Doppler ultrasound of the arm  
C. Radiography  
D. Immediate MRI of the forearm  
E. Surgical hardware removal  
F. CT angiography of the arm  
G. Compartment pressure measurement  
H. Replace the cast with a sling  
I. Pain management and observation  
J. Emergency fasciotomy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 45-year-old man presents to a physician due to difficulty swallowing and slurred speech.
2. For the past 3 months, the patient has been coughing when he drinks liquids.
3. His speech also sounds different according to his wife.
4. The patient has no significant medical history.
5. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg, pulse is 60/min, and respirations are 12/min.
6. On physical exam, he is unable to fully extend his tongue, and there are fasciculations on his tongue.
7. When tapping the mandible at the chin while the mouth is held open, there is pronounced upward movement of the lower jaw.
8. Sensory exam reveals no deficits.
question_options:
Which of the following therapies is most likely to improve survival for this patient's disease process?

A. Dextromethorphan and quinidine  
B. Tizanidine  
C. Riluzole  
D. Edaravone

step1_excerpts:
1. A 15-year-old obese girl presented to clinic with increasing right shin pain of 4 weeks’ duration.
2. The pain began after the patient began to play competitive basketball and was localized to her mid shin.
3. Dietary and menstrual histories revealed no abnormalities.
4. Examination demonstrated focal tenderness along the distal mid shaft of the tibia anteriorly.
5. The single-leg hop test elicited severe localized pain.
6. Radiographs were obtained for further evaluation (Figure).
7. Radiography of the right lower leg.
8. Left, Anteroposterior view.
9. Right, Lateral view.
10. Obtain laboratory work to assess for nutritional or hormonal abnormalities Order observation and pain management with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS)
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Obtain laboratory work to assess for nutritional or hormonal abnormalities  
B: Refer for immediate surgery  
C: Order immobilization with non–weight-bearing activity  
D: Order observation and pain management with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS)

step1_excerpts:
1. A 7-week-old, previously healthy full-term male infant presented with a 4-week history of a worsening, widespread, papulopustulovesicular eruption, which began as scattered papulovesicles over the chest.  
2. The infant was born to a 31-year-old mother by normal vaginal delivery.  
3. The mother had a benign prenatal course during pregnancy.  
4. Since the rash developed, the infant had been fussy with increasing restlessness at night.  
5. The parents denied any personal or family history of rash.  
6. On further questioning, the parents reported that the infant had had contact with a babysitter who reported pruritus, especially at night.  
7. The sitter had provided domestic care for the infant since birth until leaving that position 3 weeks earlier.  
8. On examination, the infant was afebrile with normal vital signs.  
9. Multiple disseminated, edematous, pin-sized, papulopustulovesicles and 5- to 10-mm coalescing, crusted nodules were found all over the body; some with oval to elongated, serpiginous or J-shaped burrows (Figure 1).  
10. No excoriations were visible.  
11. A Tzanck smear showed no multinucleated giant cells in the pustular contents.  
12. A Gram stain and potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation of the pustular contents showed no bacterial or fungal elements.  
13. Cultures of the pustular contents yielded no bacterial or fungal growth.  
14. The differential of a complete blood cell count showed 12% eosinophils.  
15. Results of other routine laboratory investigations were unremarkable.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Administer intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics  
B: Start a topical steroid  
C: Perform skin scraping of burrows from multiple sites  
D: Do nothing and reassure the parents

step1_excerpts:
1. A man in his 40s was referred for a 1-year history of decreased vision and the sensation of tunnel vision, which accompanied cognitive decline for the past 2 years.
2. He had a history of renal cell carcinoma and had undergone left nephrectomy 1 year prior with no recurrence.
3. Prior to presentation, his evaluation included brain magnetic resonance imaging and neurologic evaluation with unremarkable results, and he was scheduled to undergo neuropsychological testing.
4. Visual acuity was counting fingers OD, and 20/100 OS.
5. Motility and intraocular pressures were normal.
6. There was a right afferent pupillary defect.
7. Examination of the right eye revealed rubeosis iridis, a clear lens, neovascularization of the optic disc, retinal vasculitis, venous sheathing, and a dusky-appearing peripheral retina.
8. The left eye had a clear lens and a normal fundus on clinical examination.
9. Fluorescein angiography demonstrated a mixed retinal arteritis and phlebitis with extensive retinal and choroidal nonperfusion of the right eye with both retinal and optic nerve neovascularization.
10. The left eye demonstrated patches of active arteritis peripherally with a minimally affected posterior pole (Figure).
11. Fluorescein angiogram at 1 minute demonstrating a mixed occlusive arteritis and phlebitis (yellow arrowhead) with extensive areas of retinal and choroidal nonperfusion (white arrowhead) in the right eye.
12. The posterior pole of the left eye appears unaffected.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Panretinal photocoagulation  
B: Check antinuclear antibodies, anticardiolipin antibodies, anti–double-stranded DNA antibodies, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, and angiotensin-converting enzyme  
C: Administer methylprednisolone, 1 g intravenously daily  
D: Plasmapheresis

step1_excerpts:
1. A young girl presented to establish care for skin lesions on her trunk and extremities that had been present since birth.
2. Her mother described an intermittent inflammatory reaction localized only to the patient’s abnormal skin lesions that was reproducible in febrile states and was concerned about asymptomatic, stable, dark brown lesions that had developed in areas of prior blistering and scarring on the patient’s right arm, left knee, and right upper back.
3. There was no history of developmental delay, eye abnormalities, or seizures.
4. Examination revealed irregular, dark brown, well-demarcated macules with regular pigment networks on dermoscopy within prominent soft, yellow, papular protrusions in a Blaschkolinear arrangement on her upper arms, particularly her right arm.
5. The right flank demonstrated linear, atrophic pink plaques with focal erosions and crusting, evidencing recent inflammation described by the patient’s mother (Figure, A).
6. Additional irregular, well-demarcated, evenly pigmented dark brown macules were present within pink, atrophic scars located on the right side of the trunk, the right upper back, and the left knee.
7. She had well-healed surgical scars on the hands, syndactyly of the toes, and ventral pterygium and dystrophy of the fingernails and toenails (Figure, B).
8. A, Irregular, dark brown, well-demarcated macules within prominent soft, yellow, papular protrusions in a Blaschkolinear arrangement on the upper arms; linear, atrophic pink plaques with focal erosions and crusting are seen on the right flank.
9. B, Extracutaneous features show syndactyly of the toes and ventral pterygium and dystrophy of the toe nails.
10. C, Hematoxylin-eosin staining of skin biopsy demonstrates close proximity of subcutaneous fat to the epidermis with attenuated collagen (original magnification × 20).
11. Previous treatment had included surgical excision of a frequently symptomatic focus of affected skin with subsequent adjacent tissue transfer.
12. Additionally, she had received dental implantation of frontal upper incisors.
13. Histopathologic slides from the prior excision of affected skin were reviewed (Figure, C).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Epidermolysis bullosa with mottled pigmentation  
B: Focal dermal hypoplasia (Goltz syndrome)  
C: Incontinentia pigmenti  
D: Nevus lipomatosus superficialis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 58-year-old woman with a history of intravenous heroin use and chronic inactive hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection with a low serum HBV DNA value, normal liver enzyme values, and no evidence of cirrhosis presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of painless jaundice and 8 days of malaise.
2. Her last intravenous heroin use occurred 9 days prior to presentation.
3. She was not taking any prescription or herbal medications and had not been prescribed suppressive antiviral medication for chronic HBV infection.
4. She reported no history of travel outside the US and no raw meat ingestion.
5. Her vital signs, mentation, and physical examination were normal except for scleral icterus (Figure).
6. Results of blood testing were negative for hepatitis C virus RNA, anti–hepatitis A IgM, and HIV antibody.
7. Other selected laboratory values are shown in the Table.
8. A liver ultrasound performed 6 months prior to presentation and a repeat liver ultrasound with Doppler revealed no abnormalities.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Check plasma HIV-1 RNA level  
B: Order testing for hepatitis E virus IgM antibody  
C: Order testing for anti–smooth muscle antibody  
D: Order testing for hepatitis delta virus (HDV) IgM and IgG antibodies and, if positive, test for HDV RNA

step1_excerpts:
1. A 63-year-old female presents with a 3-month history of progressively worsening pain in her right calf.
2. She notes that the pain begins after walking for approximately 10 minutes and resolves with rest.
3. Her medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, and she takes lisinopril and simvastatin daily.
4. She has a 34-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day.
5. Her pulse is 78/min, and her blood pressure is 142/96 mm Hg.
6. On examination, femoral and popliteal pulses are 2+ bilaterally, left pedal pulses are 1+, and right pedal pulses are absent.
7. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.
8. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) is 0.65 in the right leg and 0.9 in the left leg.
question_options:
Which of the following complications is this patient most at risk of developing?

A. Aortic dissection  
C. Pulmonary embolism  
D. Aortic aneurysm rupture  
E. Renal artery stenosis leading to worsening hypertension  
F. Critical limb ischemia requiring amputation  
G. Acute myocardial infarction  
H. Chronic venous insufficiency  
I. Deep vein thrombosis  
J. Deep vein thrombosis in the affected limb

step1_excerpts:
1. A 16-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by emergency medical technicians because of a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that began 25 minutes ago and has continued despite administration of 0.5 mg/kg rectal diazepam 10 minutes ago.  
2. The patient was at home at the time of the seizure.  
3. In the emergency department, she is given an additional 0.5 mg/kg dose of diazepam intravenously and the convulsion terminates.  
4. Within 2 minutes, her oxygen saturation drops to 75% and she appears cyanotic.  
5. Respirations are 10/min and shallow.  
6. She receives bag-valve-mask ventilation, followed by intubation and mechanical ventilation.  
7. Medical history is unremarkable.  
8. She takes no medications.  
9. Temperature is 39.1°C (102.5°F).
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's respiratory insufficiency?

A. Airway occlusion

B. Encephalitis

C. Medication-induced suppression of central respiratory drive

D. Meningitis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 13-year-old boy with a history of sports-related blunt trauma to the left eye was referred for evaluation of an asymptomatic, pigmented iris lesion in the left eye.
2. On examination, his best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OU, and intraocular pressures were normal in both eyes.
3. Results of slitlamp examination of the right eye were unremarkable.
4. Slitlamp examination of the left eye revealed a round, pigmented lesion measuring 3 × 3 mm in basal dimension and with gravitational shifting within the anterior chamber fluid with patient head tilt (Video).
5. There was no corneal guttatae or edema.
6. Anterior segment optical coherence tomography depicted the lesion in the anterior chamber angle abutting the corneal endothelium and resting on the iris stroma with no internal fluid level and no solid component.
7. Ultrasound biomicroscopy confirmed the lesion to be cystic with a thickness of 1.6 mm.
8. Dilated fundus examination revealed normal findings in both eyes.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Fine-needle aspiration biopsy with cytology and cytogenetics  
B: Iodine 125 plaque radiotherapy  
C: Observe with no additional testing or intervention  
D: Cyst paracentesis with complete drainage

step1_excerpts:
1. An 18-year-old male with multiple stab wounds arrives at a rural emergency department.
2. His medical history includes obesity, diabetes, recurrent upper respiratory infections, heart failure, and a 10 pack-year smoking history.
3. Initially, he maintains his airway and demonstrates adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
4. His initial vital signs show: temperature 97.6°F (36.4°C), blood pressure 74/34 mmHg, heart rate 180/min, respiratory rate 24/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air.
5. After initiating whole blood transfusion and contacting the on-call surgeon, the patient develops dyspnea during the secondary survey.
6. His updated vitals show: blood pressure 54/14 mmHg, heart rate 200/min, respiratory rate 24/min, and oxygen saturation 90% on room air.
7. Lung examination reveals bilateral wheezing.
8. The patient subsequently experiences cardiac arrest and is pronounced dead after 30 minutes of resuscitation efforts.
question_options:
Which underlying condition most likely contributed to the patient's acute decompensation during resuscitation?

A. Pulmonary embolism  
B. Hyperkalemia due to hemolysis  
C. Tension pneumothorax  
D. Heart failure  
E. Anaphylaxis secondary to blood transfusion  
F. IgA deficiency  
G. Hypocalcemia from citrate toxicity  
H. Persistent intraabdominal bleeding  
I. Congenital long QT syndrome  
J. Transfusion-related acute lung injury

step1_excerpts:
1. A 49-year-old man, who is recovering in the hospital 2 days after uncomplicated left femoral-popliteal bypass grafting for claudication, has now developed increasing pain in his left foot.
2. Until now, the patient's postoperative course had been unremarkable and he has been treated with low-dose morphine for pain control.
3. Medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin and diet.
4. Vital signs now are temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse 80/min and regular, respirations 20/min, and blood pressure 150/92 mm Hg.
5. The surgical incision appears clean and well approximated without abnormal erythema or swelling.
6. The left lower extremity and foot appear pale.
7. Palpation of the left lower extremity discloses a strong femoral pulse, a weak popliteal pulse, and a cool, pulseless foot.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A. Bedside compartment pressure measurements

B. Doppler ultrasonography of the left lower extremity

C. Intra-arterial tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) therapy

D. Intraoperative angiography

step1_excerpts:
1. A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of vaginal bleeding for 2 to 5 days every 2 weeks.
2. The flow varies from light to heavy with passage of clots.
3. Menses previously occurred at regular 25- to 29-day intervals and lasted for 5 days with normal flow.
4. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications.
5. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently.
6. Her mother died of colon cancer, and her maternal grandmother died of breast cancer.
7. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2 .
8. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg.
9. The uterus is normal sized.
10. The ovaries cannot be palpated.
11. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
12. Test of the stool for occult blood is negative.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

A. Progesterone challenge test

B. Colposcopy

C. Cystoscopy

D. Endometrial biopsy

step1_excerpts:
1. A 67-year-old woman with a medical history of depression, type 2 diabetes, and insomnia comes to the clinic for a routine follow-up.
2. Her primary concern is bilateral knee pain that began after gardening last week and improves with acetaminophen in the morning.
3. During the visit, she reports new-onset urinary incontinence over the past week, characterized by frequent urination and an inability to fully empty her bladder.
4. The incontinence is not triggered by sneezing, coughing, or laughing.
5. She denies dysuria, discharge, itching, or other genitourinary symptoms, and her bowel movements are normal.
6. Her diabetes was previously well controlled with metformin and dulaglutide, but empagliflozin was added two months ago after her glycated hemoglobin levels were persistently elevated at 7.8% and 8.0% (reference range, 4.3–5.6).
7. She began taking an over-the-counter sleep aid containing doxylamine three weeks ago to improve her sleep.
8. Additionally, she started using echinacea one month ago to boost her immunity.
question_options:
Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of this patient’s urinary incontinence?

A. Echinacea  
B. None of the above - this is age-related incontinence  
C. The echinacea supplement  
D. A combination of empagliflozin and doxylamine  
E. Doxylamine  
F. A combination of metformin and empagliflozin  
G. Empagliflozin  
H. Dulaglutide  
I. Metformin  
J. Acetaminophen

step1_excerpts:
1. A 43-year-old woman with obesity is being assessed for stage 3B chronic kidney disease.
2. She has a 26-year history of type 1 diabetes managed with insulin and hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily and lisinopril 40 mg daily.
3. Her blood pressure is currently 140/84 mm Hg.
4. Laboratory results show a serum creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1) and a serum potassium level of 4.9 mEq/L (3.5–5.0).
5. Proteinuria is confirmed with an albumin-to-creatinine ratio of 760 mg/g (<30).
question_options:
Which of the following management strategies is the most appropriate for this patient?

A. Replace hydrochlorothiazide with dapagliflozin  
B. Add hydralazine to current therapy  
C. Add losartan to current therapy  
D. Increase lisinopril dosage beyond 40 mg daily  
E. Add metoprolol to current therapy  
F. Replace hydrochlorothiazide with canagliflozin  
G. Add amlodipine to current therapy  
H. Replace lisinopril with spironolactone  
I. Replace hydrochlorothiazide with furosemide  
J. Initiate sodium bicarbonate therapy

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her teens with no relevant medical history was brought to the hospital for personality changes, headache, and decreased vision bilaterally.
2. Review of systems was remarkable for concomitant hearing loss and vertigo for 1 month.
3. She was alert but confused and disoriented, and she manifested gait imbalance and ataxia.
4. White blood cell count was elevated at 14 600/μL (to convert to ×109 per liter, multiply by 0.001).
5. Results from computed tomography of the head were normal, but magnetic resonance imaging of the brain revealed multifocal punctate areas of restricted diffusion.
6. A lumbar puncture showed lymphocytosis (80%), normal glucose levels, and protein levels greater than 125 mg/dL.
7. Results from cerebrospinal fluid polymerase chain reaction were negative for herpes simplex virus, varicella zoster virus, and cytomegalovirus.
8. Results from laboratory tests for hypercoagulable states, antinucleolar antibodies, antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibodies, human immunodeficiency virus, Lyme disease, and tuberculosis were unrevealing.
9. Ophthalmology was consulted.
10. Visual acuity was 20/20 OU with normal pupil response, visual fields to finger counting, motility, and intraocular pressure.
11. Anterior segment biomicroscopy was normal without vitreous cell or haze.
12. The optic discs were pink with sharp margins.
13. The macula appeared flat, and there were scattered peripheral retinal hemorrhages and areas of retinal vascular nonperfusion in both eyes.
14. Optical coherence tomography showed inner retinal thinning with preservation of outer retinal architecture.
15. Fluorescein angiography showed multiple retinal arteriolar occlusions with variable leakage (Figure).
16. In this widefield fluorescein angiography, there are multiple areas of retinal artery occlusion not at branch points, with prominent leakage of fluorescein dye at some of the occlusions in each eye.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Initiate dimethyl fumarate for relapsing multiple sclerosis  
B: Administer systemic steroids and discuss the potential need for long-term immunosuppression for Susac syndrome  
C: Give intravenous acyclovir and intravitreal foscarnet for viral retinitis  
D: Observe for acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy

step1_excerpts:
1. A woman in her 70s with a medical history of hyperthyroidism, hypertension, and neuropathy was admitted to the hospital with a 6-day history of painful lesions involving both ears.
2. Initially, the left ear developed very painful lesions that resembled bruises.
3. Subsequently, her right ear became involved and developed similar lesions, but she denied any other areas being affected.
4. She had recently been treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and levofloxacin.
5. The lesions appeared while she was taking levofloxacin; however, on admission the antibiotic therapy was continued.
6. Her other medications included propylthiouracil, amlodipine besylate, pravastatin sodium, solifenacin succinate, and gabapentin.
7. On physical examination, the patient had localized retiform purpura on the right earlobe and bilateral helices that were tender to palpation (Figure, A).
8. Findings from laboratory tests, including a hypercoagulability workup, complete blood cell count, comprehensive metabolic panel, urinalysis, cryoglobulins, cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, and complement levels were all unremarkable.
9. However, the test result for perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCAs) was positive.
10. A punch biopsy for histopathologic examination was performed (Figure, B and C).A, Retiform purpura on the right helix.
11. B, Abundant red blood cell extravasation and fibrin thrombi (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×10).
12. C, Leukocytoclastic vasculitis and fibrin thrombi (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×40).
question_options:
What Is Your Diagnosis?

A: Levamisole-induced vasculopathy  
B: Mixed cryoglobulinemia  
C: Propylthiouracil-induced hypersensitivity vasculitis  
D: Septic vasculitis

step1_excerpts:
1. A 1-month-old girl presents to her pediatrician with her mother.
2. The patient was born at 38 weeks gestation via Caesarean section for cervical incompetence.
3. The patient’s mother has no complaints.
4. The child had a runny nose and cough for a few days last week.
5. The patient’s mother endorses decreased appetite during the aforementioned illness which has now returned to baseline.
6. The patient’s family history is significant for an older brother with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency and a maternal uncle with cirrhosis secondary to chronic hepatitis B.
7. On physical exam, the patient has scleral icterus and dark urine staining her diaper.
question_options:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Decreased metabolism of bilirubin  
B. Increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin  
C. Obstruction of the extrahepatic biliary tree  
D. Obstruction of the intrahepatic biliary tree

step1_excerpts:
1. A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife due to a 2-week history of fever, chills, night sweats, and generalized fatigue.
2. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), and he appears unwell.
3. Physical examination reveals a grade 3/6 mid-diastolic murmur at the left sternal border and crackles at both lung bases.
4. Transesophageal echocardiography identifies a 12 mm vegetation on the aortic valve.
5. Blood cultures grow gram-positive, catalase-negative, gamma-hemolytic cocci in chains that fail to grow in a 6.5% NaCl medium.
question_options:
What is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient’s condition?

A. Gastrointestinal instrumentation  
B. Recent urinary catheterization  
C. Recent dental procedure  
D. Colon cancer  
E. Rheumatic heart disease  
F. Bicuspid aortic valve  
G. Chronic kidney disease  
H. Intravenous drug use  
I. Periodontal disease  
J. Valve replacement

step1_excerpts:
1. A 65-year-old male is referred to a neurologist by his primary care physician due to progressive bilateral leg pain over the past six months, which is more severe in the left leg.
2. He describes the pain as "burning" and rates it as 5/10 at its worst.
3. The pain worsens when walking downhill but improves with activities like riding a stationary bike.
4. His medical history includes hypertension, diabetes mellitus, a prior myocardial infarction, and a distal radius fracture from a fall last year.
5. His medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, metformin, glyburide, enalapril, and metoprolol.
6. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history and drinks 2-3 glasses of wine with dinner daily.
7. On examination, his temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg, pulse is 91/min, and respirations are 18/min.
8. He appears well and is not in acute distress.
9. A straight leg raise test is negative, and a Valsalva maneuver does not exacerbate his pain.
question_options:
Which diagnostic test would be most appropriate to confirm the suspected diagnosis?

A. Computed tomography of the lumbar spine  
B. Ankle-brachial index  
C. Computerized tomography myelography  
D. Doppler ultrasonography of the lower extremities  
E. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies  
F. Magnetic resonance imaging  
G. X-ray of the lumbosacral spine  
I. Myelography

step1_excerpts:
1. An 18-year-old woman presented to the dermatology clinic for evaluation of recurrent skin, nail, and oral mucosal abnormalities.
2. At age 4 years, she developed white oral plaques that resolved with oral nystatin.
3. Approximately 6 months later, the oral plaques recurred, her toenails became thickened and yellowed, and red plaques appeared on both feet and lower legs.
4. After 3 months of daily oral itraconazole, her skin, nail, and oral mucosal abnormalities resolved for approximately 1 year.
5. Over the following years, she received intermittent 3- to 6-month courses of daily itraconazole for recurrent skin, nail, and oral mucosal abnormalities, which typically recurred within 6 to 12 months of discontinuing itraconazole.
6. Her last dose of itraconazole was approximately 2 years prior to presentation.
7. On physical examination, the patient had white, moist, nonadherent plaques in the oral mucosa and moist red fissures at bilateral oral commissures (Figure, left panel).
8. She also had thickened, yellowed toenails and scaly erythematous plaques on her lower legs and feet bilaterally (Figure, right panel).
9. Results of complete blood cell count with differential were normal, as were results of measurement of serum IgG, IgA, IgM, and IgE levels and analysis of CD3, CD4, and CD8 T-cell subsets.
10. Potassium hydroxide wet mount preparation of skin scrapings from the lower extremities demonstrated fungal elements.
11. Fungal culture of the skin scrapings grew Candida albicans.
12. Patient presentation.
13. Left, White plaques in the oral mucosa and angular cheilitis.
14. Right, Thickened, yellowed toenails and scaly erythematous plaques on both lower legs and feet.
question_options:
What Would You Do Next?

A: Administer oral cefazolin  
B: Prescribe hydrocortisone cream  
C: Restart daily oral itraconazole  
D: Treat with oral terbinafine

step1_excerpts:
